Taxes and insurance

Alan Scharf 
Plantation 
Posted December 19 2006 


 	    E-mail story
   Print story
   Most e-mailed
   News on your cell
RSS  RSS news feeds

 Click here to subscribe	Click here to subscribe today to the Sun-Sentinel or call 1-877-READ-SUN.	

 
 LocalLinks 
	
 

In the past six years, property taxes have provided a windfall to government agencies throughout the state. 

Yet governments have seen fit to increase those budgets and spend this windfall. At the same time, property insurance has skyrocketed in cost. Between the tax and insurance increases, homeowners are being driven to desperation. 

Every government entity needs to roll back today's budgets to those of six years ago, before the tax windfalls, and adjust for 2 percent to 3 percent annual inflation only. Government should then contribute these tax windfalls into the state's Citizens Property Insurance Corp., so that all Floridians could then obtain insurance at reasonable rates.

From:	Gotsha@aol.com
Sent:	Friday, December 22, 2006 5:14 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	self insurance

Dear Governor Bush:
     I own a condominium in Key Largo, Florida and like many 
others have faced a significant increase in our maintenance fees due to 
insurance costs paid by our Condo Association.  For example, in 2005 the 
total insurance cost covering our 82 unit condo complex was $62,400.  
The equivalent coverage in 2007 is expected to be $195,800.  Our complex 
is composed of three large buildings constructed of nine inch thick 
concrete.  Many units have hurricane glass or shutters.  The likelihood 
of a hurricane loss as high as $196,000 in any given year is nil.
     We feel that the answer to this situation lies in a self-insurance 
plan but we are being told that State Laws make this impossible.  For 
example, please see this web link:

http://www.naplesnews.com/news/2006/dec/03/rob_samouce_condominium_association_selfinsurance_/

      I respectively request that the State Government of Florida 
consider revisions to its statutes to permit the use of Self-Insurance 
arrangements on a reasonable basis.  I object to paying premiums which 
bear no relation to the risks involved in order to make up for losses in 
other high risk areas.  This problem has become a major negative for 
second home owners like me and as the cost of maintaining a second home
in Florida, I will now start to look outside the state of Florida.  I can no 
longer afford these high costs to maintain a second home.
Robert Livoti
104350 Overseas Hwy  #B201
Key Largo, FL 33037

From:	Mike996381@aol.com
Sent:	Friday, December 22, 2006 8:40 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Homestead Exemption

Dear Governor Bush:
 
First off, I'd like to thank you for eight years of wonderful service to our State. You have been a great Governor. Next, I'd like to offer my humble suggestion for potentially fixing the property tax problem in Florida. 
 
Currently, each property owner receives a $25,000 homestad exemption. I believe that there are a great many people in our State who are abusing this exemption. They are receiving this exemption based on false or incorrect information. The Florida homestead exemption is available to those owners of property who meet certain criteria. One of those criteria is that the owner of the property continue to reside in that property. As the homestead exemption is automatically renewed each year, the owner receives that homestead exemption each year regardless of whether they actually continue to reside in that property. There is no system of checks and balances to assure that that is correct. How many owners of property who continue to benefit by the homestead exemption have actually rented the property to someone else thereby receiving the benefit of the homestead exemption while, at the same time, receive money from the renters for that property? This seems not only unfair but how much money are the State and counties losing annually due to this? The law is already on the books specifying the criteria of who can receive the homestead exemption but there are no checks to assure that the law is carried out correctly. If the homestead exemption was correctly done each year, there would be countless property owners who would no longer be entitled to that exemption and that would create additional revenue possibly resulting in an overall reduction of assessed value of property taxes or, at the very least, stabilizing property taxes while providing additional revenues annually. Of course, it would create the need for additional resources to monitor this annually, but I would assume that the State's computers already have the information necessary to check and cross reference much of the information required in order to implement a law which is already there. 
 
In my humble opinion, this is one possible solution to a problem that I have yet to see offered. 
 
 
Sincerely,
 
Michael Perlman
Tampa, Florida 
From:	Diane Faulkner <DianeJFaulkner@Yahoo.com>
Sent:	Thursday, December 21, 2006 7:47 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush; George W. Bush
Attachments:	BD10358_.GIF; netbkgnd.gif

 

 



POINTS/GOALS, WHICH H.A.C. FLORIDA, INC. FEELS NEED TO BE ADDRESSED TO MAKE MEANINGFUL REDUCTIONS AND CHANGES IN THIS STATE'S HOMEOWNERS INSURANCE.


 

1.  A complete investigation and overhaul of Citizens, by an un-bias, non-political entity. This would include looking into the salaries of executives, bonuses paid out to Citizens employees, while policy holder’s claims from past storms still have not been paid, for example.

2.  Insurance laws in Florida need to be addressed and changed. A complete overhaul of current laws is needed to allow change. Many are archaic and outdated, just adding to the confusion. New laws need to be put in place which do not conflict with the old laws.

3.  Immediate rescission of the 20% rule that Citizens has to charge over any other company. This has only allowed an escalation of rates/premiums. 

4.  All insurance companies doing business in Florida need to be operating under the same rules and guidelines. Startup companies such as Homewise and Florida Peninsula (to name a just a couple) should not be allowed to play outside the rules of other companies, by taking policies from Citizens and charging double the premiums.

5.  Florida only companies should be looked into as to why they are allowed and to who’s benefit.

6.  Insurance companies are a risk business and should be made to accept their risk the same as any other company has to do, without bailouts from individuals and state money.

7.  Should a policy be taken from Citizens by another company, cancelled by Citizens, or just not renewed by the policy holder, the policy holder should be let back into Citizens if they so choose. In the current situation of insurance companies not writing in many areas, policy holders can be left without any insurance and those with mortgages have to cover the property or lose the mortgage, looking at foreclosure.

8.  An independent committee needs to be formed to look into our insurance reform. This committee should be formed of people who are in no way connected to insurance companies, lobbyists, legislators or any people in any way benefiting from insurance profit. The current Reform committee is comprised solely of people “connected”, and cannot be objective. 

9.  Homeowners need to be allowed to choose the amount of coverage they are comfortable with, not mandated to. Homeowners also need to be able to set the value of contents coverage based on their comfort zone of value, not mandated as to one-half the replacement cost of the home.

10. Insurance companies need to lower their risk exposure. One way is stated in   item nine. There are others.

11. There needs to be clear and concise definitions of “sinkhole”, “flood vs. wind/rain” and other catastrophes, so everyone is “on the same page” and there are no ongoing disputes as to who pays out what. Clearly definitions would put blame where it belongs and avoid litigation and the consumer suffering through the process. Sinkhole claims must be “actual” and not just paid off to get rid of the claimant, the number of “actual” sinkholes needs to be clarified – again, a clear definition is needed. A very complex situations which needs to be addressed.

12.  The so called “subsidized” premiums must stop for homes in high risk areas. The three million dollar home on Miami’s waterfront, should not pay less then the $150,000 home in another county. Equality across the board is needed.

13. “Cherry-picking” policies has to stop. If a company is to write policies in Florida, they must take all or nothing, not choose only the lucrative areas for a higher profit and lower risk.

14. Florida should look into what other states, such as Pennsylvania and California have done. One example being: If you sell insurance in the state, you must sell to all and all forms of insurance offered.

15. Older homes should not be penalized because of their age. Upgrades to these homes should allow for substantial decreases in premiums, not a token reduction as has been the case. 

16. Homeowners rates should not be connected to their credit rating in any way.

17. All of Citizens and all insurance company records should be open to the public and easily obtainable.

18. A consumer advocate should be involved in the process of reviewing rate hikes, by all insurance carriers. The current Consumer Advocate is under the direction of the CFO, this creates a conflict of interest. A consumer advocate from the lower and middle class, not connected in any way to big money.

19. We are told that Mississippi offsets its catastrophic loss from casino revenue. We should seriously look into allowing casinos in Florida, to do the same. Instead of allowing gambling boats offshore and losing out on the taxes while others get rich. Another consideration would be a separate Hurricane Lotto.

20. We need to stop building in sensitive and high risk areas. These barriers are one of our first lines of defense against storm surge. Anyone choosing to build there should pay appropriate premiums or be self insured. High risk areas should not be subsidized by the rest of the state. 

21. Older homes should be grandfathered in and insured without penalty. Penalizing them because they are old is unfair.

22. Florida law states that no policy can be cancelled except for non-payment. So, insurance companies call it “non-renewal” to get around the law. Policies must be renewable and remain with the original insurer unless for non-payment, ONLY.

23. Citizens and any other insurer should not make others pay for their losses. Every homeowner and taxpayer is paying to keep Citizens in business, no matter what insurance company they have. That is like paying twice for the same thing and paying for others mistakes.

24. Citizens must work for the policyholder, as it was designed to do, not spend money hiring attorneys, and all, to fight against the government and people it was designed to help.

25. When rates are lowered in specific areas, such as Monroe County, the rest of the state should not have to “pick up the slack” as stated by representatives of Citizens Insurance.

26. Politicians and people from the insurance industry should stop proposing “band-aid” fixes and concentrate a real fix of this problem. Stop throwing state money away in schemes to appease the people who can see through most of the schemes anyway. The ‘matching grant’ program is one example – people who cannot afford insurance in the first place, can’t afford to spend upgrade money either. Loans to pay insurance still makes the homeowner the target.

27. Those with the power to act, need to look at the “trickle down” effect of all this. The whole state is going to feel the “trickle down”, some already and some in the future, but the whole economy of this state is going to suffer.

28. Look into the “take-out” program where other insurance companies are allowed to take Citizens policies and then charge almost double, and get paid a bonus if they keep them for three years. Why should Citizens pay a bonus to these companies? Why should they be allowed to charge double? If “cancelled” where do the people go, they can’t go back to Citizens.

29. The Speed to Market initiative that allows insurance companies to raise rates without requiring normal rate approval must be changed. 

30. Re-insurance is big business. Some insurers have created Florida only companies and buy their re-insurance from the parent company reducing risk and making large profits because of it. Re-insurance needs to be looked into, as it adds greatly to the cost of insurance to the taxpayer.

31. Stop “give-away” programs that benefit the rich and do not help those who cannot afford insurance in the first place, such as the matching grants program. The little guy cannot afford to upgrade when they can’t afford insurance to begin with. Even if they could, the return on lowered premiums is negligible – the program only benefits those with money. Loans to pay insurance premiums only add to the consumer’s burden and programs to give one-thousand dollars to offset premiums doesn’t give relief for those who’s premiums have gone up five-hundred percent. Plus, the thousand dollars comes out of taxpayers money to begin with. The consumers are being hit every time they turn around, not the insurance companies. Insurance companies still post high profits every year.

32. The citizens of Florida should not shoulder the burden of risk. Insurance companies are in the risk business, let them accept their risk.

33. Sinkhole claims must require a permit so that adequate record counts of actual sinkholes can be kept. Instead of adding all, good or bad, to the count.

 

We would be willing to discuss any and all of this with anyone concerned.

Without changes to coastal development rules and regulations the state 
will not be able to solve, long term, the insurance issue.

I heard Governor Bush say that there there is no quick solution to this 
and he is right.

Future coastal development needs to be treated in a different manner 
than it has.

In the 1970s there was a resort built over here in Northeast Florida 
called Amelia Island. It was placed behind what is called the primary 
dunes rather than right on the beach. This is not a big deal, nothing 
radical except that if all coastal development had been done that way 
since the 1970s the insurance crisis would be less than it is now by far.

Just building back a ways behind the dunes for new development could 
protect the state from minor storms and lessen the impact of major ones.

It is a shame that a series of Governors and legislatures have really 
done little or nothing to address this simple partial remedy.

I think that in a way without this simple reform of not allowing 
building directly on the beach for new projects that there is no sign of 
a serious dedication to doing the job in the long term. Without this 
change the political talk is just talk.

I know it would be a big change but nothing else will serve to begin to 
off set the insurance risks to property that beach development poses . 
This is setting aside other risks such as the cost of beach 
re-nourishment and emergency services.

Whatever is there on the coast now would have to be grandfathered in, 
but new development has to be treated differently now. If we do not 
start now, the long term situation will never change. Toying around with 
rates and formulas in this year or the next is not a fundamental change 
that should have been made decades ago.

Anyway thanks
Thomas Joseph
thomas.joseph@att.net

told).  I have learned from a relative who bought a house 5 or 6 years 
ago for $150,000 that he pays less than half of what his neighbor pays, 
because the neighbor paid $300K.  If everyone's property is more or less 
the same why are they not assessed something in between?

taxes be based upon values?  Where I live houses are selling for 
anywhere from 375-400,000. They are assessed at about 65%. Then they are 
charged 1-1.10% Whether you live here 20 years or 3 years we all pay 
within $600 of each other beacause our values are being looked at (taxes 
are 2200-2900 on a 50x100 lot.......the higher amount is assessed if you 
have done upgrades).  By doing this the tax based is shared, "new home 
buyers" and those relocating can purchase.  I get the impression from a 
Florida realtor that school teachers and other hard working people 
cannot afford to purchase due to the property taxes.

It seems like the very well off can afford this, and newcomers or first 
time buyers are forced into manufactured home communities; not very safe 
or cost efficient in a state with hurricanes.

It seems like the millage rates are disproportionate to the median 
income purchaser.  In Oregon, higher income people pay higer state 
income tax.  Perhaps there should be a graduated millage rate based upon 
incomes and/or property values; that would then take into consideration 
your retirees or those on a fixed budget.  Those who can afford more 
expensive homes might not be so effected and they usually are not buying 
less expensive homes say under $300,000.

While i an not an economist in making these comments and suggestions I 
hope I have at least helped you realize the seriousness of this issue 
from someone interested in living in your state.

Of course as the price of oil goes up so does our electric bill and so does the taxes to the City. Then there is a 10% tax on our water bill along with a $10 per month storm water improvement fee. There is also a 7% City tax on our phone bill. This is not to mention garbage collection fees, recycling fees, parking meter charges, recreational fees for use of City owned facilities. And the list can go on. All the City Government has to do is quietly raise these fees and collect more revenue.

I am very fortunate that I have a very comfortable tax cap on my home. I figure I pay more to the City of Clearwater in fees and utility taxes then I do in property taxes. I am on my private campaign to inform every on I know of these taxes and fees imposed by our local government. I wasn't aware of these until just recently and I find many many people are also not aware of them. They as so many of us just look to see how much the bills are and just pay them without realizing what is going on.

  I know that this is late in your term to bring up an issue that has bothered me for quite some time, but please
review the rest of my e-mail and if you feel it is appropriate, pass it along to your successor.
  My wife and I are average citizens who like to attend both sporting and cultural events. There is a law in Florida that prohibits
individuals from re-selling any event ticket for more than the retail price of the ticket(scalping). However, "ticket brokers"
are allowed to do exactly that for any price they can get. This law has allowed this business to flourish. In doing so, it has also
locked out most individuals from enjoying many events as ticket brokers will pay people to snap up as many tickets as they can 
to any event. 
  A prime example of this is the future performance of "Wicked" at the new Carnival center in Miami. My wife and I 
are not season ticket holders but wanted to attend this play. We went online as soon as the tickets were available to the public
but the only seats available were the 4th tier which is way up in the theater. On a lark, I decided to check with several ticket brokers 
for these tickets. Every single ticket broker I spoke to had tickets in all sections but of course at a premium. An example of the
scalping that takes place is that I was quoted a price of $400.00 for a ticket that has a retail value of $150.00.
  These brokers no longer rely on individuals to sell them tickets they have purchased but can no longer use as may have occurred 
the past, they are now paying individuals to purchase tickets strictly for them to re-sell. This is killing the opportunity for individuals such
as my wife and I to attend single events that we would like to unless we purchase season tickets or buy them at a significant premium from
a ticket broker.. 
  I know if I buy season tickets, I can always re-sell my tickets to these brokers, but I refuse to do so.
  
David Victor
A Concerned Citizen

From:	Marie Baker <IceAngel818@tampabay.rr.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 12, 2006 7:09 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Please help me stop violence against the homeless
Attachments:	hatecrimes_bwNEW.pdf

To Whom It May Concern:
 
My name is Marie Baker. I am a senior at the University of Tampa. It has recently been brought to my attention that people are paying homeless people to do gruesome things to themselves and other homeless people. These horrible acts are filmed and then distributed for sale!  Hate crimes and violence against the homeless is rising. I know that Florida has a large population of homeless so this is definitely a pressing issue. So far, California and Maine are the only two states to pass legislation regarding violence against the homeless being classified as a hate crime. I understand that a Bill was brought forth discussing this very topic, but died as a result of the Legislature’s session ending. I hope that you will be able to help not only me, but the entire homeless community!
 
I contacted the National Homeless Organization and they provided me with a model of what the state legislation might look like: 
 
Whereas, hate crimes and violence against homeless persons has become a nationwide epidemic, with 472 reported cases of violence against homeless people over the past 7 years, resulting in 169 deaths;
 
Whereas, the scope of prohibitions against the commission of hate crimes against certain groups of persons should include homeless persons;
 
Whereas, understanding violent crimes committed against homeless persons and adequate punishment for such crimes play key roles in preventing and managing violence against homeless persons; and
 
Whereas, law enforcement needs proper training to handle and prevent violent crimes against homeless persons; 
 
Be it enacted:
 
(1)               Definition of Homeless Person – For purposes of this section, "homeless person" refers to an individual who lacks a fixed, regular, and adequate nighttime residence, or an individual who has a primary nighttime residence that is:


(a) A public or private place not designed for, or ordinarily used as, a regular sleeping accommodation for human beings, including cars, parks, public spaces, abandoned buildings, substandard housing, bus or train stations, or similar settings; 

(b) A supervised publicly or privately operated shelter designed to provide temporary living accommodations, including motels, hotels, congregate shelters, and transitional housing; or


(c) Housing of other persons in which the individual is temporarily staying due to loss of housing, economic hardship, or a similar reason.
 
(2)               The state hate crimes statute shall be expanded to include homeless persons as 
a protected class.
 
(3)               Prohibition on Hate Crimes against Homeless Persons – The following acts shall be deemed a hate crime and prohibited when carried out against a person on the basis that person’s status as a homeless person:
 
(a)    Assault, aggravated assault, battery, or aggravated battery upon the person; or
 
(b)   Acts that deface, damage, or destroy or attempt to deface, damage, or destroy the personal property of the person; or
 
(c)    Acts that result in the death of the person; or 
 
(d)   Any other crime against the person.
 
(4)               Punishments for Hate Crimes again Homeless Persons – 
 
(a)    A person convicted of aggravated assault or aggravated battery upon a homeless person based on the victim’s status as a homeless person shall be sentenced to a minimum term of 3 years and fined not more than $10,000.  The person shall be ordered by the sentencing judge to make any restitution to the victim of the offense and to perform 500 hours of community service work.  Restitution and community service work shall be in addition to any fine or sentence that may be imposed and shall not be in lieu thereof.
 
(b)   Whenever a person is charged with committing an assault or aggravated assault or a battery or aggravated battery upon a homeless person based on the victim’s status as a homeless person, the offense for which the person is charged shall be reclassified as follows:
 
(i)                  In the case of aggravated battery, from a felony of the second degree to a felony of the first degree.
 
(ii)                In the case of aggravated assault, from a felony of the third degree to a felony of the second degree.
 
(iii)               In the case of battery, from a misdemeanor of the first degree to a felony of the third degree.
 
(iv)              In the case of assault, from a misdemeanor of the second degree to a misdemeanor of the first degree.
 
(5)               State Office of the Attorney General Study -  
 
(a)    The Office of the Attorney General shall assess the extent of the problem of crimes against homeless persons and develop a plan to prevent these crimes and apprehend and prosecute the perpetrators of these crimes.
 
(b)   In developing the assessment and plan, the Office of the Attorney General shall consult homeless persons, service providers and advocates for homeless persons, and law enforcement agencies with experience investigating crimes against homeless persons.
 
(6)               Law Enforcement Training on Hate Crimes against Homeless Persons – 
 
(a)    The lead state law enforcement agency shall develop a telecourse that shall be made available to all law enforcement agencies in the state.  Every state, local, and correctional law enforcement agency shall certify that each of its officers has taken the course.  The telecourse shall address crimes against homeless persons and methods of dealing effectively and humanely with homeless persons.  The course shall include instruction on each of the following topics:
 
(i)                  Information about homelessness, including causes of homelessness, its impact, and solutions to homelessness.
 
(ii)                Indicators of hate crimes.
 
(iii)               The impact of these crimes on the victim, the victim’s family, and the community.
 
(iv)              The assistance and compensation available to victims.
 
(v)                The laws dealing with hate crimes and the legal rights of, and the remedies available to, victims of hate crimes.
 
(vi)              Law enforcement procedures, reporting, and documentation of hate crimes.
 
(vii)             Techniques and methods to handle incidents of hate crimes.
 
(viii)           The special problems inherent in hates crimes against homeless persons and techniques on how to deal with these special problems.
 
(b)   The lead state law enforcement agency shall develop a protocol that law enforcement personnel are required to follow, including, but not limited, to the following:
 
(i)                  Preventing likely hate crimes by, among other things, establishing contact with persons and communities that are likely targets, and forming and cooperating with community hate crime prevention and response networks.
 
(ii)                Responding to reports of hate crimes, including reports of hate crimes committed under color of legal authority.
 
(iii)               Providing victim assistance and follow up, including community follow up.
 
(iv)              Reporting methods and procedures to track hate crimes against homeless persons.
 
(c)    In developing the telecourse, the lead state law enforcement agency shall consult subject matter experts including, but not limited to, the following:
 
(i)                  homeless and formerly homeless individuals;
 
(ii)                the National Coalition for the Homeless and National Law Center on Homelessness & Poverty
 
(iii)               other service providers and advocates for homeless people;
 
(iv)              experts on the disabilities homeless persons commonly experience; and
 
(v)                law enforcement agencies with experience investigating hate crimes against homeless people.
 
Thank you for your time,
 
Marie Baker

These firms have been licensed and have honorably and ethically served the medical practitioners and institutions for years.  We have been placed in  disadvantageous competitive situation with the primary major drug wholesalers. 

As an example, McKesson, has stopped shipping into Florida, because of the Pedigree requirements.  Yet, their subsidiary, General Medical, has salesmen in Florida, competing against us and have product to sell.  Amerisource-Bergin, as of December 1st, has begun charging $5,000 per month from each of the secondary wholesalers who purchase from them, purpose of which they state, is to cover their added administrative and IT costs.  (With an estimated twenty (2) such secondary wholesale companies purchasing from them, equates to collecting $100K/month or $1.2M/year.  How is one to sustain themselves in business with legislation which tips the field unfavorably toward such a market???  This is not creating a free and open market where a business can compete based on the merit of its service, quality, or delivering a new a better widget. 

As a lifelong Republican, I sent my financial support to Charlie Crist, and after I read where he was in favor of this legislation, I wish I had not. 

A second e-mail is forthcoming without editorializing but will give you added insight into what RxUSA is legally doing to thwart the implementation by the F.D.A. of a national PDMA regulation. 

Respectfully yours, 

Stanley G. Tangalakis

Attachments:	untitled.JPG

  
Hello Again Governor Bush,
 
         My Name is Russell Smith and back on 07/22/2003 I wrote to you about the laws that governed firefighters and the use of red warning lights. Together we made firefighters more visible on the roadways. But now it seems that there may need to be a little more to this law. I have checked laws in other states that allow firefighters to use red lights and most of the states say that if a red light is used it must be used with an audible siren. Here are some of the situations that I and other firefighters are running into. 
 

1.	When responding to a scene of a call or the fire station for a call some people don’t understand what is behind them or don’t even see us. So it slows the response. Like myself I am a Driver / Engineer and in my department sometimes I am the only driver available to drive the fire engines. In that case I sometimes get hung up in traffic which slows my response to possibly save someone’s life or property.

 

2.	See attached illustration. I have run into this situation a few times where I have come to a red traffic light to go straight thru. I come to a full stop when all traffic has stopped in the intersection I proceed with caution but it always seem that someone comes from the left or right that didn’t see my red light and didn’t’ hear me cause of no audible siren.

 
 
Just as police officers responding to calls the firefighters would have to abide by the same laws. The firefighters and police officers go thru similar emergency driving courses. The class that firefighters have to go thru is called EVOC (Emergency Vehicle Operators Course).  This teaches exactly what it says. This course is a nation wide course. Any firefighter in this state now that runs any type of red lights in his/her vehicle must have this course. This rule is already in place. 
As with any law there must be some rules. Like if a firefighter/responder misuses his or her emergency equipment it can be pulled by the Chief of the department. But these laws are also already in effect.  All emergency driving laws are taught in our EVOC course. They are the same as if we were driving the fire engines / ambulances. To the point for emergency personnel to respond to the station or to the scene in a timely fashion to save someone’s life or property we need to add the audible sirens to our vehicles. Many other states use lights and sirens for their firefighters and EMS people i.e.: West Virginia, Ohio, North and South Carolina, Georgia and many more. These are just the states that I have checked into that allow this and most all the laws are the same. The ultimate decision to who will get a red light/siren permit as it is now would be up to the Chief of the department. If you have any questions feel free to contact me at:
Luv2firefight2@aol.com
 
 
Sincerely, 
Russell Smith
 
 
PS. The attachment is just a street drawing to show one problem we have without the use of sirens.

Subject:	WAL-MART SEEKS TAX BENEFITS under Florida Statute Sec. 288.106

            RE:       Application for designation of Wal-Mart Stores East LP as a Qualified Target Industry business pursuant to Section 288.106, Florida Statutes

 

Dear Governor Bush:

 

Florida Statute Sec. 288.206 reads, in part:

 

 The business activity or product for the applicant's project is within an industry or industries that have been identified by the office to be high-value-added industries that contribute to the area and to the economic growth of the state and that produce a higher standard of living for citizens of this state in the new global economy or that can be shown to make an equivalent contribution to the area and state's economic progress (emphasis added).  

 

I strongly object to Wal-Mart being designated a Qualified Target Industry in connection with the distribution center it wants to build in Putnam County over the strong objections of residents, as well as neighboring Volusia County.  The above-quoted language does not apply to a minimum-wage paying company like Wal-Mart.

 

I am aware that Florida Statute 288.106 was not intended to benefit low-wage retail businesses like Wal-Mart.   I don’t think Wal-Mart should receive any rebate on state taxes (which could amount to several million dollars) for a distribution center that will simply create low-wage jobs.  Further, the sole purpose for this distribution center is to supply goods to their retail stores in Florida.  This seems to go completely against the intent of this statute.

 

Thank you for your thorough review of Wal-Mart in connection with this project and their desire to receive my tax dollars for it.

 

Sincerely,

 

SANDRA WALTERS

480 Warrior Trail
Enterprise, FL  32725

the revenues the local government acutually needs to provide its services.

with the identical townhouse, is paying less than $4000, even though he 
bought it 5 years after I bought mine.  How, in any way, is that fair?  I am

months or use no community services.  I can appreciate the argument that if 
I can afford a second home then I can pay more that the fulltime Floridian

rental houses and I apartment house in Dade county and am forced to raise my 
rents every year because of the tax increases.  I have a clause in all my 
lease agreements that the rents are adjusted every year based on the tax 
increase.  These tax increases are not only unfair to the owners but to a 
larger extent to the tenants that are trying to find affordabile housing.  
Also, several years ago, the City of Miami informed me they would no longer 
collect garbage at my Apartment building and I had 45 days to provide them 
with a signed contract with one of there approved vendors or face a fine.  
This, in a year where my property taxes were raised substantially.  It is 
hard to believe this is happening and nothing is being done to correct the 
obvious inequalities.  I know there is a new Governor and I hope you will 
pass this letter to his staff but more importantly that you will personally 
speak to him about this problem.  Although presently not legally a 
Floridian, I consider myself Floridian as being a graduate of Coral Gables 
Elemetary, Ada Merritt, Coral Gables High School and the University of Miami 
and only left to serve in the Air Force and then to fly for Eastern Airlines 
in Washington and New York.  Someday I again might be a legal Floridian

be ignored.  Think of my poor tenants.  You did well as Governor sir but

From:	mike spangler <sparky45@spannersites.com>

Subject:	State Of The State

3215 Primrose Dr.

Dear Mr. Bush:
 
I find myself afloat among mixed emotions of anger, frustration and sorrow at the current state of the Florida economy, housing in particular.
 
Being that I have made my income in the inspections, repairs and building aspect of the housing market for the last 10 years I'm angry to say that I have to move out of Florida with the rest of us who choose to pursue this field, to find work again in other states where the housing markets are fair.
 
Due in large to political decisions and actions (or inactions as the case may be) by our representatives in all three offices of this state, you have not only allowed the individual counties to increase taxes over 100% with no justification, you have also allowed insurance companies (like Citizen) to increase rates over 120% (with still no end in sight) causing the housing sales & construction market to come to a near dead stop with absolutely no financial consideration as to the repercussions of this action.
 
As things currently stand, to buy a 900 sqft, 2 bedroom, 2 bath home in west central Florida, you must be able to afford a monthly expense of $750.00 monthly mortgage payment, $150.00 monthly tax payment a $200.00 monthly dwelling insurance, $100.00 monthly flood insurance and $75.00 monthly wind insurance (hurricane coverage). That works out to nearly $400.00 per month for insurance and when you add the taxes we are paying nearly 70% of our mortgage payments in extra costs.
 
Mr. Bush.  If a 900sqft, 2 bedroom, one bath, one car garage home costs $100,000 to buy and your income is less than $100,000 a year as a single parent, you can't get a loan because you won't qualify for financing due to these extra costs.
 
Ironically, very few single parents make that much and worse yet, many single parents and other people are now being forced into foreclosure due to this financial ineptitude, myself one of them.
(In this income range currently in the State of Florida, it's less expensive to rent the same size apartment for $800.00 a month than buy a house for $1,100.00 a month).
 
You as Governor, are responsible for any and all the problems of this State just as any captain is responsible for any and all problems on his ship.
If you do not do something immediately to create some relief for us, you will not only leave this state worse than it was when you got it, but with the responsibility of having increased the Florida homeless statistics single-handedly.
 
As a suggestion:
    Why not:

1.	Establish an immediate moratorium on foreclosure procedures,
2.	Require the counties to return to a realistic taxing rate (perhaps a flat rate)
3.	Require the insurance companies to do away with the ridiculous wind policy and return to reasonable rates spread across the entire state of Florida rather than incurring the burden of insurance cost and profit on just the coastal areas
4.	Require all Florida counties to institute a mortgage assistance program similar to Pasco County's Community Development Division Program and finally,
5.	Put someone in the Insurance Commissioners office that can do the job properly (after 3 years, Kevin McCarty has obviously demonstrated he is ineffectual).

We, the citizens of the State of Florida, will wait, watch and remember how you leave us.
 
Sincerely,
Mike Spangler

From:	Leon Hilfstein User <leonh74@verizon.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 5, 2006 5:58 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Thoughts

Governor Bush,

I am a retired Florida State employee. I served some of the most needy
persons for 30 years as a mental health professional at the Florida State
Hospital. I am disappointed that career service employees, particularly
those who toil in the trenches do not get a decent retirement stipend upon
retirement with 30 or more years of continuous service. While correctional
officers get somewhat better benefits the rank and file employee at mental
health institutions, who face serious bodily harm and danger daily, get much
less. There are certain classes of employee who do receive better benefits.
However, those classes usually have less direct contact with residents while
receiving increased benefits. Frankly, something is very wrong with this.

Regarding privatization, I firmly believe that this trend is harmful to
those being served. This is quite obvious based on reports from around the
state in the media. I am certainly not advocating unrestricted spending but
careful and thoughtful administration under State auspices through
established public institutions will provide acceptable quality of services
without private corporations milking the system though cost overruns, poorly
trained employees and profits above acceptable quality care. Privatization
at all levels only adds to a system that rewards mediocre services with less
oversight. The role of a government is to protect its citizens, provide for
infrastructure and defense. Certain functions can and should be accomplished
with private contracting. Social and mental health services as well as
public education to name three should not be among those that rely on the
private sector. Private businesses should not benefit from lessened
oversight and control while public institutions get slammed for problems.
The trend for private takeover of essential government services is dangerous
at all levels. Your very active support of the privatization of government
activities is just plain wrong in my most humble opinion.

It is time to rethink this trend while at the same time support those loyal
career service employees through appropriate levels of benefits while
employed and compensation upon retirement that provides for an acceptable
quality of life.

Thank you for your time,

Leon Hilfstein

Subject:	Our Gulf - LAST STAND 

Dear Governor Bush,  

As I looked out on the beautiful Gulf of Mexico this morning from my marvelous vantage point here in our home on Casey Key, I suddenly felt very sad. Like your dad, I now shed tears with mixed emotions. This in spite of the fact that the water is clear today and the pelicans are playful.   I know that I will take a walk on the beach later now that we have a respite from the Red Tide.  In addition to this plague upon us, we have already suffered erosion over the years due to the variants allowed for various armoring projects along our prestine coastline.  Yet along our more than 200 feet on the Gulf  the sea turtles still return to nest every year.  Nature finds a way.  Then there is the threat of hurricanes - a risk we assumed when we decided to buy a home on a barrier island. No doubt a direct storm would find our weak unarmored property and probably open up a new channel as was done years ago at Midnight Pass!  What I did not anticipate was your failure along with your brothers (and now our Florida senators) to protect our coastline from oil drilling after promises to the contrary in your several political campaigns.  Of course, you could still live up to these promises right now by stopping the advance of the current legislation that has been given priority this week in the Congress...that last greedy grab of our natural resources by this generation without due consideration of our children and grandchildren already facing the financial burden they will bear from our diplomatic failures in the world. Then there is the veto power of the President as a last resort.  How naive of me to think that a family whose fortune was made in off-shore drilling would now take a stand for Florida's Gulf coast against the special interests of the oil industry!  Even so, I do have faith that you and your family would be willing to take a last stand for Florida because of your family tradition of service that goes back generations. I used to think I knew your family even though I have never met any of the members.  Friends in Connecticut were great admirers of Prescott and we all wanted your dad to win the presidency his first time 'round. There were also background similarities - my ancestors from colonial Massachusetts and Connecticut...the Episcopal Church...the loss of our daughter Robin from a congenital heart defect as a little child.  I must admit I have become disillusioned over the last decade but hope and faith spring eternal.  Do the right thing.  If for no other reason, consider our increased vulnerability as a result of using up our natural resources now instead of saving something for the future.

Considering our legacy in life,

Roberta Somach
2701 Casey Key Road
Nokomis, FL 34275-3391

From:	Elaine and/or Karl Gerwe <ekgerwe@netzero.net>
Sent:	Sunday, December 3, 2006 2:34 PM
To:	Transition; Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	 Insurance and Property Tax Crisis Examples
Attachments:	Insurance.jpg; Tax.jpg

Re-sent message with corrected attachments.
 
From: Elaine and/or Karl Gerwe 
To: transition@myflorida.com ; jeb.bush@myflorida.com 
Sent: Sunday, December 03, 2006 2:29 PM
Subject: Actual Homeowner's Insurance and Property Tax Crisis Examples

Gov Bush and Gov-Elect Crist: 
 
I've attached scans of my latest homeowner's insurance cancellation letter and my son's Volusia County tax bill for his vacant, palmetto-covered 50' X 175' lot.
 
Regarding the insurance cancellation, I'm a 56 year old Florida native who has never filed a homeowner's insurance claim even though I've been a homeowner in Palm Beach and Volusia Counties since I was 23. I've always done whatever I could to protect my home from damage of all kinds. I have full hurricane protection consisting of removable panels which I installed before the disastrous '04 season. I suffered no damage while my neighbors (also insured by the same company in some cases) did nothing to protect their homes prior to the storms nor to prevent further weather-related or mold-related damage after the storms. They filed large claims which were paid by their insurers despite doing nothing to mitigate potential damage while I did everything possible and did prevent damage yet I'm being dropped as fast as they drop those customers who are and always were, poor risks. Where's the logic there especially given their elaborate screening process for new policies? You're a good risk until they decide you're a bad risk even though nothing has changed except their desire to insure you??? You need to force all insurers that are in the homeowner's market anywhere in the US to offer it here or get out of Florida all together - no Florida subsidiaries and no excuses. 
 
2nd, regarding the property bill attached, note that the Ad Valorem taxes on the smallish, albeit waterfront, vacant lot are $9826.46! Brian, an Air Force F-16 pilot and father of two small children, has had the lot on the market for a year (can't sell it either!) since he's decided that he cannot afford to live in Florida on the lot of his dreams!!! Even if you forget the fact that Volusia County has the 3rd highest millage rate in the state, why should a vacant lot be charged at the same rate as one with a home or business upon it? A vacant lot doesn't use the school system ($3,748), it doesn't get sick and need the hospital district at $1,080, it just sits there consuming no services until someone builds on it. You need to change the law to correct this blatant tax grab. So, let me illustrate further -  Brian's vacant lot pays over $9800 per year in tax, my nearby waterfront house built in '99 on the same size lot pays about $6000, my neighbor's built a few years before that pays about $3000 and so on down the ridiculous and inequitable line is the best tax system we can offer? Please address this terrible situation before we all go under! Like most of my friends, I'm looking at leaving the state upon my retirement as I can't afford the taxes I will pay if this system isn't changed. I looked up my County Councilman's tax bill and that of the County Council Chairman - $1200 and $1500 respectively - they feel no tax pain and don't even bother to return e-mails on the subject and won't until you force the issue.
 
Florida's Golden Goose (as long as I've been alive) has been development, tourism, and as  a haven for retirees. Now two of the three are dead or dying fast. You need to do something real and not just a band-aid homestead exemption doubling - the whole system needs to be re-vamped. I'll even consider a state income tax if it gets us some equity in the property tax arena! 
 
Thanks for your review and action...........Karl Gerwe

The text version of the e-newsletter is below.


CECIL FIELD COMMERCE CENTER SELECTED AS SITE FOR MAJOR AVIATION PRODUCTION
SITE

On Monday, I applauded the C-27J industry team of L-3 Communications
Integrated Systems, Finmeccanica's Alenia North America, Global Military
Aircraft Systems and Boeing Integrated Defense Systems for their commitment
to establish the group's advanced aircraft operation at Jacksonville's Cecil
Commerce Center if awarded a Department of Defense contract. I toured the
C-27J aircraft and potential assembly and production site along with
Congressman Ander Crenshaw, Jacksonville Mayor John Peyton, and state and
local business leaders. In selecting Jacksonville's Cecil Field, the C-27J
Joint Cargo Aircraft team has embraced the strengths of our state's
pro-business climate, robust defense industry and highly skilled aviation
and aerospace workforce. This new assembly and production activity will
enhance Florida' economy and would be a great addition to the state's
thriving aviation sector, currently the third strongest in the nation. Most
importantly, the C-27J will help our men and women of the Army and the Air
Force continue to serve and defend our country. The Department of Defense
is expected to award the Joint Cargo Aircraft contract in early 2007. Should
the Department award the multi-billion dollar contract to the C-27J team,
the group will begin establishing its advanced aircraft operation at the
Jacksonville site in 2007. The facility is expected to employ more than 200
people. For more information on our economic development initiatives,
please visit www.myflorida.com.


2006 FLORIDA YOUTH SUBSTANCE ABUSE SURVEY RESULTS ANNOUNCED

On Tuesday, I announced the results of the 2006 Florida Youth Substance
Abuse Survey. In the last eight years, we have worked to strengthen
substance abuse prevention, and we have seen significant progress in the
cause. This year's results confirm that progress is being made, but the
work is not done. Since 2000, Florida has seen declines in the use of
heroin, ecstasy and LSD, as well as in the use of cigarettes and alcohol.
This year, 12 of the 21 categories measured current use below two percent.
Conducted among 6th through 12th graders throughout the state for the
seventh consecutive year, the Florida Youth Substance Abuse Survey is the
most extensive survey of its kind in the nation. The survey assesses
lifetime drug usage and current usage. I was joined for Tuesday's
announcement by First Lady Columba Bush, Lt. Governor Toni Jennings,
Director of the Florida Office of Drug Control Bill Janes, state agency
heads, law enforcement officials and substance abuse prevention specialists
- key partners in reducing substance abuse throughout the state. For view
the complete results of the 2006 Florida Youth Substance Abuse Survey,
please visit www.dcf.state.fl.us/mentalhealth/publications/fysas.


2006 FLORIDA HOLIDAY ORNAMENT AND GOVERNOR'S MANSION 50TH ANNIVERSARY
COMMEMORATIVE BOOK AVAILABLE

The Florida Governor's Mansion Foundation is pleased to announce its annual
holiday ornament, the fourth in a series. Coinciding with its 50th
anniversary and inclusion in the National Register of Historic Places, the
image of the Governor's Mansion is appropriately featured on this year's
ornament. The Foundation is also proud to announce the publication of First
Families in Residence: Life at the Florida Governor's Mansion, by
distinguished architectural historian Ellen J. Uguccioni. The new
commemorative book is a lively chronicle of both the residence and the lives
of the families, including interviews with many governors, first ladies and
family members, as well as outstanding new and archival photographs never
before published. To view and order both the new 2006 ornament (as well as
2003, 2004, & 2005 ornaments) and the book, please visit:
www.floridashistoryshop.com or call (850) 245-6396.

From:	Rivera, Angel L. <Angel.Rivera@va.gov>
Sent:	Friday, December 1, 2006 12:20 PM
To:	Roddenberry, Tiffany; Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Response to your e-mail answer

November 26, 2006

Angel Luis Rivera

3301 Yellowknife Circle

Wimauma, FL 33598

To: Ms. Tiffany McClellan-Roddenberry

Executive Office of the Governor – Jeb Bush

Tiffany.McClellan@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US

 

Dear Ms. McClellan-Roddenberry:

Thank you for your response to me on behalf of Governor Bush.

I believe from the tone of your letter that there is some degree of understanding and sympathy on your part and that of the Governor for what people like myself are going through in this deplorable situation. To put it in human terms: I feel despair, sick with profound sadness, depressed, terrified, frustrated, angry, and bitter at the thought that I have worked hard all my life, always contributed to society and to my government, only to have my government turn around and take it all away from me. I cannot imagine anyone with an iota of feeling not being able to relate to what I am going through.

I will be at a hearing on Friday, December 8, 2006 with the Hillsborough County Value Adjustment Board (VAB) at 601 East Kennedy Blvd., Tampa. I believe the Governor is a good and just man. I have never asked anything of my government for myself; I now ask for his support in whatever way possible to help me with this agency in my plea for a more reasonable tax on my property. $8000, $7000, $6000, $5000, $4000 are all TOO MUCH for me to pay in taxes.

Following are queries and suggestions for consideration by anyone attempting to solve the current plight of the homeowner vs. property taxation in Florida today. Since I live in Hillsborough County, I will address my grievances toward that entity – but they apply to every other taxpaying citizen, county and municipality in the state.

INEQUITY

My immediate neighbor's adjoining property (3302 Yellowknife Circle) is the same size as mine (3.24 acres). My land is contiguous and continuous with his. The neighbor's 1.4 acres, on which his house and stables sit, are designated Use Code 9950, Land Use Description Acreage Class 50, assessed at $68,600.00. The remaining 1.84 acres of their property are designated as Use Code LOWLANDS and assessed at $1,380.00.

My house and shed sit on less than 1 acre of land. The remaining 2.24(+) acres to the sides and the rear of the house are wild lowlands. Looking at an aerial map of both our properties, you cannot tell where one ends and where the other begins – the properties are identical in elevation – or rather, descent. However, all of my 3.24 acres were classified as Use Code 9950, Land Use Description Acreage Class 50. As a result, all of the land was assessed at $144,180.00.

Further, I am not using the remaining 2.24(+) acres. Nor do I intend to; what for – so I can get taxed more? They are just wild woods. My neighbor's land assessment is for $69,980.00; mine is $144,180.00. Where is the justice here?

Also, as I indicated in my previous e-mail to the Governor, my property was initially assessed at $34,400.00. Then it jumped to $55,000.00. Then $144,180.00. I thought that county rules prevented property from being assessed at more than 3% higher per succeeding year. Over a 4 year span, my assessment went up by 419%! If the above land assessment was prompted by the building of my home, then this is mere opportunism and gouging by the Property Assessor.

I was previously homesteaded in Bradenton for 14 years. I did not move out of the state. I moved into Hillsborough County in order for my wife and I to be closer to our jobs. Why couldn’t my Homestead status be continued when I changed residence and moved into Hillsborough County? This is where my home was being built – why did my land appraisal jump so high?

I paid for $35,000 for our 3.24 acre property. That’s all it’s worth to me and would not have paid another penny for it. I bought it to live on it until I die, with no plans to sell it. I have no qualms paying property tax on the amount I paid for it – but to have it appraised at $155,000 + is absolutely ridiculous. I am living on only less than 1 acre of my land – why then is all of it appraised so high?

We sacrificed and sent our children to private schools. We do not have children in school. Why do we have to pay for other people’s children’s schooling?

We provide our own water and pay for our own electricity. What services is Hillsborough County providing us with that would be worth $8,000.00?


A CAP ON REAL ESTATE TAXES FOR THE INDIVIDUAL HOMEOWNER


If Hillsborough County got along fine with my $2,000.00 in taxes last year, why was it necessary for the Property Assessor to increase my taxes by 400% to a staggering and crippling $8,000.00? Why can't $2,000.00 be sufficient as my "fair share"? There are thousands and thousands more homeowners throughout the county due to all the building that has gone on. If each of those households is paying $2,000.00 in property taxes, why isn't that enough for the county?


VALUE ADJUSTMENT BOARD IMPARTIALITY?


Special magistrates are appointed to preside over VAB hearings – which our tax dollars pay for. My understanding is that these persons are in the real estate profession. If so, then that brings their impartiality into question – after all, real estate brokers make more money on sales of properties with higher sales values, which higher property assessments imply, so it is in their best interests for properties to be assessed high and it would be natural for them to resist any lowering in assessments as it would threaten their income. This implies a conflict of interest on the part of said magistrates that are part of the real estate industry.


DOWNSIZING THE BEAUROCRACY


1.	Has anybody done an accounting of just how many employees are currently working for Hillsborough County? Does it number in the thousands or tens of thousands? 
2.	Just how many office employees and receptionists are required in order to keep a beaurocracy running smoothly? How many of these positions are essential? How much money would be saved by eliminating as many non-essential beaurocratic positions as possible? 
3.	There is a far greater need for medical workers such as EMTs, Paramedics, and Nurses. Non-essential county workers should be sent for medical and teaching training and placed in private hospitals, fire departments, private ambulance companies and private schools. 
4.	How about eliminating county governments altogether and letting everything emanate from the State level? My understanding is that there was a fiscal surplus this last year and monies were refunded to the counties – how about returning those monies to the taxpayers instead of giving it back to county beaurocrats to spend on themselves?

Who is responsible for the horrendous tax rates? County Commissioners? An individual? How do they arrive at their disastrous figures? Who are they accountable to? What are we, serfs, born to do the bidding of a higher class, never to have a life of our own? Do the taxing authorities collectively believe they are the sheriffs of Nottingham? Do they think they are entitled to levy taxes and plunder the citizenship at will with no accountability?

Thank you for your attention. Please pass this on to the appropriate authority and register my feelings with them.

Very truly yours,

Angel Rivera

When I purchased my property approximately 20 years ago I paid $45,000.00 for the property.  Therefore,  the value of this property is $45,000.00.   However, each year my property appraisal value increases and now the tax collector appraises the value of my property as close to $180,000.00.  
 
The  appraisal figure  is what I am taxed on each year  not the price of the property.  I feel that since I paid $45,000.00 for the property and I contribute to the community each year by earning money and paying taxes it is unfair I am taxed on an appraised value and not the realistic true value of what I paid for the property.  
 
I have no intention of selling my property and yet I am being taxed on what the county is appraising my home for.   Respectively, it is only worth $45,000.00 because that is what I paid for the property.  
 
If I were to sell the property for $180,000.00 it would only be fair that it would be the responsibility of the new buyer to be responsible for paying taxes on the price they paid for the property. 
 
The tax collectors assessment of the value should only be a standard for what the community feels the value of my house is if I were to sell it.  Not a figure that I am taxed on.   I would have never purchased a house for $180,000.00 to begin with as computing insurance, taxes, etc this would have put me out of my league. Respectively, why should I be paying property taxes on an appraised value?  Where did I ever agree to that when I purchased my home?  
 
The tax bill should be rated on the price of the property not the tax collectors appraisal.   I don't know who's idea paying taxes on the appraised value was, but if you think about it, its totally wrong.
 
My neighbor moved a few years ago and sold her house for $40,000.00.  The people that bought the house fixed it up and re sold it for $95,000.00.  This figure was totally absurd, however, the purchaser agreed to pay that amount and that should be the amount the new purchaser is taxed on.  Meanwhile, my property value increase dramatically because someone was dumb enough to pay $95,000.00 for a $40,000.00 house next door.
 
I believe in consistency because I feel that is fair for everyone.   Instead of having a homestead exemption there should be a standard percentage for property tax.  For example 5% of the price the homeowner paid for the property each year.  This way you know if you spend $5,000.00, $50,000.00 or $500,000.00 what your taxes are.  We spend our life budgeting for things and I don't feel its fair I have to budget for an appraised value bill instead of the actual value of the property.
 
A homeowner who brought their property 50 years ago for $7,000.00 and have been paying taxes in the community for 50 years should not have to pay for an appraised value of their property, especially if they never sell their home. I wonder how senior citizens on fixed incomes can afford to pay an increasing appraised tax bill each year on a fixed income?
 
Who's idea was this?  Do you think its fair?  I would think it would be a lot easier for the government to figure what they would be collecting each year for property taxes if each person paid the same percentage on the purchase price of the home.  I dont mind paying taxes on something I buy, but I do mind being taxed on something that's not real.  The reality is my home is worth $45,000.00 because that's what I paid for it.
 
In the next couple years the banks are going to be crashing because people were so stupid the last couple of years and over extended themselves on property they are not going to be able to afford in the future.  The government sending them bills for appraised value and not real value is going to play a big part in this in the future.  
 
I have never written a government official in the past, but I have seen you on tv and you seem to have compassion and know the difference between right and wrong. Is there anything you can do to fix a problem that is hurting thousands of floridians?
 
I don't know if I will get a response, so I will thank you in advance for taking the time to read this and give my thoughts possible consideration.
 
Blessings to you and your family during the holiday seasons and always.

From:	Whitaker, Wayne <Wayne.Whitaker@techdata.com>
Sent:	Thursday, November 30, 2006 1:15 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Potential Property Tax Solution

Dear Governor Bush,
 
The property tax issue in Florida has been weighing on my mind, as I am sure it has yours.  As I was thinking through possible solutions, the thought came to me that we have capped the wrong variable under the current system.  Allow me to explain.
 
Currently we cap the amount of appreciated value that can be taxed until the property changes hands (I know I am simplifying this greatly).  When the property changes hands the full market value is then taxed.  Therefore, there is a step function increase in property tax revenue from that property as it changes ownership.  Since there is a certain amount of property turnover during the year (someone told me once that the US average is every 5 years) for some percentage of the property market the taxing authority gets a windfall.  If no one sold their homes and there were no new building during a year, the tax revenue would increase by the amount of the tax cap (I'm not sure what it is -- 3%?).
 
The potential solution is to have the property assessed at fair market value BUT have the cap placed upon how much tax the taxing entity can receive.  For example, the cap could be inflation plus rate of growth (for new property construction).  This would allow revenue to be extracted for services needed to support a larger population base while limiting the amount of increase levied on existing property.  Just because a property changes hands does not mean that the level of services required by that property has increased.  Therefore, as property increased in value, the rate at which it is taxed would decrease.  The formula could work so that there would be enough tax collected from the new property to cover the growth rate and existing property would be taxed at a rate not to exceed some legislated level (CPI, for example).  If incremental tax would be needed to cover something unusual, a special vote could take place to temporarily increase the rate to cover the extraordinary expense.
 
Thanks for all your hard work and for caring about Florida.
 
All the best,
 
Wayne Whitaker
Common Citizen
 
P.S.  If any of these ideas get adopted, please let me know.  I would like to know I was able to help in a small way.

Dear Govenor Bush,
 
Regarding a story today November 30 2006 "Tourism Outlook Not All That Sunny"
St Petersburg Times November 30 2006 Business Section
 
I am a member of the Florida Superior Small Lodgings. The SSL consists of a group of vacation rental owner operators dedicated to maintaining high standards for small lodgings. Our guests for the most part are middle income families.
 
The folks at FLA USA and Visit Florida seem not to have got the full picture regarding the reasons for the downturn of tourism in Florida.
It is not rocket science. It is old down home, grass roots common sense.
 
Florida is a hostile environment for the tourist industry. 
 
As an owner of vacation rental condominiums I have seen the TAXES on a one bedroom St. Petersburg vacation rental condominium rise from $1146.64 in 2000 to $4350.21 in 2006.
 
1. This is an increase of 280%.
2. Taxes have gone from 8% of my overhead to 30% of  
    overhead!
3.  Add to this the sky rocketing cost of insurance and you 
    will quickly see that tourism in Florida is in dire straights.
4. Businesses must raise rates to reflect this increase. This 
    is not  always possible in a competitive environment as 
    you will see.
5. No business can consistently raise prices this steeply 
   and not have a consumer  backlash.
   That is, no business unless you are in the business of 
   government levying taxes. 
   And today Government is my primary business partner.
 
My silent business partner - who shares in the all of the benefits of my labor and who shares none of the risk, is the state of Florida and Pinellas County.
 
Tourism is our # 1 industry in Florida. But unrestrained government is hauling in our money like pigs at the trough. Biased tax laws are what is strangling the tourist industry as insidiously as citrus canker is devastating the citrus industry.
The difference is that the tourist industry die off is self inflicted. 
 
The looming disaster can be stopped if Government were to return to their budgets of 2000 and limit themselves to Cost of Inflation increases rather than windfall gains.
 
The truism of Civics finance is that government will spend whatever it receives. Each years budget is based on the previous year. If a department does not spend ALL of its budget income, then the following year it may get a reduced allocation. Therefore the incentive of government - unlike the private sector is to SPEND.
 
The property tax structure is akin to a person owning shares in the stock market. You may have bought Berkshire Hathaway (Warren Buffet) 10 years ago when the stock was $30,000 and today it is over $100,000. A similar 280% increase to that which we have experienced in the property market here in Florida.
 
Imagine if each year you were taxed on those shares even though you have not sold them. And imagine that as your shares go up in value, your tax assessment increases each year based on their current market value.
 
How long do you imagine that you would hold on to those shares?
You would not!
 
You would sell out.
 
More to the point - investors, Wall Street and the Federal Government would be outraged. And rightly so.
It would not be tolerated!
 
We are paying taxes on the value of something (property) whose value or capital gain we have not yet realized. It is only a paper gain until such time as we sell it. We have NOT received the beneficial use of this gain. However we are taxed as if we had.
In fact we are taxed each year on the potential capital gains, not just once - compounded taxation. 
 
Normally a capital gain is only taxed once - and that is upon sale, as in the case of stocks. Not so in the arcane world of property taxes in Florida. 
 
Property taxes in Florida are made more diabolical - because the tax is based on the "highest and best use of the property" as defined by the property appraisers office. Such definitions defy logic. As I recently found out. The appraisers office is unable to define their own standard of what constitutes the "highest and best use of a property."
 
I called Jim Smith Property Appraisers Office about my huge increase in property taxes. I was met with the most cold hearted and callous response from a man in that department.
He dismissed me with the a short comment "If you cannot afford the taxes then perhaps you are in the wrong business!"
 
"Oh?" I replied. "What business did he suggest I should be in?" And he replied, "Well maybe you should be flipping burgers or maybe you have to sell out. Go and sell used cars or something"
 
Perhaps this "Public Servant" has life time job security. I do not. He does not have to worry about providing for his family, medical benefits and a retirement plan. Or "working" for a living. Public servants rarely deal with these concerns.
Perhaps what he should have said to me, is, "Give up the struggle, don't try to earn a living, come and join the wonderful world of public service."
 
I fear that his attitude is not isolated, it is endemic in the Tax Assessors Office and the office of tax collection. It is endemic in our government leaders.
 
This is OUR public money at work!
 
Regarding Florida Tourism. Consider this.
My European business, mainly UK tourists, carry us through the summer months. Traditionally Americans and Canadians do not travel to Florida in the summer months as much as they do in winter.
So in the summer, the entire USA is our competition, whether it is New England, Colorado, the Canadian Rockies and even Alaska. Florida is not a top of the mind destination.
However for Europeans it is. They have 3-6 weeks annual vacation in summer.
 
We compete for those tourist Euros with the likes of the Mediterranean countries, Egypt, Morocco, Spain, Greece, Italy, etc., as well as with more exotic places like Thailand, South Africa and Australia.
 
A UK tourist can get flight and hotel packages - all inclusive, for $700.00 per week AND LESS - to most of the Mediterranean, to Eastern European countries,  and to many Asian destinations.
 
I have seen a huge drop in European travelers.  
 
American travelers have a choice as well. Be it summer or winter. A 7 night cruise with all inclusive fare, meals, travel, entertainment costs about $700.00,
 
Mexico, with its fabulous beaches and great shopping is the same.
 
Other sunshine destinations such as Las Vegas, which you mentioned in your article, has real family appeal. The Carolina beaches are head to head competition with us. So are the Texas beaches.
 
The Caribbean and Central and South America are wonderful bargains. Seven nights in Peru, Machu Picchu, Amazon rain forest, Inca highlights with fully guided tours are $800.00 airfare included!
 
I am in what is considered a moderate price range for Florida.
This week I have turned away several inquiries for Christmas lodging because folks were turned off by the cost. Perhaps I need to cut prices in the face of rising costs?
 
Our taxes and our government are killing tourism in Florida as surely as day turns to night.
And a long, cold night it will be.
 
Sincerely,
 
Jeffrey Solomon

OFFICE DEPOT GLOBAL HEADQUARTERS EXPANSION ANNOUNCED

On Monday, I applauded the announcement by Office Depot to build a new
corporate headquarters facility in Boca Raton. With the expansion of this
business unit, the Florida-founded Office Depot expects to create 430 new
jobs and invest at least $210 million in facility construction ($180
million) and new equipment ($30 million). I am honored to recognize Office
Depot's longtime commitment to Florida, the state where it first established
roots in 1986. While this fine global corporate headquarters would be
welcomed anywhere, I am distinctly proud Office Depot chose South Florida to
foster its future success. We greatly value the company's presence, economic
contributions, and corporate citizenship, and I look forward to its ongoing
success in the Sunshine State. Office Depot opened its first store in Fort
Lauderdale in October, 1986. Today, Office Depot is a Fortune 150 Company
with annual sales of nearly $15 billion and 50,000 associates around the
world. My Office of Tourism, Trade and Economic Development worked with
the Palm Beach County Business Development Board and Enterprise Florida,
Inc., to encourage this important expansion project in South Florida. For
more information on our economic development initiatives, please visit
www.myflorida.com.


FLORIDA COMPREHENSIVE ASSESSMENT TESTS RELEASED

Also on Monday, Florida Department of Education Commissioner John L. Winn
and I announced the release of eight Florida Comprehensive Assessment Tests
(FCAT). The reading and mathematics tests are actual tests taken by students
in 2006 and are no longer in use. The reading and mathematics tests for
grades 3, 7, 9, and 10 are available in two formats - one which can be
downloaded, and a new, interactive version that allows you to take the test
and get results online. The Department of Education began releasing
full-length FCAT tests last year, starting with grades 4, 8 and 10 reading
and mathematics tests. The release of the Grade 3, 7, 9, and 10 tests
enhances the educational resources for students and parents to better
understand the FCAT. I am thankful to all of the Florida educators who help
develop and review appropriate test questions. As a result of their
commitment, the State continues to take steps toward increasing the
transparency of the FCAT. Test questions are written according to specific
guidelines developed by Florida educators. Questions are reviewed and
revised by teachers, curriculum experts and school and district
administrators to ensure they are appropriate for the grade level tested.
Each year, more than 500 classroom teachers, special education teachers,
English language learning instructors, administrators, curriculum
specialists, policy leaders, college and university experts, school board
members and parents take part in the FCAT question review process. The 2005
and 2006 released FCAT tests, as well as the supporting documents, can be
found at http://www.firn.edu/doe/sas/fcatrelease.html

of the families, including interviews with many governors, first ladies and
