HOW QUICK ARE THESE TAXES GOING TO BE ROLLED BACK TO THE CONSUMER, AS THE BELOW LAW STATES THEY ARE SUPPOSE TO? 


Tax Limitations on County Commission and Cities 

By special act of the Florida Legislature (Laws of Florida Chapter 74-430 House Bill No. 4173), municipal taxing authorities are limited to a maximum 10% increase in the amount of revenue that can be raised in comparison to the prior year. A March 1996 Charter Amendment referendum limited the Board of County Commissioner's ability to increase revenues over the preceding year for operating funds to 3% or the change in the consumer price index, whichever is less. 

taxauth.asp" \l "Contents: taxauth.asp" \l "Contents:The Millage Rates of the Taxing Authorities 

When the total taxable value (the total assessed value of all individual properties in the County added together after exemptions) of the tax roll increases from one year to the next year, the Taxing Authorities (County Commission, Municipalities, School Board, etc.) are required by State Law to begin their budget with a roll-back of the millage rate to a rate which will generate the same revenue as in the previous year; reference hypothetical Example of Annual Roll-back Procedure below.

The Property Appraiser is responsible for certifying to each Taxing Authority the annual taxable value. Each Taxing Authority then must compute a roll-up or a roll-back millage rate and a proposed millage. The "roll-back millage" rate is the millage rate, or tax rate that the Taxing Authorities must use as a basis for computing any increase in their annual budgets. Usually, this millage rate is lower than the preceding year's tax rate, because as a general rule, there is usually an increase in the tax base each year sufficient to allow for a millage roll-back. The value increase in the tax base is due to re-assessments and new construction in the prior year. However, new construction is not permitted by Florida Law to be used to calculate the roll-back millage. If the total taxable value (as defined) decreases, the Taxing Authorities are entitled to an upward change of the "roll-back" in the tax millage rate in order to maintain the same level of revenue as the preceding year as the starting point for any budget increases. 

The term "roll-back" is used to describe the economic conditions of total taxable value in the prior year and the amount of monies raised by ad-valorem taxes. It does not relate to the rate of change in the millage. 

With the millage roll-back rate, the Taxing Authorities will realize exactly the same amount of revenue as the preceding year. If they decide to raise the millage rate above the roll-back rate, it usually means that the cost of government operations has increased, or that new public service programs have been added to their budgets. The effect of the millage roll-back on your property taxes will appear on your "Truth In Millage Notice" (TRIM) each year in Column 3. By referring to your Notice, you will also note that Column 1 indicates the previous year's taxes and Column 2 indicates the proposed increase or decrease in tax dollars if the proposed budget is adopted. An example of this calculation is given below. The tax millages for 1999 are also listed below the example of the annual roll back procedure table. Clicking on the Millage Code will present the user with the specific millage rates by each taxing authority.

EXAMPLE
HOW TAXING AUTHORITIES CAN HIDE TAX INCREASES BY IGNORING THE
ROLLBACK MILLAGE RATE

PROPERTY APPRAISER
Determines Tax Base             TAXING AUTHORITY
Sets Budget, Tax Rate & Levies Tax                     
TOTAL TAXABLE VALUE                     TAX RATE        REVENUE
YEAR 1  $12,000,000,000         7.000 MILLS     $84,000,000    
YEAR 2  $14,000,000,000 ROLLBACK        6.000 MILLS     $84,000,000    
YEAR 2  $14,000,000,000 ADOPT 10%
TAX INCREASE    6.600 MILLS *   $92,400,000    


* TELL TAXPAYERS THEY REDUCED THEIR TAX RATE FROM 7.00 TO 6.60 MILLS BUT THEY ACTUALLY INCREASE TAXES. 
Detailed Example Explanation 

In this example, "Year 1" reflects a $12 billion dollar tax base (established by the Property Appraiser) times a 7 mill tax rate, (tax rate set by taxing authority) providing the taxing authority $84 million dollars in revenue. The subsequent, "Year 2", reflects a $14 billion dollar tax base times the required rollback rate of 6 mills to again provide the taxing authority $84 million dollars in revenue. Should the taxing authority adopt a 10% tax increase, as displayed in the above chart, total revenues reach 92.4 million dollars. This represents an increase in taxes of $8.4 million dollars even though the tax millage rate was reduced from the prior year. 


I look forward to your response. 

Jackie Buscemi 
jjbuscemi@bellsouth.net

Subject:	Property Insurance & Property Taxes 

Things you may not know. We recently received our property insurance renewal from State Farm. I was very surprised that our Windstorm Insurance had not been canceled. However, our Windstorm coverage went up 152%. The policy also included a charge of $150.00 to Citizens Insurance Group. I was told by our agent that in the 1970's Ormond Beach, Daytona Beach and South Daytona chose to become part of a Wind Zone Area. In other words an Insurance company can sell a homeowners policy and not offer Windstorm coverage in these cities. If you live in another city, the Insurance company must offer Windstorm coverage. I was told that anyone who has State Farm will get hit with the increase in Windstorm Coverage if their policy renews after October 10th. I sent this information to the Mayor, my City Councilman and Jeb Bush. The only person I heard from was someone in the governors office and his response was just fluff.  
 
If you review your new Property Tax Bill, you may be in for a surprise. I was expecting to see a 3% increase in the appraised value of our home. It was much higher. I went down to the Property Appraisers Office and was told the following. The appraised value on our house went up more than 3% because we had pulled a permit to replace the pool screen enclosure that was destroyed during the 2004 hurricanes. I was told that the screen enclosure was considered as a new addition and that it increased the value of our house. It did not make any difference that we had to have it, and that it was not an addition to our house. I then asked if everyone who pulled a permit to repair or replace a damaged roof would receive an increase in their Property Taxes. I was told that they would. Something is wrong with this picture.You have damage to your home, you pay a high hurricane deductible, your insurance company raises your rates and your local government raises your taxes to replace something that you need according to law.   
 
 
Nancy & Paul

Dear Governor Bush:

 

Over the past two years, property insurance rates have dramatically increased – this not

 only affects, as a homeowner, but also as an owner of a timeshare property. Florida 

Law requires that my timeshare owners association insure my timeshare property for full

replacement value, leaving little room for negotiation with the insurance companies or 

reduction in coverage.

 

As a timeshare owner, my concerns with these unprecedented insurance increases include:

 

1.	How does the State of Florida plan on increasing the number of insurance carriers,

Thereby giving timeshare associations more choices with carriers? What can be done to

decrease cost or place reasonable limits on increases in premiums?

                                                                                                                                    

2.	Hurricanes have been a known weather condition in the state for years. Why have the 

Issues of increasing premiums and decreasing number of insurance carriers not been 

addressed before?

 

3.	What can be done to help timeshare and condominium associations take steps to 

Improve their properties and provide better protection from severe storms? How can

Such improvements be taken into account in determining appropriate premiums and 

deductibles?

 

4.	The Florida Comprehensive Hurricane Damage Migration Program provides free 

Inspections and grants individual homeowners, but what is being done to help

timeshares, condominiums and businesses?

 

As a time share owner, I appreciate your commitment to protecting the future of Florida’s

Dear Governor Bush:

 
Property taxes keep going up each year with no end in sight.

I purchased my condo four years ago and I am now paying roughly five 
thousand dollars more in property taxes. What has happen is the fact that 
similar condo units in my building have been reselling for more money. Yes 
this seems like a great thing, but I didn't buy at these prices and I am 
forced to pay taxes on those assessed values. Like myself, there are 
thousand of homeowners out there that have seen their property taxes 
almost double. The funny thing is that we are not getting any additional 
services for paying more property taxes.  The real winner in all this is 
the government, which gets a wind fall form the increase in property taxes 
while maintaining the same operating budget. This whole property tax 
system is a flaw of the injustice that is occurring year after year to 
homeowners across the state of Florida.  Increases in property taxes 
should not solely be based on higher property values but should have a 
more important significance on the operating budgets that are set for each 
town. This way we can hold our government accountable for any increases in 
their operating budget and limit them to how much more they will need to 
raise our property taxes to support its operation.  

1.Tax the home owner based on what he paid for his property. This way he 
is not affected by similar properties being sold for more money around 
him. This also helps the elderly people and local residents who live on a 
fixed income from increased rents and additional property taxes. 

2. Accountability to keep taxes low.  Force local and county government to 
keep from increasing our property taxes based on operating budgets not 
property values. This way local towns and county governments will compete 
with one another on attracting residents by having lower taxes. 

3. Surpluses in property taxes should be refunded back to the home owners. 
After all it's their money, and government does a poor job of misusing the 
money.

Sincerely,


Daniel Cardenas

Subject:	Copy of email to all FL legislators

Dear Governor Bush,
 
The following is a copy of an email which I sent to all Florida legislators in regard to the proposed $1,000 annual tuition surcharge/fee increase for the University of Florida, approved this week by the Board Of Governors. Inasmuch as this matter will come before the legislature in its 2007 session, and it can dramatically impact the approximate 739,000 families enrolled in the Florida Prepaid College Tuition Plan, as well as those other students qualifying for the Florida Bright Futures Scholarship, it is hoped that it would have your utmost attention.
 
______________________________________________________________________________________________________
 
"As a grandfather sponsering nine grandchildren in the Florida Prepaid College Plan, I was deeply troubled by the Florida Board Of Governors approval of the $1,000 annual tuition surcharge/fee for the University of Florida. My dismay is not with the substance of the increase, but rather its form.
 
Since this matter will come before you during the Florida 2007, legislative session, I implore you to carefully weigh the implications of this method of tuition increase on the approximately 739,000 Florida families currently enrolled in the Prepaid College Plan. 
 
As it is currently approved, this tuition increase would be outside of the scope of the state's tuition funding for the Florida Prepaid College Plan and the Florida Bright Futures Scholarship Program. In effect, families who need educational financial assistance the most will have to pay this tuition surcharge/fee out-of-pocket.
 
At a time when Florida families are besieged with the financial burdens of - skyrocketing increases in homeowners insurance premiums, spiraling real estate taxes, escalating gasoline prices, trying to recover from the expenses paid personally for Hurricane Insurance Deductibles, and a myriad of other accelerating costs - a vote to approve this type out-of-pocket tuition surcharge/fee payment is politically and socially insentitive and unwise, to say the least.
 
What is further troublesome in this issue is that this tuition surcharge/fee could be expanded to include Florida's ten other universities. How does this make any sense? 
 
If the University of Florida is seeking to enhance its status to be included in the national top ten college/universities listing by getting more money to hire more teachers, why would this have any bearing on the status of Florida's other universities. 
 
It is understandable that the University of Florida would seek to improve its ranking. Accordingly, let any tuition increase be included in the Florida state funded Prepaid College Plan and Bright Futures Scholarship Program. In so doing, it does not violate the original good faith intentions of the State of Florida to provide equal educational opportunities for its less financially privleged citizens.
 
Thank you for your consideration of this matter.
 
Respectfully,
 
Tony Ettorre
Wellington, Florida
Phone 561-543-7330 "

Dear Governor Bush
 
It was always my dream to own a Florida property where my family could enjoy all year round sunshine and of course the many parks. Two years ago, I like many Brits purchased my first holiday home in Davenport, and looked forward to visiting at least twice per year.
 
Since then, owning a home in your beautiful state has been an uphill struggle, with extreme difficulty in securing bookings for our villa due to the endless building of new homes, and rates being dragged down to unacceptable levels. General taxes having nearly doubled, and now insurance premiums increasing by 50%.
 
Together with 12% tourist taxes, spiralling power costs, owning our villa is now becoming unattractive for us and many hundreds of Brit owners. You only have to look on some of the website forums to see their dissatisfaction and the belief that non residents are being unfairly targeted.
 
When I purchased my home it was not to make money from rentals, but for somewhere for myself and my family to enjoy. Perhaps when I eventually sell a profit would be realised but now I am not even sure about that. all I wanted to do was to break even and then eventually enjoy a villa by one of your lakes and spend up to six months per year there during my retirement.
 
The Florida authorities need to decide whether you want us Brits as owners in your state or not. I predict that if costs continue to increase as they have been without additional income from our homes being realised then most Brits will pull out within the next five years.
 
 Florida is not an attractive investment anymore, and many will look to put their hard earn pounds into European property, in particular within the eastern block countries.
 
As a supporter of the American way of life I urge the authorities to consider the long term implications of their unfair charges as well as other service providers. I for one will reluctantly look to sell next year and reinvest elsewhere.
 
Yours sincerely
 
David Hearn
Villa Owner, Davenport, Orlando Florida

Mortgage rates as low as 4.625% - $150,000 loan for $579 a month. Intro-*Terms
From:	Chris Chavers <cchavers@jmerealty.com>
Sent:	Saturday, November 18, 2006 12:08 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Special Session

You can thank most of the state lawmakers for this one: The rate hike is necessary to comply with a provision in the insurance bill they passed in May. The bill requires Citizens to set rates high enough to cover all possible losses from the type of catastrophic storm that could hit once in 70 years.
 
“It’s absolutely preposterous. Who can handle this type of thing?” said Peter Otto, a Bayside resident, who was chased out of Coconut Grove two years ago because of rising property taxes and insurance costs.
 
“Quite frankly, when this becomes too painful for me, I will just leave,” he added. “Atlanta is looking far more attractive now.”
 
The flat increase of almost 56 percent will also apply to another 149,000 homeowners around the state, outside the tri-county area.
 
It will be even worse for about 8,000 small businesses in coastal areas around the state that buy hurricane coverage from Citizens. Their rates will soar an unthinkable 513 percent to 678 percent. That means the average premium for many of these businesses will be well over $20,000.
 
The outsized rate increases aren’t a done deal – just yet.
 
Next month, Citizens’ board of governors needs to give the go-ahead to file the request with state regulators, who could tweak the filing. But since the increases are required for Citizens to comply with state law, it’s unlikely they would be rejected outright.
 
Citizens actuary John Rollins explained Thursday that the increase is due largely to the high cost of reinsurance – the insurance that helps insurers cover their losses after a disaster. The cost of reinsurance has soared in the past year after eight storms hit the state.
 
Citizens buys reinsurance not in the private market but from the Florida Hurricane Catastrophe Fund, which provides a lower rate. However, the new law requires Citizens to calculate its expenses as if it were buying reinsurance at the going market rate.
 
Some lawmakers are dismayed.
 
“This is a ridiculous section of that bill. It should be fixed in a special session,” said state Sen. Rudy Garcia, the Hialeah Republican who chaired the Senate Banking and Insurance Committee during the past two sessions.
 
Garcia said he was always worried about the impact of this requirement on homeowners.
 
However, prospects seem to be dimming fast that legislators will be back to Tallahassee in either early December or January to tackle the state’s insurance crisis.
 
Leaders in both the state House of Representatives and Senate say a consensus is needed before setting a special session, but the call has to be made by Gov. Jeb Bush. And the provision in the new insurance law wasn’t addressed in the 50 recommendations put out Wednesday by a state task force Bush appointed to devise fixes for insurance woes.
 
“This onerous provision alone should be enough to call lawmakers back to Tallahassee,” said Rep. Dan Gelber, D-Miami Beach.
 
Copyright © 2006 The Miami Herald,Beatrice E. Garcia. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

Dear Governor Bush:

 

Unfortunately, I will not be able to participate in your Property Tax Rally in Tampa today as I will be busy at work.

 

I am writing to you because our Florida dream has become our Florida nightmare. As we approach retirement age, Hillsborough County property taxes are in the process of destroying our lives.

 

During the hurricane seasons of the last two years, Attorney General Charlie Crist took a very strong stance on the prosecution of opportunistic gougers of every ilk. Well, the Hillsborough County Property Assessor's office is effectively gouging property owners and we need yours and his protection from the Property Assessor and the people that run that agency. 

 

We lived in Bradenton in Manatee County for 14 years. When our younger son graduated from high school and went away to college, we made the move to Hillsborough County in order to be closer to our jobs. I had been commuting an hour and a quarter in each direction to North Tampa for 7 years to care for patients at the James A. Haley Veterans Hospital. My wife had been commuting to Ruskin where she has been working at a migrant care clinic for 16 years. We'd had enough of the expense of the commuting and the toll it took on our cars, our pocketbooks and our physical health. 

 

In 2001, we purchased 3.24 acres in Hillsborough County; while the previous owner had paid $14,900.00 for the property, we paid her $35,000.00 for the land. This was all we could afford and, although we thought the property to be overpriced as it was, this was the most we were willing to pay for the property. 

 

Our first taxes were based on an assessment of $34,400.00. In no time at all, the property was re-assessed at $55, 000.00. Then re-assessed again at $144,180.00. With our home  completed, the total assessment is $364,980.00. Last year our tax bill was $2,000.00 – tough for us, but still manageable. Taxes this year? Quadrupled to $8, 000.00!!! This is reprehensible and totally without conscience on the part of the local government.

 

To begin with, just because the Property Assessor thinks a property is worth much doesn't necessarily make it so. There are many, many houses and properties in our area that have languished on the market for more than a year and have still not sold. Who in their right mind will pay me $144, 180.00 for my land? Who will pay for my house what the Property Assessor thinks the house is worth? Who in their right mind would even consider buying my property when the tax bill is $8,000.00 a year. NOBODY!!! 

 

The housing market has declined and the consequence of this is that we are not able to sell our property and find another place to live at a price we can afford. We are stuck here. And if we are not able to meet this $8,000.00 tax burden, I am certain that the Hillsborough County Property Assessor will gleefully swoop down, take our home from us and cast us into the street without a second thought. I never thought that I would have to fear my government; but at this point, my local government terrifies me at the thought of how easily it can ruin my life. 

 

How are we going to manage such a tax burden in our retirement years? How will we survive? At this point, it appears that after working a lifetime, we will never be able to retire and that we will be working until the day we die. It was our dream to live our remaining years in peace and leave our house and property to our children and grandchildren for them to live in – but that dream has now been dashed to pieces.

 

As it is, we are paying a mortgage of $24,000 a year. The additional $8,000.00 a year in taxes is more than we can bear. We are in the process of borrowing the $8, 000.00 to pay our current tax bill. During the coming year, we will have to repay this $8,000.00 and somehow also find a way to raise an additional $8,000.00 for next year's taxes. What are we going to do?

 

Over the next ten years, Hillsborough County will have taken $80,000.00 from us. This is money that we could put toward our mortgage to pay our house off and make our old age less difficult. This is money that could help us in our retirement and the medical demands that are sure to come. Both my wife and I have medical conditions that require numerous medications to keep us going. My wife is at a point where she may not be able to work more than another year due to her medical problems. 

 

Governor Bush, what can you do for us and all the other people who are in our position? Who else in government will help to right this abominable situation? Why can't there be a $2,000.00  or $3,000.00 cap on property taxes, no matter what the county thinks a property is worth? Why can't government live within its means and why must we continue to shoulder the burden of government growth running amuck and government spending that is completely out of control? 

 

Mr. Crist said in his political ads that he understands, that it's our money – but it’s not just our money the county government is taking – they are also taking away our future and destroying our very lives in the process. 

 

Very truly yours, Angel Luis Rivera

This is the response I received.

Thank you for your writing with your concerns regarding property insurance.
The Governor received your letter and has asked that I respond on his
behalf.

Insurance is the number one issue facing our state today.  Two
unprecedented back-to-back hurricane seasons - with eight hurricanes and
four tropical storms - caused $36 billion in insurance claims.  According
to the Florida Hurricane Catastrophe Fund, annual insured losses in years
without a major storm average $2.8 billion.

Predictions of more catastrophic hurricanes making landfall in the U.S.
have triggered significant increases in insurance premiums to cover
potential future losses.  Many insurance companies have dropped policies
and restricted new policies to avoid high risk areas and reduce overall
exposure in Florida.  Homeowners who cannot get private insurance have only
two options, no insurance or insurance from Citizens Property Insurance
Corporation, which has the highest rates in the state.

This is a serious situation.  Higher rates and the inability to get private
insurance have created a significant hardship for many homeowners and small
businesses. Moreover, Florida cannot maintain a robust economy and high
quality of life if our state continues to sustain tens of billions of
dollars in damage every year.

The key to solving the problem is fortifying Florida against the potential
damage of future storms.   Reducing the risk of damage will reduce
estimated cost of future disasters, which should stabilize rising insurance
premiums.

You can take steps today to protect your home and reduce your insurance
premium.  Florida requires insurance companies to give a discount on
insurance premiums - as much as 44% on your wind policy - for certain
improvements that guard against wind damage.  Choosing a higher insurance
deductible, either 2% or 5%, can also reduce your premium.

To help homeowners make these improvements, the state is providing $250
million for the Florida Comprehensive Hurricane Damage Mitigation Program,
a new program to perform free home inspections and provide matching grants
to qualified homeowners who harden their homes against wind damage.
Qualified homeowners that make approved improvements to their primary
residences may be eligible for reimbursement by the state,
dollar-for-dollar up to $5,000.  Qualified low-income homeowners may be
eligible for up to $5,000 in improvements without providing any matching
funding.  The Florida Comprehensive Hurricane Damage Mitigation Program is
managed by the Department of Financial Services.  For information about how
to apply for the grant, please visit www.mysafefloridahome.com.

To provide immediate relief to policyholders, the state provided $715
million to Citizens Property Insurance Corporation to offset the company's
deficit and reduce the surcharge assessed on all policyholders - not just
those with coverage from Citizens.  Without this funding, your insurance
policy would have increased an additional $172.48 for every $1,000 of your
insurance premium.

To increase the availability of private insurance, the state is providing
$250 million for a new Insurance Capital Build-up Incentive Program to
provide matching funds for insurance companies bringing new capital to the
market.  This program will enable private insurance companies to underwrite
more policies.

On August 8, Lt. Governor Toni Jennings held the first meeting of the
Property and Casualty Insurance Reform Committee.  This committee is open
to all ideas to bring down the cost of premiums, increase availability of
affordable insurance and reduce the risk to homeowners and taxpayers.  If
you would like to make a suggestion, please visit
www.myfloridainsurancereform.com.

Thank you again for your letter.  I am committed to finding a solution to
ease the financial burden that you and many other Florida homeowners are
facing with the rising cost and declining availability of insurance.

Sincerely,



L. Wright
Aide to the Governor
Office of Citizen Services

Thank you for your writing with your concerns regarding property insurance.
The Governor received your letter and has asked that I respond on his
behalf.

Insurance is the number one issue facing our state today.  Two
unprecedented back-to-back hurricane seasons - with eight hurricanes and
four tropical storms - caused $36 billion in insurance claims.  According
to the Florida Hurricane Catastrophe Fund, annual insured losses in years
without a major storm average $2.8 billion.

Predictions of more catastrophic hurricanes making landfall in the U.S.
have triggered significant increases in insurance premiums to cover
potential future losses.  Many insurance companies have dropped policies
and restricted new policies to avoid high risk areas and reduce overall
exposure in Florida.  Homeowners who cannot get private insurance have only
two options, no insurance or insurance from Citizens Property Insurance
Corporation, which has the highest rates in the state.

This is a serious situation.  Higher rates and the inability to get private
insurance have created a significant hardship for many homeowners and small
businesses. Moreover, Florida cannot maintain a robust economy and high
quality of life if our state continues to sustain tens of billions of
dollars in damage every year.

The key to solving the problem is fortifying Florida against the potential
damage of future storms.   Reducing the risk of damage will reduce
estimated cost of future disasters, which should stabilize rising insurance
premiums.

You can take steps today to protect your home and reduce your insurance
premium.  Florida requires insurance companies to give a discount on
insurance premiums - as much as 44% on your wind policy - for certain
improvements that guard against wind damage.  Choosing a higher insurance
deductible, either 2% or 5%, can also reduce your premium.

To help homeowners make these improvements, the state is providing $250
million for the Florida Comprehensive Hurricane Damage Mitigation Program,
a new program to perform free home inspections and provide matching grants

residences may be eligible for reimbursement by the state,
dollar-for-dollar up to $5,000.  Qualified low-income homeowners may be
eligible for up to $5,000 in improvements without providing any matching
funding.  The Florida Comprehensive Hurricane Damage Mitigation Program is

To provide immediate relief to policyholders, the state provided $715
million to Citizens Property Insurance Corporation to offset the company's
deficit and reduce the surcharge assessed on all policyholders - not just
those with coverage from Citizens.  Without this funding, your insurance
policy would have increased an additional $172.48 for every $1,000 of your
insurance premium.

To increase the availability of private insurance, the state is providing

provide matching funds for insurance companies bringing new capital to the
market.  This program will enable private insurance companies to underwrite

From:	Julia G. Duke, P.A. <jgdukelawoffice@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Thursday, November 16, 2006 12:37 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Lack of Funding for Indigent Counsel
Attachments:	Conflict%20Counsel%20Funding[1].pdf

Dear Governor Bush:
 
My employer, Julia Duke, is one of thousands of attorneys in the State who provide legal representation for indigent cilents.  For a second time this year, attorneys are being told that their payment for services will be delayed due to lack of funding.  
 
I have attached a copy of the notice sent out by JAC.  It clearly states that JAC does not anticipate funding for some unspecified amount of time.  It further states that they are working with the Legislature, (which, ironically, isn't even there now), and the Office of Policy and Budget.  I have spoken with Ms. Bruley at JAC and have been further advised that additional information has been requested from JAC before the any further action is taken.  It is my understanding that the Legislature does not reconvene until March of next year.
 
This affects not only the attorneys who provide the services.  Their support staff expects to be paid.  And, the real truth is that there will be many who are going to be told that there is simply no money with which to pay them.  These attorneys are providing services that are mandated by the Constitution of this State.  The utter disregard with which they and their office personnel are being treated is absolutely disgusting.  I'll bet my bottom dollar, not one of the individuals involved in deciding when funding will be available is going to be worrying about a pay check and how they are going to survive until someone decides there's a problem.
 
Governor Bush, I am a good citizen, who works hard, pays her bills and takes her responsibilities seriously.  I'm not convinced that you really feel that there is a serious problem here.  Let me assure you ... most of the attorneys who represent indigent clients are NOT attorneys who enjoy the luxury of a well-padded bank account.  Most will not be able to last the rest of the year without borrowing money.  I'm also not convinced as an out-going governor, that you actually care.  I would apologize, but I can't.  That is just an honest feeling.  If my boss is not able to pay me, I will not be able to pay my obligations.  I will face the loss of my home, my good credit standing and everything I've worked for the last 61 years.  I'm screaming ... this is your problem.  And, it is your responsibility to all of us who are affected by this crisis to do something immediately to stop this insanity. Money is given away by the buckets to those who won't get out and do something constructive.  Those of us who work hard and are responsible citizens at least deserve to be paid what we have earned.
 
I would very much appreciate, and, frankly, expect, some sort of response.  I would also deeply appreciate any assistance you are willing to offer to us to help alleviate this very real and serious financial crisis.
 
Margie Atkinson
Legal Assistant
Julia G. Duke, P.A.

‘Everybody’s taxes went up.’ And two letters sent went

dealt wrongly. If I had had the money to hire an
attorney I would have done so but it would cost me
more to have the attorney then to just pay the taxes
and do on.

is not worth that much. At present, according to the

never sell it for that—not with the interior damage
that is still present. Besides, Brand New homes that
are a lot more fancier then mine sell for $139,000
starting and my house is almost 20 years old. 

I have not seen the property tax bill for 2006 yet,

I have a law office to run, must pay my bills associated with the running of my practice and of course, have employees who expect paychecks, as they also have bills to pay. The outstanding billing to the JAC for my fees is based on services already rendered to the State of Florida based on a contract I entered into originally over one year ago and recently renewed in July of 2006.

 

I am required by my oath to the Florida Bar and my contractual obligation with the JAC to continue to provide representation to my existing court appointed clients. I am not allowed to say to the Court that I cannot represent these current clients because I am not getting paid for my services. However, I will not be getting paid for proper and timely bills and services already rendered on behalf of my clients. To say that this situation is outrageous and unfair is an understatement. I will have to try and borrow money from a bank to pay my bills for November, 2006 through March, 2007 unless something is done immediately.

However, I would like to give you the benefit of the doubt and believe that you and those in the Office of Policy and Budget will do whatever is necessary to resolve this untenable financial position that I and all other court appointed attorneys have been placed in. I understand that your responsibility will soon be at an end for a matter such as this. Until that time, clearly, this immediate problem falls squarely upon your shoulders. Dear Governor Bush,

 

I own a home in Pensacola, Fl. I have owned it since 1979. In 1987 I accepted employment outside of Florida, but kept the house as rental property with the hopes of eventually returning to Pensacola. To this date, I have not been able to return. I continue to own and rent the property, however, since I do plan to retire in a few short years to that home. 

 

Over the years, the property taxes have continued to rise. Along with the increase in insurance premiums, it will take an average of 4-5 months of rental income to pay for these items. My only choice is to raise the rent. The problem is that in order to raise it to an acceptable level the list of potential renters is greatly reduced. If I lived in the home, I would qualify for the homestead exemption and receive an amount of tax relief, yet I must charge a renter enough to cover the entire tax liability. In other words, those who choose to rent in Florida must pay a higher property tax than those who purchase homes. 

 

I would suggest that Florida either (1) enact a form of tax relief for owners who rent their property in order to keep rents lower or (2)_ place a cap on the amount taxes can be raised for these individuals. Please note that I am not talking about those who rent property for a living, such as apartment owners or property rental companies, just individual owners who desires to rent their dwelling. Without some type of relief, I will be forced to sell my home in Pensacola, thus leaving one more piece of rental property unavailable for those who need it.

 

Sincerely,

 

Robert Heck

Re: Possible solution to soaring property tax in Florida

 

The property tax initiative Save our Homes enacted more than a decade ago helped ensure lifelong affordable housing for permanent residents of Florida.  At the time, it was reasonable and appeared farsighted.

 

Now it is time to consider an updated amendment to limit the property tax benefit to the first million dollars of value and expand it to cover up to the same value for all residential and business property owners to add equity to the ever changing and thriving economy in Florida.

 

If all properties are assessed at true market value each year and the property tax paid is assessed at a dramatically reduced millage rate for the first million dollars of value all property owners will benefit equally.  This will protect Florida residents and part-time Floridians as well.  It will also protect the small business and commercial property owner from being taxed out of existence.

 

It will require a complete overhaul of the property tax system initially to establish a program like this but all citizens of Florida will benefit long term and ensure future generations can afford to continue living their dream in Florida.  It could also provide more funding than the current system without hurting the growing population of our state.

 

 

Respectfully,

 

Robert A Weisman

I really don't expect for my case to be changed by this message, but I 
wanted the Governor to know that just passing a law doesn't do anything if 
no one is willing to utilize it.  My original message, which is at the 
bottom of this page, was forwarded to the Dept. of Revenue.   According to 
an operator I spoke with, the DOR does not use criminal prosecution to 
enforce child support.  I was told that they will get an order for contempt, 
then if the payor still doesn't pay a warrant could then be issued and the 
payor COULD be put in jail.

But that's rarely what happens.  I have an Order for Contempt against my ex 
husband for non payment of support.  The magistrate in charge of the case 
decided that, in order for my ex husband to avoid jail time, he could purge 
himselft by making the regular child support payment, PLUS repay the past 
due child support at a rate of $75 bi weekly, for a total of $348+/- 
bi-weekly.  My ex husband made 3 weekly payments of about $175+/-, then 
skipped 2 weeks, made 2 more weekly payments of $175+/-, then skipped 
payments for about 6 weeks.  Since my ex-husband was not following the terms 
of the purge, was not communicating with me as to when he would start paying 
again, I filed a Motion for Committment.  My ex husband was sent a letter 
stating that he had to appear in court to present evidence as to why he 
SHOULD NOT  be put in jail.  Right before we were due to appear in court he 
made a large payment of $1,100.  However, even with this payment, he had 
still paid $800+/- less than he should have since the last time we appeared 
in court, which means that he was still behind by about $3,100.  The 
magistrate did not ask my ex husband why he had not paid the child support. 
He did not point out that 90 days prior, my ex husband said that he could 
afford to make the payments and agreed to the terms that the magistrate laid 
out for him.  Instead, the magistrate basically lectured me.  He told me 
that he wasn't a surgeon and he couldn't make my ex husband pay support if 
he didn't want to.  Then he said that he had never seen how taking away 
someone's ability to earn a living was supposed to get child support paid.

I was prepared for that argument, so I suggested that perhaps my ex-husband 
could be jailed over the weekend - that way he could still work 
Monday-Friday, but he would also understand that there were consequences to 
not paying child support on a regular basis.  The magistrate actually 
snickered at this suggestion.   Then he flat out told me that unless I could 
prove that my ex husband had the ability to pay but just hadn't.  It should 
not be up to me to prove this.  My ex-husband has never once asked for a 
reduction in support payments.  Which should tell the magistrate that he 
does have to ability to pay, otherwise, he'd be disputing the amount.  But 
he never has.

From my point of view, the magistrate gave my ex husband a free pass to not 
pay child support.  So I guess I am going to have to spend the next 8 years 
fighting for each and every penny that is due to me for the care of my 
child.  Which the magistrate apparently knows, because he told me that he 
was sure he'd be seeing me back in his courtroom.

So, unless the magistrates and judges to take this problem seriously, no 
matter how many laws are passed, the custodial parents will still be left 
holding the bag when it comes to supporting their children.  I'm lucky that 
I have a decent job and can usually scrape by until my ex husband feels like 
paying.  But not everyone is as lucky as I am.

In a message dated 11/8/2006 1:24:49 PM Eastern Standard Time, Brett.Rayman@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US writes:

November 2, 2006 
Fran Griner
gfgriner@aol.com 
Dear Ms. Griner: 
Thank you for writing to Governor Jeb Bush to express your concerns regarding the Department of Revenue and the handling of child support cases. The Governor appreciates hearing your views and asked that I respond on his behalf.

I contacted the department regarding your allegation that it refused to produce records, pursuant to a public records request, relating to the amount of money spent on individual cases. According to the department, it does not track spending on a case-by-case basis. Unfortunately, the requested information cannot be provided. For your information, the Child Support Enforcement Program operates on an annual budget of $260.9 million. During the state fiscal year 2005-06, the department collected over $1.2 billion in child support and served approximately 993,000 children.

Regarding your concern that the state is involved in family law matters, government involvement in child support gained momentum in the 1980’s with a growing concern over the non-payment of child support. The federal government passed a series of mandates (42 United States Code, section 666(b)) that attempted to address the widespread problem of non-payment of child support. These mandates represented a plan for all of the states to address the issue of ensuring support for all children.

Florida established the Child Support Enforcement Program with the goal of ensuring that every child in Florida is financially supported by both parents. Section 409.2551, Florida Statutes, provides that the public policy of this state is for parents to be responsible for providing the financial resources needed to support their children and relieving, at least in part, the burden presently borne by the general citizenry through public assistance programs. While most parents do support their children voluntarily, some parents must be encouraged to provide that needed support. The enforcement methods you described, such as reporting to credit bureaus and suspension of driver’s licenses, are tools developed by both federal and state governments to address the needs of children for support and encourage parents to provide that support. 

A matter over which you expressed concern was the due process received by a non-custodial parent in child support cases and your concern that the Florida Attorney General’s Office provides legal services for the Department of Revenue. The department does contract with the Office of the Florida Attorney General and some State Attorney’s offices to provide legal services in certain areas; however, these state officials are there to represent the best interest of the child. In child support matters, the best interest of children is to receive support from both parents. There is no state policy which requires a judge or hearing officer to “cooperate” with the department; judges and hearing officers function as neutral parties within the laws of Florida. If you feel that a particular judge or hearing officer is not acting as a neutral party in a case, I encourage you to raise the matter in the particular case or with the Judicial Qualifications Commission.

Again, thank you for taking the time to write to the Governor. Your thoughts are very important to him. The Governor appreciates hearing from citizens, like you, sharing their concerns and ideas about child support laws and procedures. Please be assured that the Governor will continue to support laws in the best interest of children and that make improvements to our child support system.

Sincerely, 
Paul Whitfield, Policy Coordinator
Executive Office of the Governor
Office of Policy and Budget 
JPW/ggb

From:	Lynne/Dennis Birdsall <lrbird@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Thursday, November 9, 2006 10:03 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Property taxes and insurance

  

  Dear Governor Bush;

 

The real estate market in the nation and in this state is at a complete standstill. I believe that the underlying reason for the real estate problems in this state are two fold, one being the high cost of insurance and the other is property taxes.  My first reaction on the high cost of insurance would be to have a federally funded wind storm insurance plan similar to the current federal flood insurance program.  Homeowners in wind storm prone areas would be required to have the federally funded program in the same way that those in flood prone areas are required to have.  The problem with that would be trying to get a new program for a localized problem thru the federal government. 

 

I’m proposing the following:

 

As much as I am against suggesting it, we need to increase the state sales tax by ½ point.  Half of that would go to a windstorm fund to be used to repair wind related damages from hurricanes and tornados.  The processing could be done thru existing insurance companies who would only have to sell insurance for fire, theft, and normal liability, but would handle all damage assessments and the disbursements of funds either from the insurance company or from the state fund.  In quiet hurricane years, the funds could be invested and used for educational needs or to temporally reduce the sales tax rate.

 

The governor elect has pledged to raise the homestead exemption by an additional $25,000. As I see it that would not accomplish a thing, because the local taxing authorities will just raise the tax rates to make up the difference. I’m proposing that the other half of the sales tax increase should be used to create a property tax fund. Each year the sixty seven counties would forward their final annual operating budgets and their assessed property value base to the state. The state takes each counties tax base as percent of the sum of all 67 counties’ tax base and applies that percent to the fund and then sends each county their appropriate share. The counties would then adjust their tax rates down resulting in reduced property taxes for the homeowners. There would have to be a state committee to review the budgets to insure that the counties are fairly representing their needs and not overestimating their requirements.  My concern here is that the individual counties will, with this new influx of state money, propose questionable projects.  Anything above normal inflationary increases should be securitized. 

 

As much as I am against new taxes, the benefits here would be two fold.  Homeowners would see reduced property taxes and insurance costs, and some of the cost of these services would be spread to the seasonal residents and tourists who now use our roads, beaches and other facilities.  

 

Best regards and good luck in the future.

 

Dennis P. Birdsall

1045 SW 25th Ave.

Boynton Beach Florida 33426

561-737-3119-Home

561-797-2227-Cell

From:	Karen Manning <KMANNING@agsc.biz>
Sent:	Tuesday, November 7, 2006 11:00 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Best Business Practices

As you are aware, public-private partnerships (P3s) are quickly becoming the new avenue of choice for meeting the needs of Florida’s citizenry.  The premier example of a successful public-private partnership is, of course, Florida’s Turnpike Enterprise.  Exempted from FDOT policies, procedures, and standards (subject to the discretion of the FDOT Secretary of Transportation), Florida’s Turnpike Enterprise is enabled to develop its own rules and implement best business practices in management, finance, organization, and operations. 

Equally fundamental to our quality of life as our transportation system is an aggressive land preservation program.  Following the tremendous success of Florida’s Turnpike Enterprise, it seems worthwhile to consider replicating this public-private partnership model to accomplish the goals of the Florida Forever program.  Although the creation of a “Florida Forever Enterprise” would provide for a myriad of new land conservation and management tools, it is the potential for use of best business practices in financing and funding, including the use of private equity, which would have the greatest impact of the success of the program.

Creating a new public-private enterprise empowered to utilize the best practices of the private sector while operating in the public interest – and operating as a separate business unit of the Florida Department of Environmental Protection – would have the added benefit of providing some financial relief to struggling real estate and banking industries.  With additional funding this legislative session and the ability to maximize its purchasing power through creative private sector financing tools, a “Florida Forever Enterprise” could be a powerful tool in the ongoing acquisition and management of Florida’s real estate conservation portfolio.

 

 

 

Karen Manning

President & CEO

American Government Services

3812 W. Linebaugh Avenue

Tampa, Florida  33618

(813) 933-3322 ph

(813) 931-3362 fax

www.agsc.biz

*	Property tax formulas 
*	Property assessment processes 
*	Property tax allocation process of dollars for the City of New Smyrna area.

Personal profile, future hopes and concerns:

*	My wife and I are in our early 60’s.  We achieved what we thought is a middle class economic level. 
*	We are former residents of Florida and had plans to return for our retirement years to a condominium apartment we purchased in 1973.  
*	Over the last 33 years we achieved paying off the New Smyrna mortgage for a condo apt...  
*	Our plans were to retire to the condo apt with a reasonable cost owner ship related to property taxes, utilities, etc and shared common property maintenance costs.  We thought property expenses to be financially manageable for our modest future fixed income.  
*	Our condo apartment taxes for 2006 are proposed to be $ 7,821.00.  An increase of 58% from last year.  Less than 5 years ago taxes were $2,394.  
*	When we retire, we are financially planning that we could live for another 20 years.
*	For those future 20 years the majority of our yearly retirement income will come from social security and the rest supplemented by modest monthly diminishing amounts from savings and a small 5 yr monthly pension left over from a “Hostile” take over and liquidation sale of the Singer Company.  
*	Now it appears that taxes will initially be almost half of my gross estimated social security in 2008.

I’m requesting that the present tax assessment methodology be audited and revisited. I’ll also try to be part of the solution since I have expressed my concerns which could be considered negative to the reader. 

 

The following thoughts/steps are for an approach to get our arms around a situation which seems very unbalanced and riddled with inequalities.  

 

1.	For 2007 freeze all property taxation schedules to 2006 levels by virtue of initiating an audit.  
2.	Freeze all new ground breakings/projects requiring Gov’t Financial Support unless other sources of $ can be found (such as selling municipal bonds to the public etc.)
3.	For 2007, continue with the enhancement of “only” critical activities that can be supported with-in the 2006 funding levels with out creating deficits.  Focus on Police, Fire/Rescue, Education, Community Medical and Maintenance of existing public properties.  
4.	Initiate an audit of property assessments procedures, processes, revenue allocation structure touch points, and the beneficial use New Smyrna receives from Property tax revenues collected.
5.	Initiate a concurrent study conducted by disinterested 3rd party chartered to generate a Feasibility Study Report that explains the “AS IS” conditions and recommends a “TO BE” new tax lowering assessment methodology.

 

Thank you for your time.  I hope you will take my communiqué seriously. From:	dparker2018@tampabay.rr.com
Sent:	Friday, November 3, 2006 9:53 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	lee.tom.web@flsenate.gov; dockery.paula.web@flsenate.gov
Subject:	Re: RE: Property Ins Reform Committee

Dear Governor Bush,

   Thank you for your reply to my letter.  Unfortunately I believe we 
see things very differently.  While you are trying to keep all sides 
happy and maintain what I feel is the status quo, my fellow Floridians 
and I on the other hand want results.

    A first starting point that our government can do and has direct 
control over is the accounting practices for re-insurance by 
subsidiaries thru their parent companies and using the costs as 
expenses.  Stop this practice by not allowing these major insurers to 
form spin off companies for just the state of Florida.  This practice 
allows nationwide insurers (who are making record profits) to show on 
paper a loss.  Force these companies to account for re-insurance costs 
using GAAP.  If a cost is paid from one entity of a corporation to 
another in equal amounts, it is NOT to be treated as an expense by the 
corporation.  This alone would make it much more difficult for these 
companies to justify rate increases which are just hidden massive 
profits by the parent company.

    The next item that YOU and the legislature must address 
immediately is the use by nationwide corporations of the ability to 
form subsidiaries that only operate in small geographic areas and use 
that ability to confine loss mitigation and claims within those 
areas.  State Farm and Allstate are prime examples, but just about all 
the companies do it.  They form State Farm Floridian for the state of 
Florida then claim after a storm they need to raise rates, restrict 
new policies, and “cherry pick” new areas to serve.  All the while 
they pay millions in re-insurance to State Farm Corporate, claim an 
expense, and corporate shows record profits.  They should be required 
to issue policy, balance risk, and account for funds on a nationwide 
basis, not just Florida.  Why is that the only states that have these 
subsidiaries are the high risk states?  I’ll gladly tell you, their 
actuaries show them it is the best way to maximize profits and 
minimize risk to shareholders and executive
 salaries and perks.  As Governor and Legislators YOU have the power 
to stop this practice.  Stop being swayed by campaign contributions 
and lobbyist influence and do what is right for our state.

   You mention the Hurricane Mitigation Program.  Good idea, but under 
funded to do what it was intended to do.  In addition you and the 
government have seen fit to earmark ALL of the funds to coastal 
areas.  This keeps my neighbors and I out of the program, even after I 
submitted all necessary paperwork.  A nice government perk for coastal 
property owners, you subsidize them upgrading their mansions at 
taxpayers cost.  Good idea Mr. Governor!  This in my opinion just 
exasperates the whole problem of reducing the insurance load.  One of 
the main reasons we are having an insurance "crisis" is that coastal 
development is inherently much more risky than inshore development, 
and couple that with the fact that most if not all of the homes in 
those areas are of much higher value than the median Florida home 
price.  The bottom line for me and many of my neighbors is STOP 
government subsidy of coastal development and high priced homes.  If 
people insist on moving and building there,
 let THEM assume the risk of doing it, not the rest of us. Place a cap 
on coastal homeowners insurance at $500,000 for property and let the 
individual owners assume the additional risk.  If one can afford to 
live there, one should be responsible for paying the cost, not the 
rest of Florida.  Another GOOD option is after a storm destroys a 
property have the state buy out the owner and take the land and make 
it un-developable.

   As for insurance discounts for windstorm mitigation, as someone on 
a fixed income, with children and limited in regards to money 
available to improve a home we thought was strong, having to come up 
with a lot of cash or go into debt to secure a modest insurance 
discount is just not possible.  Instead of matching grants for people 
living in coastal areas in homes valued at $1 million plus, the money 
should be earmarked for fixed or low income homeowners who truly need 
the help whatever area they live in.   The whole state of Florida is a 
high risk area, but the coastal areas are off the risk charts. It must 
be nice for someone living in a $1,000,000 home to get a $5000 
matching grant from Florida to reduce his already subsidized Citizens 
insurance premium while the majority of us who cannot afford to 
mitigate see nothing but increases in our insurance premiums.  You 
MUST start limiting the giveaways.  Stop the grants to people with 
income over $60,000 a year or homes value
d more than the mean (maybe $500,000 replacement value).

    As for the Citizens bailout, again if you as Governor didn't allow 
Citizens to become overloaded with expensive coastal properties that 
no one else will touch Citizens would not be in its current 
situation.  Watching some of the OIR hearings and testimony by 
Citizens executives and actuaries, it is plainly clear that unless the 
government, meaning YOU changes Citizens economic model things will 
NOT get better.  There is just TOO much high priced coastal exposure 
within Citizens overall risk for it to ever not need large government 
grants.  Again, the solution for this problem also is to restrict 
government subsidies for wealthy coastal property owners and 
developers but limiting Citizens to a maximum policy limit for ALL 
homes.  It seems to a lot of us that normal Floridians are suffering 
because local and state politicians want to allow developers and 
builders (who are large campaign contributors) to develop risky areas 
so as to gain tax revenue and campaign contributio
ns.  This has to stop for Florida to ever have a chance to continue 
growing.  The constant pressure on inland homeowners to subsidize 
coastal property owners will eventually force most middle income 
people out of their homes.  And without the middle income people 
Florida will lose industry, business, and the driving economic force 
behind the economy.

    As for your "Reform Committee" it is frankly a joke!  You have 
seen fit to staff the committee with politicians, insurance agent 
politicians, and political insiders who all have their own agenda, 
which is NOT reform to help homeowners and small business owners.  
Maybe if you politicians listened to average people you would take 
heed of the real answers, peoples need, and be strong enough to do the 
right thing and stop helping the wealthy, influential, and connected 
individuals that have contributed to this entire mess.

     Why can't you, as our Governor use our Congressional delegation 
and your personal access to the President to get the federal 
government to institute a national hurricane disaster insurance 
program that would spread the risk out over the entire country.  They 
do it with the national flood insurance program, put some pressure on 
them to do the same for hurricanes!  When my grandparents could pay 
$655 a year on $500,000 of replacement value on a beachfront home in 
NJ, we here in Florida should be able to pay no more than $1000 a year 
for the same coverage here.  Even if it is capped at $275,000 
replacement value it would be a BIG break for homeowners here to only 
have to cover the excess value through primary carriers.  And it would 
give the primary carriers a break in the event of a major hit from a 
Cat 4 or 5 storm.

   As an independent voter I personally am fed up with the Republican 
Party and its leading politicians.  I am a great proponent of small 
non-invasive government and have supported the Republican agenda for 
years, but this mess leads me to wonder.  The party that used to be 
small government, low taxes, and open markets has become the party 
that caters to the wealthy and influential.  If you hope to save your 
legacy and our great state YOU need to take action NOW, before your 
term is up.  While you have no beholding to anyone to be re-elected 
you need to do the right thing and fix this mess.  Please Mr. Bush, 
stop the tax and insurance problem NOW, before it causes this great 
state to become an  uninhabitable quagmire and causes election 
upheaval.  I know I am but one voter, but I have spoken with numerous 
others in my community and we all feel the same.....stop this mess 
now!!!  Do something right now!!

   Sincerely,

      David Parker
  Spring Hill Fl 34609
     352-279-7100

From:	Katrina Herrero <katrinaherrero@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Thursday, November 2, 2006 8:07 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	MDCPS - PLEASE help!

Dear Governor Bush:

 

I implore you to get involved in the Miami-Dade County Public School teachers’ contract renegotiations.  The salary proposals being considered (union and county) are both woefully inferior.  The skyrocketing cost of living in Miami is not even being considered by either side, and teachers in nearby counties with lower costs of living are earning much more now and will continue to do so if either of these proposals is accepted.

 

At one point, I was a 7th-grade language arts teacher in the district, but I realized that the tremendous effort required was not worth the meager salary, especially since I was so poorly paid that those long sought-after summers off were impossible, since I used to make half my annual teachers salary consulting as a tech writer and technical trainer during the summers.  When I quit teaching, I was making low-30s because I’d only joined the system two years earlier after having spent several years in the business world.  Do you know how many teachers asked me, “But how many years do you have in the system???” when they found out that I was considering leaving?  I was amazed that, for these poor folks, teaching is no longer a career that they derive pleasure from.  It’s more like a means to an end, just time served till retirement, and the fact that they don’t make enough to even survive here anymore adds insult to injury.  Most teachers have to work two and three jobs just to make ends meet, and that sad fact has resulted in a decline in the quality of education in MDCPS because no one working that many hours can put in the time and effort required to be a good teacher.  The worst of it all, if I may be so bold as to say so, is the fact that the district superintendent, Rudy Crew, is showered with bonuses and raises and accolades for the improvements in the county while the teachers haven’t had a new contract ratified for the last three years.  He isn’t worried about paying his rent or getting his old clunker fixed or having his water turned off.  He lives in luxury, yet the majority of his employees – not just teachers, but office personnel, paraprofessionals, security monitors, and cafeteria workers – live in the poorest neighborhoods, many without the most basic dependent health coverage because the county only provides free insurance to its employees.

 

To be blunt, there seems to be a fundamental flaw in the way education is organized in the state of Florida.  Having grown up in Massachusetts, I can say that I have always wondered why each union (in this case UTD) meshes so perfectly with its district (in this case MDCPS).  Why are UTD and the MDCPS so close?  Who is on whose side anyway?  In MA, there is a STATE-WIDE teachers union, and the districts are by TOWN, not by county.  That is the definition of collective bargaining, isn’t it?  There are so many problems with the district because of its sheer size and incredible growth year after year.  If the district were broken up into smaller units, there would be great improvement.  For example, as things currently stand, administrators are always looking for the next school to open in order to take their next career leap.  If an AP knows that several new schools will open in the district in the next year, how much incentive does he really have to stay where he is and dedicate his life to improving his school?  All he wants is to climb until he gets to the top.  In MA, assistant principals remain contentedly in their positions for years and years because there is nowhere else to go, unless they want to move on to a new district.  In fact, there are principals who have spent their entire lives at the same school, and in general MA schools obtain excellent test scores and do not have unhappy, underpaid teachers, as we do in MDCPS.

 

I know that I have thrown a lot of information at you, but there are better ways of doing things.  Sometimes, people just keep doing things the same way simply because that is the way they have always been done.  However, I’ve heard that the definition of insanity is “doing the same thing over and over again expecting different results.”  I just hope you can help stop the insanity.

 

Very warm regards,

Katrina Herrero

Miami Lakes, FL  33016

From:	Stan Tangalakis <STangalakis@mercurymed.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, October 31, 2006 12:05 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	al@midmed.com; rdrucker@rxusa.com; mh@lakeeriemed.com; IMDA@IMDA.org; bmclaughlin@imcoinc.com; rowan@hida.org; Executive Team


Dear Honorable Governor Bush, 

I am a graduate pharmacist (non-practicing), in healthcare for over fifty (50) years, as an executive with a major pharmaceutical company for twenty-three (23) years, two (2) years running a small pharmaceutical company, a business owner for twenty-six (26) years, and life long Republican. 

As a healthcare professional I understand the need for control over the manufacture, distribution and marketing of pharmaceuticals.  However, when you signed into law, Florida Statute 499, PDMA Prescription Drug Marketing Act, you positioned the secondary distributor of pharmaceuticals in a noncompetitive, compromised market position.   

You and your staff understand the requirements under which a licensed, small business drug distributor must now operate under this law.  This same law unfairly precludes the larger, direct buy distributor, from the costly administrative and operational impact of pedigree tracking , which has been placed on the smaller, secondary pharmaceutical distributor.   

The rippling effect of this law has now created a monopolistic situation for these same larger, direct from the manufacturer purchasing distributors.  McKesson, has stopped shipping to secondary distributors in the State of Florida, while General Medical, a subsidiary of McKesson, has sales people calling on the same accounts as our sales people.  With pricing and operational advantages, how are we to compete????  The attendant fallout from this legislation will be the reduction in the number of smaller, local, privately held, licensed, creditable pharmaceutical distributors, who can't afford the additional operational costs and competing in a monopolistic environment with the larger, primary pharmaceutical distributor companies. 

As an example of this monopolistic positioning, under the guise of covering the additional (?) administrative and software costs,  Amerisource/Bergen Brunswick, as of December 1, 2006, will implement a charge of $5,000 per month per distributor, $60,000 per year, if we're to continue to purchase drugs from them.  With McKesson, withdrawing from shipping into Florida, Bergen is our sole source.  Estimating at least 20 small distributors in the State of Florida, represents $1.2M IN JUST ONE STATE!  (This is extortion made legal under the guise of covering the additional costs to administer the requirements brought about through the passage of Statute 499.) 

I endeavored, before this legislation was signed, to present a logical and rational perspective in my letter to you, as well as legislators at both the State and Federal level.  I have also communicated and encouraged our national healthcare associations to do the same, which they did.  Unfortunately, the lobbying of the  Healthcare Medical Distributors Association (HMDA), which is comprised of the "Big Three" primary drug wholesalers, with their war chest,, prevailed.  Now we're experiencing the fallout effect, which has already started. 

The sincere intent of this message is to present additional perspective as to the ramifications of what has and is taking place at the national level, as a fallout from this type legislation.  Therein, I would hope that the staff member who reviews this message allows it to come through to you directly. 

Respectfully and sincerely yours,

Stanley G. Tangalakis

DRUG WHOLESALERS SEEKING INJUNCTION TO STOP DRUG TRACKING PROGRAM
A coalition of drug wholesalers will soon seek an injunction in federal court to delay the implementation of the FDA's long-awaited drug tracking program, contending the new requirement will devastate their businesses. 

The National Coalition of Pharmaceutical Distributors and companies like RxUSA Wholesale are challenging the FDA's plan to require certain manufacturers to have pedigrees for their products beginning Dec. 1. A pedigree is a record of all transactions a drug goes through, from the manufacturing plant to the dispensing pharmacy. 

Smaller wholesalers say the program will ruin their businesses by establishing a requirement they are unable to meet. The problem is that these wholesalers purchase their products from larger authorized distributors that are not required to keep these records or provide them to the unauthorized companies. 

The agency based its rule on the Prescription Drug Marketing Act (PDMA). The act, which amended the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act, exempts a drug's manufacturer and the "authorized distributor of record" from the pedigree requirement. 

The PDMA states that an authorized distributor of record is a wholesaler with an "ongoing relationship" with a manufacturer to distribute that manufacturer's drug. To become an authorized distributor, a company merely needs to receive written permission from the manufacturer. 

The net effect of the rule is that "the entire secondary wholesale industry will be completely and immediately destroyed," the groups argued in their Sept. 20 complaint before the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York. The parties allege that the rule is unconstitutional, denying them equal protection under the law. 

Other observers have pointed out flaws in the federal statute that will undermine the rule. The agency is hamstrung by limitations in the PDMA, including the broad exemption from pedigree requirements and the lack of a federal preemption clause, Eric Greenberg, an attorney who specializes in regulatory and labeling requirements, said during a Sept. 7 audio conference sponsored by FDAnews. 

The FDA is still reviewing public comments on the rule and will soon respond to them and publish guidance to address questions about the rule, an agency spokeswoman said.

> among Florida's humane societies to strengthen their independent 
> organizations through the sharing of best practices and the creation of a 
> consolidated animal ed ucation outreach. The event, which preceded an 
> educational symposium for directors, was attended by 50 humane societies 
> from across the state. County music legend and animal protection advocate 
> Mel Tillis served as a special guest. Greater collaboration will strengthen 
> services to help ensure animals throughout the state are treated with the 
> love and respect they deserve. There are currently 50 Humane Societies 
> operating in 50 counties throughout Florida. For more information, please 
> visit www.myflorida.com. 
>

> GOLD SEAL NURSING HOME AWARD WINNERS ANNOUNCED 
> 
> Also on Thursday, I announced the winners of the Gold Seal Nursing Home 
> Award. These awards were given to eleven of the state's top long-term care 
> facilities. The Gold Seal Award was implemented in 2002 as a way to 
> recognize Florida nursing homes that exhibit excellence in care management 
> a nd quality of life for their residents. While the vast majority of nursing 
> homes in the state adhere to laws requiring high quality of care, the Gold 
> Seal program was designed to reward those facilities with exceptionally high 
> standards and quality of care. I commend this year's outstanding Gold Seal 
> Award recipients for serving as models for their peers across the state, 
> while creating a habit of excellence by making quality of care for their 
> residents a top priority. Gold Seal award recipients include Bay Village of 
> Sarasota, Sarasota; Baldomero Lopez State Veterans' Nursing Home, Land 
> O'Lakes; John Knox Village Med Center, Tampa; John Knox Village Medical 
> Center, Orange City; Mayflower Healthcare Center, Winter Park; The Pavilion

> awards please visit, www.myflorida.com. 
>

> $100 MILLION TO FORTIFY FLORIDA ANNOUNCED 
> 
> This week I announced that Florida will receive more than $100 million from 
> the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development to harden homes in the 
> state to protect against future disasters. The Community Development Block 
> Grant disaster relief funds are a portion of the additional $5.2 billion 
> allocated nationwide by the federal government following the destructive 
> Hurricanes of Dennis, Katrina, Rita and Wilma. I thank President Bush and 
> the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development for this significant 
> investment in hurricane recovery and mitigation in Florida. Fortifying 
> Florida is essential for instilling a 'culture of p r epa redness.' Hardening 
> homes is an investment that can save Floridians money on their annual 
> insurance premium and spare them the anguish of losing their home during a 
> natural disaster. Florida is currently finalizing a plan to use these funds 
> to complement the "My Safe Florida Home" program. Through the program, 
> homeowners can apply for a free inspection and a grant up to $5,000 from the 
> Florida Department of Financial Services to help protect their homes. The 
> final plan must be approved by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban 
> Development. For information on creating a Family Disaster Preparedness 
> Plan, please visit www.floridadisaster.org.

NO. 8

CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT

ARTICLE X, SECTION 6

(Legislative)

Ballot Title:

EMINENT DOMAIN

Ballot Summary:

Proposing an amendment to the State Constitution to prohibit the transfer of private property

taken by eminent domain to a natural person or private entity; providing that the Legislature may

by general law passed by a three-fifths vote of the membership of each house of the Legislature

permit exceptions allowing the transfer of such private property; and providing that this

prohibition on the transfer of private property taken by eminent domain is applicable if the petition

of taking that initiated the condemnation proceeding was filed on or after January 2, 2007.

Full Text:

ARTICLE X

MISCELLANEOUS

SECTION 6. Eminent domain.—

(a) No private property shall be taken except for a public purpose and with full compensation

therefor paid to each owner or secured by deposit in the registry of the court and available to the

owner.

(b) Provision may be made by law for the taking of easements, by like proceedings, for the

drainage of the land of one person over or through the land of another.

(c) Private property taken by eminent domain pursuant to a petition to initiate condemnation

proceedings filed on or after January 2, 2007, may not be conveyed to a natural person or

private entity except as provided by general law passed by a three-fifths vote of the membership

of each house of the Legislature.
