I have another issue that I believe is as important to the future of
our nation as maintaining the right to display the American Flag has
been. It is the right to pursue alternate energy sources as property
owners. Finding ways to reduce America's dependency on foreign oil and
other non-renewable energy sources should start at home.

Florida is the Sunshine State, but homeowners associations won't let
us harvest the sun's energy via solar panels on our roofs. Likely out
of antiquated notions of what 'look's good' in a neighborhood. What
looks good to me are whole neighborhoods doing their part to reducing
energy costs by participating in Solar Energy projects. With solar
panel efficiency improving and prices reducing, it's become time for
patriotic Americans to take advantage of this technology.

I am requesting that your office research and introduce a bill that
would forbid homeowners associations from preventing home owners and
business owners in their developments from installing solar panels on
roofs and other backyard structures. Reasonable limits would be
allowed (nothing extending off the roof structure more than 10 inches,
etc), but an outright prohibition would be illegal.

I am sure the Florida Solar Energy Center ( http://www.fsec.ucf.edu/ )
would be happy to provide you with whatever statistics and research
you need to back up your bill.

Thank you for your time and support of this important matter.

Regards

John Frost

Sent:	Wednesday, October 18, 2006 10:35 AM
To:	Windham, Carol; Governor Jeb Bush

Subject:	HOA vs CONDO Law-Enough Study-Let's do Topic#3

Thank you Ms. Windham!  Your note was just what I needed to catch up.
 
Dear Governor Jeb Bush:
I appreciate the need to study issues before acting, but this one is beyond critical.  Catastrophic losses are still accumulating thanks to the utterly inadequate legal/regulatory structure of FL State Statute 720.00 HOAs & 718.00 Condos.  You just can't see them because there is no way for them to surface in a systematic recognizable fashion.
 
Currently, my Additional Living Expense outlay since Hurricane Charley is approximately $35,000 in lost income.  My HOA has failed to resolve rebuild issues in a timely fashion, the work they have done is inadequate (because the codes are inadequate), and my roof is still leaking.  I retained an attorney in 01/06, and while it calmed me down and may have provided indirect leverage, it did not affect their decisionmaking at all.  I have endured absent communication from the CAM, the CAM failing to follow instructions, repeated trespass on my property, vandalism, theft, and construction damage from unmonitored work... and I am not home yet.
 
I helped another H-C survivor who's Condo took the insurance money and refurbished the Condo Board's buildings while failing to restore his... He and 3 other unit owners are still out of their homes and the Condo board wants to roll the remaining insurance money into the reserves.  How can this be??

From a former Board Treasurer perspective, I support devoting taxpayer resources to Topic 3. Fooling around with the other two is a waste of time because:

    a) HOA Volunteer Board Mgmt - The demographics no longer exist to support fully functioning volunteer HOA boards.  Working people (or w/families) have no time.  The older generation of retired motivated former execs/mgrs from the 1950's - 60's are dead or dying now.
 
    b) HOA Education - Even if you CAN find people to serve on the volunteer HOA Boards, they have to learn the HOA statutes and then constantly clarify for owners who have been in condos, how their old condo rules no longer apply.
 
    c) HOA Education - HOA Boards have attorneys and a set of docs.  They have a few old time members with an oral history of varying reliability and a vast majority who really could care less.  So how would improved educational options apply?  We don't have any to begin with.
 
    d) HOA Dispute Resolution - Even if an owner can find an attorney (very difficult), the attorney just waits the situation out and collects fees.   This has been my personal experience as an owner and I have observed my HOA endure the exact same treatment in going after owners legally.
 
    e) FL Construction Law - Does not support the individual or common interest entity.  Another legal sink hole for attorney's line their pockets.
 
I realize that the public comment time for HB.391 is over, but I do want you to know that your recommendation to re-study the issues further, w/o pursuing Topic 3 directly at this time, makes me very frustrated.  Please focus on Topic 3 exclusively and let's get a move on.
 
Joe Adams of Becker & Poliakoff did a wonderful article series in The Snooze Press that details the subtle and not-so-subtle regulatory differences between the statutes.  So the regulatory comparison work is finished for the most part.   
 
Please note:  The ONLY educational opportunity I could find after H-Charley was B&P's seminar at Seven Lakes.  In spite of 12 pages of notes, I did not succeed in managing the Genl Contractor who failed to perform and abandoned.  The reason was that I failed to manage the HOA Board and CAM manager who did NOT take the time to attend the seminar with me and who refused to learn the process and follow it.
 
The cynic in me bets that the developers will drive the reg-neg bus and the end product will screw the people once again.  Please make me wrong.
 
Sincerely,
 
Grayson Porter
Owner & H-Charley Survivor

 -----Original Message-----
From: Windham, Carol [mailto:Carol.Windham@dbpr.state.fl.us]
Sent: Tuesday, October 17, 2006 3:22 PM
To: ptp999@earthlink.net
Subject: RE: Quick Question: Need Name of Committee Studying HOA vs CONDO Law Reg Recon



Dear Mr. Porter:

 

Thank you for your recent email to Governor Jeb Bush regarding condominium laws in Florida.  Secretary Simone Marstiller has asked that our division respond directly to you on her behalf.  We appreciate this opportunity to assist you. 

 

In his veto letter of HB391, the Governor directed the Department of Business and Professional Regulation (DBPR) to conduct a study and make recommendations regarding the following issues: 

 

1. Ways to improve and/or expand existing alternative dispute resolution and education programs to accommodate stricter association requirements such as those set forth in House Bill 391.

 

2. The extent to which protections afforded members of mandatory homeowner associations can approach parity with those afforded condominium owners while still upholding the legislative intent that homeowners’ associations not be regulated.

 

3. Whether, using the Uniform Common Interest Ownership Act (UCOIA) as a starting point and analyzing the laws of other states, the State of Florida should move toward establishing a comprehensive common interest realty law.

 

The department solicited comments from the public, and met with stakeholders representing community associations, unit owners, developers, and management companies on September 6, 2006, to discuss these issues.  This information was analyzed and compiled into a report, which was submitted to Governor Bush on October 1, 2006.  I have attached a copy of this report for your review; you may also access the full report (including attachments) and the veto letter on our website at http://www.myflorida.com/dbpr/lsc/condominiums/index.shtml.

 

I hope this information proves to be helpful.  If you have any questions, please let me know. 

 

Sincerely, 

 

Carol Windham, Government Analyst I

Division of Florida Land Sales, Condominiums and Mobile Homes

Department of Business and Professional Regulation

WTVJ-TV 
11:36 p.m. EDT October 11, 2006 
MIAMI - Thousands of Miami-Dade County teachers ditched school Wednesday to make a pitch for higher pay, and several teachers aired their opinions at a school board meeting. The United Teachers of Dade called on teachers to rally in support of higher salaries as the school board prepared to hold a regularly scheduled meeting Wednesday afternoon. 

Related Content: Images <http://www.nbc6.net/slideshow/news/10050730/detail.html?qs=1;s=1;dm=ss;p=news;w=400> | Survey <http://www.nbc6.net/surveypopup/10051951/detail.html?path=/news/>      
       
       
More than 8,000 protesters gathered on streets throughout the county as well as at the Miami-Dade Public Schools headquarters. Some of the protesters chanted "We need a raise." 

Teachers argue that their salaries are not high enough, saying teachers in Miami-Dade are some of the lowest paid in South Florida. 

"We work hard and we want our money," one teacher said. 
"This is an absolute disgrace that we as teachers and professionals, educators, have to be out on the street to get a small raise," said teacher Suzan Godoy. 

The starting salary for a teacher in Miami-Dade County is $34,000. In Monroe County, the starting salary is $40,000 and it's $37,000 in Broward County. 

Teachers compiled a list of school administrators throughout the county with six-figure salaries, while teachers in the classroom, they said, cannot afford to pay their bills. 

Godoy, who is a single mother, said she just doesn't make enough. 
"My electric bill has gone up. My food bill has doubled. I am having a tough time making ends meet as a single mom," Godoy said. 

"We're very upset because the cost of living has been so high and our salaries haven't been raised, so we're basically living on poverty level," said teacher Anthony Kontos. 

"We believe there is an adequate amount of dollars here to be able to settle this and to be able to craft a deal that ultimately gets a good settlement in November," Superintendent Rudy Crew said. "We thought that $40,000 in a place as expensive as Miami really is more respectful of the work." 

There was no discussion on the agenda of the School Board of Miami-Dade County's meeting Wednesday about contract negotiations. 

"I believe very strongly that we'll be able to come together in the next month or so and bring before the board and, frankly, our community a settlement package that reflects what we all really want for teachers and what is a fair and equitable package," Crew said earlier in the day. 

Teachers spoke out during a public hearing portion of the school board meeting. 
"The number of teachers who are finding themselves in serious financial difficulty and even filing for bankruptcy is outrageous. It is also a disgrace," teacher David Kirsner said. "This crisis has been manufactured by this school board through bad planning, misplaced priorities and poor fiscal management." 

Contract talks between the district and the union have been going on for weeks. School board member Marta Perez said she is confident a compromise will be reached. 

"There has to be more thrift in the budget and live within our means so that we can provide for our teachers," Perez said. 

"We do understand economics. We teach it, and our salaries are no longer competitive," said Karen Aronowitz, president of the United Teachers of Dade. 

The next bargaining session is planned for Oct. 19.

From:	timothy & bev wilson <timbevwen@msn.com>
Sent:	Monday, October 16, 2006 9:44 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	have you heard?

Have you heard the breaking news- the insurance industry is preparing to announce record profits later this week? Wow! What a stunner!
 
Well, not really. That's pretty much what any sane person would expect to happen when you have a state (Florida) allowing insurance companies to rate premium on a series of unprecedented events (8 storms in 2 years). This will happen every year that the unprecedented events do not occur. Unprecedented means those events do not occur very often, as in never before.
 
Enough with the band-aids. Enough with the task forces. Enough with public meetings. CALL A SPECIAL SESSION AND FIX THIS.
 
The problem is obvious and the answer is equally obvious. The state is already in the 'insurance business' up to their eyeballs. The only problem is the state only participates in losses and not profits. This is absurd and needs to stop immediately. Record profits for the insurance industry while the state will be bailing out Poe for years. What is wrong with this picture? 
 
Had the state acted with the sense of urgency it should have and taken over all wind risk by this past June 1, there would already be a massive war chest for next year instead of huge insurance industry bonuses and shareholder profits.
 
As a free market / the smaller the government the better proponent, the very concept of state run anything troubles me. However, the market has become completely dysfunctional and the state is the only entity positioned to restore it quickly. Free market forces might eventually fix things but the operative word here is 'eventually'. People are losing homes now. We do not have 3 or 5 or 10 years to get this fixed.
 
THE STATE AND ONLY THE STATE CAN RETAIN SURPLUS PREMIUM FOR SUBSEQUENT YEARS OR SURCHARGE TO MAKE UP DEFICITS. THIS ELIMINATES THE RATINGS GUESSING GAME. IT IS WHAT IT IS. EVEN ALLOWING FOR BUREAUCRATIC INEFFICIENCIES AND CORRUPTION, COMPLETE STATE RUN WIND INSURANCE WOULD BE FAR CLOSE TO RATING ACTUAL RISK THAN WHERE WE ARE NOW AT.
 
There is no reason solution can not be achieved by January when you leave. While Citizens does have a poor name, it already exists, it writes new policies every day, and state insurance is state insurance regardless of the name.  They could start writing one new policy statewide (there is no meaningful differential as to wind risk anywhere in this state) with rates in the middle of 2003 rates and current rates immediately. If this leaves surplus premium (as it would have this year) it is put in the bank for next year. If losses actually did exceed premium collected, then a modest rate increase next year plus surcharges to make up the deficit. 
 
Our crisis would effectively be over had this been implemented for 2006.
 
As it now stands, with the insurance industry's risk exposure vs. their premium intake, they operate with no risk and a 'state guaranteed' long term profit.
 
Respectfully from a two-time supporter,
 
 
Timothy B.Wilson

From:	SKRHOME@aol.com
Sent:	Thursday, October 12, 2006 2:08 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	SEADVL@aol.com
Subject:	Property Taxes

I am sure, I am not the only one complaining about property taxes. But since we have moved to Florida, the unfairness of the taxes is more than apparent.
 
We live on a street that has access to water. The homes about the same size being built back in the 60's/70's. However, the taxes are far from being in a similar range.
 
I have thought about how to make the taxes more equitable and here are my thoughts.
 
Major Problem: Accessed value of a property should not be used as the tax basis.
                        This is very inequitable and too volatile.
 
My Plan: Assign each property - PROPERTY  TAX  UNITS
 
Residential:
1. Units based on the square foot of the enclosed house/shed/garage
2. Units based on the square foot of the land
3. Additional units for: swimming pools (they use valuable water)
4. There can be a homestead rebate
 
Businesses:
1. Units based on the square foot of the Business floor
2. Units based on the square foot of the land
 
Farms:
1. Units based on the square foot of the enclosed house/barn/shed/gargage/other
2. Units based on the square foot of the land
3. Additional units for: use of water
 
Property taxes should be levied on the number of units a house has, once calculated and assigned, no adjustment need to be made unless additions are made to the structures.
 
Each municipality should then develop it's budget, and the taxes be allocated based on the number of units of each type of taxable property. Total budget divided by total units will give the cost per unit, which is the same for everyone. Times that by the # of Property Tax Units will tell each household what they owe.
 
Everyone would then be paying taxes on an even plain, not what we have today. Everyone receive basically the same benefits from the city/state despite what they "live-in" so make the system more fair.
 
My ideas.
 
Respectfully,
 
Suzanna K Reiff
6394 Scorpio Ave
North Port, Florida 34287
(941) 429-1020

From:	FDolan4333@aol.com
Sent:	Wednesday, October 11, 2006 10:14 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Property tax changes

Mr. Bush,
 
Please consider the following. What a way to end your tenure as Florida's governor than to take action on Florida's property tax problem.
 
Maybe an end to the madness that is the Florida property tax system would be to adopt something similar to what California has enacted.
 
Under California Proposition 13, the real estate tax on a parcel of residential property is limited to 1% of its assessed value, until the property is resold. This "assessed value", however, may only be increased by a maximum of 2% per year. This applies to all real estate, and not just homesteaded properties.
 
Proposition 13 passed with 65% of those who voted in favor and with the participation of 70% of registered voters. After passage, it became article 13A of the California state constitution. Its passage resulted in a cap on property tax rates in the state, reducing them by an average of 57%. In addition to lowering property taxes, the initiative also contained language requiring a two-thirds majority in both legislative houses for future increases in all state tax rates or amounts of revenue collected, including income tax rates.
 
Frank Dolan
 
Sarasota

1. As far as insurance goes, I don’t have access to all the facts and figures, but I think that raising the hurricane deductible from 2% to 4% and making the same deductible for sinkhole claims along with capping insurance company liability at $1,000,000.00  should result in an approximately 20-25% reduction in insurance premiums. This should reduce most of the nuisance type claims for cosmetic damage as opposed to structural damage.

Home owners with houses valued at over $1,000,000.00 should be able to buy additional coverage at their expense or from a special pool for this amount of coverage. This I believe is similar in effect and concept to a luxury tax

2. Doubling the homestead exemption is a step in the right direction, but I think people need to be reminded that there is no state income tax here, so property taxes will be higher. Try living in Ohio where you have state income tax, city income tax and school district income tax.

3. Political responsibility. Pass a state law that would make politicians convicted of a crime not only criminally responsible, but also financially responsible for their crimes. There is no reason that taxpayers should have to foot the bill for investigating and prosecuting a politician that violated the public trust. If they were morally deficient enough to violate that trust, then they should have to bear the full burden of their acts.

Thanks for your time, Steve Martin, Clearwater Florida

Dear Sirs and Madams:

I am writing to voice my support for Nemours Children's Hospital proposed facility in Orlando. Nemours Children's Hospital will bring a highly specialized, pediatric focused, endowed institution to Central Florida.

The services and programs of Nemours Children's Hospital will focus on the chronically ill patient providing services not currently offered in this region and establishing a location where medically complex pediatric conditions can be treated in a single facility with one seamless system of care.

This institution will be located on a children's health care campus that will support research, physician and health care worker education, and advocacy programs for children. Nemours Children's Hospital will be an economic driver offering high wage, high skill jobs and it will support the development of the region as a worldwide destination for health care.

The Nemours health care system will treat all children, regardless of their economic station in life, with no restrictions on the type of the breadth and depth of treatment. Simply put, what our children need, they will receive.

Growth Information:

- Florida?s pediatric population is growing rapidly and 10-15% of the children born in any given year will need specialized pediatric care. Moreover, that percentage is on the rise.
- By 2030, Florida will have the third largest pediatric population in the country (source: U.S. Census Bureau.) Between 2000 and 2030, Florida will gain more than 2 million children. This large and growing population needs access to the specialized services that Nemours will offer.
- The number of children admitted to a hospital in Central Florida grew by 37% in the past five years, from 11,684 admissions to 16,029; however, the number of pediatric hospital beds shrank by 24% during that time, from 328 beds to 249 beds. (source: Health Council of East Central Florida)

Economic Impact Information:

- Nemours has contributed more than $550 million to Central and North Florida since 1980 as evidence of its commitment to the children of Florida.
- There will be no fundraising or community contributions solicited to build this hospital. No tax dollars or government resources are required.
- Nemours has offered a gift to the Central Florida community that includes:
- $250-300 million capital investment in a top-tier children's hospital
- $30-40 million annual mission investment in a children's hospital (double the current mission investment in the existing Nemours Children's Clinic in Orlando)
- 1,500 potential jobs with an economic impact of over $350 million in Central Florida
- Central Florida will have access to the Nemours Biomedical Research Program, ranked 13th in 2004 NIH funding among children?s hospitals.
- Today, there are presently 103 Nemours clinicians and 17 PhD lab heads involved in biomedical research programs. Those numbers would increase with a children?s hospital in Orlando.
- Nemours academicians produce almost 250 peer-reviewed contributions to journals, books and chapters annually. Nemours contributes several million dollars annually to the cost of the programs.

Nemours children's health care system and hospital will serve as the catalyst for a broad-ranging advocacy program aimed at addressing issues affecting the quality of life and health status for children. Nemours will collaborate with other health care providers, community agencies, and related pediatric organizations to further pediatric advocacy.

I sincerely hope that you see all the good that can come to our city with the addition of a facility such as Nemours. Please make your support for a new children's hospital for Orlando known, as well.

Thank you for your time!

John Cox
Orlando, FL

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Governor Jeb Bush 
To: Governor Jeb Bush 
Sent: Saturday, October 07, 2006 12:07 PM
Subject: Governor Jeb Bush's IN THE NEWS... Friday, October 6, 2006

For those E-Newsletter recipients who have Adobe Acrobat reader, Governor
Bush's e-newsletter is available in .PDF format by clicking here:

http://www.flgov.com/in_the_news

The text version of the e-newsletter is below.


FLORIDA MAINTAINS 'AAA' BOND RATING IN ANNUAL REVIEW BY STANDARD AND POOR's

On Tuesday, I touted Standard and Poor's Corporation's decision to affirm
Florida's 'AAA' bond rating in its annual review of the state.  'AAA' is the
firm's highest rating.  Standard and Poor's cited Florida's strong,
conservative financial and budget management practices in affirming the
'AAA' rating, first issued in 2005.  Undaunted by eight hurricanes in two
years, Florida's economy is surging. I am pleased to see that Standard and
Poor's has recognized that our low-tax, pro-business approach to government
is working for Florida.  Our reasonable tax structure and record-level
financial reserves have also helped to create stability and opportunities
for long-term growth, as evidenced by this rating decision.  For more
information on Florida's growing and robust economy, please visit
www.myflorida.com.


LEROY COLLINS INSTITUTE HOLDS GOVERNORS FORUM

On Wednesday, I was joined by four former Florida governors at the LeRoy
Collins Institute Governors Forum in Tallahassee. The Leroy Collins
Institute is an independent, nonpartisan and non-profit organization which
studies and promotes creative solutions to major private and public issues
facing the people of Florida and the nation.  Among those taking part in the
event were Governor Claude Kirk, Governor Reubin Askew, Governor Bob Graham,
Governor Wayne Mixson, Tallahassee Mayor John Marks, Leroy Collins Institute
Chairman Curt Kiser, family and friends of Governor LeRoy Collins and other
state and local officials.  For more information on the Institute and the
legacy of Governor Collins, visit www.fsu.edu/~collins/.


FLORIDA LAUNCHES INAUGURAL SALES TAX HOLIDAY FOR ENERGY EFFICIENT PRODUCTS

On Thursday, I encouraged Floridians to take advantage of Florida's
inaugural sales tax holiday for energy efficient products. The sales tax
holiday is an important component of the 2006 Florida Energy Act. To promote
energy conservation during Energy Awareness Month, I signed a proclamation
recognizing October 5 - 11, 2006, as Energy Efficient Week. Energy Efficient
Week encourages Floridians to invest in energy efficient products by
providing relief from sales tax for approved products and appliances for up
to $1,500. Qualifying energy efficient products include a dishwasher,
clothes washer, air conditioner, ceiling fan, incandescent or fluorescent
light bulb, dehumidifier, programmable thermostat, or refrigerator that
meets all requirements of the ENERGY STAR program.  For more information on
energy in Florida, visit www.floridaenergy.org.


REMARKS TO 2006 K-12 INNOVATION CONFERENCE

Also on Thursday, I addressed 700 educators attending the 2006 K-12
Innovation Conference in Orlando. The Department of Education and the
Florida Education Foundation co-hosted the 2006 K-12 Conference and
Innovation Fair.  The conference focused on innovative approaches to
improving student achievement at the middle and high school levels.  I was
joined by Florida Education Commissioner John Winn, K-12 Public Schools
Chancellor Cheryl Yecke, and education officials. For more information on
the Conference, visit www.fldoe.org/K12/Conference.


POINTS OF LIGHT AWARDED TO CRISTINA GARCIA

Congratulations!

To read more about this week's winners, please click here: 
http://www.flgov.com/release/8249


GOVERNOR BUSH'S 2006 LEGISLATIVE INITIATIVES

Please visit www.govfloridaforum.com.

From:	panchojones@aol.com
Sent:	Friday, October 6, 2006 11:36 AM
To:	cfo@fldfs.com; Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	 THE AMERICAN DREAM

Dear Governor and Dear CFO,  
 
I feel compelled to write to you under this title hoping it will catch your eye among the large amount of e-mails I am sure you get everyday.
 
It’s simple. We all want to own a home, the major investment the average citizen will make in a life time, and an assumed security to help put kids through college and perhaps in the long run a reverse mortgage to secure a decent place to live one’s final days…
 
For the past 7 years lending institutions have been pushing home market values up to justify lending money based on equity earned. No one ever considered the actual market and/or assessed values as they appeared in the trim notices year after year…a more expert value appraiser, (licensed by the city or the State, but well paid by those hidden closing costs), appraised homes at a higher value so banks could make huge profits…eventually this led to the infamous real estate “bubble” which, after all the big guys made all their money, it burst, leaving the average American citizen with yet another predicament: Property taxes and insurance no one can afford!
 
If taxes are serious enough so we have to pay for them, taxing authorities should have been serious enough to enforce the actual market and assessed values as stipulated by expert official appraisers year after year in trim notices. And therefore, lending institutions and independent state licensed property appraisers should be prosecuted…or, the taxing authorities should be challenged with either looking the other way, or being part of this process…but authorities make it even worse when they approve an increase on the insurance, which in my case went from a $1,500 premium last year to a $3,844 premium this year!...and it's due in 10 days! I guess it's all right for you guys to have us pay more than twice...Are you passing a law for employers to raise our salaries 160%...Where do I get $2,344?...Oh I know, I shall ask for another line of credit based on the equity of my home, Right?
 
As if this was not bad enough, Broward county has determined my property value has increased 23% in less than 12 months, based on bla, bla, bla, bla which I have nothing to do with…expert licensed appraisers valued the house for a purchase price of $266,000 while the assessed value was at $ 160,000…not my fault, I needed to buy a home, remember? The American dream?  In less than 24 months the city assessment goes from $228,000 to $283,000 for 2006 tax purposes…probably a state licensed property appraiser will estimate the house value at $460,000…Who is correct? Why the speculation? Why is it allowed?
 
The question to you both at this point is whether or not at the end of the day people will be able to afford an additional $500 a month to pay for taxes, on top of flood coverage and dwelling insurance for which an additional $320 will be requireed…or whether to rent instead of own a home while renting communities are asking for an additional $200 minimum to renew rent contracts…and if you add to that the condominium and condominium additional assessments, the actual rent or mortgage will reach amounts no one will be able to afford...
 
This being an election year, you couldn't have picked a worse time to do this to the people who voted for you. But, Do you really care? You won't be running for Governor anyway...
 
Good bye American dream…

Subject:	Nemours

Dear Sir:

As a mother and a respiratory therapist, I have a concern regarding the
state of the Nemours hospital in Orlando.  I was employed in the Detroit
area for almost 20 years before moving to Orlando.  The large metro area
reaped the benefits of a world class Medical Center.  I then spent nine
years working for one of the hospital systems that is using it's political
clout to block the Dupont foundation from servicing our area's children.  I
have personally seen the games that are played with our public's trust.  We
need to have a hospital that caters to our children, one of the largest
population groups growing in central Florida.  I have first hand knowledge
of patients that lost battles with disease because of the limited scope of
practices within the Florida Hospital and ORHS systems.

These hospitals fear competition.  As a registered respiratory therapist, I
fail to see what is wrong with a little competition.  Is it not competition
that makes others strive for higher standards?  Comments about shortages of
medical staff can be true.  When I moved here, I took a large cut in pay.
The lack of competition in this area contributes to wage ceilings.  The
competition can only better the standard of living for those of us that are
paying the higher cost of living of Florida while we try to make ends meet
with the compensation standards of many years ago.  Central Florida's
housing and insurance rates have risen higher than all hospital employee's
wages.


For the sake of our children and to bring down more medical professionals,
please give Orlando a Nemours hospital that creates not only jobs, but the
backing of specialists around the country.

Thank you,

Lori Weinzierl, RRT


From:	jonieb@juno.com

Subject:	Nemours

Nemours Children's Hospital will bring a highly specialized, pediatric focused, endowed institution to Central Florida. 

The services and programs of Nemours Children's Hospital will focus on the chronically ill patient providing services not currently offered in this region and establishing a location where medically complex pediatric conditions can be treated in a single facility with one seamless system of care. 

This institution will be located on a children's health care campus that will support research, physician and health care worker education, and advocacy programs for children. Nemours Children's Hospital will be an economic driver offering high wage, high skill jobs and it will support the development of the region as a worldwide destination for health care. 

The Nemours health care system will treat all children, regardless of their economic station in life, with no restrictions on the type of the breadth and depth of treatment. Simply put, what our children need, they will receive.

From:	Bill Mills <billcarol2003@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, October 4, 2006 5:21 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Property Taxes and other

October 04, 2006
 
The Honorable Jeb Bush
The Capitol
400 South Monroe Street
Tallahassee, FL 32399
 
Dear Governor Bush:
 
I am writing to you to express my concern and dismay regarding my recent notice about my property taxes.
 
My wife, daughter and I moved here in June of 2005 from Salisbury, MD. We had been dreaming for many years to make Florida our home. So when I was offered a transfer with my company, I gladly accepted. 
 
I came here in February of 2005 and my wife and daughter remained in Maryland to sell our home and for our daughter to complete the 6th grade. My new job took up most of my time, therefore I did not have much of an opportunity to research the area, but because my company decided to open their new facility here in Coconut Creek, we decided this would be a good place to reside.
 
We were shown many, many homes by a local realtor and finally purchased our home. We were totally "sticker shocked", but because we so much wanted to live here, we proceeded to realize our dream. We purchased our home for $350,000. Taxes on this home were a whopping $3,854.55. We were told that this years tax would increase but, by no more that 10-15%. Well imagine our surprise when we received the notice stating that our taxes would now be $5,837.78! This equates to a 50% increase. Furthermore, my electric bill last September was $221.18, this year $325.28 for the same amount of usage and number of days. Our home owners insurance is over $3,000 per year and we have been told to expect at least a 50% increase next year. I don’t even want to go into my automobile insurance.
 
Our dream has turned into a nightmare. We live in a beautiful area with many things to do, but we cannot afford to do any of them. How are we supposed to survive? My salary did not increase with my move. I am 62 years old and at this rate I do not expect to be able to retire until I am in my 70's, God willing. We have seriously considered moving, but we couldn’t even get back the money we put into our house now because the market has crashed and people are not going to purchase a home with these kind of taxes. There are many homes in our neighborhood that have been on the market for close to year, with no interested buyers.
 
What are we supposed to do? We have cut-back on everything, started taking from our limited savings account, but I am afraid that we will lose everything we own. I have contacted the Broward County Property Appraisers office, went to public hearings, and was told we just have to deal with it, this is how Florida is. After listening to others at the last public hearing, I know I am not alone, but that doesn’t make it any easier. If we had known how much it was going to cost to live here we never would have given up our 2500 sq. foot home, in-ground pool, one acre of property with $1900 in taxes, $100 per month electric bills and $300 per year homeowners insurance in Maryland.
 
I realize that your term in office will be up very shortly, and that this letter will have very little, if any, impact.  I also doubt that this letter will be personally read by you, but I felt that I would be remiss if I did not express my thoughts and concerns at this time.
 
Sincerely,
William J. Mills
2330 NW 34 Terrace
Coconut Creek, FL 33066
954-978-9311

From:	Kay Ralston <krlstn@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, October 3, 2006 1:34 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Property Taxes (& Homeowners Insurance)

Dear Mr. Bush,

 

I live in Palm Beach County, where the average cost of a home has gone through the roof (no pun intended), and property taxes along with homeowners/property insurance have become a nightmare.

 

The state legislature needs to step in A.S.A.P.,  to limit the increase in property taxes that counties are allowed to collect for primary residences.  Then, in cases where there has been a near doubling of property taxes, the state should be retroactive. There is no way any county should be allowed to garnish excessive funds  - via property taxes -  simply because housing prices have risen as they have.  There must be a mandate to protect the citizens from unfair taxes such as these. 

 

My taxes for instance, have doubled from about $4000, to this year’s $8000 proposed amount.  The county has no rational to make this the “new amount”,  other than using the old standard rules and formulas from years ago. These formulas must be replaced. People should not continue to be taxed in this way: our state government officials must step in to protect the citizens. 

 

Property /homeowners’ insurance is another huge burden for people living in Florida (again, stating the obvious). Florida’s citizens must see solid evidence that our representatives are making these issues a top priority.  

 

In closing, I am certain that you take seriously  what we are up against. I hope and pray, as all Floridians do, that you will quickly initiate ways to ease the burden of these unfair taxation and insurance issues. 

 

Sincerely,

Kay Ralston

Subject:	Help . . .

Mr. Jeb Bush, please don’t just talk about Property Tax and Insurance Reform, get the committees to resolve these crazy property value adjustments immediately and moving on the Insurance Reform before it is too late.  Time is NOT on our side.  November taxes are due.  Damage to our people and States economy happens everyday.

 

I am a very small Broward business owner in my thirties with 3 rental properties (a duplex and 2 houses) that used to just get by in the black by maybe a $100 each property.   In the last few years, I looked to the appreciation for justification, but now with the median property values decreasing and the future of the real estate market questionable it is not easy to justify ownership.  It has gotten so bad that had to take out loans to pay for the monthly/annual losses.  My taxes have increased on my rentals from13%, 58% to 61% just in the last year.

 

Now this year, I’m (We’re) in big trouble between taxes and insurance issues.  I’m still paying for Wilma damages.  I cannot keep my rents down, and it’s terribly hard to increase them to cover my new expenses, plus get responsible tenants to be able to pay what the rents need to be is nearly impossible.  I have two tenants moving out (one back to Pennsylvania) and two tenants that are late every month trying to scrape up the increased rent amounts.  As a landlord, it is IMPOSSIBLE to provide affordable housing for the “blue collar and middle class.”

 

I also own a few vacant lots (again I am a business owner) that I bought for my future financial security so I don’t have to work until I die, but now the taxes have gone up from 11%, 25%, 32%, 68% to 376%.  How can the state government allow these increases without expecting it to hurt millions?

 

In addition to my problems the Tax and Insurance issue is negatively affecting EVERYONE, and the ramifications will not be entirely realized for a few years.  Here are a few examples, but there are many, similar and additional situations that I ‘m sure you are aware of:  

 

My parents, retired on a set income can no longer pay all of there bills without putting a reverse mortgage on there home that they bought in Royal Palm Beach to be closer to me.  They can’t believe that they sold there home in New York because of taxes, and there taxes are more now then they would be paying if they stayed there.  It’s not right that people have to be put into this situation.  They worked their whole lives to retire in Florida and enjoy lives with their families.

 

My neighbors, Canadian Snow Birds tax bill doubled from $12K to 23K, and are looking at property elsewhere, so they can sell.  And these people have money (real money), and during the 6 months they live here they spend a lot of it on everything from $100K cars to local shopping and restaurants every other night.  They have company almost every week, all of which spend money in our local economy.  Once more snow birds get fed up and move out, our economy is going to really get hurt.  Not only will this affect the real estate market, but it will have devastating results to our local businesses, and residents who sometimes our “Homesteaded Owners” don’t realize.

 

I am active in the Broward Real Estate Investors Association (BREIA), and the Florida Landlord Action Group (FLAG), and I may not speak for the entire groups behave, but I know that with thousands of members strong we are concerned that these two issues will hurt us all more than what Wilma and the more active Hurricane seasons. 

 

To reiterate, who everyone is:  Small Business Owners, Large Business Owners, Blue Collar Workers, White Collar Workers, Landlords, Tenants, Real Estate Investors, Florida Natives, Homesteaded, Non-Homesteaded Property Owners, Snow Birds, Tourism, Retired, Foreign Investors and many others.

 

Please help today.  Regardless of whether you’ll be in office in the future or not, please get someone competent to resolve these issues today.  Taxes are due in November.  

 

Again, please help this state from its own demise!

 

Please feel free to contact me if you have any questions or comments.

 

Sincerely Concerned Florida Resident,

 

Jon P. Pepe

Cell:  954.205.7151
Email:  jonpepe@bellsouth.net

From:	Anthony Pike <A_Pike@earthlink.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, October 3, 2006 10:25 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Property Taxes

Mr. Governor
 
I would like to know if there is anything that you can do or plan to do regarding Florida's property taxes prior to leaving office.  There are two areas that I feel need to be addressed.
  
The first being the fact that there is no limitation on the amount of increase on the assessed value of a second home or investment property which will significantly increase the amount of taxes paid.  For the second home, this deters what we call the snowbirds and or frequent visitors to own, which contribute to our economy.  For the investor, it creates an increase in what is required to charge for rent which increases costs for all of the individuals who must rent in Florida.  Please do something to limit the amount of increase on the assessed value to help for this not to become a major issue.

The second is for us individuals who own our home and are paying basically a second mortgage when it comes to the amount of property tax we are paying.  We will pay for our house a second time just in property taxes, for the right to own our home.  It would also help if there was some form of credit if we chose to move to another home.  We had considered downsizing to a smaller home in a better area for our children and have found that we would actually be paying 50% or more of an increase in property tax.  Please do something to help us in this area. 

It would also be nice to know where all of this extra money is going because we hear of budget problems and cuts.  This is ridiculous based on the increase of revenue from the property taxes alone.  Please share with us your opinion, views and intentions, if any, on this subject.

Best regards,
Anthony Pike
Orlando, Fl

FAMILY DAY HOSTED AT THE CAPITOL

On Monday, First Lady Columba Bush, Lt. Governor Toni Jennings, and Florida
Office of Drug Control Director Bill Janes and I hosted "Family Day" at the
Capitol to encourage families to spend time together. The celebration
demonstrates how simple activities, such as eating dinner together as a
family, can open the lines of communication, strengthen families and
increase the likelihood children will remain drug-free.  Taking an active
role in our children's lives is the single best way to prevent drug use.
Regular conversations and open dialogues are easy ways for parents to learn
more about their children, get to know their friends and help them with the
challenges of growing up in today's world.  "Family Day - A Day to Eat
Dinner With Your Children" is part of a national campaign led by President
George W. Bush and the National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at
Columbia University (CASA). Families are encouraged to talk to their
children about avoiding the dangers of substance abuse, underage drinking
and smoking. Florida was the first state to adopt the "Family Day" program
in 2001 when President Bush proclaimed it as "a day to spend quality time
with family members and engage in other wholesome activities that help unite
and strengthen the bonds between parents and children".   For more
information on "Family Day", please visit www.floridafamilyday.com.


TORREY PINES WELCOMED TO FLORIDA

On Tuesday, I joined Torrey Pines Institute for Molecular Studies Founder
and President Dr. Richard Houghten, incoming Senate President Ken Pruitt and
a host of industry, state and community leaders to officially announce the
Institute's plans to establish a Florida headquarters in the master-planned
community of Tradition in St. Lucie County.  The Institute will spur the
creation of many new, high-wage jobs on the Treasure Coast in its pursuit of
significant biomedical research.  The decision by Torrey Pines Institute for
Molecular Studies to expand into Florida further establishes our state as a
hub for advanced biomedical research and commercialization.  This move will
have a significant impact on the local economy while continuing to build
upon a growing life sciences sector in Florida.  I congratulate St. Lucie
and the entire Treasure Coast region for their aggressive and successful
recruitment of Torrey Pines.  I wish Torrey Pines great success in Florida.
For more information on my economic development initiatives, please visit
www.myflorida.com.
     

STUDENTS ATTEMPT TO BREAK A WORLD RECORD

On Thursday, I joined nearly 300,000 middle school students statewide in an
attempt to break the Guinness World Record(tm) for the "Most People Reading
Aloud Simultaneously in Multiple Locations".  The event, Breaking a World
Record: Reading Aloud!, aimed to bolster reading among middle school
students.  The record attempt was aired via a live public broadcast and
Webcast from Disney-MGM Studios.  Promptly at 11:25 a.m., I led the students
in reading an excerpt from the book "Peter and the Starcatchers" written by
Dave Barry and Ridley Pearson.  According to Guinness World Records(tm), the
current record is 155,528 students from 737 schools throughout the United
Kingdom who read William Wordsworth's poem "Daffodils", on March 19, 2004.
Jane Feber, an eighth grade teacher from Mandarin Middle School in Duval
County, came up with the idea of breaking the record and shared it with me.
In the coming months, the state will receive confirmation from Guinness as
to whether or not the attempt was successful. To view the Webcast of the
event, please visit www.JustReadFlorida.com.


POINTS OF LIGHT AWARDED TO JENNIFER GONZALEZ

Congratulations!

To read more about this week's winners, please click here: 
http://www.flgov.com/release/8208

The way we tax land snuffs out mom & pop

By HOWARD TROXLER, Times Columnist
Published October 1, 2006

  _____  


Ann Hartwig thought a quilting shop would be perfect for the little building she owns on Beach Boulevard in Gulfport. The pleasant, open street leads to the waterfront and is the scene of regular "art walks" for folks to come and stroll.

Hartwig's store is named StarGazer Quilting. She has fabrics, supplies, classes and gifts. "What I've done is charming and cute and appropriate," she says proudly.

Here is what is not cute and charming: her tax bill. 

Last year, her property taxes were $3,762.

This year, they will be between $6,900 and $7,100, depending on how early she pays them to get the discount.

The appraisal of her building, a former single-family home, went from $172,700 last year to $355,200.

"This," Hartwig told me sarcastically, "is the American dream."

As we talked, Theresa Frohne and her daughter Simone listened and nodded. For the past 32 years their family has owned La Cote Basque, a country-French restaurant one block down Beach Boulevard.

Theresa got the restaurant's property tax bill a few weeks ago. "Oh, my God, Simone," she cried out to her daughter as she read it. "They've finished me."

Simone handed me a handwritten sheet with the restaurant's tax history:

$2,604.64 2001

$2,948.14 2002

$3,747.76 2003

$4,303.28 2004

$5,332.77 2005

$10,894.42 2006

The value of the restaurant property, according to the county appraiser's office, went from $255,000 last year to $510,000 this year.

"I can't exist like this," Theresa Frohne said. Simone began to cry as she talked about her late father, Ernest, who started the restaurant with her mother.

So, this is Florida's tax policy.

Yes, we have protected homeowners with the "Save Our Homes" amendment. Homeowners' valuations can't go up more than 3 percent a year.

But that's not true for small-business owners like Hartwig and the Frohne family, or owners of any nonhomestead property. Their taxes are rising a lot faster:

The real estate market in Florida has been red hot, driving up everybody's property value.

Our law in Florida - as in lots of places - says that property must be taxed according to its "highest and best use," and not its existing use.

Hartwig has a bitter but clear understanding of what this means. It means Florida's tax policy is pushing her to sell so that her land can be used for something "better."

We talk about "good planning" and "quality of life" and "community character." But beneath it all, our tax policy pushes out the quilt shops and family restaurants in favor of condos and denser, moneymaking uses.

Hartwig doesn't want to sell. "I thought this was the perfect fit for our little arts district," she said. But in dealing with the government, she said, "I feel like I'm the only one with a sense of responsibility for this neighborhood."

I talked with Jim Smith, the Pinellas property appraiser, and he was sympathetic. He owns a building in Clearwater that he rented to artists. When his building got socked with a 25 percent increase, his appraisers told him maybe he should be renting to doctors or lawyers instead - economically, a "higher" and "better" use.

Smith is frustrated. His office is only obeying the state law on how property is valued, but gets blamed for higher taxes when local governments don't cut their tax rates as fast as land values are growing. He got booed at a public event the other night.

"We need to do something to keep businesses from being valued out of their property," Smith said. "The question is, how do we help small-business people out. By God, we should."

We could create a small-business version of "Save Our Homes," with major consequences for local government.

We could assess property a different way to consider existing use, but that would require changes at the state level, and there would be other side effects and injustices.

"We have to come up with something that makes sense," Smith said. "And I don't know what that is."

© Copyright, St. Petersburg Times. All rights reserved.

 LocalLinks 
	
 

WESTON · Now that the Broward County school district has approved a new high school for the Pembroke Pines-Miramar area, parents here are wondering if they will receive the same treatment. 

More than 200 parents learned they had reason to worry after a community forum Thursday night at Cypress Bay High School, hosted by officials from the Broward school district and the city of Weston.

The parents who spoke said they question if the district is acting quickly enough to find a site to build the proposed high school, designated MMM, to relieve overcrowding at Cypress Bay High.

School officials told parents that land is scarce in the Weston area and said the district has tried in vain for three years to find a suitable home for MMM.

District leaders said they have been hopeful since July when the city of Weston identified a parcel of pastureland that could be used for MMM, located south of Weston Regional Park and west of South Post Road.

But the South Florida Water Management District owns the land and the deal hinges on the state agency accepting a proposed land swap. Weston City Manager John Flint admitted the project has "lots of hurdles to cross" and that the city would not know if it's doable until closer to the end of the year.

The available property is partially wetlands, and water district rules dictate that prospective developers buy other land to preserve, to offset wetlands loss.

Parents questioned if MMM was not headed for a similar fate as LLL, the high school recently approved for west Pembroke Pines and Miramar after a three-year delay. 

"Stop looking at property that's not feasible," said Lisa Koscs, of Southwest Ranches, a parent of an eighth-grader zoned to attend Cypress Bay next year. "You're wasting too much time. You have to look at other areas."

MMM would ease crowding at Cypress Bay, which serves Weston, Southwest Ranches and part of Davie.

Earlier this month, enrollment counts showed that the district has lost more than 8,000 students compared to last year. The drop prompted district officials and School Board members to say they would re-evaluate building projects. But School Board member Marty Rubinstein said that the decline would not reduce the need for MMM.

"We're down in enrollment [across the county] but not in this area," Rubinstein said. "The trend is a bit slower than it was, but it's still up."

At Cypress Bay, student population increased from 5,075 in fall 2005 to 5,330 this year.

The school opened in fall 2002 and has grown to become the most populated high school in the state of Florida.

The listed capacity for the Cypress Bay is only 3,400, but the school copes by using portable classrooms and sending its 1,400 freshmen to a satellite campus.

Douane D. James can be reached at ddjames@sun-sentinel.com or 954-385-7930.

The services and programs of Nemours Children's Hospital will focus on the chronically ill patient providing services not currently offered in this region and establishing a location where medically complex pediatric conditions can be treated in a single facility with one seamless system of care. 

This institution will be located on a children's health care campus that will support research, physician and health care worker education, and advocacy programs for children. Nemours Children's Hospital will be an economic driver offering high wage, high skill jobs and it will support the development of the region as a worldwide destination for health care. 

The Nemours health care system will treat all children, regardless of their economic station in life, with no restrictions on the type of the breadth and depth of treatment. Simply put, what our children need, they will receive. 

Growth Information: 

*	Florida’s pediatric population is growing rapidly and 10-15% of the children born in any given year will need specialized pediatric care. Moreover, that percentage is on the rise. 
*	By 2030, Florida will have the third largest pediatric population in the country (source: U.S. Census Bureau.) Between 2000 and 2030, Florida will gain more than 2 million children. This large and growing population needs access to the specialized services that Nemours will offer. 
*	The number of children admitted to a hospital in Central Florida grew by 37% in the past five years, from 11,684 admissions to 16,029; however, the number of pediatric hospital beds shrank by 24% during that time, from 328 beds to 249 beds. (source: Health Council of East Central Florida)

Economic Impact Information: 

*	Nemours has contributed more than $550 million to Central and North Florida since 1980 as evidence of its commitment to the children of Florida. 
*	There will be no fundraising or community contributions solicited to build this hospital. No tax dollars or government resources are required. 
*	Nemours has offered a gift to the Central Florida community that includes: 

*	$250-300 million capital investment in a top-tier children's hospital 
*	$30-40 million annual mission investment in a children's hospital (double the current mission investment in the existing Nemours Children's Clinic in Orlando) 
*	1,500 potential jobs with an economic impact of over $350 million in Central Florida 

*	Central Florida will have access to the Nemours Biomedical Research Program, ranked 13th in 2004 NIH funding among children’s hospitals. 
*	Today, there are presently 103 Nemours clinicians and 17 PhD lab heads involved in biomedical research programs. Those numbers would increase with a children’s hospital in Orlando. 
*	Nemours academicians produce almost 250 peer-reviewed contributions to journals, books and chapters annually. Nemours contributes several million dollars annually to the cost of the programs. 

Nemours children's health care system and hospital will serve as the catalyst for a broad-ranging advocacy program aimed at addressing issues affecting the quality of life and health status for children. Nemours will collaborate with other health care providers, community agencies, and related pediatric organizations to further pediatric advocacy.

Corporate Secretary & Program Officer

Subject:	Property taxes and insurance crisis

Dear Dr. Bush: 

I am writing to urge you to put together a special legislation session on property taxes and high insurance costs that have plaqued Florida residents over the past several years.  

We need to change legislation on property taxes in that your homestead follows you whether you upgrade to a bigger house or downsize to a smaller house.  Property tax has risen by 27-50% and as a Floridian I cannot afford to pay thousands of dollars in property taxes.  For example I purchased a new home last May and the property tax was $8,300 now I have received a proposed bill of $11,500 an increase of 27%.  I believe the $8,300 was already too high but $11,500 is outrageous.  It is a sad day when you look at your mortgage statement and you are paying more for property tax than the principal and interest.  I believe there needs to be an adjustment to the homestead exemption in that the 3% cap either needs to be reevaluated on property every 5 years or the exemption increased for new property owners.  New property owners are taking on the tax burden while their neighbor whom have lived in there house for 30 years is paying dismal taxes.  You cannot expect people to want to come to Florida for new jobs or to retire when the property tax is TOO HIGH.  What do you plan to do about this???

Another problem in real estate is investment property.  There needs to be a cap on this as well because what is happening is the owner of the property has to pass high property taxes onto the renter who is already in a financial bind.  There is talk about a 6% cap but whatever it is it needs to be fair for all not like the 3% cap on homestead.  My new taxes for my investment property has gone up 27% from the previous year that essentially had only been rising by 9%.  My income has not increased by 27% nor has rent prices been increasing by 27%.  Most people are lucky if they receive a 4% increase on their income. 

Lastly, our homeowners insurance costs are way too high.  I can't believe that insurance companies are allowed to back out of Florida and also not write any new policies.  While storms do devastate areas and claims are filed, they are not filed all over Florida.  So why should all of our premiums increase and some policies cancelled for the insurance companies do not want to insure Florida homes.  I believe the claims that were filed did not cause any insurance company to go bankrupt they are just upset for they did not make millions of dollars that year.  While many had claims there are still many more that did not have any claims.  Why punish all when only some have homes that are in hurricane or flood zone areas.

As a devout Republican and a strong supporter of you and your brother George W., I urge you to make these 3 things a priority and call to order a special legislation session to help Floridians.  I hope we can count on your help!!  Please feel free to contact me at sparsons@amgen.com  or on my cell phone at 813-624-2429.

Sincerely, 
Sherry A. Parsons, 
Professional Sales Representative 
Voice Mail - 800-232-9997 ext. 3 + 39846

Dear Governor Bush,

My wife Shirley and I want you to know we support the building of this hospital service in Orlando.

Nemours Children's Hospital will bring a highly specialized, pediatric focused, endowed institution to Central Florida. 

The services and programs of Nemours Children's Hospital will focus on the chronically ill patient providing services not currently offered in this region and establishing a location where medically complex pediatric conditions can be treated in a single facility with one seamless system of care. 

This institution will be located on a children's health care campus that will support research, physician and health care worker education, and advocacy programs for children. Nemours Children's Hospital will be an economic driver offering high wage, high skill jobs and it will support the development of the region as a worldwide destination for health care. 

The Nemours health care system will treat all children, regardless of their economic station in life, with no restrictions on the type of the breadth and depth of treatment. Simply put, what our children need, they will receive. 

Growth Information: 

*	Florida’s pediatric population is growing rapidly and 10-15% of the children born in any given year will need specialized pediatric care. Moreover, that percentage is on the rise.
*	By 2030, Florida will have the third largest pediatric population in the country (source: U.S. Census Bureau.) Between 2000 and 2030, Florida will gain more than 2 million children. This large and growing population needs access to the specialized services that Nemours will offer. 
*	The number of children admitted to a hospital in Central Florida grew by 37% in the past five years, from 11,684 admissions to 16,029; however, the number of pediatric hospital beds shrank by 24% during that time, from 328 beds to 249 beds. (source: Health Council of East Central Florida)

Economic Impact Information: 

*	Nemours has contributed more than $550 million to Central and North Florida since 1980 as evidence of its commitment to the children of Florida.
*	There will be no fundraising or community contributions solicited to build this hospital. No tax dollars or government resources are required. 
*	Nemours has offered a gift to the Central Florida community that includes: 

*	$250-300 million capital investment in a top-tier children's hospital 
*	$30-40 million annual mission investment in a children's hospital (double the current mission investment in the existing Nemours Children's Clinic in Orlando)
*	1,500 potential jobs with an economic impact of over $350 million in Central Florida 

*	Central Florida will have access to the Nemours Biomedical Research Program, ranked 13th in 2004 NIH funding among children’s hospitals. 
*	Today, there are presently 103 Nemours clinicians and 17 PhD lab heads involved in biomedical research programs. Those numbers would increase with a children’s hospital in Orlando. 
*	Nemours academicians produce almost 250 peer-reviewed contributions to journals, books and chapters annually. Nemours contributes several million dollars annually to the cost of the programs. 

Nemours children's health care system and hospital will serve as the catalyst for a broad-ranging advocacy program aimed at addressing issues affecting the quality of life and health status for children. Nemours will collaborate with other health care providers, community agencies, and related pediatric organizations to further pediatric advocacy.

From: Ivan Restrepo [mailto:ingesis@telecorp.net]

Dears FLORIDA GOV. and MIAMI MAYOR
 
Copy of our letter about Math. Model for Alternative Risk Transfers, with a presentation letter from our (Federal) Transportation Secretary
 
INGESISTEMAS / Iván Restrepo L
 
                                                         -----------------------------------------------
 
 
Bogotá, D.C., Septiembre 26 de 2006


Certifico que el doctor Iván Restrepo Lince, prestó sus servicios de actuaría con el Ministerio de Transporte, en desarrollo del contrato de prestación de servicios profesionales Nº 096 de 2003, cuyo objeto fue el de "Asesorar conjunta e integralmente al ministerio en el soporte técnico actuarial que se requiera para analizar y revisar la situación actual del aseguramiento en el sector transporte público terrestre, en cuanto a definiciones y medidas de riesgo, formas de ajuste y técnicas de evaluación y formular alternativas de mejoramiento, mediante modelos de simulación, tendientes a lograr mecanismos óptimos"


El contrato se inició el 5 de febrero de 2004 y concluyó, a entera satisfacción, el 4 de octubre del mismo año.
El estudio ha permitido al Ministerio de Transporte, contar con una herramienta sólida, en materia actuarial y matemática, para los análisis del SOAT, el aseguramiento en materia contractual y extracontractual, así como los Fondos de Autoseguro, así como también, para disponer de elementos técnicos que permitan superar las inconsistencias del sistema de aseguramiento.

Por bondad del actuario Restrepo, se incorporó en el desarrollo contractual  un "Estudio técnico de riesgo", que fue fuente de capacitación en taller que conjuntamente con la Dra. Gloria María Yepes Vargas, para que neófitos en el tema tabú de la actuaría, quedaramos dotados en estas técnicas.


William A. Valencia R.
Interventor del contrato
Asesor OFRE - Ministerio de Transporte
324 08 00  ext 1474.
Colombia

Nemours Children's Hospital will be an economic driver offering high wage, high skill jobs and it will support the development of the region as a worldwide destination for health care. 

The Nemours health care system will treat all children, regardless of their economic station in life, with no restrictions on the type of the breadth and depth of treatment. Simply put, what our children need, they will receive. 

Growth Information: 

*	Florida’s pediatric population is growing rapidly and 10-15% of the children born in any given year will need specialized pediatric care. Moreover, that percentage is on the rise. 
*	By 2030, Florida will have the third largest pediatric population in the country (source: U.S. Census Bureau.) Between 2000 and 2030, Florida will gain more than 2 million children. This large and growing population needs access to the specialized services that Nemours will offer. 
*	The number of children admitted to a hospital in Central Florida grew by 37% in the past five years, from 11,684 admissions to 16,029; however, the number of pediatric hospital beds shrank by 24% during that time, from 328 beds to 249 beds. (source: Health Council of East Central Florida)

Economic Impact Information: 

*	Nemours has contributed more than $550 million to Central and North Florida since 1980 as evidence of its commitment to the children of Florida. 
*	There will be no fundraising or community contributions solicited to build this hospital. No tax dollars or government resources are required. 
*	Nemours has offered a gift to the Central Florida community that includes: 

*	$250-300 million capital investment in a top-tier children's hospital 
*	$30-40 million annual mission investment in a children's hospital (double the current mission investment in the existing Nemours Children's Clinic in Orlando) 
*	1,500 potential jobs with an economic impact of over $350 million in Central Florida 

*	Central Florida will have access to the Nemours Biomedical Research Program, ranked 13th in 2004 NIH funding among children’s hospitals. 
*	Today, there are presently 103 Nemours clinicians and 17 PhD lab heads involved in biomedical research programs. Those numbers would increase with a children’s hospital in Orlando. 
*	Nemours academicians produce almost 250 peer-reviewed contributions to journals, books and chapters annually. Nemours contributes several million dollars annually to the cost of the programs. 

Nemours children's health care system and hospital will serve as the catalyst for a broad-ranging advocacy program aimed at addressing issues affecting the quality of life and health status for children. Nemours will collaborate with other health care providers, community agencies, and related pediatric organizations to further pediatric advocacy. 



 
 
Michele Maxey Burdette
630 Monmouth Way    
Winter Park, FL  32792

From:	JESSIE RAYBOULD <jessierichsid@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, September 27, 2006 5:03 PM

Subject:	RE: personal note on ins

dear computer generated generic letter
you forgot about the tax increase complaint

From a real person
Governor Jeb Bush <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com> wrote:

Thank you for your letter about property insurance.  
 
Insurance is the number one issue facing our state today.  Two unprecedented back-to-back hurricane seasons – with eight hurricanes and four tropical storms – caused $36 billion in insurance claims.  According to the Florida Hurricane Catastrophe Fund, annual insured losses in years without a major storm average $2.8 billion.
 
Predictions of more catastrophic hurricanes making landfall in the U.S. have triggered significant increases in insurance premiums to cover potential future losses.  Many insurance companies have dropped policies and restricted new policies to avoid high risk areas and reduce overall exposure in Florida.  Homeowners who cannot get private insurance have only two options, no insurance or insurance from Citizens Property Insurance Corporation, which has the highest rates in the state.
 
This is a serious situation.  Higher rates and the inability to get private insurance have created a significant hardship for many homeowners and small businesses. Moreover, Florida cannot maintain a robust economy and high quality of life if our state continues to sustain tens of billions of dollars in damage every year.  
 
The key to solving the problem is fortifying Florida against the potential damage of future storms.   Reducing the risk of damage will reduce estimated cost of future disasters, which should stabilize rising insurance premiums.
 
You can take steps today to protect your home and reduce your insurance premium.  Florida requires insurance companies to give a discount on insurance premiums – as much as 44% on your wind policy – for certain improvements that guard against wind damage.  Choosing a higher insurance deductible, either 2% or 5%, can also reduce your premium.  
 
To help homeowners make these improvements, the state is providing $250 million for the Florida Comprehensive Hurricane Damage Mitigation Program, a new program to perform free home inspections and provide matching grants to qualified homeowners who harden their homes against wind damage.  Qualified homeowners that make approved improvements to their primary residences may be eligible for reimbursement by the state, dollar-for-dollar up to $5,000.  Qualified low-income homeowners may be eligible for up to $5,000 in improvements without providing any matching funding.  The Florida Comprehensive Hurricane Damage Mitigation Program is managed by the Department of Financial Services.  For information about how to apply for the grant, please visit www.mysafefloridahome.com.     
 
To provide immediate relief to policyholders, the state provided $715 million to Citizens Property Insurance Corporation to offset the company’s deficit and reduce the surcharge assessed on all policyholders – not just those with coverage from Citizens.  Without this funding, your insurance policy would have increased an additional $172.48 for every $1,000 of your insurance premium.
 
To increase the availability of private insurance, the state is providing $250 million for a new Insurance Capital Build-up Incentive Program to provide matching funds for insurance companies bringing new capital to the market.  This program will enable private insurance companies to underwrite more policies.  
 
On August 8, Lt. Governor Toni Jennings held the first meeting of the Property and Casualty Insurance Reform Committee.  This committee is open to all ideas to bring down the cost of premiums, increase availability of affordable insurance and reduce the risk to homeowners and taxpayers.  If you would like to make a suggestion, please visit www.myfloridainsurancereform.com. 
 
Thank you again for your letter.  I am committed to finding a solution to ease the financial burden that you and many other Florida homeowners are facing with the rising cost and declining availability of insurance.
 
                                                            Sincerely,
 
 
 
                                                            Jeb Bush

Attachment:  Letter to Manatee County Board of County Commissioners

 

September 14, 2006

 

The Honorable Joe McClash, Chairman

Board of County Commissioners

Manatee County

 

Dear Mr. Chairman,

 

I have reviewed your proposed Annual Budget Document for Manatee County, Fiscal year 2006-2007, available on the web at www.co.manatee.fl.us/board/2006-2007_proposed_budget_book.pdf.

 

I am not able to attend your public review meeting coming up on September 19, 2006 at the Manatee County Administration Building, starting at 6pm.  I submit this letter as my input, and request that it be read/entered into the formal record of the hearing.

 

1.	This budget shows a total spending of $582,383,590, an increase of 15.4% over the previous year.  Over that same time period, the population increase in the County is about 2.5%, and the CPI is about 3.4%.  If the County were a business, and proposed an increase in spending of this magnitude under these realities, the Board of Directors would demand resignations or insist on a revamp showing that you can live within your means.  To my mind, this budget is nothing to be proud of – it simply represents a tax grab based upon increasing property values, with the increases being paid by non-homesteaded property taxpayers.

 

2.	Nowhere in this document do I read any clear reference to the impact this budget will have on the majority of property taxpayers in Manatee County, who happen to be not permanent residents of Florida!  This is indeed the largest audience for this Budget document, with over half of all property units in Manatee County owned by non-homesteaded taxpayers.  The chart on page 34 of the Budget document shows the impact on Manatee County property taxpayers who happen to qualify for the “Save Our Homes” cap and the Homestead exemption.  They may expect to see a tax decrease this year.  May I request that you add to this chart during your review meeting on September 19 to show the impact of this Budget on non-homesteaded taxpayers, your largest constituency?  Specifically, the Average Single-Family Home valued at $260,000 will see a tax increase of 22.5% for County services (based on the average home value increase of 24% and a 4.9% reduction in millage rate).  Please be open and clear with your largest constituency about this. It clarifies from where the 15.4% budget increase will be collected – non-homesteaded property taxpayers like myself. 

 

I am sure that you are aware that there is a major review being conducted by Governor Jeb Bush to fix the property tax system in Florida.  (See the Florida Property Tax Reform Committee website http://www.propertytaxreform.state.fl.us/default.htm.)  One of their mandates is to achieve equity – “The Florida tax system should treat similarly-situated taxpayers similarly.”  I pray to God that this will be achieved.  Then County and other tax increases currently being foisted on non-homesteaded taxpayers will be redistributed among all.  At that time I expect there will be considerably greater backlash against current and future proposed budget increases. 

 

Yours sincerely,

 

David MacLean

7527 Preserves Court

Sarasota 34243

40% just to pay the tax.  It is quite possible that the rental increase will
cause a sharp reduction in occupancy.  In turn that reduction will cause me
personal economic problems, and the state of Florida will lose sales tax
revenue.  This is a douple loss, with probable ripple effect on businesses
that may fail or go away.

include a reasonable leveler to avoid the huge increase in a 'tax windfall'
and permit a gradual scale of both increase and decline.
5.  The properties were assessed at the peak of 2005 where land speculation
was rampant.  If the appraisals were done today, they would be far short of
the boom prices seen last year.  A 'shock absorber' provision must be made
for these unusual and short lived spikes in property prices.

property owners who don't live in their second homes, or investment
properties.  I submit that this is a discrimination against investment or
vacation property owners.
7.  Ultimately, the single property owner like myself (and thousands of
others) who were able to scrimp and buy a vacation home years ago are being
singled out and financially punished for their foresight.

anti-business appraisal system.  I hope that you will change your mind and
consider the consequences.  I won't be able to afford to keep my home in
Mexico Beach, and will be forced into selling the property.  That will also
punish me as the prices will have declined due to the tax inequity.  How can
you not be involved in correcting this situation?  The answer is you can't!

I respectfully ask that you find a way to give the thousands of us some
assistance.  If tourism is important to Florida, and I know it is, then this
situation must be fixed!
