Dear Jeb,
 
This is the first time that I have actually written to any government official. I was always taught not to put all your eggs into one basket, so I thought I would be pretty safe with a little diversity, but guess what, I'm not.  
 
Don't get me wrong, I realize that any business has to make a profit, or else they will cease to exist, but there is a problem with the insurance company's profit margins.  I'm sorry that they had a couple of years of high payouts, but as a whole, spread across the nation, they still profited.  It would be like me with my company deciding to charge double or triple to build a house or pool, just because next year may not be as profitable as I would like.  Of course it wouldn't work, because no one would ever use my services if they were so outrageously inflated.  That's the checks and balances of the general public, and those are the rules I have to live by.  It is those same balances that have compelled me to write to you.  People can make a decision on what product to buy, and whom to purchase it from when it is something that is a want, or a luxury item.  They can shop around and find someone they are happy with, and a price they can live with, because they have a choice, and they don't "have" to have the item.  The government, their bank, no one is forcing them to make the purchase.  On the other hand, taxes and insurance are "have toos"  the government forces taxes on land and value, and the government requires insurance on State Licensing.  Financial Institutions require Insurance on anything where they hold an interest.  I understand the need for all of the above, but as I stated before, If we cannot get away with gouging the public, and the public keeps us in check, then shame on you and the insurance companies, and we need to keep all of you in check.

Consumers did drive the property values up so high by being willing to pay the high prices of property, but government is not supposed to be a "for profit" business.  Government just needs to cover the cost of operating, and little cushion for "just in case."  We shouldn't have to make up now for money mistakes you made in the past.  Lower the current millage rates on property to the point where government can exist, not profit.  Also, check into the outrageous impact fees being charged, in Hernando County, we have over a $10,000.00 impact fee for building, where just 3 years ago, it was only $2,000.00 a little excessive hu?  Insurance companies shouldn't be allowed to write any type of policies in the State of Florida if they are not willing to take the risk for homeowners insurance.  Why should we reward them with high returns on Health, life, auto or any other type of policies if they are not willing to stick their necks out a little also.  Personally, my personal homeowners policy almost tripled this year, and there is no logical reason for this.  Put a percentage cap on the amount that an insurance company can raise premiums in a year.  I'm sure there are many more ways to regulate the amount they can gouge the public.  Insurance is not a choice for most people, it's a "have to."  The people in your state are getting to the point where they just won't be able to keep it all together.  They will either leave or loose everything, and that is just not the right solution.  
 
I promise to do my part in helping to keep the economy stimulated, can you promise to do yours?  
 
 
Sincerely,

From:	Marie Santana <msantana4@cfl.rr.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, September 26, 2006 6:50 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Nemour's Children's Hospital
Attachments:	sub-image.jpg

Governor Bush,
 
This is a letter to support the Nemours Children's Hospital to be located in Central Florida.  I am an Orange County Public School teacher and I feel that this hospital is truly a needed facility in our area.  Here are other important facts to consider:
 

Nemours Children's Hospital will bring a highly specialized, pediatric focused, endowed institution to Central Florida. 

The services and programs of Nemours Children's Hospital will focus on the chronically ill patient providing services not currently offered in this region and establishing a location where medically complex pediatric conditions can be treated in a single facility with one seamless system of care. 

This institution will be located on a children's health care campus that will support research, physician and health care worker education, and advocacy programs for children. Nemours Children's Hospital will be an economic driver offering high wage, high skill jobs and it will support the development of the region as a worldwide destination for health care. 

The Nemours health care system will treat all children, regardless of their economic station in life, with no restrictions on the type of the breadth and depth of treatment. Simply put, what our children need, they will receive. 

Growth Information: 

*	Florida’s pediatric population is growing rapidly and 10-15% of the children born in any given year will need specialized pediatric care. Moreover, that percentage is on the rise. 
*	By 2030, Florida will have the third largest pediatric population in the country (source: U.S. Census Bureau.) Between 2000 and 2030, Florida will gain more than 2 million children. This large and growing population needs access to the specialized services that Nemours will offer. 
*	The number of children admitted to a hospital in Central Florida grew by 37% in the past five years, from 11,684 admissions to 16,029; however, the number of pediatric hospital beds shrank by 24% during that time, from 328 beds to 249 beds. (source: Health Council of East Central Florida)

Economic Impact Information: 

*	Nemours has contributed more than $550 million to Central and North Florida since 1980 as evidence of its commitment to the children of Florida. 
*	There will be no fundraising or community contributions solicited to build this hospital. No tax dollars or government resources are required. 
*	Nemours has offered a gift to the Central Florida community that includes: 

*	$250-300 million capital investment in a top-tier children's hospital 
*	$30-40 million annual mission investment in a children's hospital (double the current mission investment in the existing Nemours Children's Clinic in Orlando) 
*	1,500 potential jobs with an economic impact of over $350 million in Central Florida 

*	Central Florida will have access to the Nemours Biomedical Research Program, ranked 13th in 2004 NIH funding among children’s hospitals. 
*	Today, there are presently 103 Nemours clinicians and 17 PhD lab heads involved in biomedical research programs. Those numbers would increase with a children’s hospital in Orlando. 
*	Nemours academicians produce almost 250 peer-reviewed contributions to journals, books and chapters annually. Nemours contributes several million dollars annually to the cost of the programs. 

Nemours children's health care system and hospital will serve as the catalyst for a broad-ranging advocacy program aimed at addressing issues affecting the quality of life and health status for children. Nemours will collaborate with other health care providers, community agencies, and related pediatric organizations to further pediatric advocacy. 

 

Thank you,

Marie Santana



From:	E. Robert Fraser <erfraser@aol.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, September 26, 2006 4:09 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Florida Property Tax Reform

E. Robert Fraser
4890 Coventry Court .... Grand Harbor
Vero Beach, FL 32967


September 26, 2006

The Honorable Jeb Bush
Governor of Florida
The Capitol, 400 S. Monroe St.
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001


Dear Governor Bush:

I attempted to send the following comments to your Committe for Florida 
Property Tax Reform ... but my comments were too long for its suggestion 
channel.  So, hopefully you will read and have delivered to your 
Committee.  Thanks.

Memo to:		Florida Property Tax Reform Committee

From:		E. Robert Fraser, Vero Beach, Florida    (772-                      
                     564-2698)

Date:		September 26, 2006

Re:	                     Improving property laws in Florida

I am a resident of Vero Beach, Florida and my residence qualifies for 
homestead exemption status.  I also own three other pieces of property in 
Florida, a rental/investment condominium in Indian River County, and two 
small vacant parcels of land on the Indian River in Brevard County.  My 
comments relate to the gross inequities existing in Florida’s property tax 
laws, in particular, the gross inequities caused by the 3% (or less) 
assessment cap on Florida “homestead” properties.  

Let’s say you own a vacant ½ acre parcel of land which has been appraised 
in 2006 for $500M.  Your neighbor’s ½ acre homestead property has been 
appraised for $1,500M.  And, let’s say the appraised values for both 
properties increased by 50% over the respective appraised values for 2005. 
 

As a result of the 3% annual assessment limitation for homestead 
properties, your neighbor’s property will be assessed for only 3% of its 
2005 assessed value.  However, your vacant parcel will be assessed for 
100% of its appraised value.  

Why the substantial difference in property tax obligations?  In 1992, an 
amendment to the Florida Constitution limited to 3% the amount the prior 
years tax assessment on a homestead status property could be increased.  
No such limitation was placed on increases in the assessment of properties 
which did not have homestead status.   

The 3% assessment cap on homestead properties may serve a legitimate 
social purpose for County residents who need financial assistance.  
However, should County homesteaders who do not require financial 
assistance be entitled to 3% assessment caps.   

Florida tax laws need to be amended so that all properties in Florida 
either do or do not have assessment caps.  If assessment caps are 
eliminated, there are other methods of furnishing tax relief to lower 
income property owners.  More importantly, if assessment caps are 
eliminated, voters with homesteads in their respective counties will have 
more incentive to demand that county officials be more accountable for 
budget increases for services and projects desired … but not needed by 
county residents.   

Florida’s tax laws as they apply to taxable properties are both arbitrary 
and unreasonable … resulting in gross inequities.  Vacant land property 
owners particularly are being financially raped as they receive virtually 
no benefit from the municipal services for which they are being taxed.  
There are constitutional issues which beg to be addressed, either by 
elected officials or by the courts.

…………………………………………………………..
Suggestion:   Eliminate assessment caps on all Florida properties … and 
authorize property tax exemptions in varying amounts dependent on income 
and net worth levels.

What affect will the above suggestion have on Florida communities?    
Among other affects, 
	- level out the tax obligations imposed on the various types of 
properties in Florida;
	-eliminate the gross inequities against non-homestead properties 
presently caused by existing laws;
	-allow the respective counties to determine to what extent tax relief 
should be granted to lower income/low net worth residents;
	-homesteaders (by reason of the fact that their assessments will be 
higher) will demand less discretionary projects and services from 
government authorities;
	-furnish residents owning homestead property with more incentive to 
challenge budgets with non-essential frills;
	-encourage  businesses to locate in areas where taxes are not heavily 
biased against business property;
	-eliminate the need for vacant property owners to liquidate their 
respective properties by reason of the unconscionable tax burden presently 
being imposed on such properties; and 
	-eliminate the need for landlords to substantially increase rents (to 
those not able to afford higher rents) by reason of the disproportionate 
tax increases on non homestead properties.

Why will my suggestion not be implemented?  It might be political suicide 
to foster legislation taking away from us homestead voters the 3% 
assessment cap.  It was a mistake to adopt this cap … and now might be a 
political nightmare to eliminate.  But it is the right thing to do.        
 

Sincerely,


E. Robert Fraser
772-564-2698

From:	Steve Allison <osbuck@cfl.rr.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, September 26, 2006 10:32 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	Steve AA-Allison
Subject:	 Tax reform solution

 
To:  Gov. Bush,
 
 

I have a plan for property tax reform for Florida that I would like to share:
 
1.) Roll back taxable property assessment values to 2002 levels.  To these values, add  cost-of-living increases for each year from 2002 to current year.  Then cap the new taxable property assessment value and only allow yearly cost-of-living increases.  One side effect of this, I would think, is that it would eliminate the need for the bulk of the County Property Appraisers budget, a savings to the taxpayers of Florida.
 
2.) Cap the millage rates for all municipalities at the October 1, 2006 level.
 
3.)  With items 1 and 2 mandated, the municipalities may go to the voters, by referendum, for any other millage increases they feel necessary for capital improvements or any other wants or needs.
 
4.)  Make this plan effective as of October 1, 2007.
 
I think both non-homesteaded and homesteaded residential homes should be capped.  I think new construction residential should pay their way thru impact fees that reflect the effect on the infrastructure.  Commercial real estate, in my opinion, should have a separate assessment system, and divided by type of business.
 
This plan will force all municipalities to roll back their spending to a more acceptable and fiscally responsible level and allow the voters of the State of Florida to decide if and when they want to raise their taxes and exactly what those increased tax dollars will be spent on.
 
Steve Allison
Volusia County Resident

Dear Governor Bush,
 
As you wind down your last term as Governor, you have the opportunity to deliver one more benefit to your constituents.
 
The offer from Nemours to build and provide operating expenses for a world class children's hospital in Orlando should get your very strong and very public support. The offer makes economic, development and humane sense.  And, it is entirely consistent with the public stances your administration has taken to bring Florida to a higher level in research, jobs and services to citizens.
 
The objections raised, primarily buy ORMC, reflect a "protectionist" mentality that says "this is my turf, and I do not want any 'outside' competitor opening for business here."  ORMC and Florida Hospital do provide "pretty good" services to the Central Florida community. And Florida, with the newly approved medical school at UCF, is investing to improve further the quality of service available to our fast growing communities.  Thank you!  But there is more that you can do: lobby actively for the approval and acceptance of this "gift" from Nemours.
 
The administrative process for insuring that hospitals do not "shoot themselves in the foot" by excessive expansion is a rational system, but it was set up to manage the 'normal' competitive excesses of providers, when their expansions ignored economic realities and let 'ego driven' plans endanger their long term viability. And, like all such administrative processes, it should 'flex' when a situation not originally contemplated arises.
 
Nemours' offer is just that case of an opportunity that the administrative system was not established to manage. Unfortunately, like most bureaucratic processes, the administrative system is not responding with flexibility.  The system is processing this offer as if it was a typical competition between ORMC and Florida Hospital over the number of beds for children.  It is not. This is a gift, from a world class institution, that can only make the entire system better,  through delivery of benchmark research and delivery services for children in Central Florida. It contributes to the 'cluster effect' for medical research, education and services that Florida needs and that your economic policies have supported.
 
You and other political leaders in Florida should advocate in favor of this gift, publicly and privately, in order to make the administrative process 'flex' in response to a unique and beneficial opportunity.


Best,

Don Saunders

HardMetrics, Inc.

From:	Jerry Banks <jerrybanks@cfl.rr.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, September 26, 2006 6:37 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Support for Nemours Children's Hospital

Dear Governor Bush,

Nemours Children's Hospital will bring a highly specialized, pediatric focused, endowed institution to Central Florida. 

The services and programs of Nemours Children's Hospital will focus on the chronically ill patient providing services not currently offered in this region and establishing a location where medically complex pediatric conditions can be treated in a single facility with one seamless system of care. 

This institution will be located on a children's health care campus that will support research, physician and health care worker education, and advocacy programs for children. Nemours Children's Hospital will be an economic driver offering high wage, high skill jobs and it will support the development of the region as a worldwide destination for health care. 

The Nemours health care system will treat all children, regardless of their economic station in life, with no restrictions on the type of the breadth and depth of treatment. Simply put, what our children need, they will receive. 

*       Florida’s pediatric population is growing rapidly and 10-15% of the children born in any given year will need specialized pediatric care. Moreover, that percentage is on the rise. 

*       By 2030, Florida will have the third largest pediatric population in the country (source: U.S. Census Bureau.) Between 2000 and 2030, Florida will gain more than 2 million children. This large and growing population needs access to the specialized services that Nemours will offer. 

*       The number of children admitted to a hospital in Central Florida grew by 37% in the past five years, from 11,684 admissions to 16,029; however, the number of pediatric hospital beds shrank by 24% during that time, from 328 beds to 249 beds. (source: Health Council of East Central Florida)

*       Nemours has contributed more than $550 million to Central and North Florida since 1980 as evidence of its commitment to the children of Florida. 

*       There will be no fundraising or community contributions solicited to build this hospital. No tax dollars or government resources are required. 

*       Nemours has offered a gift to the Central Florida community that includes: 

*       $250-300 million capital investment in a top-tier children's hospital 

*       $30-40 million annual mission investment in a children's hospital (double the current mission investment in the existing Nemours Children's Clinic in Orlando) 

*       1,500 potential jobs with an economic impact of over $350 million in Central Florida 

*       Central Florida will have access to the Nemours Biomedical Research Program, ranked 13th in 2004 NIH funding among children’s hospitals. 

*       Today, there are presently 103 Nemours clinicians and 17 PhD lab heads involved in biomedical research programs. Those numbers would increase with a children’s hospital in Orlando. 

*       Nemours academicians produce almost 250 peer-reviewed contributions to journals, books and chapters annually. Nemours contributes several million dollars annually to the cost of the programs. 

Nemours children's health care system and hospital will serve as the catalyst for a broad-ranging advocacy program aimed at addressing issues affecting the quality of life and health status for children. Nemours will collaborate with other health care providers, community agencies, and related pediatric organizations to further pediatric advocacy. 

Governor, please demonstrate your leadership by processing the approval of the Nemours hospital.

Respectfully,

 

Jerry Banks

From:	Daliah Drillmann <dldrill@internationalmedicallab.com>
Sent:	Monday, September 25, 2006 6:48 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush

 
September 26, 2006
 
Dear Governor Bush:

I am writing to alert you to a matter that is of enormous concern to my company. International Medical Laboratory is a medical reference lab, founded by myself and my husband, a local Bradenton physician in 1980. Since that time, we have grown to an organization employing more than 70 people from your constituency. We are asking for your assistance as not only our growth, but even our continued survival, is now in jeopardy due to the short-sighted and misleading policies pursued by insurance carriers in our state.

The policy to which I refer is the contracting of lab services to a single provider. This is contrary to a free market practice and contrary to the best interest of the patient, for whom choice and competition can only improve the level of service they receive. Interestingly, this single provider restriction is not placed on any other ancillary service, such as radiology. The insurance providers claim the interests of the patients are served by the economic benefit. However, if the Any-Willing-Provider rules requiring payment of the contracted rate to any provider willing to accept that rate were passed then this economic benefit would still be passed along to the patient. Repeatedly, the large insurance carriers, Aetna, Cigna and even the locally based Universal Healthcare have denied us the opportunity to become providers, despite our accreditation from the College of American Pathologists, the highest standard of accreditation in the industry and our willingness to accept their rate.

The government insurances are now following suit. The Medicaid RFP desired to restrict the entire Medicaid patient population to a single lab provider. The Medicare Competitive bidding project also threatens to eliminate small providers. This "Winner-take-all" style bid also denies participation to providers whose bids are not low enough. Again, there is no cost savings in this. It simply reduces patient choice. The same "lowest bid" fee that is paid to the winners could be paid to all Medicare providers, as is done with the current fee schedule.

Because we have no recourse to demand payment from the insurance carriers when patients go "out-of-network" and the insurance companies refuse to let us "in" the network, we have been not only unable to grow, as we have in the past, but have had a 30% drop in business due in large part to the confusion among Medicare Part D patients. As Medicare patients who had long been accustomed to using our services were moved to Part D plans, they were not informed that they were restricted in their choice of lab providers nor were most even aware that their new plan replaced their Medicare coverage. Consequently, they continued to use our services stating they were still covered by Medicare and we performed hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of testing for which we could not get reimbursed. The insurances felt they are not responsible for "out of network" charges and the patients feel they had been misled. Unfortunately, we are caught in the middle and remain unpaid.

Exclusive contracts between large national companies or even local ones are not in the best interest of patient care. Why should they be denied additional choices when we have the same accreditation and are willing to accept the same fees? We are a provider for United Healthcare and BlueCross/BlueShield. Yet restrictive and misleading programs, such as the "Hassle Free" local Medicare Part D Plan Universal Healthcare Medicare MasterPiece program have caused such disruption to physicians and patients, that our business is now in jeopardy. Piece by piece we have been restricted from doing business with one portion of our population after another - first HMO member, then PPO members with "exclusive contracts." Medicaid appeared to be next. Many Medicare members who moved to Medicare Part D were lost to us and now with the Competitive Bidding, traditional Medicare beneficiaries could be the final straw. 

We ask for your help in supporting legislation that would again level the playing field by allowing us to compete based on our merits and allow the patient to choose his provider based on the level of service he receives not on the arbitrary restrictions imposed by his insurance company.

I would welcome the opportunity to speak with you about this matter at anytime. I can be reached at (800) 288-1465. 

Sincerely,

 

Mrs. Inge Drillmann

President

From:	Warren Gillis <rmiche4@attglobal.net>
Sent:	Sunday, September 24, 2006 4:03 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Adjust existing Statutes to fix the property tax problem

I believe the problem is that taxpayers do not understand the property tax system and they do not act when they think things are going their way. The current lock-in crisis is nothing more than some of the Save Our Home Beneficiaries who have been telling snowbirds to stuff it, now complaining about the same property tax increases.
 
Adjust 200.065 to require Taxing Authorities tax communications [Notices, releases, etc.] contain the rolled back tax rate, the new tax rate, a change percentage, and a statement that the change is the result of their budget change. Put the burden on the TA's to tell their story with their facts, and make it obvious to the taxpayers they have an annual obligation in addition to paying the tax bill.
 
Adjust 193.155 by requiring the base SOH cap of 3%, to be reset every two years to maintain realism. The 3% is unrealistic when there is severe selling price inflation or deflation. Also, change the CPI from a single Florida standard, to local area standards for North, Central and South Florida. Between both changes, give the TA's a more realistic target for budget planning. 
 
If portability is on overwhelming political necessity, allow TA's to give portability exemptions that may be used only in their municipal jurisdiction. I do not think the sins of one TA ought to be ported to another TA.
 
I believe there is nothing wrong with a big tax increase or local exemptions if that is what the taxpayers want.  
 
Warren Gillis, 8330 NW 51 Manor, Coral Springs, Fl., 33067, 954-346-7313

should that initiative ever gets through snowbirds will again inherit all the shortfall...
 
 
Amendment drive seeks to add 'portability' to tax break
ORLANDO, (AP) -- Sept. 21, 2006 -- A county official who spearheaded a petition drive that gave homeowners a property tax break in 1992 announced plans Wednesday for another citizens initiative in 2008 to let taxpayers take that benefit with them if they move.
 
The proposal would add ''portability'' to the Florida Constitution's Save Our Homes amendment, said Lee County Property Appraiser Ken Wilkinson of Fort Myers.
 
He announced the new initiative during a meeting of Gov. Jeb Bush's Property Tax Reform Committee. The panel's tasks include making recommendations on how to resolve inequities that have resulted from Save Our Homes.
 
The new initiative is intended to address one of those. Under the existing amendment, homeowners lose their tax break if they move. Many homeowners have complained they feel trapped in their old homes.
 
Several measures were introduced in the Legislature earlier this year to let homeowners take the tax break with them but none were approved.
 
''As the Florida Legislature has not come forth with a viable solution, we have written another citizens initiative, which will allow Florida homesteaders the portability of some of the Save Our Homes savings if they move within Florida,'' Wilkinson said in a statement.
 
The amendment now caps property tax increases for homeowners at 3 percent per year or the percentage that the Consumer Price Index has gone up, whichever is less.
 
The new proposal would allow a resident to apply the cap to a new home anywhere in Florida, but it would be limited to the percentage of the old house's market value represented by its taxable value.
 
That means if a homeowner pays tax on only half of the market value of his old home, he also would pay half on the new home. The tax break, however, could not exceed $400,000 of assessed value.
 
Save Our Homes Portability, a not-for-profit corporation, has been formed to gather more than 600,000 signatures needed to get the proposal on the ballot.
 
Its directors include state Sen. Burt Saunders, R-Naples, who introduced one of the legislative measures. He said he will try again next year. If lawmakers agree to put something on the ballot that is satisfactory, the petition drive could be discontinued.

should that initiative ever gets through snowbirds will again inherit all the shortfall...
 
 
Amendment drive seeks to add 'portability' to tax break
ORLANDO, (AP) -- Sept. 21, 2006 -- A county official who spearheaded a petition drive that gave homeowners a property tax break in 1992 announced plans Wednesday for another citizens initiative in 2008 to let taxpayers take that benefit with them if they move.
 
The proposal would add ''portability'' to the Florida Constitution's Save Our Homes amendment, said Lee County Property Appraiser Ken Wilkinson of Fort Myers.
 
He announced the new initiative during a meeting of Gov. Jeb Bush's Property Tax Reform Committee. The panel's tasks include making recommendations on how to resolve inequities that have resulted from Save Our Homes.
 
The new initiative is intended to address one of those. Under the existing amendment, homeowners lose their tax break if they move. Many homeowners have complained they feel trapped in their old homes.
 
Several measures were introduced in the Legislature earlier this year to let homeowners take the tax break with them but none were approved.
 
''As the Florida Legislature has not come forth with a viable solution, we have written another citizens initiative, which will allow Florida homesteaders the portability of some of the Save Our Homes savings if they move within Florida,'' Wilkinson said in a statement.
 
The amendment now caps property tax increases for homeowners at 3 percent per year or the percentage that the Consumer Price Index has gone up, whichever is less.
 
The new proposal would allow a resident to apply the cap to a new home anywhere in Florida, but it would be limited to the percentage of the old house's market value represented by its taxable value.
 
That means if a homeowner pays tax on only half of the market value of his old home, he also would pay half on the new home. The tax break, however, could not exceed $400,000 of assessed value.
 
Save Our Homes Portability, a not-for-profit corporation, has been formed to gather more than 600,000 signatures needed to get the proposal on the ballot.
 
Its directors include state Sen. Burt Saunders, R-Naples, who introduced one of the legislative measures. He said he will try again next year. If lawmakers agree to put something on the ballot that is satisfactory, the petition drive could be discontinued.
 
 Copyright 2006 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.

From:	Steve Allison <osbuck@cfl.rr.com>
Sent:	Friday, September 22, 2006 6:12 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Tax reform plan

 
My name is Steve Allison, my address is 4648 Van Kleeck, New Smyrna Beach, Fl. 32169. Phone: 1-386-427-6431.  I would like to submit the letter below to you for consideration.  Thank you.
*******************************************************************
 

I have a plan for property tax reform for Florida that I would like to share:
 
1.) Roll back taxable property assessment values to 2002 levels.  To these values, add  cost-of-living increases for each year from 2002 to current year.  Then cap the new taxable property assessment value and only allow yearly cost-of-living increases.  One side effect of this, I would think, is that it would eliminate the need for the bulk of the County Property Appraisers budget, a savings to the taxpayers of Florida.
 
2.) Cap the millage rates for all municipalities at the October 1, 2006 level.
 
3.)  With items 1 and 2 mandated, the municipalities may go to the voters, by referendum, for any other millage increases they feel necessary for capital improvements or any other wants or needs.
 
4.)  Make this plan effective as of October 1, 2007.
 
This plan will force all municipalities to roll back their spending to a more acceptable and fiscally responsible level and allow the voters of the State of Florida to decide if and when they want to raise their taxes and exactly what those increased tax dollars will be spent on.
 
Steve Allison
Volusia County Resident

This issue may not seem as important as laws regarding stem cell research or oil drilling in the Gulf, but unlike those issues, this one would have an immediate direct impact on the lives of Floridians. In addition to allowing Floridians to move within the state, this law would have the added bonus of boosting residential construction and stimulating Florida's economy in general. 

 I know that I am not telling you anything that you do not already know. I am just trying to make my voice heard and hope that someone pays attention.

I thank you graciously for your time and I hope that you will give the priority to this issue that it deserves.

 

Sincerely,
James R. Paquette

Port Charlotte, FL

The following issue was taken from accountantsworld.com newswire:
Taxpayers in states without income taxes may lose federal tax break 
Knight Ridder Washington Bureau (KRT) via NewsEdge Corporation : 
Sep. 17--WASHINGTON -- Congress is rapidly running out of time to extend a tax break that has saved residents of eight states billions of dollars on their federal returns, says the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.
The Internal Revenue Service needs to submit this year's tax forms to the printers by Oct. 15. Congress is set to adjourn in roughly two weeks and, at the moment, there isn't even a bill moving forward that would again allow the residents of the eight states to deduct what they pay in state and local sales taxes on their federal returns.
The tax break expired at the beginning of 2006. If Congress does act to extend the sales tax deduction, it would be retroactive to cover the entire year.

From:	Flo Bradley <floaero@ewol.com>
Sent:	Sunday, September 17, 2006 6:16 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Florida: Taxes, Insusrance, and Homestead
Attachments:	scan Md taxes.pdf; scan Fl taxes.pdf

I hope someone in the Governer's office will read this email and actually do something for a change.  I would also like to hear that you received it and what you plan to do.  

 

I always heard Florida was the place to live.  Older people liked the weather and the low cost of living because they were on fixed incomes.  I acted on what I heard and moved to Florida after I retired.  What a mistake!  I am going broke.

 

Florida is more expensive to live than anywhere else I have lived.  The real estate taxes are double or more in Florida than I pay in Maryland where my property is 25 miles away from the White House and the U.S. Capital.  Florida’s state sales tax is also higher: 7% versus 5% in Maryland.  Yes, Maryland has a state income tax, but with that, the lower sales tax and the lower real estate taxes, it is much cheaper to live there than in Florida.  And, if nothing changes, I have no recourse but to leave Florida for that reason, as are many other people who moved to Florida with the false impression that their expenses would be less and they would be living in paradise.  Florida is not what it use to be.

 

TAXES:  I am paying taxes on my Florida lot for 2006 based on sales of 2005.  It is assessed at $230,736.  I couldn’t sell this lot for that much yet Florida Law determines how the real estate is assessed.  Florida's assessments are also full value and paid in arrears.  In Maryland, 2007 assessments that we pay real estate taxes on are half the value of the property and the taxes are paid in advance.  Maybe Florida needs a change to the law.  Other states don’t assess based on prior year sales and actual values.  That is totally unrealistic, especially when we all know that values were much higher in 2005 than they are in 2006.  We didn’t cause the real estate boom any more than we caused the crash.  Why should we pay taxes (which are way high anyway) on property that is not worth its assessment?    Florida is way out of line in this department.  My Maryland tax bill is attached to show that my property is worth $700,000 at least but the assessment is $304,273 and the taxes are $318.45 for 2007; the 2006 were less than this.

 

My children also have lots in Florida that are assessed for more than they could sell them, as I’m sure many others have. The Florida mileage rate or non-ad valorem taxes must be way out of proportion to other states.  For example, my property in Maryland (6 acres, spring, 5/3/3, 3600 SF, barn, shed, etc.) in the historic Zekia Swamp area (where John Wiles Booth’s leg was set by Dr Mudd), 25 miles from the White House, is appraised at $304,273 which is usually one-half it’s value..  My taxes are $3188.45 for the year because I’m only paying taxes on one-half the value.  That is about $10.00 per thousand.  My lot in Florida, 12,000sf, waterfront, 2800sf house, 4/2/2 is assessed at $236,983 and my taxes are $3183.45.  That is about $13.80 per thousand (copies of the tax bills are enclosed).  In addition, if there are other local taxes (e.g. sewer costs, emergency services, etc., that rate per thousand goes way up).  An example of a lot that is appraised at $83,271, taxes are $1,148.90 plus non-ad valorem of $678.30 makes the rate per thousand $22.00.  That lot won’t sell for $46,000 much less $83,000.  I know this because it’s my son’s lot.  Why?  I know for a fact that the Florida lots that are assessed at $236,983 in my area  are selling for about $150,000 if they sell at all.  What exactly is the State of Florida doing for the property owner?  How can we afford to pay the fees in this state? We can’t even sell them unless we take a significant loss.  It isn’t fair to pay taxes or take a loss on property that isn’t worth the assessment!

 

INSURANCE:  When it comes to insurance. Why can’t disaster expenses be distributed evenly across the US and all US property owners pay a premium that will cover another state in the event of a disaster.  All states have their own disasters:  California has fires, Louisiana has Katrina’s, the Mid West has tornadoes, many states have floods, many states have storm damage. Texas has floods, as do many other states.  There isn’t one state in the country that doesn’t have some sort of disaster that results in exorbitant insurance payouts from time to time.  Florida had hurricanes the last two years.  Prior to that there were no hurricanes for years.  It’s as though the insurance industry which is still in the black is justifying it’s rate increases on a state by state basis, when their profits are averaged out nation wide .  Insurance should not be based on each state’s disaster for that year.  It seems to me that equal distribution of premiums would make it possible for property owners to be able to afford to live where they currently live without fear of having to move because they can’t afford the insurance anymore.  Why isn’t this presented to the legislators? Why do Florida legislators keep granting increases to insurance companies.  My insurance in Maryland is $600 a year for a $700,000 house. Why?  We had a tornado several years ago. I would be happy to pay $700.00 a year for insurance.  It would affect my payment up there by $58.00 - big deal.  It is time for this issue to become Federal!  NO ONE can predict when and where  a disaster is going to hit.  And when it does, guess what, the state citizens are penalized with outrageous premiums. 

 

STATE/COUNTY FEES:  The processes and the fees charged in this state are also ridiculous: impact fees, inspection fees, permitting, unnecessary government employees, constant rate increases, city water/sewer (whether you use it or not), construction and other permits, to name a very few.  I recently built a dock that cost $4,000.  The permit fees were $700.00.  Don’t you think that is a little exorbitant?  The permit fees were almost one-fourth the cost of the dock!  I got a residential construction permit for $200.00 to build a whole house.  But, by the time I was finished construction, my county/state fees were more than $20,000.00.  Give me a break.

 

HOMESTEAD:  The Homestead or Save a Home program in Florida is a joke.  God forbid that you want to move within Florida once you get here.  You will get clobbered with new taxes.  So, as long as you moved to Florida more than 7 years ago, bought a reasonable costing house, and will never move again, you’re OK – don’t try to better yourself and improve your living conditions, you get penalized for that also.  What kind of program is that?  A home doesn’t last forever.  Or it gets clobbered by a hurricane, is unrepairable, there maybe is no home insurance because you can’t afford it, so the person has to move.  To add insult to injury, the state hits the homeowner with a huge tax bill along with unrealistic home insurance, that most homes don’t even need.  In some cases, homes require flood insurance where it never floods.   Is Florida deliberately trying to force its residents to leave?  Money may not be important to the legislator’s but it is to the average citizen.  We can’t afford to live here anymore.

 

All of this is resulting in making Florida a very bad place to live.  Those who like it are those who have the money to afford it or have been here so long they have low costs because they bought years ago and homesteaded their property – but they will still get hit with exorbitant insurance premiums.  Hopefully they will never have to move or then they would also have to leave the state.   I am not poor but Florida is making me poor.  

 

Because of the foregoing, I really have to leave Florida as soon as I can get rid of my real estate which I will have to sell for a lot less than the assessment.  If I do, I could never come back and I would discourage anyone from moving to Florida unless there are some serious changes in this state.  As it is now, only the rich could move here.  Is that what you want?

 

Can you tell me if the Florida government is aware of these issues and if there is any consideration towards making this state more affordable for the average citizen?  I also would rather not receive one of those standardized response letters that says nothing, e.g. “we are aware and are working on these issues………” etc.  How about some answers for a change.  I would welcome an opportunity to participate in any remedial actions.

 

Sincerely

 

 

 

Florence H Bradley

Each year my lot rent is increased, in addition to the "pass-on" tax, when the owner receives the ad valorem tax on his property.

I feel that real estate taxes should be paid for by the person who owns the real estate, and not be passed on to the person renting the property. I own a mobile home and am responsible for "my" taxes, and feel that the park owner should be responsible for "his" taxes.

Most senior citizens are on a fixed income, and with the  continued increase in food, gasoline, prescriptions and insurance on our property (due to hurricanes), many have difficulty paying for medicine and food, as well as facing increases in food, gasoline and insurance. From:	Jim Mastro <ja_mastro@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Saturday, September 16, 2006 7:35 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Property Tax Solution Ideas

I guess some of the ideas I have below have been throught of already, but maybe there's one that's new.

1)  Increase the Homestead exemption to 1990 levels.  

This idea comes from my general philosophy that all laws should be required to have a time-component in them.   Saying that any decision is outside of the time-domain is rediculous, but we do it every day at all levels of government.  Clearly, $25,000 in 1990 dollars (I hope I have the year right), is not the same today.  The "intention" of the law was to offer an equivalent homestead exemption - by today I think the number is about $100,000.  But whatever the number is, it should be calculated exactly and fairly using the rate of inflation of real estate values only.  In other words, food, gas and other commodities that have nothing to do with real estate inflation should not be considered.

2)  Tax only the land

I recently calculated the cost of my taxes over the lifetime of the house I just built.  The amount of taxes paid at 3% increase per year comes to 2.5 Billion dollars.  This number defies logic.  It certainly makes me feel silly standing in Lowe's deciding between the $80 tub-filler vs. $120 one.  In fact, my first impression when I did this calculation was to say to myself - "who really owns this property".  I think the number is so great that it really begs for that question to be answered.  To satisfy myself, I decided that the "land" was really the juridiction's.  It was made by God and can not be moved.  If I choose to improve it, then I implicitly accept the fact that the land can not be moved, destroyed, etc.

3)  Tax according to improvement lifetime

If #2 above is to far of a politcal stretch, then at least r/e taxes based on improvements shoudl be inversely proportional to the lifetime of the structure.  For example, in my case I built my own house as an owner-builder.   As such I wanted a robust structure.  I heard once that the insurance industry has roughly 3 classes of building lifetimes - 100 year, 200 year and Permanent Building construction.  100 year is "stick-framed", 200 year is block built and PBC is basically poured concrete and/or stone.  In my house I fully poured concrete in all the block walls.   Naturally concrete is "incomplete" without its steel partner, so I put 2 miles of rebar in the wall first.  The whole thing cost me about $3,000 extra - well worth it.  I figure my building is 300 year construction.  But now I'm being charged extra taxes on my better structure - go figure.  So, if I build a wood shack that'll stand for 50 years, it'll be cheaper to construct, cost less in taxes and ultimately be worth far less to the county.  I think it's obvious what's wrong with this equation. 

4)  Owner-Builders should be part of the protected SOH class from the time they break ground

When I bought my land in 1998 and started construction as an owner-builder, I estimated my cost to build at $135,000 - a number that was about 50% higher than the average in my area, but my house was very large (over 6000sf).  Anyway, as an owner-builder I'm excluded from the contractor licensing laws under very stringent conditions.  Most notable are that I must be present during construction and that I must occupy the property when completed.  The first requirement caused me to take 6 years to build the house.  In my mind this timeframe is quite reasonable given the labor input to size of building ratio I was dealing with.  (Think about building a skyscraper.  Even with a large crew, it takes many years because the project is big. Also, BTW, the buidling code does not set time limits on construction because it is generally not structurally unsound to take time to build. The fact that I had to renew my 2 year permit 3 times has more to do with the convenience of the county not having to track my paperwork.)  The second constraint - that I live in my house once  built - comes from the rationale that we don't want unlicensed contractors to act as owner-builders in name only.  So, in effect, I became a stakeholder in my homesteading from the start of my construction.  To me, the date that I started construction should be the one used by the appraiser's office for valuation.  Naturally, I'd expect a 3% yearly rise from that point, but that number would be far less than the $600,000 that the appraiser's office came up with when I finally was done and the "clock stopped".  Adding insult to injury, I moved in on Oct 1, 2004, but the clock was not stopped until Jan 1, 2005 - at a timeframe when r/e values were rising at 3% per month. 

5)  An overall cap of 10% for all assessable value taxes

Whether it be a business, SOH, greenbelt or otherwise, the limit should be 10%.  Now, I can't fault the wisdom of those in 1990 for not including this in, because what's happened to r/e values in the past 3-5 years is un precedented, six-sigma, etc.  And will probably never happen again.  But let's protect ourselves now that we're a bit smarter.  Now naturally, this just simply creates a "potential" tax in the same way that SOH works.  In other words, the "assessed" value can (and will) eventually meet the "just" value.  It will simply be meted out over a slightly longer time in the case of fantastic increases in values.  In fact, I think this should be made retroactive and any excessed returned to those who paid it in the form of future credits.  I know this is a tough calculation, but -hey- we have computers nowadays.

6)  DONT allow transfer of SOH to newly purchased property.  

First of all I think this ideas goes against the grain of the purpose of SOH - to protect us in our older, flat-income days.  Anyone trading homes shouldn't have this protection.  If trading up - I don't have sympathy.  If trading down - the profit from the house should ease the pain.  But, the biggest reason I don't like this is because it even more so creates a dichotomy in our society  - those that lived/bought here before the "great inflation", and those after.  The only way I can support this is if there's a rollback in time/prices to equate all of us on this playing field.  Otherwise there will be this group of "gap" people that bought just at the peak because they reacted faster than the government to plug the leak.  It's bad enough that we suffer the (unavoidable) slowness of government's reaction, but when it does react it must act fairly.
 
7)  Tax based NOT on r/e values

I really think that the intention of government is to be fair.  When the idea of taxing citizenry based on r/e values was invented (hundreds/thousands of) years ago, there were no computers/accounting/visibility/communication like we have nowadays.  Now we can much more clearly say what the cost of each citizen is on the jurisdiction they live in.  For instance, some people have children in school - some do not.  Some people drive big trucks that wear the roads down a little faster.  Some use water/energy more, pollute more, etc.  In other words. what someone pays can quite easily today be assessed according to their direct costs.  Again, we are in a computer age.  Let's start using them as a tool to create a fairer society. 

Anyway, this was a long letter, and I'm sure you're a busy man.  Perhaps, if I'm lucky this letter will get read by one of your assistants, and if I've done my job well enough will spark interest.


Thanks,
Jim Mastro

From:	Rita Griffin <dinogrl7@houston.rr.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, September 13, 2006 11:24 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	Rose
Subject:	URGENT!!  REQUEST a Bay County Tax RollBack and reasonable cap, from a life-long Republican
Attachments:	Tom Neubauer letter.pdf

Governor Bush:
 
This petition is to request a Bay County Tax Rollback for those of us who own property in Bay County but have no homestead exemption or 3% Tax Cap.  My family home is in Parker FL (Bay County).  The home, which remains in our family, was built in 1959 by my mother, also a life-long Republican who worked at the Bay Republican Party for your father, your brother and your election to public office.  Since my father's death, my sister and I have rented our house out and hope to return to our home in FL one day. However, the excessive tax appraisal on our property may make that impossible.  Last year, our house and land was assessed at $135,667; this year the appraised value of our property was $340,710, a 251% tax increase in one year. Will such property tax increases continue? Because our house is older, even though we maintain it, we are able to rent it out for only $1,000 a month. 
 
I drove from Houston, TX to the Bay County Appraisers' office to hear Rick Barnett say on Monday he and a group of appraisers would meet with you later this week to request a tax rollback for those of us who will suffer from such a huge tax assessment in one year.  Even with a tax adjustment, my appraised value is still at $319, 873. Like others in Bay County, my sister and I understand waterfront property will continue to go up in value and have never protested any assessment before even as our property taxes have increased.  And we realize property taxes are needed for infrastructure development and education.  But we believe a land value assessment based on averaging the sales of properties in Bay County when a developer "buying boom" occurred in 2005 coupled with the current stagnated real estate market in our Parker area is a grossly unjust way to assess property taxes on small landowners. Because high density condominium development in Bay County has led to real estate stagnation, the assessed value of our property is greater than the selling price we could get for our property if we had to sell it.  I am attaching a letter from our realtor who corroborates this, given the bay area where our property is located which is not like the lush developed Panama City Beach area.
 
We have been good citizens and taxpayers, caring for our property until we can return home.  My sister and I have been life-long Republicans, believing campaign rhetoric that the GOP and its party leaders opposed excessive taxes.  We also do not want to believe, as some suggest, the higher taxes assessed on those who have no homestead exemptions are a way to force those who own single-family dwellings along the water to sell cheaply to developers who in turn will over develop the waterfront area reaping huge profits and ruining the environment we wish to protect.  Nor, do we wish to believe, as others suggest, the planned meeting between you and Rick Barnett is just a ruse, a political means to deflect taxpayer anger without any real relief.  THEREFORE, we request you grant a Bay County property tax rollback and set a reasonable cap for those owning single-family dwellings along the water. Thus, we ask for your help.  Respectfully,  Rita Benoit Griffin, Houston, TX (also for Rose Brodersen, Rosamond, CA)
From:	Richard Craparo <rcraparo@earthlink.net>
Sent:	Wednesday, September 13, 2006 10:35 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Okaloosa County Property Tax

Dear Governor Bush,
MANY people in Northwest Florida are VERY concerned about the rising property taxes.  They are entirely out of hand this year...especially in Okaloosa county.  We have lived here many years  and this is the first year that we have felt compelled to follow through with the suggestions on the TRIM notice.  I went to all the meetings and I have to say it was one of the most depressing ordeals I have been through.  There were many speakers and much of what I heard compelled me to write you.  MANY people have already left Florida for Alabama....and many more are planning to. A doctor in Okaloosa county can no longer afford her property taxes and plans to leave.  So, this is having an impact  on all economic groups.   And a great deal of them are folks who have lived here all their lives.  One man spoke in very broken English that in all his travels and the many places he has lived he has never seen anything like it....not Russia...not China, etc.  (This embarrassed me...and I had nothing to do with it!)  These high prices are REALLY affecting people's lives.....not to mention the detrimental effects it  will have on the economy.  People do not want to invest here any longer.  Many will not be able to work in the area  because they can not afford it.  One woman spoke to the fact that even though she had applied for the homestead exemption,  it will not go into effect till next year... and this year her property value increased at a rate much higher than her neighbors who had comparable houses.  She could only conclude that hers was artificially increased before her exemption goes into effect. (She did say she filed  an appeal, but it worries me for people who do not know to do this.)  Another person was going to have to take out a loan to pay property taxes.  (They went up so much last year that he figured it had probably "topped out".) And to make matters worse...it seems that none of the taxing authorities ever  have enough money to do all the things they need to do.  This gets soooo old and is very hard to hear when many people spend more on taxes than they do on their own families!!  Over the years we have paid property taxes in several counties and, for some reason that I do not understand,   Okaloosa county has always seemed unnecessarily high.  Sometimes it boggles the mind as to what is done with that much money!  One thing that became painfully obvious...we have all financed enough layers of taxing bodies that it is very easy for them to "pass the buck" to a different body!  The blame bounced all over Okaloosa county...then branched out to other counties...it even bounced all the way to Tallahassee!  That seems to be a problem of our society...a lack of personal responsibility.  And many of the things we are financing stem from the fact that government attempts to help all the people who do not take any personal responsibility themselves!!  I do not know the answer, but perhaps they are simply trying to finance some things that would be best if left alone.  I am sure that all these people have good intentions and maybe just do not fully realize the cumulative damage that is being done.
I could go on, but I will spare you.  I am writing to let you know that we need help in Okaloosa County (and perhaps in other Northwest Florida counties).  Something needs to be done to decrease the amount owed...and it needs to be done across the board.  It needs to be done for ALL types of properties...on an equal and fair basis ... that does not pit one group of people against another.  It also needs to be done THIS taxing year.  Too many people are just not able to afford it.   This has a very bad ripple effect that ends up hurting us all!!  We all hope that you can maybe call a special meeting soon to address these problems for this year...and the years that follow.  We would all certainly appreciate your help with this!
Thank you for your help with this matter...and THANK YOU for being our governor!
 
 
Sincerely,
Judy Craparo
 
 
Richard Craparo
rcraparo@earthlink.net
 

From:	Kim Sedor <kim.sedor@sa3.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Wednesday, September 13, 2006 7:28 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush; argenziano.nancy.web@flsenate.gov; speaker@myfloridahouse.gov; Jerry Blair

To The Representatives of the People of the State of Florida:

 

I currently serve as an Assistant State Attorney in the third judicial circuit of Florida.  I love what I do and I believe with all my heart that I have the greatest job in the world.  As an Assistant State Attorney I also represent the people of the State of Florida.  Every time that I try a case, I make certain that my jury knows that I am prosecuting the defendant on behalf of the “People of the State of Florida.”   However, Assistant State Attorneys are so much more than "Prosecutors"; we are the gatekeepers of the judicial system.  Without us, many innocent people would be prosecuted and many guilty people would go free.  Law enforcement officers generally do the best that they can, but they are not lawyers.  They do not always understand elements of crimes or burdens of proof.    In small communities, the only source of guidance that most of these officers have is from their Assistant State Attorney.  How sad it is that ASAs who have the knowledge and experience to guide these officers, often cannot afford to continue in the positions they love.  In many cases, ASAs must choose between paying their student loans and paying their rent (typically rent because they seldom can afford to buy a house.)  

A senior prosecutor once told me that he could teach a monkey to try a case, but he could never teach a prosecutor to have good judgment.  Unfortunately, the prosecutors with good judgment cannot usually afford to stay.  An experienced prosecutor with good judgment is a commodity that is fast fading from today’s courtroom and the result will ultimately be disastrous.  How will the innocent victim of a brutal rape be able to place their confidence in the prosecutor fresh out of law school whose only experience is the mock trial team?  How will the beautiful young woman with the hideous scar across her face feel when she finds out that the ASA prosecuting the person who slashed her face, over a parking place, has never tried a felony case before? How will the American public feel when the child molester goes free because the ASA on the case  was transferred from county traffic court to felony because the experienced felony prosecutor just couldn't afford to stay?  We all know how they will feel...now what to do about it.  

CLEARLY, WE MUST INCREASE THE STARTING SALARIES AND ADJUST THE SALARIES OF THE VETERAN ASAs IN COMPARABLE AMOUNTS AND WE MUST IMPLEMENT A STUDENT LOAN FORGIVENESS PLAN.  ADDITIONALLY, ANYTHING LESS THAN HIGH RISK RETIREMENT FOR ASAs IS ABSURD.  

ASAs are on the front line every time they walk into the courtroom.  ASAs stand in courtrooms packed with family and friends of defendants and demand...or at least urge...judges to take away the freedom of defendants.  We argue cases to juries and explain to them why the defendant's account of the events just does not make sense.  We point out every admissible flaw in a defendant's story and in their character and we boldly assert the need to imprison them for their wrongs.  And we do this unarmed and in full view of anyone who decides to come to court that day.  We do this with our backs to the audience and our attention on the job at hand.  The officer on the street is no longer the enemy; all he did was catch them.  The Judge is forgiven because he/she would not have sentenced the defendant to prison if that awful Prosecutor had not said all those terrible things about the defendant.  Suddenly the ASA is the one at fault.  They have special names for most of us at the local jails!  We don't wear robes and we don't have bailiffs.  We don't wear guns on our belts and we can't bring our guns into the courtroom but we do stand up and fight for what we believe is the "just" outcome!  For this, we don't qualify for high-risk retirement!?!?!

What the legislature does not seem to understand is that many ASAs are out banging on the doors of victims and witnesses while preparing for trials.  We follow up on information provided to us and often find ourselves knocking on the doors of former (and sometimes current) defendants looking for a witness or victim in our case.  Some agencies have investigators for these purposes but often the follow up needs to be done and the investigator is simply not available.  ASAs get up in the middle of the night and go out to crime scenes and they trudge down to the office to assist with search warrants as needed.  Again, for this we don't qualify for high-risk retirement?!?!

Stop and think about it, if you were truly convinced that your loved one was being unfairly prosecuted and you sat through a trial listening to the ASA tell how everything was your loved ones fault and pointing out every reason that your loved one was guilty, then you had to hear a closing argument that was good enough to convince a jury to convict your loved one...and finally you listened as some stranger argued passionately enough about your loved one to get them sentenced to life in prison....WHO WOULD YOU BLAME?  WHO WOULD YOU AIM BOTH YOUR ANGER AND POSSIBLY YOUR WEAPON AT...it would be the ASA.  High risk is not only justified, it is ESSENTIAL. 

NOW HOW DO WE FUND IT?  HOW DO WE KEEP OUR SEASONED ASAs?  There is a $40.00 public defender application fee in cases where defendants seek to have the public defender appointed.  There are costs assessed when the public defender or appointed counsel are assigned to represent a defendant, why not do the same with prosecution?  

I propose that we simply add a cost of prosecution fee to each and every criminal case, not just those that go to trial, but to all cases:  Criminal Traffic, $50.00 per case, Misdemeanor, $100.00 per case, and Felonies, $250.00 per case.   

Assess this fee across the board and earmark the funds for ASA salaries and student loan repayment plans.  .  Make the criminals pay to retain the experienced Assistant State Attorneys and keep the experienced ASAs around to see that inexperience due to inadequate salaries does not result in criminals going free.  This would minimize the state's contribution to funding, provide adequate salaries for Assistant State Attorneys and provide for experienced, competent prosecution of criminal cases in the State of  Florida.  We are not seeking a handout, just a hand up.  

 

Sincerely,

 

KIMBERLY G. SHELLEY SEDOR

Assistant State Attorney

Third Judicial Circuit

P. O. Box 1546

Live Oak, FL  32064

(386) 362-2320

Many of our trades people are here for specific jobs such as the Rework of Malfunction Junction (now in its 40th year); the construction of New Homes, New Office Buildings, New Roads and Streets in Developments, and in the Repair of Hurricane Damage, etc.  Some of the trades go "back home" but soon return because "back home" winter time work is not as remunerative as Florida work.
 
Some of my golfing friends suggested sending these folks to Plant City, but the "Holding on to Hometown" article on the same page as your column indicates this is soon not going to be an alternative.
 
When I came to Tampa in 1963, Clair Mel City was well underway as a home for people who are in need of this type of housing.  Progress Village soon became a similar community.  These homes were built under the FHA 235 Program (or other such FHA Programs).  Where is our FHA 235 Program for Hillsborough County or any other Florida County today?

I am not sure if we have enough Subsidized Housing, but I know we do not NOW have enough housing for our Blue Collar Workers. Thank you for allowing me to vent!  Hopefully, I will see a column on this sometime.
 

Daniel F. Moore

Governor Jeb Bush

Dear Governor Bush,

I have owned a rental condo in Palm Bay FL since the mid-1980's.  It was
severely damaged and left uninhabitable by Hurricane Jeanne in late
2004.  Since then I have been having it repaired, with the intent to use
the rent from it to supplement my pension and Social Security after I
retire.

Despite the fact that it was not - and still is not - habitable, the
Brevard County Tax Assessor levied a 45% property tax increase on it
last year, and I was recently notified that they will be increasing the
property tax on it by another 29% this year.  My calls to the local tax
assessor's office to discuss my situation were fruitless.  Since I will
be losing money on it due to these new taxes even after it is repaired
and rentable, I am now forced to sell it and invest my money in another
state.

I was planning to move to Florida later this year after I retire from
the Boeing Company in California.  I love Florida and I always thought
of it as a retiree-friendly state that had a lot to offer.   However,
due to the out-of-control property taxing authorities in your state I
now realize that moving to Florida is no longer feasible for me.  In
addition to needing my condo's rental income to supplement my Boeing
pension and Social Security, I need to live in a state where property
taxes on my primary residence are reasonable and stable.  Obviously this
is no longer the case in Florida, or at least in Brevard County.

What is ironic in all this is that I suspect I am the kind of person you
would want to come to Florida and invest in Florida's economy.  I was
going to purchase a new house there with the equity from my home in
California. I would have bought furniture, appliances, autos, paid sales
taxes and property taxes and at the same time used relatively few state
services.  I have full medical insurance from Boeing, and no children to
use your schools and libraries.  I likely would have injected several
million dollars into Florida's economy and tens of thousands of tax
dollars into your state treasury over the remainder of my lifetime.  

I realize you do not control property taxes, and I am sure this is not
the first time you have heard a story like this, but hopefully if enough
taxpayers address this issue something may be done about it, although it
will be too late for me.

Sincerely,

Jim Felicita
8541 Kelso Drive				
Huntington Beach
CA 92646

(714) 968-6743

cc:  Rod Northcutt, Brevard County Tax Assessor

Dear Mr. Somers:


Thank you for your email. Your sentiments were shared by many Pinellas
County residents at last Thursday's County Commission public hearing on the
2006-07 budget. Although I was required to attend a canvassing board meeting
that evening (due to a mandatory vote recount), I did view much of the
County Commission hearing via streaming video. As is always the case, Vice
Chairman Duncan and the Commission listened to the issues and concerns
expressed by the public.

Please be assured that your County Commission is very concerned with
developing real solutions to the tax inequities that are affecting
non-homesteaded property owners. At the conclusion of the public hearing,
the Commission asked staff to bring back options for further reducing our
millage, beyond the 3% millage reduction that was recommended in the
tentative millage and budget. I anticipate that the Commission will pass a
significantly reduced budget at our final public hearing on September 19th.

It is worth repeating Vice Chairman Duncan's statement that regardless of
which option the Commission chooses, we can only address a fraction of the
tax, valuation and insurance crisis that is affecting property owners
throughout the state. We will need your continued, passionate advocacy, at
both the local and state levels. As we move through this election season, it
is imperative that you advocate your position to other taxing authorities
(municipalities, school board, etc.), candidates and elected State
legislators, and candidates for Governor. The County Commission is committed
to being part of the solution, but we can only provide a partial solution
through millage reductions.

Thanks for sharing your thoughts with the Board of County Commissioners. We
are listening.

Ken



Commissioner Kenneth T. Welch
Pinellas County Commission Chairman

message_text Commissioners,

I have to complain vehemently about your proposed increases in property tax
millage rates for the coming year.  Per your figures the budget is
increasing by 11.78%, but my taxes (without millage changes) are going up
45% this year alone and it was substantial last year as well.  Something is
wrong with this picture.  My taxes have doubled since 2004 and my property
value has gone down.  The PCPAO is completely clued out asleep at their
desks as this takes place assessing homes they have never even seen using
real estate sales as a benchmark!  How absolutely stupid could they be!
Surely the millage rates should be adjusting downward, to reflect the
counties increasing collections due to our growing property values, not up
to be spent on additional projects.


I absolutely emplore you to reconsider your actions.  You are literally
running people out of their homes and it is spiteful.


Background info that set me off in this direction:

Per a recent St Pete Times article 8/19/06:

"Property insurance rates doubling. Gas prices topping $3 a gallon. Trash
bills, water bills, electric bills - all going up.

Whatever it is, it seems to cost more these days.

Don't expect your local government to help.

Cities, counties and school boards across Tampa Bay are using your money to
grow at record rates, sucking in huge increases in property tax revenues and
in return offering only marginal cuts to the tax rate, if any.

It has become a shrewd political maneuver in this era of robust property
growth. Politicians can tout new parks or libraries and cut your tax rate.
But the bottom line is, you're paying more. Much more.

Since 2001, the size of local government across the area has nearly doubled.
Five years ago, the city of Tampa took in $97.7-million in property tax
revenues. This year, it expects to collect $167.7-million, an increase of
almost 72 percent. The city of Clearwater's property tax revenues
skyrocketed 85 percent in the same time.

With all that extra money, what did you get?"

"People live on a budget. And when the budget gets tight, people have to
tighten their belt," said Hillsborough County Commissioner Brian Blair, who
has pushed his government for substantial spending cuts. "Government should
be no different. But for some reason, it plays by different rules."

You cannot seem to get the concept of taxation and appropriate
representation correct.  You have policies in place such as homestead and
save our homes that protect some homeowners but not others.  Policies that
cap increases in valuation at 3 percent or inflation whichever works best
for you for some homeowners but not others.  This is all very bad business
for a region that is changing it's demographics and a County Commission that
is completely and utterly asleep at the switch.  In case you hadn't noticed
this is not a retirement locale only anymore and has not been few several
years.  Corporations would like to locate here and know that the County
knows how to construct a road (not like mal-function junction the laughing
item of the entire civil engineering community or US19 between Gulf to Bay
and Tampa Road) , build schools where appropriate and implement fair and
equitable taxation by representation schemes.

I have contacted the Attorney General of The State of Florida to look into
the absolutely scandalous activities  with respect to property taxes,
valuation and millage in this county. We are not happy with you today at
all.

From: cberthoin
