Cc: Tippen.davidson@news-jrnl.com ; MorganG@co.volusia.fl.us ; jeb.bush@myflorida.com 

Sent: Saturday, September 02, 2006 5:02 PM

 

Dear Governor, Representatives, Senators, local Officials, Property Appraisers, and Media

 

Subject: SOH Amendment needs to be accelerated, and for this broken down in SEPARATE amendments as well as possible additional EXECUTIVE ORDERS from the Governor so as to take effect in 2007 (possibly even in 2006 for a certain group) as Florida can’t wait for 2008!

 

Following the recent show of the “Tax Coalition” last Thursday in the Volusia County chamber, it is clear that the train for Tax Reform is in full motion.  However, the proposed county budget is only one piece of the equation; the other main component to our tax bill computation is our Assessed Values.  The way Assessed Values are computed, allowing huge discount from Just Values to some and not to others, is a system that is flawed, unfair to many, and finally being exposed to the public.  The veil of the old “secrecy” has been pierced and neighbors now compare their tax bills thanks to the internet and readily available access to county Tax Rolls.  The system needs to and will be changed.  While this is also being addressed now by various Bills in the House and Senate, and the duty of the recently appointed Property Tax Reform Committee, most of the public is not aware of the problems and what is being proposed by various Senators and Representatives.  More importantly the public is unaware that the process of change may not take place until 2008!  So, WE FACE TWO MORE YEARS OF HEAVY TAXATION unless both the Mileage drops and the Assessed Values are rectified to many.

 

This is a subject that is not widely understood and very much of actuality.  I dare to say that nothing is more important at the moment for Florida than to maintain the "liquidity" of its Real Estate.   With the current and increased struggle Florida residents are having with their property taxes, home insurance, and hurricane prevention expenditures over the past 2 years, the News Journal and other Medias need to inform objectively, positively, and effectively about the ongoing battle and efforts to reform Property taxes.  The needs to make Real Estate Property Taxes equitable, and more importantly, ease up Real Estate Taxes for families moving their homestead within the State have been recently pointed out by the governor in his Executive Order number 06-141 dated June 21,2006.  I am glad to see that the right of all Florida residents to pay fair taxes is finally recognized and addressed at the top level.  The governor points out among other issues the current imbalance, discrimination, and special needs of first time Homeowners.  But as far as Homestaeders moving within Florida, this matter should be TO PRIORITY as the injustice hurts these groups the most.  Additionally, thousands of Florida residents are trapped into their homes as they can not SELL them

 

Florida can't simply wait till Dec 1, 2007 to grant RELIEF to that SPECIFIC group!  

 

Please read on, but first check this link for the actual text of the order and info about the commission: http://www.propertytaxreform.state.fl.us/default.htm

 

Others like me involved in Real Estate and who understands the issues at stake, we are "sounding the alarm"!  We can't wait until Dec 1. 2007 for the recently appointed commission by the governor to report "its findings and make suggestions".  This is not a complicated matter like some conservative politicians make it appear. 

 

The Real Solution is to isolate the three main issues being looked into namely "making Real Estate Taxes equitable between neighbors", "Tax abatement for first time homebuyers" and "portability for Floridians who wish to move their homestead" and look at them individually and take care of them separately!  Each should be the subject of its own amendment.  

 

The portability issue for example is easy to deal with.  A positive change would immediately "defrost" the market and should therefore be top priority.   Because it is the lack of portability, second only to the first time homebuyer issue that puts strains on the market by preventing homeowners to sell their homes. There is a simple solution to the problem like allowing people with homestead to move to a different property and carry with them the RATIO between "Just" and "Assessed", a measure of the break they have earned over the years.  Since most people move to a home of higher value when they move, their tax bill will be higher than at the previous location and ultimately there is no loss of revenue to the counties.  The Status Quo is intolerable for Florida Homesteaders "on the move" that are currently discriminated against and "trapped" into their homes.  This, because the proposed tax bill at a new location can go up as much as 5 times as the one at the previous home.   For example, a family moving from a $200K home where they lived in the past 5 years, and where the current RE Taxes may be as low as $2,000 face a huge dilemma.  This is because their "Assessed value" was capped at 3% at their location from a low assessment of say $100K at time of purchase.  But, if that same family acquires a home in the $300K to the $350K range (pretty much the norm these days), then the new bill is $7,500 due to the loss of the discount we all get by the old SOH amendment of 1992.  For many families this differential of $5,500 is cost prohibitive and a deal killer in Real estate! 

 

So, if it is easy, let's deal with this NOW!  Why should we wait for that issue to be resolved to deal with the ones directly affecting our Real Estate LIQUIDITY?  The Inequity issue does not affect the marketability of Real Estate (at least as directly) as it only deals with the correction process needed so that the "assessed value" between taxpayers living in similar homes at similar locations becomes equitable.  Everyone knows this is not presently the case.  Without any doubt much work will be needed to undo the unfairness created by SOH.  But "Portability" and "First time homebuyer" issues are easy to correct and should not see much opposition.  These are good measures fueling our Florida economy! So why wait so long?  

I call on the officials, the press, other Realtors and elected Representatives and Senators to impress upon the governor the need for additional executive orders.  Let’s deal with the pressing matters NOW for 2006 Tax season!   Let’s leave the issue of inequity between neighbors due to the differential caused by "Save our Homes" (SOH) amendment enacted in 1994 to the new commission.  This is a much more complex issue and a much bigger one.  It will raise the most controversy and will require time to correct.  Perhaps even a referendum?

 

Let’s get rid of this "new mortgage" on some properties imposed by the counties and the State of Florida on some of its residents.  This was UNPLANNED by SOH, and inequities has become extremely UNFAIR to “first time Owners” and “Movers”!  All Floridian with Homestead should have the same right to the differential between "Just" and "Assessed".   This problem was created by the legislators in 1994, or the then SOH committee, who could not predict that property values would increase exponentially in the last 5 years and certainly beyond the 3% Cap created by SOH?  But one should assume that the cap was to protect all Floridians! Then why leave out their fundamental right to those that move their homestead within the state? Removing the tax break after their move is unfair and really doing nothing about it NOW is OUTRAGEOUS!  The right SOH was trying to protect, was most certainly meant to be "IN PERSONA" therefore OWNED by the Homesteader, and not related or attached to "THE REAL PROPERTY ADDRESS!  This would not make any sense!  The problem is THAT IS THE WAY THE TAX ASSESSORS INTEERPRET THE TEXT OF SOH!   THIS IS WRONG!  That "break" which Homesteaders earn over time should not be taken back when they moves!  Or we are going to have a war between those that move and those that stay put for many years. Come on! 

 

 Now that I am thinking about this, I am even questioning and concerned to know whether the current discrimination is possibly and illegal and unconstitutional (Florida Constitution) and  should be possibly challenged all the way to the Florida Supreme Court.  Certainly, all of us should have the same right!  So, should those affected adversely by SOH complain to the Tax Assessor and seek relief?   Or even sue the state for discrimination?  Probably not, but I think the County Assessor should be more lenient to those who contribute "beyond the call of duty" to the Tax Roll and not bluntly apply an unjust formula which we all know will eventually be repealed. 

To those affected (recent movers in 2005) I say file a petition by the September 13 deadline and let's get the ball rolling!  It cost only $15, and the form is available in all County offices.  Remember; ask for preferential treatment since your neighboors have it!  I am not joking, do it and document it!  This is the only way we are going to see changes any time soon.  Hopefully, the Property Appraisers and their depuites will make special exceptions to the 2006 (and 2007?) tax rolls.  It is the right thing to do and hopefully you can get a break.  If not, go argue with the Value Adjustment Board, and all the way to the County Councils if needed.  They know the whole darn thing is unfair and has been so for the past 5 years!  

Obviously the text of SOH had many loopholes adversely affecting some. Let’s hope that the governor was diligent in the selection of the committee this time.  Indeed, this matter of Property Taxes affects 18 millions Floridians according to his order!  So, clearly, this portability RELIEF is only a correction to reinstate civil rights and Floridians affected should not have to wait 2 more years!   

 

I call on the County Appraisers to be lenient towards those affected this tax season.  It is obvious to me that they are aware of the problems but do not know how to deal with it having fear of granting favors to some against the others.  Well, the real problem is that the old homestaders are not paying their fair "market share" of taxes and they are the ones getting the favors of the Tax assessors by virtue of SOH!  Is that normal and equitable?  It is clear that the injustices will eventually be cured.  The problem is when? 2008?  In my view, the County Assessors should be granted temporary rights by another immediate Executive Order to give a break now to those that moved in 2004 and 2005.  It is only good business and fair to correct a loophole in SOH.  Tax Assessor’s review can be monitored for possible Fraud.  This immediate cure should be welcome by all because the families that moved their homestead, should be compensated and not PENALIZED.  This will incite people to sell and purchase properties.  By the way, few people are aware of the fact that the counties “double dip” when someone moves their homestead to another Florida location.  The old property address is sold and tax paid by the new homeowner there (either existing Homesteader from Florida, or from foreign States/Countries), nearly double/triple each time.   Meanwhile the taxes at the new home always double/triple too!   Yes, Floridians on the move, you are currently treated like "furners".  This is NUTS!  As long as their new property is of a higher value why do counties not give a break!  What do we need to make this happen and grant them the power?  2 more years? How about if bills get a NO vote in the Senate?  Governor Bush, can you do something about this?

Additionally, further provisions need to be put in place for retirees downsizing that are finding their tax bill has increased.  They are not protected under the system either.  IOW, the status is: Don't Move!  Now, is this good for our Real Estate Market?  

 

IMHO, the increase in RE taxes, compounded by the recent increase in Home insurance rates, and the overall increase in cost of living, is going to take a huge dent in the Florida Real Estate and Economy in 4th quarter of 2006, worsen in 2007 and be intolerable to some in 2008.  The signs are already there:  The MLS systems are at record high with over 6,200 residential listings in the Daytona Beach Area.  Add the FSBO’s and the units under construction, and we possibly have 20,000 units on the market, indeed an unprecedented amount.  This is GRAVE, especially for the construction business which will enter into a huge crisis. Worse, it is reasonable to predict possible massive foreclosures and unemployment if we do not ease up the "liquidity" of Real Estate transactions.  The market is "frozen right now" and unless we inform that there will be relief soon, things will escalate. 

Recent articles and letter sent by Morgan Gilreath, our Property Appraiser, do help inform.  Both his "Understanding Your Property Tax" letter sent with the recent TRIM notices, and his Aug 27 article in Community Voices are to be congratulated.  But, he is the Property Appraiser representing Government and has to apply the Florida Laws regulating real estate.  He currently does have the ability but not the authority to correct inadequacies.  We are the taxpayers and we need to support any grass root movement to correct a terrible situation.  This means supporting the Volusia Tax Reform Group, our representatives (make sure they read and reply our e-mails) ask for more views, opinions and suggestions from the public.  For this to happen, we need the Medias to DRIVE this effort.  For example, the public reads about the word "portability" (in Mr. Gilreath’s letter) for the first time ever, but aside for its definition nothing is mentioned of What, When, How will new taxes be computed?  More importantly, will it be retroactive? How many years?   

 

Right now it is our Government that decides this, and the residents of Florida need to get the grip on these major issues that affect them to avoid another SOF Fiasco. 

I firmly believe that our future as far as Real Estate Property Taxation should be decided by the Florida residents at large i.e.: BY REFERENDUM!   Not in the hands of politicians, and certainly not in the hands of those that were involved with SOH in 1992 when the SOH amendment was voted on. :-(  

 

Please do research the matter and use whatever influence you may have to impress our legislators, the Governor, the Property Tax Reform Committee, and above all the public to accelerate the process.  

 

Respectfully,

 

 

Claude D. Berthoin

 

Florida resident since 1974.

Homestead since 1980; Moved 3 times since 1994, the effective date SOH was put on tax rolls.

Responsible for about $50,000 of increased tax money for Volusia County due to moves.  County "double dipped" on all three properties!

Captain Tom Gill
CC Margaret Podlich 

Vice President of Government Affairs

BoatU.S.

 
Captain Gill,
 
Thank you for contacting me regarding House Bill 7175 pertaining to vessel relocation during hurricanes.  I appreciate your thoughts on this issue.
 
As you know, hurricanes can cause catastrophic damage to marinas and vessels. During a storm event, changes in wind direction and fluctuations in wind intensity, excessive rain and storm surge cause moored vessels to repeatedly collide with stationary docks, and often culminate in extensive damage assessments which may evolve into a dispute between the vessel owner and the marina owner. The dispute often hinges on whether the vessel caused damage to the dock, or whether the dock caused damage to the vessel during the storm.

 

This is great

 

Florida law emphasizes the protection of life over property by prohibiting marinas from requiring vessel owners to remove their vessels from a marina once a hurricane watch or warning has been issued.

 

The bill authorizes marina personnel to take reasonable actions to further secure any vessel within the marina to minimize damage to the vessel, the marina property, private property and the environment, if the vessel is not removed once a tropical storm or hurricane watch has been issued. The marinas may charge reasonable fees for securing the vessel and held harmless for any damage that occurs as a result of securing the vessel or from any damage incurred to a vessel from such storms or hurricanes. The bill provides that no immunity is granted to the marina for any intentional acts or negligence that causes damage to the vessel during the removal or storage under this act. 

 

This will end up with vessels being made to leave every marina. If every marina is allowed to make boat owners sign a contract or notice that they must leave where do all the vessels go? It is foolish for a marina not to add this to their contract, from an insurance standpoint.

But it give the marina a reason to put vessels out in harms way. 

 

The bill provides noticing criteria in the contractual agreement which may be utilized by the marina and the vessel owner relating to the removal of the vessel once a tropical storm or hurricane watch has been issued and provides that a time frame be established for such vessel removal.

 

Again, thank you for contacting me on this issue.  If I may assist you in any matter, please contact me.
 
Regards,
 
Allan Bense

We kept it affordable for her.  We recently received our tax bill from Brevard County and have been notified that the proposed budget will raise the taxes on that unit from $985.07 to $1850.43.  That is almost a 100% increase.  On the renewal of her lease, we will need to raise her rent by $72.00 a month.  We have tried to keep this rent affordable for her but the state and local authorities find nothing wrong with raising the taxes on a property by unbelievable amounts. The state and local governments must bear a great deal of responsibility for the lack of affordable housing.
 
Thank You for Your Time
Susan Pietris

Dear Governor Bush:
 
It is with profound disappointment we learned of Escambia County’s efforts to significantly raise the property taxes on our Perdido Key condominium at Palacio (Unit # 1003).
 
What we find to be specifically objectionable is the targeting of condominiums for property tax escalation. As you are well aware, many of these units are owned by individuals such as us who reside outside of Florida area. As you are also aware, increasing the property values of this group casts the appearance of taxing out-of-state residents to avoid political repercussions that would surely result from similar taxing circumstances at the local level.
 
Our purchase of this condominium was intended as a retirement destination, a time that will come within the next several years. However, the proposed property tax increases would mean that we would have to place our unit up for sale – a common result of such tax imprudence. 
 
Consequently, how many others will do the same thing? What will then happen to Escambia’s tax base? As property values decrease (and they will) as a result of high taxes, who will then rescue the county when the proverbial Golden Goose has been sacrificed in the name of fiscal assertiveness? Who will become Palacio’s new tenants? Who will become the new taxpayers? 
 
Consider, if you will, the effect of such a scenario on local commerce. At present, every person vacationing in Perdido Key contributes between $750 to $1,000 to the local economy. With a lack of hotels in this area, those who occupy our units are there because of our units. 
 
It is important to also note that abrupt tax escalation never benefits a community. Such action only results in negative economic and social impact. In Perdido Key, and subsequently in Escambia County, that impact will assume the form of job losses and income taxes – particularly within the construction industry.
 
At a time when Escambia County should be helping to restore beachfront property, it has instead elected to financially burden the very people who are the foundation of its resort community. Given what we all went through following Ivan (including nonresidents), the effort to significantly raise Palacio taxes represents an insensitive gesture of remarkable proportion. 
 
Since purchase of our unit two years ago, we have seen its value decrease by nearly $150,000. Additionally, because we are renting our unit until retirement, we must subsidize the mortgage payment by almost $1,500 per month. And that does not take into account a hefty increase in recent insurance costs.
 
While we may not be registered voters in Escambia at present, we both vote. And when we do retire, we will be obviously looking to elect those individuals with the common sense to put the best interests of Escambia at the forefront of their respective agendas.
 
From what I understand, you are such an individual. 
 
We are certain you fully understand the grave situation that will result from any form of a tax grab. It is for this reason we ask your support in seeking tax reductions that will accelerate – rather than negate – economic momentum to achieve a viable, fiscally sound Perdido Key resort.
 
Your consideration is greatly appreciated. 
 
Sincerely,

Subject:	Objection to tax increase

The undersigned are all winter residents, otherwise known as "Snowbirds," living in Century Village, Deerfield Beach, Florida, and we believe as temporary residents, we are being discriminated against.
 
Who are we?  We are a group of senior retirees who have worked hard all our lives, and now, when we thought we found a place we could live quietly and relatively inexpensively for a few winter months each year, it has become evident that this is not to be.  More and more of us will be selling our modest condos because we just cannot afford the increased taxes and insurance premiums.

Does it make sense to you that the relative few who live in Florida less than half a year should be responsible for the bulk of the expenses of all home owners in the State of Florida?  Does it make sense to you that those who live in Florida all year round, or for tax purposes say they do, should be exempted from carrying their fair share of expenses?  We don't use your schools, we don't wear out your roads, we don't use up your electricity or water.  We do, however, carry our full share of condo fees and insurance even though we only live in our condos a few months a year.  We do make it possible for all the "Homesteaders" to live at a fraction of the cost.  We do spend money in your shops and restaurants and help to keep your economy rolling by keeping people employed.  We do believe that it is time for the governing bodies to respect and acknowledge our contribution and not to make us their cash cow. 
 
Logic dictates that users should be payers.  And yet, the State of Florida continues to perpetuate this discriminatory Homesteaders taxation policy not only with unequal tax assessements, but with unreasonable and untenable tax rates.  We understand that as we are not permanent residents of the State of Florida we do not have the right to vote, however, because of the system that is in place, this is a blaring example of what can happen when there is taxation without representation.  
 
We are angry, disappointed, frustrated and financially strapped and we ask that you consider the following:
 
1)  CUT THE TAX RATE - there has been a 91% price hike over the past three years for the "Snowbirds."
 
2)  Understand that we just cannot afford these stiff increases and it will show clearly if and when we return to Florida, for our disposible income is severly shrinking.
 
3) Consider what your situation will be if a majority of "Snowbirds" decide to sell their properties to  only Homesteaders.  Where will you find the tax dollars that you are presently getting from us?  It is time for you to take it there now.
 
4) Consider that many may be forced to sell and either not return to the U.S. or move elsewhere to a more welcoming climate.
 
The courtesy of a response to this e-mail will be most appreciated.  I will convey your message to the others who have joined with me, gracealter@bellnet.ca

From:	Carole Hogancamp <ClassicRealtors@tampabay.rr.com>
Sent:	Monday, September 4, 2006 4:13 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	New Construction Property Tax Discrimination

The following has also been submitted to my Senator and State Representative, as well as the Citrus Cty. Chronicle this date. I sincerely hope a  remedy is soon implemented to correct  this grave inequity. Thank you.
 
 

 

I applaud Fred Miller’s letter of 8/17 regarding the residential homestead exemption. I, too, am a retired Michigan realtor and wish to expand on this issue based on my personal experience since moving to this community last year.

 

Assessments of residential properties are performed each January. These assessments include homes sold the previous year. The new owner who purchased an existing home for $200,000 in 2004 will have a pretty good handle as to what his taxes will be, particularly if he bought during the last quarter of the year, because he will be assessed at current market value in January 2005, almost immediately following the purchase. 

 

The purchaser of new construction, however, experiences something quite different. He contracts for a $200,000 home in 2004, closes in 2005 (if he is lucky) and is assessed in January of 2006. His $200,000 purchase results in an assessment of $350,000 which is determined to be fair market value in 2006. 

 

Both sales in the above examples were $200,000. If the existing home sale had been assessed 2 years later as was the new construction they would probably both have been assessed at a fair market value of $350,000. Why is it such a tax disadvantage to purchase new construction? 

 

Property tax discrimination against buyers of new construction must be eliminated. The result of a $350,000 assessment in the example above is $5,000-$6,000 in taxes. Many  purchasers of new construction in Citrus County are seniors living on fixed incomes. Combine the taxes with our horrific utility costs and seniors will not only be selling, but permanently taking leave if they can’t take their “Save our Homes” cap with them. 

 

I challenge our politicians to bring this grave inequity to Tallahassee’s attention. There may be several effective remedies. If the purchase price on the closing document is not acceptable to assess, then offer a reduced millage rate to new construction. I also urge you to take a good look at Mr. Miller’s solutions to homestead exemptions and to offer seniors the opportunity to take their “Save our Homes” cap with them when they move.

 

 

Carole Hogancamp

352-560-7059

From:	Sam Katz <samkatz@skyweb.ca>
Sent:	Monday, September 4, 2006 11:02 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Realty taxes

Dear Governor Bush,
 
I am a snowbird from Canada who purchased a home in Palm Beach County last year. I am writing to express my concern regarding the "Save Our Homes" legislation. I find this law extremely unfair and short sighted. 
 
Why should I pay realty taxes three times the amount of my neighbor who lives in exactly the same home. This is contrary to one of your country's founding principles. Where I live in Canada we have a system where all real estate is valued to market value every three years and the mill rate adjusted to provide sufficient taxation to local government. The result is most homeowners pay a little more each year rather than gouging new residents. If a neighborhood has higher priced homes being built then the homeowners there pay more but poorer neighborhoods end up paying less. It is more like the income tax system where those that can pay more. Under your current system most people can't afford to move, even to a less desirable location, because their new home's realty taxes will far exceed what they are currently paying.
 
The current legislation may appear to be politically expedient but it is not. It will ultimately result in lower real estate values and slower housing sales. The population base that it is intended to protect will soon be leaving their homes as a result of aging. Their ability to sell their homes will be severely limited by exorbitant insurance costs and even more exorbitant realty taxes. Why should someone pay theses huge housing operating costs when they can simply live in a similar life style in Georgia, South Carolina, California or Arizona. 
 
Your government has to act to correct this oversight. Otherwise people will become unable to sell  their homes and the real estate market will collapse.
 
Sam Katz B.SC. CA

Thank you for your recent e-mail regarding property taxes in Bay County. I will be sure to pass your concerns on to the Property Tax Reform Committee. Your input, like that of many others we are hearing from, will be important in shaping the recommendations of the committee. Also, I encourage you, if you have any specific ideas for solutions to the problems you mention, to submit them to the committee via our website at www.propertytaxreform.state.fl.us. 

If you are not already aware, you should know that current Florida law offers you a couple of ways to try to reduce the tax increase you are facing.  First, if you feel your property is not properly valued, you can appeal the Property Appraiser's assessment to the appraiser himself and to the Value Adjustment Board in your county.  I strongly urge you to contact the Bay County Property Appraiser for more information on how to do that.  Second, you can attend the budget hearings at which the local governments in your area will be setting their tax rates.  Let them know of your concerns.

From:	ralphneama <ralphneama@swfla.rr.com>
Sent:	Saturday, September 2, 2006 4:14 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Save Our Homes

Dear Governor Bush,

 

I am a Florida Licensed Real Estate salesperson and Mortgage Broker. My wife and I moved to Cape Coral, Lee County, Florida 3 years ago as we were attracted to lower home prices and property taxes. In the past few years I have developed a better understanding of how “Save Our Homes” works and would like to share my thoughts with you in the hopes that they will result in improvements in the way we levy property taxes in Florida.

 


What Is "Save Our Homes"? The following is the answer as it appears on the Lee County Property Appraiser’s web site:


Save Our Homes" (SOH) spearheaded by Mr. Wilkinson, approved by Florida voters in 1992, effective January 1, 1995.  SOH places a limitation of 3% on annual assessment increases on homestead exempt property. For all property first granted homestead exemption in the prior year, that year’s assessed value will be the base value for the implementation of "Save Our Homes". Thereafter, the assessed value will not increase more than 3% or the percentage change in the Consumer Price Index, whichever is less. 

 

 

Save our homes is nothing more than a subsidy program which extends an undeservedly large real estate tax exemption solely on the basis of how long the home owner has owned and lived in his/her home. The tax exemption given to one homeowner is being paid for by another homeowner. The homeowners who have purchased their homes in 1995 or earlier, get the most tax subsidy at the expense of all the other homeowners who have purchased their homes in subsequent years. The residents who pay the most real estate taxes per assessed dollar, are the most recent homebuyers.

 

In essence, the save our homes law had the effect of shifting the tax burden from one group of property owners to another. There are 4 main groups of property owners that pay the cost of those subsidies or exemptions in the form of relatively higher real estate taxes:

 

1)      New home buyers/first time home buyers

2)      Part time residents

3)      Investment/Rental property owners

4)      Commercial property owners

 

In the first group, the first time homebuyer is predominantly a young buyer that can ill afford to be subsidizing the real estate taxes of other more established homeowners just because they purchased their home earlier. In addition to not making any sense, the law seems to discriminate against the younger homebuyer.

 

In the second group, part time residents (snow birds) do not qualify for the S.O.H. exemption because they are not homesteaded and pay the highest tax, year after year, and they only occupy their home less than 6 months a year. They certainly don’t use as much of the city’s services and resources, yet they subsidize most of the full time residents.

 

In the third group, the rental property owner does not qualify for the S.O.H. tax exemption and is also paying the highest tax per assessed dollar and must pass this tax subsidy on to the tenants in the form of higher rents.

 The S.O.H subsidy program is indirectly discriminating against all renters in the State of Florida in favor of all or most resident homeowners.

 

This shift in the tax burden from one group of taxpayers to another has created significant inequities as shown in the next example. The homes chosen in the example are on the same block and have relatively close assessed values. Because the 2006 taxes have not been finalized yet, the 2005 millage rate of $20.02 per $1,000 of assessed valuation was used to calculate the ad valorem taxes using the Lee County Property appraiser’s most recent assessed values:

 

 

                                                     EXAMPLE 1

 

PROPERTY                  DATE             ASSESSED          S.O.H.             AD VALOREM


   ADRESS              PURCHASED           VALUE       EXEMPTION             TAXES_


#5318                           9/1/1995          $527,010           $378,110             $2,480.48


 

#5317                            8/27/2001            504,590              208,120                 5,434.83

 

#5229                            8/27/2003            520,660                  -0-                   10,423.61

 

 

The inequities that the Save Our Homes has created are gigantic in proportions and will only get worse in the future. The only way to fix this mess now is to eliminate the tax subsidy, which discriminates against some groups of taxpayers in favor of others for no logical reason. This law cannot and will not pass the test of time. In time, the disparity between the taxes paid by established residents with high S.O.H. exemptions and those paid by new homebuyers, will grow bigger and bigger. It will be increasingly difficult to fix the problem in the future.

 

Save our homes has created the following problems:

 

1)      Tremendous inequities in the amount of real estate taxes paid by owners of 2 identically assessed homes. In the above example, the owner who purchased the house in 2003 is paying 4 times as much as the one purchased in 1995. Both homes get the sameidentical services and have basically the same value. Save our home has created a seniority system whereby the homeowner accumulates tax exemptions the longer he/she stays in his/her home while the costs of those exemptions are being picked up by other taxpayers. That’s totally absurd. A person moving to the State of Florida today is no less of a resident or citizen of the USA than a person who came 2 years earlier. The new homebuyer is entitled to the same fair and equal treatment as his neighbor who came before him/her.

 

 

 

2)      Because the Save our Homes system shifts the tax burden from one group to another, the first time homebuyer is assuming an unfair and relatively larger share of the tax burden. It is hard to believe that we would penalize this group, who are usually the young buyers, when it is already difficult for them to purchase a home.

 

 

 

3)      Tenants are another group that are indirectly being penalized because they have to absorb, in the form of higher rents, the higher taxes imposed on the property owner who is not entitled to any exemptions and pays the full tax on his/her assessed valuation.

 

Tenants are usually not renting by choice. They most likely can’t afford to buy a house and yet in the State of Florida they help subsidize the taxes of someone who owns a $500,000 home. How unfair and embarrassing is that?

 

4)      The sizeable S.O.H. exemptions trivialize the other exemptions available to some taxpayers in the State of Florida. They are:

 

a)      Widows and widowers who have not remarried ……………………….$500

b)      Blind persons …………………………………………………………...$500

c)      Veterans of military service with at least a 10% service disability……..$5,000

 

Compare these disability related exemptions with the $378,110 S.O.H. exemption, given to the resident in example 1 above, simply because he/she purchased and lived in the home since 1995. The S.O.H. exemption is not awarded because of any disability and is not based on income or ability to pay a fair share of the tax. Outrageous doesn’t begin to describe this unjust system of subsidies, which totally defies logic and common sense.

 

5)      Impact on the Real Estate market: Because of the huge sums of the S.O.H. exemptions, property taxes have become so personalized and customized to the current owner that they have become meaningless to a prospective buyer. Currently, when a Real Estate agent lists a property for sale on a local multiple listing service the property taxes paid by the present owner is automatically entered on the listing. If the seller’s property is homesteaded and he owned it for a few years, his property taxes are relevant to him and no one else.

 

In other words, because the S.O.H. exemptions, the dollar amount listed for property taxes on most listings for sale apply only to the present owner and are totally meaningless to a potential buyer. In fact, listing the present owner’s property taxes is misleading and could easily deceive a potential buyer into believing that the present owner’s property taxes are indicative of what his/her taxes will be if he/she purchases the property.

 

Using the property purchased in 1995 from example 1, if that owner uses a real estate agent to list his/her property for sale, the listing will indicate property taxes to be $2,480.48 when in fact no buyer on earth would qualify for this reduced tax amount.

 The minute any new buyer purchases that property, it will be taxed at the fully assessed value, which will bring the tax up to $10,550.74 and if the new buyer were homesteaded, the tax would be $10,140.60

 

How many potential buyers, who use the internet to view listings in Florida, are mislead by the low property taxes on listings for properties affected by the S.O.H. exemptions? How are they alerted to the fact that the tax amount on a listing could be meaningless to them and that their tax could be substantially higher? 

Aren’t we obligated to disclose this fact to all potential buyers and make them aware of what their property taxes will be once they purchase the house?

 

 

6)      Eventually, word will spread to potential out of State buyers and investors that because of      

the S.O.H. exemptions, purchasing a new property in the State of Florida will require them to assume a bigger share of the tax burden because they have to subsidize all the previous residents who purchased before them and who are enjoying those large exemptions at their expense. I would venture to say that other States that compete with Florida for new residents, i.e.: North and South Carolina, Georgia, Tennessee, Arizona, Nevada, Texas etc. do not discriminate against new homeowners by making them pay a higher property tax to subsidize the lower property taxes of current residents. 

 

The real estate market in Florida will become less and less attractive to potential new buyers and investors as the save our homes exemptions grow larger and larger resulting in larger and larger taxes imposed on the newcomers to make up for the difference.

                         

PORTABILITY

The Save Our Homes system works in a similar way as a “pyramid scheme” whereby the people at the base of the pyramid benefit the most at the expense of the people at the top of the pyramid who benefit the least. Here is what “save our homes” pyramid looks like:

 

_  2006

___  2005

_____  2004
_______  2003
_________  2002
____________  2001
______________  2000
________________  1999
__________________  1998

_____________________  1997
_________________________  1996

_____________________________  1995

 

ß size of S.O.H. tax exemption à

 

 

Residents with homestead properties purchased in 1995 or earlier are at the base of the pyramid enjoying the largest exemptions and paying the smallest amount of tax per assessed dollar and are being subsidized by everyone above them. As you move up the pyramid, let’s say for a homestead property purchased in 2000, the tax reduction or the exemption is smaller and the owner is subsidizing the property owners below him/her and is being subsidized by all the property owners above him/her. Obviously, the new comers who purchased their properties recently, let’s say in 2006, are sitting on top of the pyramid paying the highest property tax per assessed dollar and subsidizing all the property owners below them.

 

Save our homes has created a dilemma for property owners who are at the bottom of the pyramid and are enjoying large exemptions but would like to move, within the State of Florida, for any number of reasons. Should they move, they will be placed at the top of the pyramid and will be paying the highest property tax per assessed dollar and will be subsidizing the taxes of all the homeowners under them and they don’t like it!

 

This is the height of hypocrisy. Those homeowners who have enjoyed lower taxes, by being subsidized by other newer homeowners for the past number of years, have not complained about the system. Now that they are being placed in the same position as any other new home buyer and finding that they also will be placed at the top of the pyramid and they will also be paying more than their fair share of the tax burden, they are all of a sudden crying foul.

 

They are now claiming that the system is broke and needs fixing. They want to be able to take those huge S.O.H. exemptions with them when they move to a new house. They know what happens when they are placed on top of the pyramid with no exemptions and having to subsidize all those homeowners under them. Their gripe is that they will end up paying a higher tax and that’s not fair!

 

Those who are pushing for portability are now paying less than their fair share of the tax burden and are happy to have someone else pay a higher tax to make up for the difference and don’t want to see this scenario change when they move, which will otherwise make them new homebuyers. 

 

In essence, I would like to see the Save our Homes system abolished basically for the same reasons that some homeowners would like to see portability of the S.O.H. exemptions. I don’t like the idea of a newcomer who buys a property in Florida, and who sits on top of that dreaded pyramid, paying a higher property tax to subsidize the tax of those established residents that bought their homes earlier. Supporters of the portability issue also don’t like to see themselves paying a higher property tax, and being placed at the top of that dreaded pyramid, to subsidize the tax of those who bought their homes earlier. The only difference between us is that they don’t mind if someone else is paying the higher property tax as a new homebuyer as long as it is not them! That is a selfish and hypocritical stance to take.

 

Save Our Homes has created a lot of inequities and a lot of problems with enormous long-term effect. To make S.O.H. portable will make a bad situation even worse. Supporters of the S.O.H. portability are disillusioned into thinking that the S.O.H exemptions that they are now enjoying, and that are being paid for by others, actually belongs to them and that they are entitled to take those exemptions with them when they move to a new house. 

To put in another way, they want to be excluded from being categorized as “new homebuyers” when they move to a new house because they will encounter the wrath of that good old  “Save Our Homes” and its unfair and inequitable consequences.

 

I say “what’s good for the goose should be good for the gander”. To start making exceptions to the “new homebuyer” rule for absolutely no reason other than to extend what are now clearly unfair exemptions to those who are benefiting from them and would like to make them lifetime exemptions, would be absurd.

 

If the system penalizes the new homebuyers, to the advantage of the existing one, let the penalty be applied evenly and consistently. I would rather see the penalty and this unfair system of subsidy totally removed instead of creating an artificial classification of “repeat or second time New Homebuyer” who will get substantial property tax subsidies that the “first time Homebuyer” is not only excluded from, but pays the cost of those subsidies. Let’s stop making these different classifications of taxpayers, which do not make any sense and create unfair and inequitable tax subsidies and penalties. 

 

The answer to the problem is really a simple one. Eliminate the subsidies and penalties and make comparably assessed properties pay the same tax (with the exception of the current disability related exemptions) If a cap is needed, to protect the taxpayers from increased government spending, consider a cap that would apply to all taxpayers and not one that favors some taxpayers and penalizes others. It’s ludicrous to say that we will reduce the property taxes of some taxpayers by having other taxpayers, who own comparable properties, pay a portion of their tax based on a seniority system! That is exactly what the “Save Our Homes” is doing now.

 

I don’t know how on earth this law was passed in 1992. But, it’s never too late to get rid of it. Certainly, it makes no sense to exacerbate the problem by allowing “portability”.

 

 

Ralph Neama

2623 SW 43rd Ter

Cape Coral, FL 33914

From:	Michael Woodward <wood207@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Saturday, September 2, 2006 10:24 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] real property tax

First, let me say that I am proud to have you as Governor of Florida.  Thanks for doing such a fantastic job!
 
The purpose of this letter is to address the dramatic increase in property taxes these past few years and the effect it is having on our (those of us with a homestead) ability financially to move around within the state.
 
Is there not some way to adjust or freeze the tax base for a homesteaded homeowner when he sells his Florida house and buys another homestedable Florida house?  Hypothetically lets say my tax is now based on my house's original value of about $250,000 but the house is currently worth about $500,000.  If I retire and downsize (move into a smaller house) and pay $350,000 for the new smaller house, my taxes GO UP.  If I move into a house like mine in another part of the state and pay $500,000 (an even real estate exchange value), my taxes DOUBLE.  If I am a growing young family and need a bigger house for my children my taxes will MORE THAN DOUBLE and easily TRIPLE.  It appears that the only way to move out of a Florida homesteaded house without getting hit with a large tax increase is to move out of the state to a place that has a much lower tax base.  
 
I bought a small rental house a few years ago with plans to downsize into it when I retire but I can not afford to because the tax on that house (I paid half of what I did for my own home - I paid $130,000 for the small house, $250,000 for my large homesteaded house) has increased over $1,000 each year for the past two years making the final tax on it higher than I pay on my homesteaded house.  I would have a large tax INCREASE to downsize to a house I paid half the price of my current home for.  I can not afford to move into my own house.
 
This is hurting the economy by discouraging homesteaded Florida residents from selling and buying owner occupied Florida real estate.  Is there not something you can do to fix this problem and stimulate the real estate economy for Florida homesteaded residents?
 
Respectfully,
 
Michael Woodward
Saint Lucie County
772.342.2818

High property taxes killing home sales

Editor,

 

I'm Realtor with 1st Realty Network Inc. in West Palm Beach. I would like to express my concern, and the concern of others, about ever growing property taxes.

 

Let's be honest: It's a killer of home sales. As soon as my buyers hear the amount of the yearly tax bill they'd have to pay for their new home, they go into shock. Nothing scares them more than that number, next to maybe the property insurance cost in some cases. If they get a mortgage on the house, they know that paying the bank is like putting money back into their pocket because when they sell the house, they get money back.

 

Oftentimes, the mortgage payment almost equals the monthly tax amounts! It's outrageous! Paying high taxes is extremely expensive for most families, especially with children. This slows the real estate market tremendously!

 

I would like to find out if there is anyone I could contact in our state government to address this issue. I'm sure there other Realtors fighting for tax reductions. Please let me know. Thank you.

 

Iya Tsymlyakova

1st Realty Network Inc.

Royal Palm Beach

This is because we are not Florida residents and not eligible for the homestead exemptions and the SOH amendment which would limit the assessed value increase.  We purchased this property from my wife's parents when it became necessary for them to go into an assisted living facility and we wanted a place close to them so we could be there when needed.  We have come to enjoy Florida, but I find that based on the current laws we obviously are not very welcome at least when measured by the tax laws that affect us.  I have a home in Colorado with a market value of about $475,000.  My tax bill without any exemptions is about $2700.  The market value on my tax notice for the Florida condo is $275,000 but the proposed tax is $5889 or about 2.2 times what I pay in Colorado.  I realize that when comparing states tax structures it is necessary to look at the total picture, but this seems excessive and I am one who generally votes to support local government when requesting rate increases.  This seems even more onerous when I find that when I am in Florida many local governments and private entities make me pay more or exclude my participation because I am not a full time resident.  My neighbor with the same condo has a proposed tax bill of approximately $2200 because he has the homestead and other applicable exemptions.

With these types of tax increases I will not be able to afford to own a property in Florida.  Perhaps this is the intent of the laws currently being administered.  I am sure there are many others that find themselves in the same situation.  I am hopeful that this email will reach you.  I realize that you receive many communications and that your staff must assist, but I do hope that they are making you are aware of these issues.

The State of Florida has an opportunity to apply for new federal funds to expand housing opportunities for people with disabilities. 2003

1500

3900

2006

40000

142.42%

-----Original Message-----
From: Ivan Restrepo [mailto:ingesis@telecorp.net]
Sent: Monday, August 28, 2006 3:37 PM
To: luis@lsu.edu; armando.zarrul@colseguros.com; arodriguez@fasecolda.com;
johnurbe@suramericana.edu.co; luz.falla@colseguros.com;
Cesar.E.Escalante@marsh.com; crenteria@dnp.gov.co
Cc: gtorres@eafit.edu.co; lquinte3@eafit.edu.co; avelez@eafit.edu.co;
ucarcamo@eafit.edu.co; htrefftz@eafit.edu.co
Subject: RESULTADOS



Apreciados amigos:



Vayamos a la VERDAD, a la comparación de resultados entre los diferentes
modelos de VIDA ESPERADA DEL FONDO (o si prefieren: distribución de T, el
tiempo hasta el primer déficit).



Desde 1940 Lundberg hizo un enorme aporte conceptual a la racionalidad y
medida del RIESGO. Pero su modelo, ampliamente demostrado y base de los
posteriores, es UNA DESIGUALDAD, un simple acotamiento. Si bien es “del
lado de la seguridad” queda por definir qué tan ineficaz puede ser en
muchas condiciones.



Desde entonces y en especial desde los computadores personales (80s)
asistimos a un enorme esfuerzo científico que trata de llevar a LA
IGUALDAD, a determinar la probabilidad de supervivencia. Todos ellos
desafortunadamente viciados por  falta de rigor en el manejo de las
Integrales Impropias.



Ya a fines del siglo pasado, los Actuarios buscaron ayuda en otras
disciplinas, concretamente en la Teoría de Colas y sus funciones de
reabastecimiento; también en los modelos físicos de Movimiento Browniano.
De nuestro lado INGESISTEMAS insiste en los muy buenos resultados
obtenidos en la línea de solución de H. Seal que hemos generalizado para
superávit inicial no nulo, para incluir el valor del dinero en el tiempo,
para analizar horizonte temporal finito e infinito y para incluir el
Reaseguro más eficaz que es el “Stop-loss”.



A continuación encontraran la comparación de Lundberg para los mismos
casos reportados por Dickson & Waters )U. de Victoria y de Edimburgo), a
saber: capitales iniciales de 0, 10, 20, 30, 40 y 50 períodos; Factores de
Estabilidad (teta o “realative security loads” de .1 y .25; distribución
de extensión exponencial de media y parámetro 1: distribución de
intensidad Poisson de parámetro (lambda) 1.



NINGUNO DE LOS DEMÁS MODELOS ESTUDIA EXPLÍCITAMENTE EL INTEREÉS SOBRE EL
FONDO, para facilitar la comparación haremos inicialmente lo mismo aunque
insistimos que no se debe restar de un capital en pesos de hoy los
siniestros muy distantes sin descontarlos.



Los resultados anexos casi no requieren comentario: baste decir que  donde
Lundberg prueba que el tiempo es mayor que, los otros modelos (Excepto el
de INGESISTEMAS) dan resultados menores; donde es obvio que con un aporte
periódico de .25 veces la media se tiene mayor superávit que con .1, dan
frecuentemente menor vida.



Y en EFICIENCIA QUE DECIR: para u0=30 y teta=.25, Dickson&Waters dan vidas
de 100 y 120; Lundberg dice que es mayor que 800 y la realidad es 884
MILLONES DE AÑOS o sea recursos inmovilizados inútilmente.



Pero ésta es la primera parte de la historia: incluyamos un rendimiento
tan discreto como .05 por año, en la parte final del estudio.  Los tiempos
en algunos casos disminuyen frente a no-interés pero siempre mayores que
Lundberg, se deben al DESCUENTO de capitales alcanzados en el futuro
distante donde ya no hay  déficit posible.



Se observa que los resultados son UTILES, difícilmente se requiere más de
.1 de Estabilidad y no tienen sentido práctico capitales iniciales de 50
veces la media (aplicados al caso colombiano, serían autoseguros tan
costosos como el seguro mismo y con la inmovilización de 3 a 4 veces el
valor de un vehículo) es tal la diferencia que debimos repetir nuestros
resultados para valores de u0 entre 0 y 15.



Una vida media de 100 es excelente: incluso podemos considerar una de 20
años, si se entiende que el administrador del fondo no es un sujeto
PASIVO, que sabe hacer correcciones y que todo lo que requiere es que es
un plazo prudente antes del déficit. ESTO SE LOGRA EN EL FONDO CON
CAPITALES INICIALES DE 4 y 5.5 VECES LA PERDIDA MEDIA, con cargas de .1 y
.25  respectivamente.



CON FONDOS DE PRIMERA PERDIDA CLAROS, ENTENDIDOS, COMPROBABLES, SI HAY
OFERTA DE SEGUROS se puede entrar a calcular la retención o deducible
óptimo que depende del “costo de oportunidad del dinero” para el
asegurado.



Esta es la solución para TERRORISMO (Voladura de torres de energía y
oleoductos, aviones), para DAÑOS DE HURACANES Y TORNADOS (reparación de
redes), PARA VIENTOS EN BANANERAS. Para enfermedades costosas (diálisis y
transplantes renales, quimio y radio terapias) y para CONTAGIO (Sida).



Y ESPECIALMENTE ES LA SOLUCIÓN PARA CIUDADES QUE HAN VISTO EMIGRAR SU
GENTE COMO NUEVA ORLEANS, QUE HAN VISTO PARALIZADA  LA INVERSIÓN Y EL
CRECIMIENTO. LAS AUTORIDADES DEBEN PROMOVER ESTA CLASE DE FONDOS Y DARLES
INCENTIVOS TRIBUTARIOS MIENTRAS SE DOTAN, PARA GARANTIZAR EMPLEO Y NUEVOS
IMPUESTOS A FUTURO.



INGESISTEMAS / Iván Restrepo Lince

What I see in my area which is Volusia county are a high number of people with no insurance and medicaid. What bothers me is the abuse of the medicaid system that all our tax dollars support. I have no problem with legitimate use for injury or disabled or true emergency situations but what I see too much of are people with what we call the "gold card" coming in for cough and cold symptoms and other minor ailments.It seems to us they don't want to spend 6 dollars for cough medicine so they come to us for free as they see it.  And its the same folks week after week. What I would suggest and I hope you can consider it is a limit of 6 visits per year for medicaid recipients unless disabled then there would be no limit. I believe this would save tens of thousands probably hundreds of thousands of medicaid dollars and force these folks to use these cards wisely and not abuse them. They are not even attempting home remedy for minor ailments..they come to the ER "gold card" in hand within two hours of a minor symptom clogging up our emergency rooms delaying treatment to people in real need. I would say half if not more than half of patients we see on a daily basis are indigent folks with ailments that most people would never consider going to an emergency room if they didn't have medicaid. I have no problem helping those who need it but I do have a problem with people who take advantage of our system and our tax payer dollars. Again limiting non emergent visits may be an idea you can work with to stop the waste of medicaid dollars. Thanks for your time..sincerely Rob Hasty  lifetime Florida resident

From:	Dane Clark <stowers@tampabay.rr.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, August 29, 2006 9:09 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	HB 7121

To The Honorable Jeb Bush: 

Thank you for taking the time to read my concerns regarding HB7121 and the installation and financial burden it is placing on the 778 units contained in the 9 Associations that I manage.

I am the Community Association Manager at the Federation of Sea Towers in St. Petersburg, Fl.  I have managed and maintained the physical property here for the past 25 years.  Past experience with tropical storms and hurricanes, although not as fierce as recently, has taught us how to protect our property.

We are in Evacuation Level A, which being the first level evacuated in the event of a hurricane, is mandatory and leaves the property evacuated.  When the mandatory evacuation order is given by Pinellas County, we begin our procedure to evacuate, protect and secure our community, which includes but is not limited to, locking the elevators on the top floors and shutting them down and turning the power off until the evacuation order is withdrawn.  This is done to protect the elevator cars and to prevent extensive damage that was experienced during one of the recent hurricanes when the elevators were left running after evacuation.  Wind and rain caused severe and very costly damage to the elevator cars, leaving them inoperable until repairs could be made.  Having a generator to supply power to elevators that are not operable is absurd.

Being between 5 and 7 feet above sea level, places our community in a flood zone.  Because of insurance regulations, we have been forced to insure with FEMA.  My agent tells me that because it is not possible to incorporate the generators into the structure of our buildings, that my very expensive flood insurance will not provide coverage for my equally expensive generators (which will not work if flooded) that will sit in front of my beautifully landscaped buildings, making them less appealing and reducing the value of our first floor units.

These are just 2 concerns that I thank you for taking the time to consider.  Please also take into consideration the burden that the cost of not only purchasing and installing these generators and the many hidden costs involved with their upkeep, will add to the already exorbitant cost of insurance on a mutli - million dollar community such as ours.  A burden that is being placed upon voters who worked hard all of their lives in the hopes of a good retirement, only to have it taken from them, not only here at Sea Towers but at other communities in our fine state.  

On behalf of the residents and Boards of Directors of  The Federation of Sea Towers Owner’s Associations, Inc., I humbly ask you to reconsider HB 7121.


Dane Clark, CAM 
On Site Manager 
Federation of STOA Inc. 
ph 727 397 1164 
fax 727 397 8910

From:	Tim Maki <tmaki@localnet.net>
Sent:	Friday, August 25, 2006 10:03 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Recreational Treasure Hunting in Florida

Greetings Governor Bush,

 

In the gold rush days of California among the most successful were the merchants.  They sold the goods and services to the prospectors, making a fortune.

 

The current restrictions virtually banning treasure hunting in Florida are costing the State of Florida a fortune in lost revenue, money for both merchants and the state.  No sales = no taxes.

 

Treasures found are not treasures lost.  Treasures lost and never found do not serve anyone.

 

I can only imagine that the few millions of dollars the State of Florida collects when a large treasure is found is a mere pence when compared to the money spent by adventures looking for the treasure.

 

Because a private citizen discovers treasure does not mean the item is lost.  Often museums can pay a fair price to add the item to their collection.  The entrepreneur should be rewarded for his hard work.

 

What good are treasures never found?  

 

Please repeal FS 267.  Or amend it to read:

 

*	All state lands: underwater, upland, and lowland, be open to recreational artifact collection by any means, including scuba diving and metal detecting, unless buoyed, roped, and marked by the state archaeologist as off limits to artifact collection for the purpose of preserving a designated historical site. In no instance shall a buoyed, roped, or marked exclusion area be larger than 600 feet (200 yards) in any direction from a site's perimeter as measured from the center of the site (the intent of this provision is to preserve historic sites without infringing on the public right to the use of state lands). 
*	Anyone found collecting artifacts in any area buoyed, roped, or otherwise marked by the state as off limits to collection shall be in violation of FS 267
*	Any sight discovered by a private party, deemed to be of important significant Historical or Archeological find, may be immediately confiscated by the State of Florida for fair market value of the find.  This includes finds on both private and public lands.

This is a fair and reasonable revision.  Everyone wins, specially the State of Florida.

 

There are already laws and penalties to protect the environment and such should be upheld.  Nobody has the right to ruin or destroy the environment.

 

Thank you for considering my proposals.

 

Sincerely,

 

Timothy James Maki

Future Florida Treasure Hunting Tourist

August 25, 2006

 

Governor Bush:

 

I want to bring to your attention a tax fiasco in Bay County that defies your stated priority to cut taxes to stimulate economic growth.  Property taxes are being increased in Bay County to such an extent that they will break the back of the local economy.  The TRIM notice I just received estimates my 2006 property tax bill will be a 203% INCREASE over the 2005 tax if the proposed budget is adopted and ONLY a 97% increase if no budget change is made.  Those of us in the small town of Mexico Beach have been uniquely hammered, having been assigned a 129.24% increase in taxable value in just one year—twice as high as the next highest unit in the County.  

 

In addition to being an egregious abuse of government, the planned property tax rates fail to take into account a number of critical factors:

 

*	The estimates do not reflect the current real estate market.  The formula includes property sales completed as of January 1, 2006.  Real estate sales in Mexico Beach, like the rest of the coast, have crashed since the time of Hurricane Katrina—few have wanted Gulf Coast real estate since then.
*	This tax hike will exaggerate the current glut of unsold property.  Because no one is buying real estate in Mexico Beach, we property owners are held captive by these taxes.  With this tax increase, we couldn’t find a buyer even if we wanted to flee.  
*	I am ineligible for the Homestead Exemption, but my property makes me a Bay County small-business owner, so the tax hike will likely drive out small-business owners, like me.  We are being unfairly burdened because taxes on property under the Homestead Exemption are capped at only CPI increases.
*	Because I bring in vacationers to my Bay County property, I have contributed to the economic engine that has led to the “very dynamic year” described in the full-color brochure that accompanied my TRIM notice.  This tax increase will drive this economic engine into the ground.
*	Vacationers who have come to Bay County in the past will surely take their vacation dollars to neighboring states when they see the rental prices that will be required to support these tax increases, so the taxes will drive away the very source of income that supports the Bay County economy.
*	Bay County--and Mexico Beach in particular--has just started to enjoy some stable years after the devastation of Hurricane Opal.  How outrageous to victimize again those who have worked so hard to rebuild after that devastation!

 

The Bay County property value roll has been increased by 47% in one year.  This tax increase defies understanding in a state where you have declared your intention to cut government spending.   Mr. Rick Barnett, the Bay County Property Appraiser, has stated that his hands are tied because the Florida legislature failed to pass any of the bills intended to reduce the burden on uncapped property owners.  About 90 Mexico Beach residents who met with Mr. Barnett this morning were told that a meeting with you and members of your Property Tax Reform Committee is being set up for next week.  I urge you to attend this meeting and hear from your concerned constituents.  I pray that you can act quickly to prevent an economic disaster for our small town.  The same long-term property owners who have helped to keep Mexico Beach such a Florida gem are being crushed.

 

Sincerely yours,

 

 

Suzanne M. Smith

2313B Hwy 98

[Mexico Beach Unit 3 (14.2)]

Mexico Beach, FL 32410

not including food, transportation or the like.  As you are aware, incomes
have not kept pace with the increase of home ownership, and we are headed to
a very scary place for middle income families.

I just opened my Lee County Tax Trim notice, and my property taxes have
increased due to the newly assessed value of our home since our purchase
last year.  We left our families in Broward County because we could not
afford to pay $7,000/year in property taxes plus all the other expenses for
the same home we bought here in Cape Coral.  Due to our home assessed value
going up, our taxes went up from $1734.92 to $3890.68.  My husband and I
knew that it would go up and are working hard to afford it.  However, the
proposed budget is forecasting a possibility of our taxes going up to
$4763.89.

As an aside: almost half of our taxes are going toward the school district!
My husband and I do not have children and do no plan on having children.  We
are part of the new stream of individuals who opt not due to the uncertainty
in our world.  A big concern to me is not only our situation, but also the
retirees who also do not have children.  Why do the people with no children
have to carry such a high tax burden?  Also, what about lotto?  Isn't there
suppose to be a large some of money going to the schools from Florida's
lotto?  Shouldn't those who are not over burdening our population be
rewarded?

I am very proud to be an American and want to pay our fair share of expenses
to keep our country going, but with rising insurance costs and the thought
of property taxes going up almost $900 every year, I feel that we are headed
toward danger as many citizens are forced to sell their homes and move away
from families.  The homestead exemption that we receive does not help very
much in the big scheme of things.

Please help!

Yours in Good Faith,

Subject:	Consulting Project on Future Structure of the State University System
Attachments:	2006_08_25 Pappas Consulting Project.pdf

TO:                  Board of Governors Members

                        University Boards of Trustees Members

                        State Board of Education Members

                        State University Presidents

Ed Moore, Executive Director, Independent Colleges and Universities of Florida

David Armstrong, Chancellor, Florida Community College System

 

FROM:            Mark Rosenberg, Chancellor

 

SUBJECT:       Consulting Project on Future Structure of the State University System

 

 

In order to help the Board of Governors orient the State University System for long-term growth and improvement, the Board of Governors Foundation has hired the Pappas Consulting Group to evaluate the current structure of the system and make recommendations for the future.

 

The Pappas Group emerged as the most capable and experienced firm for this project in a competitive negotiation process.  They have extensive experience consulting with other state systems, including the University of North Carolina System and the State University of New York.  Dr. Alceste Pappas, the group’s CEO and former head of KPMG Peat Marwick’s higher education consulting practice, will be directing the project.  She will be joined by Dr. Stephen Portch, Chancellor emeritus of Georgia’s university system, and backed up by experienced professional staff in their Connecticut offices.

 

Late next week, Dr. Pappas will be meeting with Board staff in Tallahassee.  University leadership teams will then be invited to meet with Dr. Pappas and Dr. Portch during one of three site visits to Florida—to Tallahassee, Tampa and Boca Raton—in late September and early October.  Depending on schedules, face-to-face or telephone interviews will also be scheduled with representatives of other key stakeholder groups, including the other education sectors, faculty and students.




 

Dr. Pappas will be presenting initial findings at the November 16 meeting of the Board of Governors, and making a final report at the January meeting.  Vice Chancellor Nancy McKee will be managing the project on the Board of Governors end and you are welcome to forward any questions, concerns or ideas to me or to Dr. McKee at Nancy.McKee@flbog.org.            

 

This project, funded through several generous contributions to the Foundation, provides a unique opportunity to think strategically about the educational legacy we leave to the next generation.  I know I can count on your thoughtful, creative participation and leadership as we take this critical step toward building the system that our citizens deserve.

 

MBR/jkm

Sally Leach

431 Ridge Court

Naples, FL 34108-2602

 

August 24, 2006

 

Dear Governor Bush 

 

I recently received the property taxes for our second home which is located in Apalachicola. My husband and I purchased the 1893 Victorian house in 1997 and have been gradually restoring it with meticulous care to detail. The house was to be our retirement home. Alas, this is not to be.  We recently received our property taxes. This year, the assessed value doubled. In such as Naples, this would not come as a surprise, but in Franklin County? I was stunned. I spoke with the Franklin County property appraiser – Doris Pendleton. She said we had done a lot of work to the house. (In addition to making it safe and insurable by adding a new roof, and new wiring, we added a fresh coat of paint, more space for the kitchen and a second bathroom.)  I replied that I did not think it morally fair to penalize people for restoring their own home - a historic house that is significantly valuable to the historic district. *When we began to restore our house most of the historic district was in a state of total disrepair. Caring people like us have made Apalachicola a “destination”; a place people want to visit – and perhaps one day live. And yet, now we are being chased out of town.

 

I researched the assessed value of other residencies, and what I found did not make sense. Basically, unless the property owner lives in Franklin county (or tells a little white lie - or is flat out deceitful), they have the Homestead exemption, thus they are protected by the Save Our Homes act. 

 

My next door neighbor’s historic home is on a bluff overlooking the bay. Their land extends across the street and into the marshes and into the bay. Their house which is on 2.25 lots was just assessed at 585K. Our house – behind theirs, in a sump, on 4.25 lots was assessed at $1,151,086. Yes, technically we have two additional lots, but our neighbor actually has more land along with a magnificent bay view! It would seem that the visual appeal of our house - provided by the fresh coat of paint and the new roof - came at a far greater expense than I could have ever imagined.    

 

Furthermore, during my research, I discovered that the other historic 1880’s home next door to us - that sold for 160K in 1996 - is being assessed at 102K. Odd, considering in 1997 we paid 375K for ours and it is now being assessed at well over $1,000,000.   I must conclude that there have been some faulty assessments, and that there are some greedy – and perhaps corrupt people who live in Franklin County. 

 

Not only is Franklin County forcing out the second home owners they are putting the opportunity to own a home out of locals reach (first time home owners, especially).  Unless there is a reversal of this greed – prior to the tax increase - I, along with many others will be forced to sell - and invest in States where this is NOT happening. 

 

Sincerely,

Sally Leach

From:	Linda & Willie <tocapecoral@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Thursday, August 24, 2006 6:24 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Homestead Exemption

Dear Governer Bush: 
 
 We understand that you have put together a committe to review the Homestead Tax Exemption.  We also understand the HJR 353 will become effective January 1, 2007 which will increase the Homestead Exemption to $50,000.  This exemption would be a step in the right direction if the tax burden was distributed equally by ALL RESIDENTS.  A great disparity exists between new homeowners (both resales and new construction) and existing neighbors with like homes and lots.  For instance, in Cape Coral (Lee County) our house is assessed at $599,000 and our taxes will be $10,300.00.  Our neighbor is assessed at $591,160 and his taxes will be $5,623.00.  A difference of $4,677.00.  We all get the same services.  Does this seem fair?  
 
We would like to propose the following idea:  ALL Homestead/SOH residents will be given a 25% exemption on their ASSESSED VALUE not their SOH assessed value.  This way, the scenerio above, would produce the following:  We would pay $8,086 in taxes and our neighbor would pay $7,480.00.  Total taxes collected would be $15,403.00 under the current plan and $15,467.00 under our proposed plan.  
 
This plan would allow new growth into the area and still allow for the $3% SOH for Homesteaded Residents.  It will also allow existing residents to downsize and move around the state without incurring a huge real estate tax burden.  
 
We would appreciate you taking this proposal into consideration and passing it along to your committee members.
 
Thank you,
 
Linda and William Thompson
Cape Coral, Florida
