Dear Jeb,
Yesterday I received a notice of a substantial increase in my property tax for my home in Ruskin, Florida (Hillsborough County).  My real estate taxes increased from $1,299.54 in 2005 to $5,863.20 in 2006 because I lost my homestead exemption and the market values increased considerably since we bought it in 1994. I moved to North Carolina in August of 2003 because my husband passed way in December 2002 and it was very difficult for me emotionally to be here in the house without him. I moved back in May of this year and missed the January filing deadline.  The condition of my home was deplorable and I had to have many things repaired before I moved back ( I also have custody of my 3 year old grandson).  I thought that when you lost your exemption, it meant the $25,500 figure listed under exemptions on your tax bill that is deducted from your assessed value. I was not aware of the fact that you would also be taxed on the current market value of your home and not what you originally paid for it which is how it has always been.
 
I had a tenant/caretaker stay in my house while I was away supposedly to take care of it at a very small rent amount so I could keep it insured while I was trying to figure out what I was going to do with my life and decide if I should sell this house.  So now my payments are going to increase from $640 per month to over $2,000 per month because I wasn't smart enough to have read the Florida constitution.  
 
Had I been aware of the consequences I would have stayed in my house and probably taken antidepressants and had extensive counseling to cope with my devastating loss.  
 
Everyone I have talked to also doesn't know about the increased market value penalty (we are all college graduates).
 
For some reason I thought it was similar to the taxable gain provision that if you live in your house at least 2 years out of the last 5 there was no penalties involved.
 
I believe that this provision in our constitution regarding homestead  exemptions is extremely onerous and should instead be modeled similarly to the federal guidelines for taxable gains giving the homeowner a period of time they can be away from their primary residence without destroying their american dream through severe tax consequences.
 
In today's world family members are scattered about the country and one may have the need to live somewhere else for a year or two due to an unfortunate life event like perhaps taking care of their elderly parents or living close to a hospital to be with their sick child, or choosing between a job too far away to commute or of being unemployed. One shouldn't have to lose their hard earned equity too.
 
The good news is that I missed all of those hurricanes and the worst part of my grief process is over but now I am forced to sell my home in a housing bust economy because I cannot afford the increased payment amount.  The Hillsborough County tax assessor's notified me of the potential exemption loss in November of 2005 when I called them about a notice they had sent. I explained that I couldn't move back by January 1 but they did not explain to me about the higher market value part of the exemption. I could have lived in a tent in the back yard. I am real sure I am not the only one to make that mistake.
 
Please try to help me but if you can't is it possible that you could require that the counties provide some kind of warning on tax bills/notices containing homestead exemptions that taxes would increase substantially if the exemption was lost and provide some detail that in addition to actual loss of the exemption amount, what could happen to the market value and actual tax amount with an example.  Maybe someone else can benefit from my stupidity.
 
Thank you for your consideration.
 
Sincerely,
Susan Burk

Subject:	 Property assesssments and taxes

 

For some years now, as a result of Florida State legislation, owners of
"seasonal" property in Florida have been unjustly treated in the area of
property taxation. Where "homesteaders" have seen their taxes increase by a
maximum of 3%, many of us "Snowbirds" have been subjected to significant
double-digit increases.

The situation where I live in the wintertime, Century Village East,
Deerfield Beach, has peaked with the latest notice of proposed property
taxes from Ms. Lori Parrish, the County Appraiser.

In my specific case, the assessed market value has increased by 60% (the
valuation as at January 1, 2006, after the major hurricanes), and it may
well be that this is a real market value. I do not know as I am not
"testing" the market by putting my condo up for sale. In any case, more than
550 of the 8800 units in our "village" have been on the market for some
nonths with no buyers.

But if that is the "real" value, if you apply the tax rates as indicated by
Ms. Parrish, my property tax will go up by 53%....that is an outrageous tax
increase if ever there was one.

No one can tell me that Broward County and Deerfield Municipal services
increased in cost by anywhere near the proposed increase in my tax; the
proof of that is in the Deerfield Fire assessment which is going up only by
6%.

It is well and good for the city and County to hold public hearings next
month, but you must also realize that for many Snowbirds who will not be in
Florida until November cannot afford to try and attend the hearings; in many
cases, the costs would outweigh potential gains as a return flight and
living expenses for a couple of days could reach a thousand dollars.

If the State of Florida does not want to scare away investors and tourists,
who come and spend billions of dollars in your economy each year, you must
ensure that the proposed tax increases are withdrawn, or at the very least,
capped to not more than the cost of living.

If the budgets for the coming year are so inflated as to need more than a 50
per cent tax increase from "seasonal" property owners, as the expression
goes, there is something very wrong.

Anything more than single-digit increases in the current economic picture
can only give rise to forced sales, decreased values, and a drop in Snowbird
migration.

It is bad enough that we are captives of the property insurance companies
who have been authorized to obtain exorbitant increases in premiums. Surely
you elected representatives have the interest of the general public and can
show leadership in keeping a lid on taxes.

I would appreciate hearing your positions on this matter at your earliest
convenience.

Cordially,

Sidney Margles
501-5845 Marc Chagall
Montreal

Deerfield Beach, 33442

From:	Matthew Kahn <mkahn@yourfloridacpa.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, August 23, 2006 3:48 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Property taxes

Dear Governor Bush,
 
I wanted to address a problem that effects most individuals living in the State of Florida.  The issue is with the property taxes we pay to our government.
 
I am a CPA and have heard many of my clients as well as friends say that they are stuck living in their homes because they wouldn't be able to pay the increased property taxes that would be associated with the purchase of a new house.  These individuals aren't concerned with the monthly mortgage payment or even the cost of additional insurance premiums.  The deal buster always comes back as the substantial increase in property taxes.
 
I had read an article issued by the Broward County Property Appraisers office stating that law makers were considering a bill that would let existing home owners take their assessed value of their current homestead to a new home.  I was disappointed that the State did not act on this relief.  A law of this nature would have benefited all Floridians.  This bill would not effect the purchase of real estate purchased for first time home buyers, investors or individuals looking to flip properties.  
 
Another form of potential relief would be to increase the amount of the homestead exemption.  The amount of $25,000 has not been increased for inflation.  As an example, I purchased my home 11 years ago.  I paid $172,000 for my 4 bed 2 1/2 bath home.  The homestead exemption of $25,000 represented an exclusion of taxation of 14.5%.  As per my last property tax bill my home has been assessed at $375,810.  The homestead exemption of $25,000 represents an exclusion of taxation of 6.6%.  This makes no sense.
 
The State has passed a number of tax relief statues over the years.  Some of these statues I agree with and some I disagree with.  To my knowledge there has been no relief for homeowners with the exception of our "save our homes".
 
I would highly urge you and your office to attempt to help solve this problem.  A number of proposals have been submitted along with various ideas on how to correct this problem.  Unfortunately as what happens in government, people listen but fail to act.
 
Thanks for your time in this matter.
 
Sincerely yours,
 
Matthew Kahn

For example, we’ve been looking at very modest two and three-bedroom single-family houses, most built in the 1950’s and less than 1500 square feet, in South Pasadena (where we currently reside), Gulfport, Seminole, and Largo. I’d say the average price has been around $250,000.00, which is what we think our condo is worth. Problem is, we’ll go from paying $1400 in annual property taxes to an average of $4,000, and from $400 per year insurance, to about $2400 per year. This phenomenon has priced us completely out of the market, and we have three choices; stay where we are, go down in value to a dump house or a mobile home, or relocate to another county or state. I’m shocked and dismayed that our leaders would allow property taxes to get to that point. I’ve reads in the newspaper that government revenues have grown, yet I see no more services than I ever have, and you’re spending it nearly as fast as it’s going up!

*	Just because property prices (not values, just prices in reality) have risen, doesn’t mean the average taxpayer’s ability to pay them has.
*	Where do you get off thinking you’re entitled to spend my money instead of doing the right thing and keeping taxes in check?
*	Not only do we have to pay more for a home, now we get the triple whammy of dramatically higher mortgage payments, taxes, and insurance.
*	You should lower the taxes to offset the increase due to price increases.
*	Make the homestead exemption 50% of the cost of a home, not to exceed a certain ceiling, like a max of $250,000 exempt. When the homestead exemption started it was about half the price of a home, but it hasn’t kept pace with price increases, so now it’s an eighth instead of half.
*	Reduce the millage by the same rate that home prices increase to keep the tax base the same. Actual dollar amount increases should require a solid budgetary reason and vote.
*	 Reduce the millage rate on home purchases to offset the increase in prices, thereby resulting in the same, or slightly higher taxes than were paid by the seller.
*	If private insurance companies can’t make a profit in Florida with sensible rates, then perhaps the state should look at self-funding and running our own insurance, similar to FEMA flood insurance.
*	Look into passing law making it illegal for mortgage lender and underwriters to require hazard insurance.
*	$2400 annually for a normal homeowners policy on a 50-year old $236,000 concrete block house not in a flood zone is nothing short of outrageous.

Subject:	Bay County Property Taxes

  
August 22nd,  2006
 
CDR Stephen J. Kozloski, USN (retired)
12607 Ensley Lane
Leawood, KS 66209
 
The Honorable Jeb Bush, Governor of the State of Florida
 
Dear Governor Bush,
 
    I have been fond of Florida since my first visit to Naples, Florida in 1961, as a youngster, to visit my grandparents who wintered there.  My mom currently lives in Leesburg where she moved to retire with my late father in 1984.  And, though I had been away from the state because of my duties in the Navy, I was a resident from 1985 to 2005.  I now live in Leawood Kansas, a suburb of Kansas City, where my wife enjoys a fulfilling career with SPRINT.  (Her career is the only reason we are not in Florida – after following me around for the past 18 or so years, supporting her new career only seems fair.)
 
    In my travels during my Navy career I purchased a small piece of property in Panama City Beach.  We have visions of either living in the house we built there full time or have it be a vacation home in the near future (currently we have a renter in the house). 
 
    Recently I received my annual statement for expected property tax from Bay County.  It was quite unsettling to see that the property tax that was approximately $1700 in 2005 is now more than $3650.  I understand the need to properly assess homes to ensure fair and equitable taxes are paid in order to deliver valuable county services.  However, three things bother me regarding this property tax increase:
 

1.	There are people in Bay County who, for one reason or another, cannot take advantage of the homestead exemption protecting them, to some extent, from this large property tax.  The result will be middle income people being forced out of the community because they cannot afford to live there any longer.

    2.   Poor people who live in the county will be forced out of the community because of the resultant increase in rents that  
          will inevitably occur.  (Unfortunately I know this will also negatively impact the military personnel at the Coastal Systems 
          Station area; and could possibly impact decisions to continue to grow that facility.)
 

3.	The assessments (appraisals) conducted, in no way match what the property is worth, and this is a very important factor, nor has the property ever been as valuable as the current assessment suggests.

 
    If the third point is true, and I am certain that it is correct, the first two points will occur unnecessarily.  Sometimes people get “taxed out of a community” – I know this to be true.  I understand it, it is unfortunate, but I know it occurs and basically I have no problem with it when it occurs over time, as it usually does.  But to have it occur so quickly and to such a large degree is unprecedented.  It is important for you to know this will have only a minor impact on me, I am passing you this information because many of your constituents are to be seriously impacted by this situation.
 
    I know this is not really your problem, because technically it is a county issue. But, because I know what kind of person you are, I know this will concern you.  I also hope this is not the first information you have received about the choices the county commissioners are making in Bay County; it would be hard to believe I would be the first to bring this to your attention.  Nonetheless, if any “common-sense” can be introduced to the decision makers in Bay County many people will be in your debt.  
 
    I will send you a formal letter, as well as formal letters to each of the county commissioners, in the near future.  But I thought I would pass this note to you quickly via e-mail.  A large constituent of people in Bay County will greatly appreciated your involvement in this matter.
 
Very respectfully,
 
Stephen J. Kozloski

From:	william wheeler <wpurviswheeler@yahoo.com>

To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] homestead excemtion

Governor,
Please use your leadership abilities to make sense of this homestead exception debate. 
Let’s face it, we are all going to have to pay taxes. All we can hope for is that the taxes are equitable. I propose all homestead exception be eliminated, not increased. Under the present scheme of things a person with a $50,000 home pays 100% more taxes than a person with a $25,000 home; a person with a $75,000 home pays twice as a person with a $50,000 home. The people that really get the shaft is the renters, they don’t get any exemptions. Their rent reflects what the landlord has to pay in taxes, with no exemptions. The homestead exception is nothing but a political gimmick. Some of the lawmakers look at our temporary citizens (winter visitors) with real-estate as a good source of taxes, Lets face it winter visitors are an industry just as much as a factory. Rather than giving them a break, as we do other employers, we tax them more even though they use fewer services, such as schools. Another thing about winter visitors, in most cases they have no school age children, but they support schools big time. Eliminate the homestead exception not increase it.
 
Thanks for your service,
 
W.P. Wheeler
4100 vanguard Ave
Titusville, FL 32780
a taxpayer on a $100,000 home

Hence my property taxes for next year will be either $14,054.98 or $18,227.91.

Greed is a powerful thing.

We had a large number of  families relocating from the northeast when are sales prices were lower but now with our price increases these families our finding our taxes higher than the taxes even in New York or New Jersey.

From:	Kevin McInerney <kmcinerney@rrsells.com>
Sent:	Friday, August 18, 2006 12:02 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Property Tax Legislation

Dear Governor Bush,

 

Thank you for taking an interest in the property tax issues our state is having and will continue to have until something is ironed out.

I have personally bought and sold property in various states and cannot understand why we cannot look to other states for the answers to our problems.

 

In Illinois they have a reassessment every four years on property taxes. This allows a buyer or seller not to get socked with a huge increase on all property, commercial as well as residential. The growth is continual as the assessments are divided into four areas which in turns promotes a continual base of growth for the state coffers and an expected increase for all property owners.

 

Easiest and most desirable is Prop 13 from California. Basic and to the point it promotes growth based on sales price and a one percent constant. Any buyer of commercial or residential real estate can figure out what their taxes will be to date of purchase and can also generate a finite number for the increases to come in future years. 
This will promote stability and growth especially on the commercial sales for a variety of reasons. First and foremost you can establish a set amount of money you will need this year and each following year for your budget and adjust your budget for future years. This works not only for commercial but also for residential. If a quick study was done by just averaging all property in the smallest county and using the Prop. 13 method the numbers will quickly show that the state will not lose and should actually gain from this position as well as spreading the tax throughout instead of burdening the new owners. Another plus will be people will be able to sell their property without issues from taxes and gain on the amount of sales increasing which in turn will increase the doc. Stamps due on sale. Which can be raised a percent or less to help add to the coffers from any decrease the state may see from the percentage cap. Another thought is maybe we can increase the California idea to 1.25 or 1.5 percent of the purchase price, whatever numbers make sense. Also there can be a rollback on sold properties through out the state which may not make everyone happy but will be fair in the long run to all involved.

 

 

 

Here is an example of what happened to me and my customer.

DATE:  November 17, 2005 

TO:  Dennis Brotman 

FROM:  Jane Marshall, Tax Law Specialist, Property Tax Technical Unit Your email to Governor Bush was forwarded to this office for response because the Department of Revenue is the state agency charged with the responsibility of providing information pertaining to the local property tax to Florida property owners. Your concern, as with many others, is the rising values and property taxes in Florida. You note that a primary residence is capped at 3 percent but also that non-resident and second home properties in Florida do not enjoy this protection. You also propose appraising property on an index of 50 percent rather than exempting the first $25,000 due to the fact that many who use the same government services pay no taxes because their property is valued at less than $25,000. The Florida Legislature is aware of the skyrocketing property values and taxes for all residents of Florida. There are currently two prefiled bills for the upcoming legislative session which would place the same assessment limitation on all residential or commercial properties as the current homestead property enjoys. These are HJR 39 and SJR 22. You may wish to encourage your friends and neighbors to contact their legislators to urge support of these proposals. 

In the meantime, non-residents can appeal the amount of their assessment through an informal conference with the property appraiser, the county value adjustment board and finally the circuit court. 

However, if the value of the property is not at issue, each taxing authority is required to compute the "rolled-back rate" defined as that millage rate which will provide the same ad valorem tax revenue for each taxing authority as was levied during the prior year". (Emphasis

supplied) See section 200.065(1), Florida Statutes. Even if the fair market value or assessed taxable value of substantially all property in the county were to increase at a uniform rate, most taxpayers would not incur any significantly increased tax bill if the "rolled-back rate" were adopted. Each year, on the Notice of Proposed Taxes sent out by the property appraiser, there is a listing of the taxing authorities levying the actual tax on your property. There are listed the times and places of the budget hearings. These are public hearings at which you may speak directly to the officials who are levying the tax. Prior to the hearings, the taxing authorities are required to publish the proposed budgets for the ensuing fiscal year. We encourage taxpayers to become involved in the budget and hearing process in order help alleviate the type situation that you describe. 

This response is not a policy statement or interpretation of state law or rules, but is provided for your information and assistance since the Department of Revenue does not administer property tax. 

NOTE:  If you should decide to communicate with us by e-mail again, please bear in mind that the Department of Revenue does not currently provide a secure site for Internet communication and cannot guarantee the confidentiality of any information sent to us by e-mail. We recommend that you send confidential information to us by mail rather than e-mail. You can write to us at: 

Florida Department of Revenue 
Property Tax Administration 
P. O. Box 3000 
Tallahassee, Florida 32315-3000

How can people Budget for unknown and extremely high increasing Property taxes?

They use the same Government facilities as others and are entitled to the same Government programs, even more then those who own property appraised in excess of $25,000.00.  A better way to make the Florida Property Tax system more far would be an index.  That is, all homes would be appraised but taxed only on a State Fixed Percentage number. 

ie....house appraised at 50,000.; index 50%...taxable figure $25,000, etc.  Using a method like this will more fairly spread the Tax Burden to ALL.

Trim notice time again, and the property tax assessors office is licking their chops. The worn-out line “your house will be assessed at current market value” gives the assessors office a blank check, to withdraw money from your pocket. I believe the property tax system here is extremely unfair, mainly because “market value” has risen so insanely in the past few years. People with a home here, who for some reason can’t legally homestead, have been “market valued” to death, causing many to sell or go in debt. 

For one example, say you bought a home in Sarasota four years ago, you lived in it but for some reason couldn’t legally homestead it. The way property values have been rising recently, your tax bill has probably doubled or tripled… The unfair “market value” blank check shakedown.   

For another example, two moderately-priced brand new homes were built side by side four years ago. One was occupied and homesteaded, one was bought as a second home by middle-class people who wanted a home to retire to in a few years. Today, four years later, the people with the homestead are still there, but the house next door has a for sale sign because the people who wanted to come down here and retire can no longer afford the property taxes which have tripled in four years. The unfair “market value” shakedown again. This should be a crime. There needs to be limits! I really think the mafia helped write the tax laws in the state of Florida. Why should the state and local government be the only ones who enjoy the increased value of our homes?   

My solution? Right now my “market value” is equal to my “assessed value”. Cap the “assessed value” at a max of 5-7% per year for residential single family homes, regardless of homestead, and issue an official document to all home-buyers stating that the local assessor has a blank check written on your bank account if you don’t or can’t homestead. Then give examples of properties that have doubled or tripled in value in the past four years, leaving non-homesteaded people giving it all away to the government. This should be part of a legal form designed to be a warning and signed by anyone buying a home down here.   

Will this cause great loss of money to government services? Probably not. Right now, for many people who in the past few years couldn’t homestead, government is the primary beneficiary to our insanely increased property values. Again, a crime.

August 17, 2006
TO:  Florida Legislators
 
Yesterday was a dark day for Florida. The Governor and his cabinet found an old provision on the legislativ e shelf to activate an "Insurance  pool" to rescue the business  owners of the state.  While I agree it was necessary to address the business property insurance problem, I believe it should have been a part of an overall resolution to alleviate the property insurance crisis not only for busines owners, but for the homeowners who after all, are the customers for the businesses just bailed out and the people who pay to operate the State of Florida including the legislature.
 
By  this action,  the emergency and crisis status has been reduced and thus, the priority of addressing the homeowner's crisis has been diminished.  What instead should have ben done is  for the governor to have called a special session to address the entire crisis and find a solution applicable to homeowners as well as for business.  
 
The problem clearly is that Citizen's Property Insurance is insufficienty braodly based leading to its failure to deal with the homeowner's crisis. Coverage mst be far more broadly based while there is a need to put a cap on the maximum exposure by comercial insurance companies making it feasible for them to re-enter the market.  Yes, this may mean public financial underwriting of some of the risk. But the public already pays billions via disaster assistance programs at federal, state and local levels. 
 
The fallacy of the  present system is illustrated by the South Miami Dade  Dixie Hwy  division of risk. East of Dixie Hwy, commercial lines refuse to write windstorm  forcing residents into Citizens. But Country Walk which was destroyed by   Andrew  is west of Dixie as are many flood zones such as Sweetwater.   On a national scale,  disasters can and have hit across the country as tornadoes devastate entire communities, floods in the Northeast  ravage large areas, fires all over burn homes and earthquakes in the west threaten millions of residents.  
    The problem is national as is the cost exemplified by what happened last year with Katrina and other  storms. The resolution therefore must also be national but at the least, statewide.  It is wrong to  make homeowners pay horrendous premiums  which can reach $5-10,000 for average homes under the threat of foreclosure by banks. This borders on extortion and has led to unaffordability of homeownership by more and more people.  There is a resolution for this and it is not  for the Florida Cabinet and Legislature to  save  businesses while putting the homeowner on the backburner.
    I urge you to elevate this to the highest priority and demand a special session to resolv e the crisis not only for the business owner, but also for the  homeowner.
 
Gunther Karger
August 17, 2006

well.  Halifax Medical Center has gotten permission to increase their

already cover.

insurance premiums increase that amount resulting in no raise (for those of
us lucky enough to have insurance).

to 10 years.

will either lose their homes due to foreclosure or sell and move back

assessments to the 2004 level.  Residents on fixed incomes may then be able
to survive; a tax decrease would be a godsend.

Sincerely,
James L. Russell, Jr.

Today I am writing concerning the 90% proposed budget cut for the Family Cafe's Annual Governor's Summit on Disabilities and Conference.  I was going to begin by reviewing the agenda's of these meetings and specifically telling you the workshops and contacts I have made while attending these meetings. Nearly 10,000 individuals attended this year's meeting alone.  This venue  needs expanding, not cut! 
 
    I have ask the Family Cafe to send you back issues of the meeting agendas.  Please imagine yourself as an adult with disabilities or the caregiver of a loved one or  the parent of a child or adult who is severely disabled as you review them.  Even with your position in our government, as an individual where would you begin to find the services that you need?
 
     I attended every workshop on the IDEA and IEP's that I could find locally, but I didn't really learn how to help my son until I attended a Family Cafe's Conference.  Now my son is 20, we have issues of housing, transportation, the legal system, relationships, independence vs. guardianships options, additional medical needs and supported employment, and much more as he ages.  I have obtained information, had questions answered and made contacts at these conferences that I truly would not have gotten anywhere else. 
 
    As a member of several local organizations for the disabled, I share the information that I obtain because they do not have such contacts and resources.  I have obtained information for my son's medical staff as they are interested in having such resources for other patients.   It just isn't out there any where else. This is an opportunity to meet with representatives of many organization, vendors and other parents to get the solutions we so desperately need.  It is a weekend packed with so much vital information that you wish it would last a week.  I return home with a notepad of information and literally 3 or 4 bags of information to read and it is all relevant. 
 
   My son like many disabled individuals does not have a case worker, I am his case worker.  My mother is my 40 year old brother's case manager.  We have to find and do and follow-up on everything.  Services for the disabled are shamefully scare in our state.  Proper support services for mentally ill are even harder to find. Too many budgets have already been cut.  Often disabled citizens are left to fend for themselves.  Navigating these systems are difficult for even able-bodied people.  But we do not give up, we learn, we learn what is out there and what isn't  and we learn to do things for ourselves.  The Family Cafe's Conference has been  instrumental in the success of so many disabled individuals as well as families.  I know it has been influential in son's progress and my ability to guide him to independence.

More and more individuals are becoming disabled and babies are being born with disabilities.  You can't ignore them, you can't allow further budget cuts,  they are not going away. And we do not deserve to have this vital networking opportunity taken away from us by our government. 
 
   Families are fighting battles within the walls of their homes to care for their loves ones, becoming financially and spiritually broke seeking services and answers to the many questions and needs.  Please continue to budget this service, so they we learn to help them and help others along with way.

Dear Lt. Governor Jennings,
     I am a citizen of Cantonment, Florida, and a registered voter.  I am writing to you about the Property and Casualty Insurance Reform Committee.  In 2004 Hurricane Ivan devastated the area I live in.  The State of Florida and Gulf Power did a wonderful job making sure the people of the area had food, water, and making sure the power was quickly restored.  My family was personally very lucky, we had minimal damage and never even had to file an insurance claim.  
     The problems begin after the hurricane.  In 2004 our insurance premium was $687.00 per year.  This year our premium is $2,267.00.  My husband and I own our home, and have a moderate mortgage.  We are a low-income family, making approximately $21,000 per year for a 3 person family.  This brings our homeowner insurance to 10.9% of our income.  Couple this with raising gas prices, higher property taxes, and overall inflation and we are in serious danger of losing our home.
     I recently read a proposal put forth online by a group called Americans for Insurance Reform.  Their plan suggests taking hurricane coverage out of the hands of the private insurance sector, as was done with the National Flood Insurance Program.  I am not well informed about the possible solutions to the problems with homeowner insurance, but this possibility has a certain appeal to me.    
     The stories I have heard about denied claims scare me.  People have lost their homes and their belongings.  Many of these people paid premiums to the insurance companies believing that this would protect them.  Only to find that the insurance companies are more concerned with profits than with the needs of their clients.
     I beg you as a human, a citizen and a voter to please consider the lives and interests of all of Florida's citizens.  I realize that you are a very busy person, and that there are many aspects of this problem that make it very difficult not only for policy holders, but policy carriers.  Insurance companies are refusing to write policies, denying claims, and doing their best to mitigate their losses.  We need someone to stand up for the citizens.  
     Thank you for your time and your commitment to solving this horrible problem in the State of Florida.
Jennifer Senna

From:	Karl_F_Gerwe@fpl.com

To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	"Save Our Homes" situation


Dear Gov. Bush:

I'm writing in favor of either the repeal or substantial re-write of the
so-called Save Our Homes amendment. I'm a 56 year old, native white collar
Floridian from a blue collar upbringing who has worked very hard to
"trade-up" over the years to a nice home here in New Smyrna Beach.
Ironically, my neighbors who moved here to retire from other states and
have contributed little to Florida via taxes or hard work, pay less than
1/2 of the $6500+ in property taxes that I pay. Newer neighbors are saddled
with property taxes in the $10K-$12K and up range despite all of our homes
and "fair market values" being very similar. It shouldn't be this way as
it's killing the real estate market (it's not really the rising interest
rates - it's the growing realization of what happens to your property taxes
when you move!!!) and prohibiting older "empty-nesters" like me from
downsizing to a smaller, less expensive home. I've done the calculations
and, even if my home were many thousands lower in value, my taxes would go
up to $8k or more. That's nearly $700 per month that I would have to budget
for property taxes in my retirement years - not what one would want or
could afford to do unless very wealthy and certainly not "saving my home"!
For those of us who have moved or built a new one since the amendment was
implemented, it has created an unbelievable inequity in how we are taxed.
Note that my wife and I, both professionals, will be moving out of our home
state of Florida upon retirement in order to maintain the lifestyle we
would like to live as we cannot afford to retire here if "Save Our Homes"
stays in-place as currently written. In addition, my son, a 28 year old Air
Force Captain and F-16 fighter pilot, has already told me that he will
never come back to Florida to live as he cannot afford the property taxes
here which are higher than any other state in the US that he's been
stationed at - a sad comment for a father to hear.

Please pass my perspective on this subject to your committee now studying
the amendment. The State must do the right thing and tax all who live here
equitably. Even if my taxes increase (they shouldn't if Volusia County
government would follow private enterprise's lead and operate in a leaner
mode), at least it will be equitable.

Thank you for your concern and leadership........Karl Gerwe, 6960
Turtlemound Rd, New Smyrna Beach, FL 32169

Karl F. Gerwe Jr., CEM
Manager, Major Accounts
PO Box 2851
425 N. Williamson Bvd.
Daytona Beach, FL 32120-2851

From: lfahey@familycafe.net [mailto:lfahey@familycafe.net] 
Sent: Tuesday, August 15, 2006 1:13 PM
To: thewhetros@yahoo.com
Subject: HELP SAVE THE FAMILY CAFE ANNUAL CONFERENCE


Dear Friends,

The Family Café began with a simple dream: educating and empowering people
with disabilities and their families, so they could participate fully in
society. 

Thanks to much hard work, and the financial support of the State of Florida,
that dream has become a reality. The Family Café Annual Conference has grown
from a simple vision to become the largest, most successful statewide
conference of its kind in the nation, hosting over 10,000 individuals this
past June. 

Sadly, THAT DREAM IS NOW IN JEOPARDY. 

The State of Florida has informed The Family Café that THE BUDGET FOR THE
ANNUAL CONFERENCE WILL BE CUT BY 90%! 

This puts the entire Annual Conference in danger of being CANCELLED!

We believe that THIS IS UNACCEPTABLE, and we believe you will feel the same
way. 

Informed families make better decisions and build effective partnerships
that improve outcomes for children and adults with disabilities. Floridians
with disabilities deserve a forum for education and networking; they
certainly DO NOT deserve to have such an essential resource as The Family
Café Annual Conference taken away by their state government. 

Our event has provided great benefit to thousands of Florida’s families, and
will continue to do so in the future, WITH YOUR HELP! HERE’S WHAT YOU CAN
DO:

1.	Contact Agency for Persons with Disabilities Director Shelly
Brantley at (850) 488-1558 or shelly.brantley@apd.state.fl.us. Let her know
how much The Family Café Annual Conference has meant to you and your family.
Ask her to submit a Budget Amendment Request to the Florida Legislature to
fully fund the Annual Conference immediately. 

2.	Contact your State Legislators in the House and Senate. (To find
your State Senator online, visit www.flsenate.gov and enter your zip code.
To find your State Representative, visit
http://www.myfloridahouse.gov/Sections/Representatives/myrepresentative.aspx
and enter your zip code.) Tell them how much the Annual Conference means to
you, and ask them to fully restore its funding immediately. 

3.	Contact Senator Lisa Carlton, Chair of the Senate Ways and Means
Committee, at (941) 486-2032 or carlton.lisa.web@flsenate.gov, and
Representative Joe Negron, Chair of the House Fiscal Council at (772)
221-4904 or cheri.vancura@myfloridahouse.gov. These two Legislators lead the
committees that make budget decisions. They need to know about The Family
Café Annual Conference, and how essential it is to keep its funding intact. 

4.	Let us know what action you have taken, either by e-mail to
lfahey@familycafe.net or by calling our office at 1-888-309-CAFÉ (2233). 

This is a CRITICAL MOMENT FOR THE FAMILY CAFÉ. Will the dream die, or will
it be sustained? WE MUST ACT NOW! This is the time to advocate for
ourselves, to make our voices heard. Please take action immediately, and
continue to call, e-mail and write between now and August 28th. For you
family, your community, and for all of the Floridians that will benefit from
the Annual Conference in future years, please SPEAK OUT TO SAVE THE FAMILY
CAFÉ ANNUAL CONFERENCE TODAY! 

Thank you,
The Family Café

           Planet Realtor > Florida > News > Daily 
                        More feel insurance crisis pinch


                        PINELLAS PARK, Fla. -- Aug. 14, 2006 -- Florida's high-priced insurer of last resort, Citizens Property Insurance Corp., is increasingly becoming the only choice for thousands of condominium associations, resulting in skyrocketing unit maintenance fees and special assessments to pay the rate increases.



                        Since April, the number of condominium associations covered by the state-sponsored insurer has gone from 3,500 to 5,000, Citizens officials said, and new applications are coming in at a clip of 250 a week.



                        The increase is because of major insurers such as Allstate, Nationwide and State Farm exiting the condo market. That comes on top of the financial insolvency in June of Southern Family Insurance Co., a Poe Financial Group company and a major insurer of condominiums.



                        Over the past few months, Citizens has become the largest property insurer in Florida, mainly from homeowners who can't find coverage elsewhere.



                        "We are a symptom of a sick market," Christine Turner, Citizens director of consumer and legislative affairs told a group of condominium association officials in Pinellas Park on Friday.



                        "Eight hurricanes in two years has all but shut down the property insurance market in Florida," she said. "In the short term, Citizens is only the answer."



                        That answer, however, translates into much higher rates as condo owners discover the pain that hundreds of thousands of homeowners already have experienced as Citizens policyholders.



                        Condominium associations are seeing rate increases, of 100, 200, even 500 percent over rates in the voluntary market, said insurance brokers present at Friday's meeting.



                        In turn, the associations are sharing that cost with individual owners.



                        Condominium association insurance covers the common parts of a complex, such as unit exterior walls, roofs, foundations, clubhouses, swimming pools and grounds. It is in addition to an individual unit owners' own insurance.



                        Larry Huffman, the finance chairman of the Paradise Village condominium in Treasure Island, said the 51-unit complex is being dropped at the end of the year by its private insurer, and Citizens is the only insurer willing to cover it. He said premium rates are expected to more than quadruple from $87,000 annually to nearly $400,000 for the complex.



                        Huffman said that will raise his individual monthly insurance fees, part of his maintenance payment, from $390 a month to $600.



                        Although most condo owners have benefited by rising property values exceeding 100 percent, they worry that the higher monthly insurance costs will show up in reduced prices when it comes time to sell.



                        "The higher insurance rates will make units less marketable," he says.



                        The news only will get worse, said Paul Palumbo, Citizens chief underwriting officer. Starting Aug. 1, Citizens raised rates by 100 percent for condominiums in wind pool areas, which include the barrier islands in Pinellas County, he said.



                        In March, a second increase will occur as Citizens complies with a legislative mandate to ensure the company can better cope financially with a major hurricane, he said.



                        He did not have details on that increase but said "it would be significant."



                        © 2006 Tampa Tribune, Fla., Randy Diamond. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News.

Subject: Florida Intangibles Tax Vanishes

 

FYI,

 

The Florida Intangible Personal Property Tax has finally vanished altogether under legislation signed recently by Governor Jeb Bush. Florida investors’ portfolios of stock, bonds and mutual funds will no longer be subject to a wealth assessment on January 1 each year.

 

Florida investors are now free to invest more freely, without having to think about what your wealth might be on January 1. 

 

If you need more information on how the demise of the Florida Intangibles Tax could affect your investments or asset choices, please don’t hesitate to call me.

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Governor Jeb Bush 
To: Governor Jeb Bush 
Sent: Thursday, July 27, 2006 3:03 PM
Subject: Concerns regarding homeowner's insurance

Dear Friend:

 

Thank you for sharing your concerns regarding homeowner’s insurance.  Governor Bush appreciates your views and asked me to respond on his behalf. 

 

As a result of the past hurricane seasons, property insurance rates have increased.  The Governor knows this is a challenging reality for homeowners, businesses, and local governments, but understands increased rates are a common market reaction to the risk associated with insuring homes and businesses in Florida at a time when so much damage was caused by recent hurricanes.  

 

Governor Bush believes the underlying problems in the property insurance market can be resolved by encouraging mitigation of homes and buildings to make them more resistant to wind damage, and by encouraging private insurance companies to underwrite more of the state’s wind risk.  This would minimize the number of policies and the amount of claims exposure for Citizens Property Insurance Corporation (Citizens), the state’s insurer of last resort.  Citizens covers those who cannot obtain property insurance from the private market.     

 

On May 16, 2006, Governor Bush signed Senate Bill 1980 into law.  This bill provides policy reforms and funding to stabilize and improve the property insurance market.  Senate Bill 1980 assists private insurance companies with an Insurance Capital Build-up Incentive Program allowing private insurance companies to underwrite more policies in Florida.  The bill provides funding for free home inspections and grants for homeowners who choose to reinforce their homes against wind damage through the Florida Comprehensive Hurricane Damage Mitigation Program.  It also provides funding to offset the deficit of Citizens, reducing assessments to homeowners, and provides reforms to prevent future Citizens’ assessments.  Those with internet access can view the complete text of the bill online by typing in the bill number on the Senate’s homepage at www.flsenate.gov.

 

Governor Bush believes that long-term reforms are necessary to repair the underlying problems that exist in the insurance market.  The Governor created the “Property and Casualty Insurance Reform Committee” to address these important issues.  This Executive Order is online at: www.flgov.com/executive_orders.

 

Thank you again for writing.  Governor Bush wants to know how Floridians feel about the many critical issues we face and encourages you to share your views with your local legislative delegation.  Please be assured that the Governor will keep your ideas in mind as he forms policy for addressing these concerns.  

 

 

Sincerely,

L. Wright

Aide to the Governor

Office of Citizens’ Services

RE: Insurance in the State of Florida
 
Dear Lt Governor Jennings
 
 
Our property owners association (Inverness Landings, Inverness, FL) was recently notified by Allstate Insurance Company that the insurance coverage on the exterior and common areas and on the amenities of our condominium community where I reside is being cancelled. I have the required insurance coverage on the interior of my unit only, as the Association has always provided sufficient insurance to cover the exterior and common areas. All of the unit owners of our small complex have been advised by the Board of Directors that it will be necessary to charge each owner a special assessment of anywhere between $813.00 and $3048.00. This must be done thirty days prior to the expiration of our current policy in order to pay the up front premium that is required by the state insurance company.  According to the current insurance agents for our association, this state insurance company will not finance premiums and, therefore, we must pay the very high premium upfront. Prior to cancellation, the amount of my yearly maintenance fee that was going for insurance was approximately $202.26, a monthly rate of approximately $17.00.
 
As you can imagine, having to come up with a 300%-1400% increase in a short period of time on a fixed income presents an unreasonable financial burden on me and other property owners in our community and in other communities across the state. Due to the fact that we are in the middle of hurricane season, I know that our Association cannot go without insurance. My request is that something be done to review the insurance situation in this state and to fairly and justly determine premium costs based on actual claims, just like insurance companies do on auto insurance (e.g. many accidents, citations= higher premiums). To my knowledge, our Association has only had one claim since its inception in 1987, and the total amount of that was approximately one year’s premium. I do understand that, in order to cover uninsured owners, there is an add-on premium, but there should be a better way to come up with the necessary funds.
 
Any help or information you can offer me and other owners would be much appreciated. Thank you for your time.
 
Inverness Landings Unit Owner,
Joe Beaulieu

From: "McClellan, Tiffany" <Tiffany.McClellan@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US>
Subject: Your E-mail to Governor Bush
Date: Thu, 10 Aug 2006 14:59:19 -0400

Thank you for your letter to Governor Bush regarding property tax rates.
He appreciates hearing your views and has asked that I respond on his
behalf.

Governor Bush certainly appreciates your concerns regarding the
increasingly unfair property tax burden on Floridians.  There are
several inequities in our property tax structure which have become more
apparent in recent years.  In fact, in its recently ended regular
session, the Florida Legislature struggled with all of these issues, but
could not find a comprehensive solution because of the complexity of the
problem.  Consequently, the Legislature commissioned the Florida
Department of Revenue to conduct an in-depth study of the property tax
structure, with special emphasis on the unequal effects among various
groups of taxpayers.  Additionally, the Governor has appointed a 15
member committee to consider the research findings of the Department of
Revenue and others and to propose to the Legislature changes to the tax
system.  I know that this sounds like they are trying to avoid the
issue, but in all honesty, a thorough understanding of all the
consequences of any changes in Florida's property tax system must come
before concrete proposals are put forth.  This is particularly important
because the changes that are likely to be needed will require amendments
to the Florida Constitution, which will, in turn, require voter
approval.

Thank you again for contacting Governor Bush with your concerns.  He
always appreciates hearing from Florida taxpayers, whether they are
permanent residents or seasonal visitors.

Sincerely,

Tiffany McClellan
Executive Office of the Governor

Subject:	Insurance Reform  Committee "HELP"

I am so frustrated with the rising costs of insurance in our state. No only are the costs rising but our company "Nationwide Insurance" has been reducing the quality of our insurance policy for the past 5 years.
Let me explain.
We bought their premier policy which covered full replacement value for losses. We have been their customer for 12 years!
Then they started sending us notices to tell us that they were changing the coverage "reducing" coverage and excluding valuable coverage. They have chopped up our policy until there isn't much that they have at risk since any major losses get passed on to the reinsurer any way.
For example....they reduced coverage and do not cover water damage or mold or replacement "just repair" for loss incurred. Now they won't cover liability for our boat because they reduced the size boat they will insure to a limit under 26 feet 1". My husband and I own a florida built boat that is 28 feet. "That will make the boat manufacturers in Florida unhappy too! I think they should  be required to keep coverage in place that they have insured when they have not had to pay any claims for the coverage received.
 
Your new committee needs to look closely at the way insurers do their accounting. They actually make alot of money that they can transfer to reserve accounts and at the end of the policy year there books show them as making minimum gains because they can hide their money in reserve accounts.
 
When they do have losses they are able to pass them on to others and the re-insurance pays and we pay for the re-insurance too.
 
I think they should have to account for all their reserve monies and the reserve accounts should have to be adjusted to reflect their actual earnings by returning it to their bottom line when those reserves aren't actually paid out in claims at the end of the year.They like to keep the money in reserves for up to 5 years while their profit and loss statement goes from policy year to policy year.
 
In addition the committe should look at the fact that insurance companies actually make money when there are natural disasters like storms because they get to insure the re-build in the state which generates more profits for them on new construction from government insured loans.
I really think that in order to solve this insurance crisis this is what needs to happen.........
 
1. Insurance companies should only be able to underwrite the number of polices in any state equal to the amount of financial solvency that company has within it self before 're-insurance"
 
2. Give new companies incentives to come and write the surplus here at competative prices and again they should only be able to write what they can pay for without insulating theirself by being able to pass their large losses on to a third party. Presently the carriers that are writing here gobble up so much business here that they have too much risk in one state. Then they chop up the policies that they have on their books reducing the protection for customers and all the while they maintain a large profit center for theirselves because it's hard for other companies to get started here. 
Limit the amount that any one company can write here. Bring in many more companies that would be willing to take a piece of the pie and share some of the risk. 
 
3.Require insurance companies to give discounts that are meaningful. We have increased deductables and certainly have a no frills policy that results in a reduction of only $30.00 per year. That's nothing compared to how much we have to commit to pay out of pocket for any loss less than a total loss. In addition, where discounts are available for storm protection like shutters and tie-downs and so forth the homeowner has to pay for a licensed inspector "$200.00 for a discount that will be in the neighborhood of $80.00. 
 
4. Require insurance companies to tailor the policy to the homeowners needs...for example my policy makes me take contents insurance of more than $75000.00 as part of the standard policy. This amount is excessive since my contents and personal property are no where near that amount in value. I asked to have the amount reduced and the insurer said that it's standard and I have to carry that much insurance on contents even if I believe I am over insured in that area.
 
5.Encourage insurers to let homeowers buy insurance "ala-carte" for example we should be able to either buy a package or just liability if that's what we need. I have had to spend Sunday morning searching the internet for liability coverage for my little day sailer because I can't get it with my homeowers package any more. A product like that priced at about $75.00 a year isn't something most carriers want to  bother with. 
 
6. Time to introduce some new markets to start up companies looking to expand their book of business with minimal risk. 
 
In summary...All of us homeowners know your aware that there is a crisis here and we don't know how long we can hang on to our homes in Florida. We are being priced out of the state. School enrollment was actually down in our district because there were not as many children to serve as anticipated from surveys taken. Reason.....young families cannot afford to purchase a home in Hillsborough county. Who can afford the homes  that are being  built on the income received for jobs in this area...not many! 
 
We support our state...Help us with our insurance and Homestead exemption!
 
Thank you

http://www.sun-sentinel.com/business/local/sfl-zinsurethree08aug08,0,475264.story?coll=sfla-home-headlines&track=mostemailedlink 
Insurance companies shower Fla. politicians with donations to get rate hikes 




By Mark Hollis
South Florida Sun-Sentinel

August 8, 2006



TALLAHASSEE -- Florida's teetering property insurance industry got what it 
wanted this year from the state: new power to raise consumer prices.

The Legislature crafted the industry incentives as insurers poured hundreds of 
thousands of dollars into election campaigns of lawmakers, state political 
parties and candidates for statewide offices.

Insurers now can automatically raise prices for homeowner coverage 10 percent 
without any state review. And to make Florida even more enticing to property 
insurers, legislators tossed in $250 million in loans for insurers willing to 
expand in this state.

The changes have been hailed across the country by the insurance industry as a 
big help to do business in a hurricane-battered state.

Consumer activists say it was a giveaway to an industry that already gets its 
way in Tallahassee.

Analysts say the legislation was not a surprise, given the industry's 
consistent political donations.

``It's always hard to say that the money bought something specifically, but the 
money certainly buys the industry access to decision-makers,'' said Sue 
O'Connell, research director for the Institute on Money and State Politics, a 
nonpartisan watchdog group based in Montana. ``It opens doors and allows them 
[insurers] access in a way that the typical citizen may not have. It also seems 
pretty clear from the way that industry distributes its donations that Florida 
is a pretty important state to the insurance companies.''

Since 1996, the property insurance industry has given $11.2 million to Florida 
candidates and state political parties, with roughly three of every four 
dollars to Republicans, according to research by the South Florida Sun-
Sentinel.

The 2006 campaigns already have received at least $1.7 million from the 
property insurance industry, state records show.

O'Connell has examined property insurance industry campaign contributions 
across the country over three election cycles -- 2000, 2002, and 2004 -- and 
found Florida is vital to the property insurance market, judging by where the 
industry spends its campaign donations.

She said that in 2004, Florida ranked No. 10 among all states in total 
contributions from political donors. But in candidate contributions from the 
property insurance industry, she said, Florida politicians ranked second in the 
nation, behind only California that year.

Most donations to GOP

The insurance industry has given the bulk of its money to the party in power, 
the Sun-Sentinel has found. At least $4 million has been given in the last 
decade to the Republican Party of Florida, mainly from industry trade groups 
and associations but also from insurers, their lobbyists and executives.

By contrast, the Florida Democratic Party received slightly more than $1 
million.

The contributions represent a small fraction of what's given each year to state 
parties and candidates in Florida. Other industries, such as telecommunications 
businesses, home builders and real estate agents, give more. Sun-Sentinel 
research found that about 2 percent of what's been given to all Florida 
campaigns and state parties since 1996 -- or $11.2 million of more than $557 
million -- can be reported as having come from the property insurance 
industry.

Campaign finance analysts say the Florida insurance industry still packs a 
political wallop. That power was on display May 16 when Gov. Jeb Bush signed 
into law the 156-page property insurance bill that guarantees higher 
policyholder costs and bigger insurance industry profits.``This is the most 
significant, comprehensive property insurance legislation that has been enacted 
since Hurricane Andrew,'' said Len Brevik, the national executive vice 
president and chief executive officer of the National Association of 
Professional Insurance Agents. He said it's ``precisely the kind of 
innovation'' that Congress should mimic.

Critics call it a politically timid and anti-consumer answer to what ails 
Florida's insurance market. The law has been criticized in recent weeks by 
Democratic candidates for governor and some Republicans, such as state Rep. 
Randy Johnson of Winter Garden, a candidate to be Florida's chief financial 
officer.

``The insurance crisis has crept on the kitchen tables of Floridians and they 
are mad about it and responding to it. ...,'' Johnson said of reaction to 
increased rates. ``It is about insurance company greed, plain and simple.''

While some candidates criticize the law as an industry sellout, Florida's top 
insurance regulators, such as state Chief Financial Officer Tom Gallagher, a 
Republican running for governor, say it was just the start of a solution. His 
2006 gubernatorial campaign has received at least $379,000 in donations from 
the insurance industry. Only the Republican and Democratic state parties and 
Bush's gubernatorial campaigns have received more money from the state's 
insurers than Gallagher has taken in for his 2006 race for governor.

He also has received at least $369,000 in industry donations during previous 
campaigns for other state offices, including the one he holds.

Gallagher campaign aides say Gallagher is not beholden to the insurers.

``No one has been more forceful and cracked down on insurance companies more 
than Tom Gallagher,'' said Alberto Martinez, Gallagher's gubernatorial 
spokesman. ``He's called State Farm and Allstate out on the carpet whenever 
they've tried raising rates and not responding to their customer's needs. ... 
Tom has a record of fighting for consumers and a record of speaking his 
mind.''

Campaign finance records show Jeb Bush's campaign for governor in 2002 received 
at least $201,000 from the property insurance industry. This year, he gave 
legislators surprisingly little guidance on how to fix the state's troubled 
property insurance market.

During his State of the State speech in early March, Bush called for better 
hurricane preparedness but provided no direction about insurance issues, 
including what to do with financially troubled Citizens Property Insurance 
Corp. Citizens is the state-run home insurer, and now the state's biggest 
property insurer. Its size is a sore point the state never intended.

When Bush signed the new property insurance bill into law, he knew consumers 
wouldn't be happy. ``I will accept responsibility that we will have higher 
rates,'' Bush said.

Bush and Republican legislators made their first move when they created the 
Task Force on Long-Term Solutions for Florida's Hurricane Market prior to the 
2005 hurricane season.

The 13-member task force conducted eight public meetings. The panel of mostly 
insurance industry insiders overwhelmingly recommended short-term, industry-
friendly solutions, only some of which were adopted.

In a 58-page report, the task force repeatedly called for what the Florida 
property insurance industry wanted -- ``greater flexibility'' with regulators. 
``The majority of the people on the task force had some industry tie,'' said 
Steve Burgess, a task force member and a consumer advocate who works under the 
state Office of Insurance Regulation.

`Afraid to be bold'

Some legislators, insurance industry lobbyists and analysts say lawmakers 
settled on the bill because of their concern about doing more harm than good.

``The single biggest issue that will cause the state's economy to stop is not 
handling this insurance situation correctly,'' said Sen. J.D. Alexander, a Lake 
Wales Republican on the Senate Banking and Insurance Committee. Records show 
Alexander, who helped negotiate the final bill, has accepted at least $95,000 
in donations from insurance interests to his political campaigns since 1996.

Bush says Florida is better off with the law than nothing.

``It's not easy to make the tough choices,'' Bush said. ``If we had not made 
the tough choices this year, it would have come back to haunt us.''

Others don't see it that way.

``A lot of these issues are technical. So a lot of legislators aren't 
comfortable with certain things. When an insurance company lobbyist says `this 
and this,' it's pretty difficult for someone who is not an expert to know that 
they are lies,'' said Birny Birnbaum, an economist with the Center for Economic 
Justice, in Austin, Texas.

Robert Hunter, director of insurance for the Consumer Federation of America, 
said: ``The (Florida) Legislature is afraid to be bold. They were so afraid 
that the industry is going to bolt that they won't take the kind of action that 
needs to be taken.''

Dear Honorable Governor of Florida, Jeb Bush,
 
   Anthony House needs your help. Anthony House is a 501C3 organization in Mt Dora/Zellwood, Florida serving homeless individuals and families from far beyond the Tri-County area. Anthony House is so much more than the “shelter “ it is billed as. Anthony House is a life-changing program serving 65 “Guests”.   At any given time 1/3 are children. Anthony House, beyond dorm-style living accommodations, includes children’s Day Care, playgrounds, library, and Adult Learning Center where paradigms are shifted and lives become focused to re-enter employment and gainfully into community.
   What many aren’t aware of is that Anthony House serves its community offering household goods/furnishings, childcare furnishings, toiletries, and food, support to any who ask.   Being willing to say “I am in need” maybe a stumbling block called denial, but here it is utilized as an invitation. Cooperating in assistance to another may be the lifting of a straw,  which alone had become insurmountable obstacle.
   Being rural Anthony House becomes like the homeless: marginalized. “Out of sight = out of mind”.  With paperwork being the essential element in programs demonstrability instead of the actual work resulting in overcoming problems of which homelessness’ became the critical symptom of, perpetuates the problem. Homelessness’ and hunger are symptoms of other issues that need personal, individual attentions, which  ‘2 hots and a cot’ without bars can never provide. Personally, I have witnessed miracles in lives here. 
In its 22 years of operation, Anthony House continues to hold individuals as our priority over numbers; doing so Anthony House has lost much funding. Many have perfect paperwork with limited works as results. The Anthony House program is simple without frills for further cuttings.  
      Please help Anthony House help those in need ? Having a disability, and having had problems, and been in need where there was no such place, I feel Anthony House is a miracle that needs duplicating. We are not perfect, nor do everything perfectly, but with HIS Grace. Anthony House is a God thing for sure… right from Mathew 25:29,32-46.  Please support us with provision for this to continue.   Anthony House needs food, forks, and funds.

From:	maryanne barksdale <mastcb1@msn.com>
Sent:	Friday, August 11, 2006 3:57 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Insurance

Dear Gov. Bush,
 
Reluctantly, I will add to your burden of messages of insurance woes. Our homeowners policy was renewed  in April with the company we have had for 8 years, Horace Mann. The payment was due on July 1st and I got it there in full, for the year well ahead of time. We felt we were safe for another year. In a letter dated Aug. 5th,  one month into our coverage, we received notice it was cancelled and we would be insured until Nov. 5th. 
 
We were stunned and have spent this week  trying to get coverage as we must protect our investment in our home. Today we located a company  through AAA who would give us coverage for the coming year for $ 4,500. We really can not afford it and I will have to sell stock to pay for it.
 
Our home has been for sale for a year as it is much larger at this point in our lives than we need. It has not sold though we have reduced it 8%. It is among 3 houses on out street for sale and  ours is similar in size  and space as the  others and we have it priced well below the others. The cost of insurance, taxes and interest makes it out of range for most people. We would be willing to reduce it more but have had no offers.
 
We are from Va. and our children are all there. We love Pensacola and want to stay here but it is getting out of the question  to be affordable to live in Florida. Many people we know in our age bracket have gone. I am nearly 76 and my husband nearly 80. He has been retired 16 years and the costs of everything have gone up so much we live a rather spartan life now. Help is impossible to get here and we really can not afford to pay for it. We can continue the yard work  and home repairs for awhile but it isn't so easy now to do it all.
 
Today, we are down and out because we love it here and know we must leave when we can sell our home. I realize we are fortunate that I do own some stock to sell to pay for the homeowners insurance. However, we can not continue to do that.
 
My hope is that someway, somehow, insurance costs can be contained to a more reasonable fee. We had damage from Ivan and were very poorly treated by Horace Mann Ins. For instance, we had 6 estimates for our roof and our insurance paid less than any of them. We found them so unpleasant to deal with we paid for much ourselves  rather than fight with them. When Dennis came along we had a more modest amount of damage, below our figure of deductible which is between $5,000 & 6,000 . We had that to pay and our pad for unusual and unexpected expenses was  exhausted.
 
I would appreciate any efforts  in controlling insurance costs you could make on behalf of those of us who are old, possibly goofy, not so well off financially as we   once were. It makes me very sad to accept the fact that we will have to leave this lovely area.
 
Thank you for your consideration,
 
Mary Anne Barksdale
7413 Camale Dr.
Pensacola, Fl. 32504

From: MICHAEL F FITZPATRICK [mailto:mike1929@verizon.net] 
Sent: Friday, August 11, 2006 1:15 PM
To: Lt. Governor Toni Jennings
Subject: What About Us?


Dear Lt. Governor Jennings:
   I read where the first day of the insurance reform committee was taken up discussing the matching funds program It was interesting to note that there wasn't even one comment reported that this program is for the richer Floridian. Not one member stopped to say wait a minute, this program doesn't apply to the less financially fortunate Floridian, who can't even afford the uncalled for exhorbitant homeowner's insurance premium never mind paying for repairs. Not one of them showed the common sense to realize that the program is stacked to favor the rich as only the rich can take advantage of it.
   I've been a Republican for over 50 years, but I have to say that Jeb Bush is a failure; he's failed in the only real crisis Florida has faced in his near 8 years in office. 
   The home resale market has collapsed. Prices are going to tumble,and even after they do, it is doubtful the market real estate will recover. Foreclosures have already tripled, and they are still multiplying while the Governor's hand picked committee lauds a program that is useless to the little guy. 
   I spent over 35 years in the insurance field as an underwriter, consultant and an insurance purchaser for a very large corporation, and I'll tell you that there is no way the private insurance industry is retuning to Florida unless the insurers can cherry pick and charge even higher premiums. This Governor, by his inability to see and do what s necessary, is responsible for the financial destruction of the lives of thousands of Floridians, and before someone is elected who will do what is right, millions of lives will be destroyed.
   There is only one viable answer, and it must be done quickly before more lives are ruined along with the state's economy. The State must adopt a State Catastrophe Property Insurance Program with a single per $1,000 premium rate based on insured value and applicable througout the state regardless of area or region. It is the only way to spread the risk so everyone has a chance of affording to pay the premium. The insurers can return and right their ordinary homeowner's policy, and they could also collect the premiums and pay the claims of the Catastrophe Program for a fee.
   I'll predict that if this isn't done Florida will not solve the crisis, and ruin will be upon millions of us.
   Sincerely yours, Michael Fitzpatrick
                            Port Richey, Fl.

Subject: Florida Insurance Crisis



08/11/2006

 


 To Whom It May Concern,


>
> I am an insurance agent here in Homosassa Florida. I have seen too many elderly
> People, young couples starting out, and the average American middle class.
> Many elderly are opting to go without insurance this year then ever. Young
> couple's lose closing due to the insurance costs. People paying 2k a year
> for insurance covering 20 k on an older mobile home is a spirit breaking.
> I am heartbroken each day. Insurance companies raise rates, cut people out AND reduce

   our commissions. I'm in this business for the long haul and to protect properly my insured’s

   who are my friend’s family and neighbors. My family, friends and I are suffering greatly
> and at the insurance companies mercy. There are SO many worn out now in
> insurance and forced to close or suffering physically from stress and lack of income. 

   What can I do to help? Please let me know. I've been in the insurance
> industry since 1999. I am a pulse of the community as I have lived here since
> 1989 and given birth proudly to my 2 children (who are "crackers" and I'm
> very proud of that) I love my family, my community and my state. I'm not
> wanting to leave, but as a single mother and an independent insurance agent
> I am in a position I may have to leave, that would take my kids away from their Dad,
> Grandparent’s and heritage.  All because of our world crashed because insurance rates,

   gas tax, and other bills in Citrus County. I simply cannot afford to live in a rural county in the state of Florida

   which also will leave many here missing my service and my sympathy and the enthusiasm. This email as this is not an 

   Advertisement for me. I hurt each minute I see someone across my desk cry and decide to "risk it all!" 

   Something has got to give. I know this December when my bill comes due I'll be done. IN
> October I'll be out of business because I can't afford to stay in business.
> My E& O will be nonrenewed! Whoever picks me up will be more then 8k a yr
> ..for a single mom who has been in this alone for 2 yrs to serve her community
> this is WRONG! I am one of the few who will fight for my insured as if they
> were my babies.

 

 

I am not sure HOW exactly I can contribute.  I know we need a cap on rates.  We need to hold companies accountable and lock them into a time commitment and dollar amount they will spend, and that they will write insurance in FL without cancelling people for stated amount of time. They must cover wind and sinkholes in all counties and offer sinkhole buyback coverage where it's omitted.  If you manufacturer a home you should provide a company to the people who will cover that risk and who will allow independant agents to write x amount of policies per zip code.   Insurance companies base rates on our credit but many times there are mitigating circumstances to why our credit isn't a 700 score (Divorce, illness, identity theft....etc etc.).  MORE people would be insured in their autos, homes, renters IF it were affordable.  We as Americans have this mindset that if it goes wrong there will be our Governor or President with their wallet open to help.  WRONG! I can say IF a Katrina were to happen here now, many would watch TV all over the nation and say those idiots why didn't they get insurance? Now they want a donation.  If we as Americans can send scads of money to tsunami victims in a country many did not know existed and many could not even find on a map before that tragedy why we can’t fix a problem in our very home.  We helped heal NY after 911 (being from Jersey, with my family working in NYC and having friends who worked in the Pentagon that was horrific time for me).  Our reinsurance is from overseas and they have tremendously hiked their rates to our insurance companies who pass on that to us the ones in need!  Basically it's the reinsurance holding companies to extreme high rates and companies holding us hostage.  California many states have huge losses yearly and they rates are not like ours.   I'm a single mom, who started her own insurance agency with no capitol just a passion to stay here and make it better for my children financially. To be a role model for my own children.  To show them a single mom can do this. I love what I do.  I love teaching people how insurance works.  I have had no income for 3 yrs.  I have a dream and now I face losing my home, my business my children’s future because of insurance rates alone.
