-----Original Message-----
From: Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com
To: Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com
Sent: Thu, 27 Jul 2006 3:03 PM
Subject: Concerns regarding homeowner's insurance


Dear Friend:
 
Thank you for sharing your concerns regarding homeowner’s insurance.  Governor Bush appreciates your views and asked me to respond on his behalf. 
 
As a result of the past hurricane seasons, property insurance rates have increased.  The Governor knows this is a challenging reality for homeowners, businesses, and local governments, but understands increased rates are a common market reaction to the risk associated with insuring homes and businesses in Florida at a time when so much damage was caused by recent hurricanes.  
 
Governor Bush believes the underlying problems in the property insurance market can be resolved by encouraging mitigation of homes and buildings to make them more resistant to wind damage, and by encouraging private insurance companies to underwrite more of the state’s wind risk.  This would minimize the number of policies and the amount of claims exposure for Citizens Property Insurance Corporation (Citizens), the state’s insurer of last resort.  Citizens covers those who cannot obtain property insurance from the private market.     
 
On May 16, 2006, Governor Bush signed Senate Bill 1980 into law.  This bill provides policy reforms and funding to stabilize and improve the property insurance market.  Senate Bill 1980 assists private insurance companies with an Insurance Capital Build-up Incentive Program allowing private insurance companies to underwrite more policies in Florida.  The bill provides funding for free home inspections and grants for homeowners who choose to reinforce their homes against wind damage through the Florida Comprehensive Hurricane Damage Mitigation Program.  It also provides funding to offset the deficit of Citizens, reducing assessments to homeowners, and provides reforms to prevent future Citizens’ assessments.  Those with internet access can view the complete text of the bill online by typing in the bill number on the Senate’s homepage at www.flsenate.gov.
 
Governor Bush believes that long-term reforms are necessary to repair the underlying problems that exist in the insurance market.  The Governor created the “Property and Casualty Insurance Reform Committee” to address these important issues.  This Executive Order is online at: www.flgov.com/executive_orders.
 
Thank you again for writing.  Governor Bush wants to know how Floridians feel about the many critical issues we face and encourages you to share your views with your local legislative delegation.  Please be assured that the Governor will keep your ideas in mind as he forms policy for addressing these concerns.  
 
 
Sincerely,
L. Wright
Aide to the Governor
Office of Citizens’ Services

 -----Original Message-----
From: 	Robert Vail [mailto:rvail1@cfl.rr.com] 
Sent:	Thursday, August 10, 2006 8:31 PM
To:	Lt. Governor Toni Jennings
Subject:	Property Insurance Costs solution

Hello Ms. Jennings. My name is Robert Vail. I live in Titusville in Brevard Florida. I am retired from the US Army and now work for the State with the Department of Revenue. I too have begun to suffer under the ever increasing Property Insurance premium. I heard the other day about a proposed solution where the State covers the first $100,000.00 in covered damages. I think this is a novel idea and wish to submit my plan based on this proposal. 

I too am disgruntled beyond belief at my continually increasing homeowners insurance premiums. I purchased my 1651 square foot home in 1997 for the sum of $92,000.00. My insurance premium was only $567.00 per year, including hurricane insurance, and with a $500.00 deductible. When my annual renewal goes into effect on August 25, 2006, my premium will exceed $2500.00, and I have a 2% deductible on a home worth $192,200.00.

The current crisis in the insurance industry will not be solved at the State level. We must have Federal Government intervention. And their only way to do that is to have the Federal Government create a "Federal Hurricane insurance" plan, similar to Federal Flood insurance. 

With a Federal Hurricane Insurance policy, the insurance companies then only need to sell regular casualty insurance. This will immediately and substantially lower premiums. With the shared cost of the Federal Hurricane Insurance by the Insurance companies, the homeowner, the Federal Government and the State Government, premiums for this insurance, if combined with regular insurance, would show a reasonable total reduction in premiums.

With a 1/2% increase in the State sales tax, the State can generate in excess of $102,000,000.00 per year towards this plan. If all of the States along the Eastern Seaboard and Gulf Coast were to do the same, one can only imagine the amount of money generated toward this program. 

Participation in this program will of course, be voluntary, but who wouldn't want to be a part of it? To continue selling Hurricane insurance by the current methods is no longer viable. We must make a bold and dramatic change, if we don't want to see a migration from Florida similar to the Great Dust bowl migration during the depression. It's getting to be such that only high income people will be able to afford to live in Florida. 

Robert S. Vail
Titusville, FL

From:	dave wesellpg <dhofer@wesellpg.com>
Sent:	Thursday, August 10, 2006 9:51 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	A serious solution to a serious hurricane insurance problem

Importance:	High

We Floridians have 2 major problems that need to be solved quickly to
insure the economic viability of this growing state.
They can both be solved simultaneously with compromise legislation.

1.    Our coastal counties need to have a stable insurance pool
available.  This can be done with a quasi government sponsored and
authorized private reinsurance company.  Private insurers should be
required to insure for windstorm damage only for the top 20% of the
total coverage.  They would set a standard deductible amount of  a flat
$ amount, say $5,000 for windstorm damage.   The State would set
underwriting standards required to be followed by insurers.  For
example, a grid would be established setting standard rates for coverage
for a pool cage or a roof based on age and standards under which they
were built.   The state reinsurance company would take the rest of the
coverage and negotiate standard payment rates and regulate and schedule
approved vendors.   This company would take over the actual restoration
and make payments directly to contractors.   This would eliminate the
huge waste of time and money resulting from hundreds of thousands of
unquailified insureds suddenly becoming general contractors.
This company would be funded by a) payment of reasonable premiums
actuarily computed over a very long period of time.  (Our current
insurance coverage problems stem from carriers reacting to isolated
catastrophes influenced by their desire to please stockholders.) and b)
local real estate taxes.

2.  Local real estate taxes would, in turn, be aided by a much needed
revision of the Save Our Homes Amendment.   The huge inequities of this
concept discourage new development of all kinds and penalize commercial
property owners.   The initial motivation for this terrible idea stemmed
from the cries of pensioners on fixed incomes that did not rise as much
as local taxes.   The 3% cap was a naive attempt to corral local tax
spending and to protect these retirees, so that they didn't have to move
to escape unaffordable taxes.  The reality is, that while real estate
values are going up, the quality and cost of effective government
budgets have been rising in step.   Rather than giving away thousands of
dollars of tax dollars at the expense of non homestead taxpayers, these
excess taxes should be DEFERRED and collected on the resale of the home
with interest!  After all, if it is this excessively rising valuation
that caused the dreaded tax increases.  Why shouldn't those windfall
beneficiaries repay their fair share of that boon to the society that
gave them the opportunity for that wealth creation?

I would appreciate staff's careful consideration of this concept and
response to this email.

Dave Hofer
 Harbor Realty

1-941-827-9700 24/7 fax

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Governor Jeb Bush 
To: tj-dkreutzel@peoplepc.com 
Sent: Thursday, August 10, 2006 8:36 AM
Subject: RE: outrageous insurance


Dear Ms. Phillips,

 

Thank you for sharing your concerns regarding homeowner’s insurance.  Governor Bush appreciates your views and asked me to respond on his behalf. 

 

As a result of the past hurricane seasons, property insurance rates have increased.  The Governor knows this is a challenging reality for homeowners, businesses, and local governments, but understands increased rates are a common market reaction to the risk associated with insuring homes and businesses in Florida at a time when so much damage was caused by recent hurricanes.  

 

Governor Bush believes the underlying problems in the property insurance market can be resolved by encouraging mitigation of homes and buildings to make them more resistant to wind damage, and by encouraging private insurance companies to underwrite more of the state’s wind risk.  This would minimize the number of policies and the amount of claims exposure for Citizens Property Insurance Corporation (Citizens), the state’s insurer of last resort.  Citizens covers those who cannot obtain property insurance from the private market.     

 

Governor Bush recently signed Senate Bill 1980 providing policy reforms and funding intended to stabilize and enhance the property insurance market.  The Governor believes this legislation is a good first step at resolving the underlying problems of Florida’s property insurance market but recognizes that more far-reaching changes are required to stimulate affordable private alternatives to the unsustainable growth rate of public insurance and reinsurance.

 

Governor Bush believes that long-term reforms are necessary to repair the underlying problems that exist in the insurance market.  The Governor created the “Property and Casualty Insurance Reform Committee” to address these important issues.  This Executive Order is online at: www.flgov.com/executive_orders.

 

Thank you again for writing.  Governor Bush wants to know how Floridians feel about the many critical issues we face and encourages you to share your views with your local legislative delegation.  Please be assured that the Governor will keep your ideas in mind as he forms policy for addressing these concerns.  

 

 

Sincerely,

 

 

 

L. Wright

                                                                        Aide to the Governor

Office of Citizens' Services

to insure it less than the replacement cost to rebuild
it. This results in higher premiums for us and more
risk exposure for the insurance company

premiums for us who live in safe areas and don't file
minor claims and/or never will file a claim unless

All 4 couples were rushing to find another insurance company who would write them now during the hurricane season! None had succeeded. I have yet to receive this “letter” and I pray every night for them that had and for myself. My next door neighbor, who received this letter had found Citizens High Risk Group to write a policy over 4 times the amount of their previous insurer! NO ONE CAN AFFORD THIS! One of the other couples had State Farm and had received a letter raising their premium 53%.

WHAT DO WE DO?

 

We are in a weather pattern that lends itself to possible destruction at any time, and our homes have to be insured. However, we need to look at WHAT we are insuring and WHAT the insurance companies SHOULD be covering to replace! The policy coverages should be overhauled to cut the cost of replacement items such as screen enclosures, outbuildings, lean-to’s, sheds; pole barns, patio swings, swingsets, bbq grills, etc. My first suggestion is to STOP THIS THEFT FROM THE INSURANCE COMPANIES! These items are “add-ons” that homeowners should have a separate “rider” to replace. If the consumer wants to insure those items, they would pay extra for an insurance rider to cover them.  

 

My second suggestion is for insurance policies to cover our homes. This means the actual home structure. The residents of Florida are going to have to bite the bullet and become responsible for these items added to and around the home. 

 

The lending institutions enforce insurance policies to cover their investments. People cannot invest without those policies. I ask that you continue to give your utmost attention to the future of Florida while in office, as you have done in the past.

 

In closing, I applaud your efforts in addressing this crisis and I hope you and the task force will come to very drastic measures to insure that the people of Florida will continue to be able to work and thrive in our beautiful state.

 

I look forward to hearing from you,

Lisa Haas

Florida is going to be always subject to a higher risk of major weather conditions that effect property owners and renters as well. In order to provide a re-insurance market that could be operated by the state of Florida Insurance Commission, I have the following suggestions:
 
 
Pass legislation that will provide for a one percent increase in the Florida State Sales Tax that will go into a new super re-insurance fund in a State of Florida controlled Corporation. As this fund builds reserves, you can eliminate the Citizens Insurance fund that you are now subsidizing.
 
After all the State of Florida does not need to be in the insurance business of writing insurance directly to the consumer because of the extreme difficulty in establishing and maintaining the necessary experienced personnel with the knowledge to operate such a plan. That should be left up to the Property and Casualty Insurance Companies some of whom are reluctant to operate in the Florida or do so on a limiter selective basis. These Companies seek to outsource some of their insurance risk by outsourcing for re-insurers in the world market place. Thus that is where the ultimate problem of high premiums and high risks are involved. 
 
That is also where the State of Florida can be the most effective with the least amount of risk and administrated costs. It becomes it's own re-insurers with funds developed from not only it's residents, but also from visitors or guests who use our facilities which must be insured. Everyone pays for covering the obvious hazards of owning all types of insured property from real estate, motorized vehicles, and personal property.
 
The Florida resident will pay more in sales tax (we could exempt food and medicine if we have to) but receive a reduction in their insurance bills. I do not have at my disposal the exact dollars this idea of the one  percent sales tax would raise in any given year, but I am sure that if the tax was passed, that it would generate enough funds over a period of years to be a player in the re-insurance market and eventually able to stand alone in covering Florida's needs for cheaper insurance premiums through providing cheaper re-insurance for the existing Insurance Companies operating and licensed by Florida. Eventually, Florida could shut down the Citizens Insurance Fund or if necessary to keep it for competitive reasons for island or near shore properties being able to get reasonable insurance coverage.
 
Hope this may be passed on to the new special task force committee on insurance.

Dear Governor Bush,

There are some ideas that are so good, you know from the start that they will benefit society.  There are some ideas that are so bad, they never get past the thinking stage. This morning, Wednesday, August 9, 2006, I read a story in the Jacksonville, Fl. Times that the law is in effect and local business owners are figuring ways to capitalize on this law.

This situation has the possibility of being a really bad idea.  Why?  Because some time down the road something very bad will happen.  The dogs might get in a fight.   Someone, possibly an innocent child, will get bitten, perhaps mauled.  Then there are the overwhelmingly negative health aspects involved.

Earlier, I said that I was not surprised.  The reason for this is that when I first moved to Clay County, I was in a local retail establishment in Orange Park.  I saw a customer walking around with his dog following him.  This was obviously not a guide animal.  I asked an employee how it was that an animal was allowed to wander around.  What about Health Department restrictions and the risk to other customers and employees?  He said, in a matter of fact, casual attitude, that it was no big deal.  They, the county, had never had any laws concerning this.  I contacted the County Health Department and found out that indeed, there were no restrictions other than pets could not be in an establishment that sold food, unless they were a guide animal.

I was very astounded.  I have lived in various parts of the country and this was the first time I have come across a lack of restriction concerning pets. Now is the time to re-think this law and repeal it.  If dog owners can’t be away from their pets for an hour or so, they have much larger issues with which to deal. http://www.sun-sentinel.com/business/local/sfl-zinsurethree08aug08,0,475264.story?coll=sfla-home-headlines&track=mostemailedlink 
Insurance companies shower Fla. politicians with donations to get rate hikes 

  
 
 
By Mark Hollis
South Florida Sun-Sentinel

August 8, 2006



TALLAHASSEE -- Florida's teetering property insurance industry got what it wanted this year from the state: new power to raise consumer prices.

The Legislature crafted the industry incentives as insurers poured hundreds of thousands of dollars into election campaigns of lawmakers, state political parties and candidates for statewide offices.

Insurers now can automatically raise prices for homeowner coverage 10 percent without any state review. And to make Florida even more enticing to property insurers, legislators tossed in $250 million in loans for insurers willing to expand in this state.

The changes have been hailed across the country by the insurance industry as a big help to do business in a hurricane-battered state.

Consumer activists say it was a giveaway to an industry that already gets its way in Tallahassee.

Analysts say the legislation was not a surprise, given the industry's consistent political donations.

``It's always hard to say that the money bought something specifically, but the money certainly buys the industry access to decision-makers,'' said Sue O'Connell, research director for the Institute on Money and State Politics, a nonpartisan watchdog group based in Montana. ``It opens doors and allows them [insurers] access in a way that the typical citizen may not have. It also seems pretty clear from the way that industry distributes its donations that Florida is a pretty important state to the insurance companies.''

Since 1996, the property insurance industry has given $11.2 million to Florida candidates and state political parties, with roughly three of every four dollars to Republicans, according to research by the South Florida Sun-Sentinel.

The 2006 campaigns already have received at least $1.7 million from the property insurance industry, state records show.

O'Connell has examined property insurance industry campaign contributions across the country over three election cycles -- 2000, 2002, and 2004 -- and found Florida is vital to the property insurance market, judging by where the industry spends its campaign donations.

She said that in 2004, Florida ranked No. 10 among all states in total contributions from political donors. But in candidate contributions from the property insurance industry, she said, Florida politicians ranked second in the nation, behind only California that year.

Most donations to GOP

The insurance industry has given the bulk of its money to the party in power, the Sun-Sentinel has found. At least $4 million has been given in the last decade to the Republican Party of Florida, mainly from industry trade groups and associations but also from insurers, their lobbyists and executives.

By contrast, the Florida Democratic Party received slightly more than $1 million.

The contributions represent a small fraction of what's given each year to state parties and candidates in Florida. Other industries, such as telecommunications businesses, home builders and real estate agents, give more. Sun-Sentinel research found that about 2 percent of what's been given to all Florida campaigns and state parties since 1996 -- or $11.2 million of more than $557 million -- can be reported as having come from the property insurance industry.

Campaign finance analysts say the Florida insurance industry still packs a political wallop. That power was on display May 16 when Gov. Jeb Bush signed into law the 156-page property insurance bill that guarantees higher policyholder costs and bigger insurance industry profits.``This is the most significant, comprehensive property insurance legislation that has been enacted since Hurricane Andrew,'' said Len Brevik, the national executive vice president and chief executive officer of the National Association of Professional Insurance Agents. He said it's ``precisely the kind of innovation'' that Congress should mimic.

Critics call it a politically timid and anti-consumer answer to what ails Florida's insurance market. The law has been criticized in recent weeks by Democratic candidates for governor and some Republicans, such as state Rep. Randy Johnson of Winter Garden, a candidate to be Florida's chief financial officer.

``The insurance crisis has crept on the kitchen tables of Floridians and they are mad about it and responding to it. ...,'' Johnson said of reaction to increased rates. ``It is about insurance company greed, plain and simple.''

While some candidates criticize the law as an industry sellout, Florida's top insurance regulators, such as state Chief Financial Officer Tom Gallagher, a Republican running for governor, say it was just the start of a solution. His 2006 gubernatorial campaign has received at least $379,000 in donations from the insurance industry. Only the Republican and Democratic state parties and Bush's gubernatorial campaigns have received more money from the state's insurers than Gallagher has taken in for his 2006 race for governor.

He also has received at least $369,000 in industry donations during previous campaigns for other state offices, including the one he holds.

Gallagher campaign aides say Gallagher is not beholden to the insurers.

``No one has been more forceful and cracked down on insurance companies more than Tom Gallagher,'' said Alberto Martinez, Gallagher's gubernatorial spokesman. ``He's called State Farm and Allstate out on the carpet whenever they've tried raising rates and not responding to their customer's needs. ... Tom has a record of fighting for consumers and a record of speaking his mind.''

Campaign finance records show Jeb Bush's campaign for governor in 2002 received at least $201,000 from the property insurance industry. This year, he gave legislators surprisingly little guidance on how to fix the state's troubled property insurance market.

During his State of the State speech in early March, Bush called for better hurricane preparedness but provided no direction about insurance issues, including what to do with financially troubled Citizens Property Insurance Corp. Citizens is the state-run home insurer, and now the state's biggest property insurer. Its size is a sore point the state never intended.

When Bush signed the new property insurance bill into law, he knew consumers wouldn't be happy. ``I will accept responsibility that we will have higher rates,'' Bush said.

Bush and Republican legislators made their first move when they created the Task Force on Long-Term Solutions for Florida's Hurricane Market prior to the 2005 hurricane season.

The 13-member task force conducted eight public meetings. The panel of mostly insurance industry insiders overwhelmingly recommended short-term, industry-friendly solutions, only some of which were adopted.

In a 58-page report, the task force repeatedly called for what the Florida property insurance industry wanted -- ``greater flexibility'' with regulators. ``The majority of the people on the task force had some industry tie,'' said Steve Burgess, a task force member and a consumer advocate who works under the state Office of Insurance Regulation.

`Afraid to be bold'

Some legislators, insurance industry lobbyists and analysts say lawmakers settled on the bill because of their concern about doing more harm than good.

``The single biggest issue that will cause the state's economy to stop is not handling this insurance situation correctly,'' said Sen. J.D. Alexander, a Lake Wales Republican on the Senate Banking and Insurance Committee. Records show Alexander, who helped negotiate the final bill, has accepted at least $95,000 in donations from insurance interests to his political campaigns since 1996.

Bush says Florida is better off with the law than nothing.

``It's not easy to make the tough choices,'' Bush said. ``If we had not made the tough choices this year, it would have come back to haunt us.''

Others don't see it that way.

``A lot of these issues are technical. So a lot of legislators aren't comfortable with certain things. When an insurance company lobbyist says `this and this,' it's pretty difficult for someone who is not an expert to know that they are lies,'' said Birny Birnbaum, an economist with the Center for Economic Justice, in Austin, Texas.

Robert Hunter, director of insurance for the Consumer Federation of America, said: ``The (Florida) Legislature is afraid to be bold. They were so afraid that the industry is going to bolt that they won't take the kind of action that needs to be taken.''

08/08/06

National marketing campaigns increase Florida produce sales 
TALLAHASSEE -- Three produce marketing campaigns conducted by the Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services helped increase retail sales of Florida-grown agricultural products by $394.4 million over last year, Florida Agriculture Commissioner Charles H. Bronson announced Monday. 
The 2005-06 marketing campaigns -- "Global Grid," "Florida Farmers' Express" and the "Florida Watermelon Campaign" -- saw an increase in participating grocery stores, an expanded geographic area, and an increase in the number of advertisements. 
"This year's marketing promotions generated an additional $394.4 million over the previous year's increase," Bronson said. "We were again very successful in marketing 'Fresh from Florida' products to consumers throughout the United States and abroad." 
The marketing promotions, which ran from November 2005 to June 2006, are timed to coincide with Florida's important winter-spring harvest that supplies the United States with most of its domestically grown produce. 
The Global Grid campaign, now in its fifth year, included 7,684 stores and generated $324.7 million in additional retail sales. The Florida Farmers Express campaign, now in its sixth year, included 1,734 stores and generated $41.1 million in additional retail sales. The Florida Watermelon Campaign, now in its third year, included 4,293 stores and generated $28.6 million in additional retail sales. 
The three marketing campaigns spanned 43 U.S. states, the District of Columbia, five Canadian provinces, and 11 Caribbean and Central American countries. Thirty-four retail grocery chains with 13,711 individual stores participated. They featured Florida products in their circular ads 754 times, yielding 178,955 individual store ads that generated more than 8.8 billion consumer impressions. 
"We were able to drastically expand these campaigns due to their proven track record in previous years," Bronson said. "After seeing their sales increase, most retail partners eagerly signed up for another year. We also added new partners and extended the campaigns' reach into Alaska, Texas, Idaho, Oregon and Washington for the first time." 
Bronson said the continued trend of increased retail sales is good news for Florida's farmers and the state's economy. 
"Since our state's farmers know we're continually expanding markets for their products, they can plant for the future with a degree of confidence," Bronson said. "That increased agricultural production benefits our state's economy through purchases of agricultural supplies, machinery, wage expenditures, and general spending. Additionally, it's estimated that these highly successful marketing promotions helped Florida create or retain approximately 2,407 full-time jobs and generate more than $6.7 million in taxable revenues." 
The three successful marketing initiatives were joint ventures between the Division of Marketing and Development, the Florida Department of Citrus and the Florida Watermelon Association. The Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services is statutorily mandated to provide professional marketing services to Florida's agricultural community through its Division of Marketing and Development. These marketing promotions are part of the ongoing "Fresh from Florida" campaign, an identification and promotional program designed to boost the image of Florida agriculture and increase sales by helping consumers to easily identify Florida-grown agricultural products at retail stores. The "Fresh from Florida" campaign also helps increase public awareness of the importance of Florida's agriculture industry, which has an estimated overall economic impact of more than $87 billion annually. 
Geographic scope 
The three promotions included grocery chains in 43 U.S. states (all except Arizona, New Mexico, California, Nevada, Utah, Montana and Hawaii) and the District of Columbia. The Canadian provinces of Ontario, Quebec, New Brunswick, Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island were also included, as well as the Caribbean and Central American nations of Aruba, Barbados, Dominican Republic, Trinidad, Jamaica, U.S. Virgin Islands, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, and Nicaragua. 
Participating retailers 
The 34 retail grocery chains participating in the three promotions were ACME, Affiliated, Albertsons, A&P Canada, AWI Shurfine, Bi-Lo, Bozzuto's, Farm Fresh, Food Basics, Hannaford, Harvey's, Ingles, Jewel-Osco, Kash 'n' Karry, Kitchen Table, Kroger, Loeb, Lowes, Market Basket, Meijer, Metro, Nash Finch, Penn Traffic, Price Chopper, Price Smart Central America, Provigo, Publix, Roundy's, Sobey's, Sobey's Atlantic, Spartan, Ukrop's, Winn-Dixie and Waitrose UK. 
Featured produce 
The Florida produce items featured in the three promotions included bell peppers, blueberries, cabbage, carrots, celery, cucumbers, eggplant, grapefruit, melons, oranges, potatoes, radishes, snap beans, squash, strawberries, sweet corn, tangerines, tomatoes, tropical fruits and variety lettuces. 
Yearly totals of participating stores 
The combined number of retail stores participating in the 2006 and previous years' promotions were: 13,711 stores in 2006; 10,602 stores in 2005; 10,129 stores in 2004; 8,289 stores in 2003; 5,100 stores in 2002; 2,017 stores in 2001; 298 stores in 2000. 
Previous names of campaigns 
Some promotions were conducted under different names in years past, although the focus, marketing strategy and array of featured Florida products were similar. This year's "Global Grid" was named "Storming Across North America" in 2005, "PowerGrid" in 2004, and "Northern Exposure" in 2002 and 2003. This year's "Florida Farmers' Express" was named "Greetings From Your Florida Farmer" from 2000 to 2004. 
Marketing strategy 
Participating grocery chains increase their purchases of Florida products and use the "Fresh from Florida" logo in their newspaper ads and circulars. Retailers increase the size of their displays to accommodate more products. The resulting three-way "linkage" involves Florida producers, grocery retailers and the consuming public, in which: Florida producers plant, harvest and ship additional products to meet the anticipated increased demand; retail grocery corporate buyers increase their purchases of Florida products to handle the increase in sales; customers respond to the "Fresh from Florida" themes used in store advertising and increase their purchases of Florida-grown products. 
Dan Sleep is a media contact for the Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services and can be reached at sleepd@doacs.state.fl.us. 
By DAN SLEEP 
Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services

Like many of my neighbors and other citizens in Florida, I am a retiree whose livelihood depends on my Social Security benefit and my own personal savings. Sent:	Tuesday, August 8, 2006 7:44 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Commercial Insurance

copy of email sent for hearing on insurance issues:
 
  
I was most please to be made aware of Friday's hearing.
Unfortunately my schedule precludes my attendance at the hearing, but I wanted to share with the panel my situation and thoughts.
 
As a small business owner I face, as I am sure many others do, the choice of closing my business and moving out of the state, or making some uncomfortable changes in my business plan/model.  I am a geriatrician in a solo private practice focusing on providing high quality medical care to people as they age. We have a small office practice and spend a good part of the week taking care of seniors where they live. I currently lease office space at a local hospital and have been trying to buy a small property to move my practice.
 
I have been informed that my Business Owner's Insurance Policy will not be renewed due to the insurance crisis in the state, and have not been able to secure financing to purchase a building, due to the inability to obtain/afford commercial property and/or hurricane insurance.
 
How can we continue to service the public, provide high quality services, and stay in business with the ever increasing costs of doing business?
 
Why do we allow the Insurance industry to assign Florida as it's own risk adjusted rate pool different than the rest of the country combined?  Is this fair?  The concept of risk adjustment is to spread the risk across the "whole" population, not select out those perceived as the highest risk.  For decades property insurers have reaped huge profits.  When catastrophes have struck  we have had re-insurance and excess pools to bail us out in the past.
 
For my situation this is certainly a cross-over issue with medical insurance issues, reimbursements not keeping up with inflation, and other cost issues, but if we cannot protect ourselves from general liability or create equity by owning commercial property, how can we continue to care for your parents and the seniors in our community?
 
The alternatives will be large corporate entities with deep pockets providing impersonal, but highly "efficient" health care, and much continued dissatisfaction in the community.
 
I call on our representatives to challenge the status quo, enable Insurers to continue to make acceptable profits, but allow the small providers of service to continue to flourish, or I fear those of us with an entrepreneurial spirit will continue to stray for the quick buck, and unnecessary medical interventions will continue to flourish, rather than stay focused on the quality driven care we deserve and require.
 
Thank you for taking this time to listen and I hope and pray we can resolve this issue in the very near future.
 
Richard M Orlan MD
Comprehensive Geriatric Care Centers
Saint Petersburg, Florida
727-820-6800

From:	Chafu <Chafu@msn.com>
Sent:	Monday, August 7, 2006 4:43 PM
To:	KEVIN.MCCARTY@FLDFS.COM
Cc:	Governor Jeb Bush; geller.steven.web@ flsenate.gov; garcia.rudy.web@ flsenate.gov; n.dahlberg@miamiherald.com; be.garcia@miamiherald.com
Subject:	[*] Insurance Woes

 
The Honorable Kevin McCarty
Florida Office of Insurance Regulation
200 East Gaines Street
Tallahassee, FL 32399

Dear Commissioner McCarty,

When I saw my home owners policy premium jump from $5189 to $ 8429 this year  I wanted to scream. Instead I decided to educate my self as much as I could about this insurance business. 

 

First question: How does Gulfstream calculate my premium? 

Long Answer: The question of how premiums are calculated seems to be a closely guarded secret of insurance companies and not one they are very willing to reveal. What I found by completing the  "Homeowners Premium Calculation Worksheet" (no easy matter given that the only person I found qualified to help me was Dan Hulchanski, Director of Marketing for Gulfstream) was that there are a tremendous amount of variables that go into the calculations and therefore there is a huge risk of errors, (as I found in Gulfstream's calculation of my wind storm mitigation credit which was off by +20%.)  Even more disturbing I found that Gulfstream was now charging me a 20% surcharge due to the age of my home which was built in 1926. I find this item particularly troublesome because my home has been completely renovated since 1926 (obviously.)  Other than the external walls everything has been updated or renovated including the roof and windows, plumbing, electrical and heating/cooling. Yet when my renewal policy arrived neither my agent nor the insurance company told me my home now included this surcharge, nor did they give me any indication of how I could have it removed or reduced.

Short Answer: It’s very complicated, we don’t have time to explain it. Just shut up and pay your bill or we will cancel your policy. And if there are errors good luck finding them.

 

Second question: Was the increase authorized by the Florida Dept. of Insurance? 

Long answer: I went to the http://www.fldfs.com/edms/  and looked up Gulfstream. I was able to gather that yes indeed, Gulfstream had applied for a 57% increase in premiums and was approved by the dept. of insurance. What struck me however is that all policies in FL are divided by territory into wind and non-wind perils. In my case I am in Territory 034 (Dade, excluding Miami Beach) where windstorm coverage accounts for 66% of the premium. The rest of the premium includes "all other perils". However "all other perils" risk have not increased 57% as far as I know anywhere in FL. So why did the Dept. of Insurance approve an across the board increase of 57% instead of just increasing the windstorm coverage premium by 57%. In effect an increase of 57% in the total premium equals an increase of in the windstorm coverage of 186% if "all other perils" remains the same from the previous year. 

Short answer: Yes, but they raised the rates for “all perils” including windstorm and non-windstorm equally. It’s like saying because the price of gas has gone up 30% in the last year, you can expect to pay 30% more for everything else you buy as well. 

 

Third Question: What do I need an agent for?

Lon Answer: According to my investigations, Gulfstream pays 21.3% of the premiums they collect to insurance agents as commission. So in my case $8429 * 21.3%=$1795. This is particularly outrageous. With the premiums as high as they are, in addition, we the consumers are expected to subsidize insurance agents. Especially given that my agent does absolutely nothing for me. He couldn't even answer my questions regarding the Worksheet as I explained above. Regulators have really missed the boat on this one. We should be allowed to buy our policies directly from the insurance companies and reap the savings ourselves and cut out this middle man. At the very least commission percentages should be reduced given the huge increase in premiums in the past few years.

Short answer: I don’t. This is a boondoggle and a waste of my premium dollar. Period. 

 

Conclusion: It is obvious that we have an insurance crisis. And by crisis I mean we the homeowners of Florida are in crisis because insurance companies have jacked up our premiums to the point that we can no longer afford our homes. In conclusion:

 

1.	Rises in premiums should only reflect the increase in Windstorm coverage, not across the board coverage of all perils, and base class premiums should be the same for all counties, or at the very least averaged so we all pay equally. 
2.	Insurance companies must be forced to show how premiums are calculated and must inform consumers about specific ways in which premiums can be reduced, either through credits or coverage options. They should be required to send each policy owner a completed "Homeowner Premium Calculation Worksheet" upon renewal, which would explain the source of every $ spent on the policy. 
3.	Consumers should not be forced to buy insurance through insurance agents especially when agents are receiving up to 25% of every premium dollar we pay. 
4.	If the government of Florida does not get involved in a positive way to resolve this crisis they will in fact kill the goose that lays the golden eggs. If we homeowners cannot afford to pay to insure our homes than we will be forced to sell (haven’t you noticed all the “For Sale” signs lately?). But no one in their right mind is going to buy.  So what will happen is that property values will deflate, property taxes will decline and eventually this state will go bankrupt. 
5.	The federal government should be pressed to intervene in this crisis as soon as possible. As I have shown above it is the Windstorm coverage that has increased so significantly and the Feds should be required to subsidize this coverage.

I would like to hear your comments regarding these issues. Please contact me by email at Chafu@msn.com

 

Best regards,

 

Mark Schwartz

Miami, FL

 

CC The Hon. Jeb Bush

CC: The Hon. Tom Gallagher

CC: The Hon. Sen. Steve Geller

CC: The Hon. Sen. Rudy Garcia

CC: Nancy Dahlgren, MiamiHerald.com

CC: Beatrice E. Garcia, MiamiHerald.com

-----Original Message-----
From: MEARS.KATHY [mailto:MEARS.KATHY@flsenate.gov] 
Sent: Friday, August 04, 2006 3:12 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Constituent Letter



Below is the text of a constituent letter that President Lee is sending out from his district office – attached are the letters he reference in the correspondence.

President Lee said you would be expecting this e-mail.

Sincerely,

Kathy Mears

 

Thank you for contacting my office to share your thoughts on the property insurance crisis facing our state. Like you, I have experienced some of the consequences of Florida’s eight major storms during the 2004 – 2005 hurricane seasons, causing nearly $40 billion in damages to our state. My insurance company has cancelled coverage on more than one of my business properties, and I have been forced to find new coverage at an increase of 330%. The impacts are staggering, and it is doubtful that our families and businesses can hold up much longer under the incredible weight of the current market.

 

Contrary to critics, many of whom are using the insurance crisis for political gain,   Florida leaders have already begun the process of reform by proposing both long-term and immediate solutions. Our situation will not be resolved with sound bites, rhetoric, or election year promises; we must draw upon the expert advice of business leaders, consumer advocates, and policy makers across our state to provide the wisdom and insight needed to rebuild a strong, affordable, and sustainable insurance market in Florida.

 

To that end, I asked Governor Bush to commission a task force on Property and Casualty Insurance Reform – comprised of non-insurance industry business leaders and consumer advocates. I suggested the group meet while the legislature is not in session in order to receive and evaluate policy options, provide the public a forum for testimony and suggestions, and ensure that recommendations are responsible and actuarially sound.  Most importantly, the committee would deliberate in a non-political environment so that the needs of Floridians, rather than divisive partisanship, would be the paramount motivation for action.

 

Governor Bush agreed to assemble the reform committee and appointed the members along with Chairman Toni Jennings on July 26.  I immediately sent a letter to the newly appointed group asking them to evaluate several proposals. I have attached the letter for your review.  

 

In addition to the reform committee proposals, I recently asked Governor Bush to consider activating a Joint Underwriting Association for commercial property. This entity has the potential of providing insurance to commercial property owners who cannot find private coverage, thus ensuring that our economic engine will not come to a screeching halt during this crisis. The letter to Governor Bush is also attached for your review.

 

Finally, regarding a Special Legislative Session, I stand ready to call the Senate back to Tallahassee to debate and pass legislation relating to property insurance. However, it is premature to convene a session before there is some consensus as to the proper course of action. To do so would invite divisive and wasteful partisan bickering, and would detract from the problem-solving mission that is now underway.

 

Thank you for taking the time to contact me with your personal observations and concerns.  Please know that I have great compassion for what you are experiencing and that you have my sincere commitment to do everything I can to help restore a property and casualty insurance market that is affordable for Florida’s families and businesses. Please do not hesitate to contact my office if we can provide you with information, assistance, or receive your insurance reform proposals for consideration.

 

Sincerely,

 

Tom Lee

State-run Citizens Property Insurance now a troubled giant 

By Kathy Bushouse
South Florida Sun-Sentinel

August 7, 2006


Florida never intended to be in the property insurance business this long.

When legislators created a state-run company in 1992 to offer homeowner's insurance after Hurricane Andrew, the expectation was private insurers would rebound and render the so-called insurer of last resort unnecessary.

It didn't happen.

Citizens Property Insurance Corp., the successor to the state's original insurance company, is now the largest property insurer in Florida. When created in 2002, it was one of the most important moves by the Legislature to salvage the homeowner's insurance market in the state.

Without Citizens, many Floridians wouldn't have hurricane insurance for their homes. In recent years, the growing reluctance by private insurers to write new policies while shedding thousands of customers led to the rapid expansion of Citizens. That has saddled Citizens with Florida's riskiest properties -- many along the coast or in sinkhole-prone areas.

Citizens is now "part of the economic engine of the state," said the company's deputy director, Susanne Murphy. "That engine would sputter and die if there weren't a source of homeowner's coverage for people who want to move here."

System overhaul

Legislators have given Citizens more than a few tune-ups since 2002. After many Floridians balked at paying for Citizens' $516 million shortfall in 2004, legislators this year changed the pricing to bring rates in line with the company's risk. Now Citizens premiums are more than doubling for some South Floridians.

Customers complained the company was too slow handling storm claims after the 2004 season, triggering a state audit and an overhaul.

Citizens took another beating in 2005 after allegations that a former executive took bribes in exchange for promising lucrative claims-adjusting contracts to a Texas company. And the state-run insurer reported a $1.7 billion deficit last year that all Florida property owners will have to pay this year.

Still, supporters say the state couldn't have survived the last two hurricane seasons without the protection Citizens provides policyholders abandoned by private insurers.

"We've had some bumps ... but [Citizens] was never designed to cover 1.2 million policyholders, which is what they've got right now," said Tom Gallagher, the state's chief financial officer who, as insurance commissioner, lobbied for Citizens' creation.

"Our first responsibility is to have insurance available, and we wouldn't have it if it wasn't for Citizens."

There are insurance experts who say Citizens has contributed to Florida's insurance woes. Because Citizens is supposed to insure homeowners who can't find private coverage, analysts say, it has encouraged building in risky coastal areas -- in South Florida, for example -- where private companies won't sell policies.

Citizens "encouraged irresponsible development," said Robert Hartwig, chief economist for the Insurance Information Institute, a nonprofit trade group. "Citizens basically insures anyone, no matter how risky the property or high value the property is."

That has increased the state-run insurer's exposure to hurricane risk, Hartwig said.

State Sen. Ron Klein, D-Boca Raton, said the Legislature made a mistake in allowing private insurers to reduce their hurricane wind risk for areas east of Interstate 95. Legislators were told this would help keep insurers in Florida because they wouldn't have to insure homes closest to the ocean.

"It didn't do that," Klein said. But it did increase the number of homes covered by Citizens.

Sore points

During this year's state legislative session, lawmakers took steps to make sure Citizens' shortfalls don't affect non-customers in the future. But the Legislature did nothing to hasten its demise. As legislators try to help shore up Citizens, another sore point has become significant.

Analysts and legislators have criticized a program that gives bonus money to private Florida insurers that agree to take Citizens' homeowner's policies.

Known as the takeout program, it was created in 1995 to curb growth in Citizens' predecessor, the Joint Underwriting Association. Private insurers could earn $100 for each homeowner's policy taken from the association. The program didn't work at first. After its creation, the underwriting association reached a peak of more than 935,000 policies in September 1996.

Then private insurers took the state's homeowner's policies en masse. The bonus money was attractive and no hurricanes made landfall. By the end of 1999, the association slimmed down to about 67,000 homeowner's policies -- the vast majority in South Florida.

More than 1 million policies were taken out of the underwriting association from 1995 to 2000. "I think that was a hugely successful program," said Murphy, who as the state's deputy insurance commissioner helped create the takeout program.

Had Citizens still insured all of those homes, Murphy said, Citizens' deficits from the 2004 and 2005 hurricane seasons could have been much more than the collective $2.2 billion.

Takeout troubles

The takeout program left many Floridians covered by small private insurers who struggled to pay hurricane claims the past two years.

"One of the big concerns that I've had for years is that a big storm comes along and it will put most of these little takeout companies out of business," said state Sen. Steve Geller, D-Hallandale Beach, vice chairman of the state Senate Banking and Insurance Committee.

Even though the small companies meet state minimum financial requirements, "most of their business is concentrated in certain areas," Geller said, rather than spreading their risk throughout the state.

There was overwhelming support for the takeout incentive program when legislators approved it in 1995. It passed unanimously in the Senate; only two members of the House voted against it.

Legislators assumed bigger companies would take advantage of the bonuses from Citizens, said Geller, who voted for it when he was in the House.

"We didn't realize at the time that what you were going to get were these thinly capitalized companies," Geller said.

Instead, many new insurers formed to take advantage of the bonuses -- with mixed results.

Two of the biggest participants, Atlantic Preferred Insurance Co. and Southern Family Insurance Co., were deemed insolvent in April, and state regulators recently took control of their operations. The insurers were subsidiaries of Tampa-based Poe Financial Group, one of the largest property insurers in South Florida. Poe has a third company, Florida Preferred Insurance, also forced under state control.

Private insurers that took homeowner's policies from Citizens needed to have at least $5 million in cash. Some legislators and state insurance officials say that's inadequate. During this year's legislative session, certain legislators said the small insurers holding former Citizens policies are unable to cover major hurricane damage.

That makes Murphy bristle. "They need to change their law," she said. "The law said $5 million. ... They need to make up their minds what they want."

Earlier this year, legislators tweaked the takeout program so that insurers must wait five years rather than three to collect a bonus for taking policies from Citizens. And Citizens has to track property policies taken by private insurers, to see whether they end up back with the state insurer.

Even though Geller thinks the so-called takeout insurers should have more capital, he's hesitant to try to change the program now because he fears that would shrink the state's fragile insurance market.

Many of these smaller takeout companies are among the few insurers selling new property insurance policies in South Florida. "I'm not prepared to do something today that would take more capacity out of the South Florida market," he said.

Kathy Bushouse can be reached at kbushouse@sun-sentinel.com or 954-356-4667.

From: Governor Jeb Bush [mailto:Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com] 
Sent: Monday, July 31, 2006 9:18 AM
To: Teresa DeFeo
Subject: RE: Home owners insurance in Pasco county

 

Dear Ms. DeFeo,

 

Thank you for sharing your concerns regarding homeowner’s insurance.  Governor Bush appreciates your views and asked me to respond on his behalf. 

 

As a result of the past hurricane seasons, property insurance rates have increased.  The Governor knows this is a challenging reality for homeowners, businesses, and local governments, but understands increased rates are a common market reaction to the risk associated with insuring homes and businesses in Florida at a time when so much damage was caused by recent hurricanes.  

 

Governor Bush believes the underlying problems in the property insurance market can be resolved by encouraging mitigation of homes and buildings to make them more resistant to wind damage, and by encouraging private insurance companies to underwrite more of the state’s wind risk.  This would minimize the number of policies and the amount of claims exposure for Citizens Property Insurance Corporation (Citizens), the state’s insurer of last resort.  Citizens covers those who cannot obtain property insurance from the private market.     

 

On May 16, 2006, Governor Bush signed Senate Bill 1980 into law.  This bill provides policy reforms and funding to stabilize and improve the property insurance market.  Senate Bill 1980 assists private insurance companies with an Insurance Capital Build-up Incentive Program allowing private insurance companies to underwrite more policies in Florida.  The bill provides funding for free home inspections and grants for homeowners who choose to reinforce their homes against wind damage through the Florida Comprehensive Hurricane Damage Mitigation Program.  It also provides funding to offset the deficit of Citizens, reducing assessments to homeowners, and provides reforms to prevent future Citizens’ assessments.  Those with internet access can view the complete text of the bill online by typing in the bill number on the Senate’s homepage at www.flsenate.gov.

 

Governor Bush believes that long-term reforms are necessary to repair the underlying problems that exist in the insurance market.  The Governor created the “Property and Casualty Insurance Reform Committee” to address these important issues.  This Executive Order is online at: www.flgov.com/executive_orders.

 

Thank you again for writing.  Governor Bush wants to know how Floridians feel about the many critical issues we face and encourages you to share your views with your local legislative delegation.  Please be assured that the Governor will keep your ideas in mind as he forms policy for addressing these concerns.  

 

 

Sincerely,

 

 

 

L. Wright

HURRICANE INSURANCE CRISIS | FIRST IN A SERIES
State failures leave policyholders without a net 
 

By Kathy Bushouse
South Florida Sun-Sentinel

August 6, 2006


Florida's property insurance market is a mess, despite legislators' attempts to fix it for more than a decade.

The price of home and condominium insurance has soared to dizzying levels. Insurers have dumped longtime customers and slashed coverage for others. The state's home insurer of last resort now is the biggest property insurer in Florida.

More and more homeowners and businesses are forced to ponder whether they can afford the Sunshine State anymore.

Much of this is the Legislature's handiwork.

Fearing any action that would drive insurers out of the state, lawmakers have shown for years they won't stand up to the insurance companies.

This year, with great fanfare, legislators directed $715 million in tax money to help close the $1.7 billion deficit at state-run Citizens Property Insurance Corp. All Florida homeowners still are on the hook for the remaining shortfall of almost $1 billion. Yet legislators allowed insurance companies to raise rates up to 10 percent without getting state approval and cleared the way for drastic price increases for many of Citizens' customers.

"The casualty is the consumer," said state Sen. Ron Klein, D-Boca Raton. "The Legislature has made the continuing mistake, year in and year out, of giving almost everything the insurance companies want to them, with the view that `Hey, if we do this, it will make more (competition).'

"How many years does it take? It's over a decade where this thinking hasn't worked," said Klein, who is running for Congress.

Over the next 12 months in South Florida, many people will see their homeowner's insurance bills more than double.

Ruth Berge, a divorced mother of two in Jupiter, is working a third job to pay additional expenses, including insurance.

"If I can't make this work, I'll have to [move] ...,'' the second-generation Floridian said.

The insurance market quagmire started in 1992 when Hurricane Andrew slammed into southwestern Miami-Dade County. Insurers realized their rates weren't high enough to handle South Florida's storm risk, and they had too many home policies concentrated in certain areas.

In the aftermath, state insurance officials and legislators allowed insurers to raise rates and slash coverage because thehurricane caused $16 billion in losses -- that's $22 billion in today's dollars.

The promise from insurers then was simple: Allow much higher insurance prices and we'll be able to handle catastrophes down the road. The state complied, approving big rate increases.

"I consider that a total renege of what we were promised," said Robert Hunter, director of insurance for the Consumer Federation of America and a former Texas insurance commissioner. "The big rate increases we granted back in the mid-90s were supposed to bring stability at times like this ... I feel like they lied to us."

Florida insurers say claims from the eight hurricanes in 2004 and 2005 wiped out their surpluses, even though they collected higher home and condo premiums for more than a decade after Andrew.

"We paid out $35 billion. It's a hell of a lot more money than we took in those two years," said Sam Miller, executive vice president of the Florida Insurance Council, an industry trade group. "It seems to me that we're taking a hell of a loss. And we're still here."

`PATCHWORK SYSTEM'

State officials had planned for the next Andrew, not the possibility of multiple-storm seasons. Therefore, as the insurance crisis deepens, some say the trauma exceeds what the state faced more than a decade ago.

"It's on its way to being worse, in the sense that we already have created the institutions that we thought were necessary to handle a post-Andrew crisis and those institutions are failing us," said Scott Johnson, executive vice president of the Florida Association of Insurance Agents. "What makes this worse, in my opinion, is that we have our patchwork system in place, and it's leaking like a sieve."

Johnson lays the blame for the insurance market collapse squarely on the Legislature. "Through commission and omission, they are responsible for all of it.''

Sen. J.D. Alexander, R-Lake Wales, said in May near the end of the legislative session "there's enough blame on everybody's hands, [Democrats] and [Republicans] ... to go around. I'm not willing to lay that blame on anyone's hands, but I would tell you I think we all have culpability and we need to move and basically try to find a fix."

Even with the insurance fixes lawmakers approved this year, the balance of insurance risk and financial return is out of whack in Florida, consumer advocates contend. "It used to be insurance companies took some risk that they'd lose money ... [Now] they don't even want to suffer a quarterly loss," Hunter said.

"Why should we give them money and profits if they're not willing to take risk? That's the thing they're supposed to do. ... They're supposed to bring stability and comfort in a time of crisis. Instead, they're terminating people and dumping them out in a market that's a mess."

The higher prices today have nothing to do with being averse to risk and insurers are not making up for past losses, Miller said.

Insurance companies see the much higher costs of building materials and reinsurance, the insurance for insurance companies to help cover catastrophic claims; those two things make up the majority of the increases insurers are seeking, he said.

But insurers have reduced their storm risk in Florida, by shifting more of the burden in recent years to policyholders. Consider:

Thousands of the state's homeowners, after paying premiums for years, are being dropped. Allstate Floridian Insurance Co. alone is shedding about 269,000 property policies statewide.

Premiums have risen more than 300 percent for the average homeowner since 1992 when Andrew upended the state's insurance market. Before Andrew, Floridians paid an average of $366 a year for homeowner's insurance, according to industry figures. Today, that statewide average is about $1,300 a year; those averages are much higher in South Florida -- nearly $2,800 in Broward County, $2,600 in Palm Beach County and $3,400 in Miami-Dade County.

Special hurricane deductibles mean homeowners shell out thousands of dollars before insurers will pay damage claims. Prior to 1996, the standard deductible was $500.

Formed as a stopgap measure, state-backed Citizens is now the state's largest property insurer despite a decade-long program to shed policies.

Private national insurers have created Florida-only subsidiaries, which keep the hurricane risk contained to the state rather than spread throughout the country. That forces the Florida-only companies to rely more heavily on the reinsurance market, and those rates are doubling in some cases. Those increases are being passed along to consumers.

AFTER ANDREW

Andrew hit Miami-Dade County in the early morning of Aug. 24, 1992, cutting a devastating swath through thousands of homes and businesses. Until Hurricane Katrina slammed into the Gulf Coast last year, Andrew -- first measured as a Category 5 storm when it hit South Florida but later downgraded to a Category 4 -- was the costliest natural disaster in U.S. history.

The brutal storm left Florida's property insurance market in upheaval. In a special session in 1992, legislators gave a $500 million shot to the Florida Insurance Guaranty Association, which pays claims for cash-strapped insurers. Andrew bankrupted at least 11 of them.

Just months after Andrew hit, legislators created a joint underwriting insurance association, the predecessor of Citizens, as a safety net for the thousands of Floridians who had insurance policies canceled or lost coverage because insurers went belly up.

In 1993, legislators limited the number of policies property insurers could shed in a year. Insurers could opt not to renew 5 percent of their policies in Florida and 10 percentin a given county. That only applied to homes with insurance policies issued before June 1, 1996. The moratorium was lifted in 2001, when state officials weren't concerned about mass policy cancellations because theinsurance market was relatively stable.

Now the state restricts property insurers' policy non-renewals and cancellations after a hurricane. And insurers are prohibited from dropping customers with storm-damaged homes until 60 days after home or condo repairs are finished.

Also in 1993, legislators created the Florida Hurricane Catastrophe Fund to offer cheap reinsurance coverage to insurers to help pay claims after hurricanes. The money comes from premiums paid by insurers.

But insurers drained the $6 billion fund to pay 2004 and 2005 storm claims. Now the same homeowners facing escalating premiums must pay an extra charge averaging $10 a year for 10 years to replenish the insurers' catastrophe fund.

REINSURANCE SURGES

In the mid-1990s, large national insurers such as Allstate and State Farm spun off Florida companies to handle property insurance policies here. But the parent companies held onto the lucrative automobile and life insurance business in the state.

That shielded the companies from massive losses in the event of more hurricanes in Florida. Allstate earned $1.8 billion in 2005 despite losses from Hurricane Katrina, down from $3.2 billion a year earlier, according to the company's annual report. And State Farm made $3.24 billion, down 39 percent from $5.31 billion in net income in 2004, according to its annual report.

Last year, U.S. property insurers reported a record $43 billion profit, an 11.7 percent increase over the previous year and the highest net income since 1991, according to the Insurance Information Institute, a nonprofit trade group. Insurers handled the big claims from 2005 storms because they relied on reinsurance companies. Reinsurers absorbed half of the $55 billion in Katrina losses. Those same reinsurers are sharply increasing their rates in Florida coastal areas, making it more expensive for insurance companies to sell policies. And so property insurers are passing along the higher costs in the form of higher premiums.

Stuart Bowers, an Oakland Park teacher, is so angry his insurance bill keeps increasing that he has contacted legislators and e-mailed friends to "band together'' to do something. "Am I working just to pay windstorm premiums? ... At some point, something's going to give.''

Some say a national catastrophe fund will remedy Florida's insurance crisis.

U.S. Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz, D-Weston, and U.S. Sen. Bill Nelson, D-Fla., last month unveiled bills that would determine how to establish a national disaster fund. And U.S. Reps. Ginny Brown-Waite, R-Brooksville, and Clay Shaw, R-Fort Lauderdale, last November introduced a similar measure.

"When the big one comes, whether it's Los Angeles or Miami or St. Louis, the federal government is going to be in the position of [paying for] an event," state Insurance Commissioner Kevin McCarty said. "The state can only do so much. ... At some point this is beyond the ability and scope of the state of Florida to manage."

Kathy Bushouse can be reached at kbushouse@sun-sentinel.com or 954-356-4667.

From: jeb.bush@myflorida.com
To: jeb.bush@myflorida.com
Sent: Fri, 4 Aug 2006 1:12 PM
Subject: Governor Jeb Bush's IN THE NEWS... Friday, August 4, 2006


For those E-Newsletter recipients who have Adobe Acrobat reader, Governor
Bush's e-newsletter is available in .PDF format by clicking here:

http://www.flgov.com/in_the_news

The text version of the e-newsletter is below.


STATE REINSURANCE POOL FOR FLORIDA BUSINESSES BEING ACTIVATED

On Tuesday, the Florida Cabinet and I voted unanimously to activate a state
reinsurance pool to support private property insurance for Florida
businesses.   The move is a response to the growing commercial insurance
challenge in the state.  We continue to aggressively seek measures to
provide insurance relief for residents and businesses.  The availability and
affordability of insurance is the biggest threat to our incredibly robust
and growing economy.  Getting insurance, especially at a price they can
afford, can make or break a small business today.  Small businesses need our
help.  Many businesses across Florida have lost their commercial property
insurance or can no longer afford the premiums to retain coverage.  The
challenges are the result of global reinsurers dramatically raising rates
and limiting the amount of coverage they are willing to write in Florida
following two unprecedented hurricane seasons. Insurance companies purchase
reinsurance to cover catastrophic losses in the wake of hurricanes.  For
more information on the Property and Casualty Insurance Reform Committee,
please visit www.myflorida.com.


ALL ABOARD PLAN TO BRING COMMUTER RAIL TO CENTRAL FLORIDA

On Wednesday, I announced a comprehensive plan to improve freight service
and bring commuter rail to Central Florida.  Under the agreement in
principle between the Florida Department of Transportation (FDOT) and CSX
Transportation Inc. (CSXT), Florida will invest $491 million to improve
infrastructure and expand capacity on two existing rail lines, one of which
will be used to establish commuter rail service through a multi-county
stretch in the region.  Establishing commuter rail will ease congestion,
which will improve the quality of life of people both on and off the road.
Improving the existing railways will enhance the safety and mobility of both
goods and people, which will generate new economic opportunity for millions
of Floridians.  In partnership with CSXT, Florida will invest $318 million
to improve the infrastructure and expand capacity on existing train tracks.
For more information on commuter rail, visit http://www.dot.state.fl.us.


GROUND BROKEN ON MASSIVE RESERVOIR TO RESTORE AMERICA'S EVERGLADES

On Wednesday, I also joined local, state and federal leaders to break ground
on one of the most expansive reservoirs in the world as part of the massive
effort to restore America's Everglades. When complete, the first component
of the Everglades Agricultural Area Reservoir will cover 25 square miles and
provide 190,000 acre-feet of water storage to better manage water released
from Lake Okeechobee and to improve the timing and quality of water
delivered to the famed River of Grass. The $400 million reservoir is the
flagship project of the State's Acceler8 initiative to complete eight
critical Everglades restoration projects ahead of schedule.  Florida is
keeping its promise to restore the River of Grass and protect this national
treasure.  By constructing this massive water storage system, we can better
control water releases, restore wildlife habitat and protect the state's
estuaries.  Engineers will move close to 18 million cubic yards of earth to
construct the Everglades Agricultural Area Reservoir on 16,700 acres of
former farmland. Along with capturing runoff from agricultural areas, the
reservoir will store freshwater releases from Lake Okeechobee to reduce
harmful discharges to the St. Lucie and Caloosahatchee estuaries. The
reservoir will also provide additional water to hydrate the Everglades,
increase flood protection and allow water managers to capture and direct
phosphorus-laden water to constructed wetlands for treatment.  For more
information on Acceler8, visit www.evergladesnow.org.


POINTS OF LIGHT AWARD PRESENTED TO LAURA ADAMS

Congratulations!

From:	Sue Dobson <msdobson@tampabay.rr.com>
Sent:	Sunday, August 6, 2006 11:20 AM

August 6, 2006

Jeb Bush, Governor
State of Florida
Tallahassee, FL

Dear Jeb:

First, I would like to say that, as a resident of Florida for
approximately 50 years, I am very proud of the job you have done as
Governor of Florida.  You have quietly gone about the business of
preparing Florida for disaster, implementing education reforms, and have
brought a practical nature and an honest and realistic approach to
problems facing the state.

The purpose of this letter is to offer a suggestion for the insurance
crisis that we are all experiencing throughout the state.  We all know
that there are two major exposures for insurance companies operating in
Florida - flood and wind.  Flood coverage is taken out of the equation
through the Federal Government and the NFIP.  That leaves wind.  If
Citizens' windstorm program were expanded, and extended possibly
throughout the state, insurance companies would be much more willing to
write policies.  My company manages property in various areas of
Florida, all waterfront locations.  Our properties in Monroe County and
Miami-Date County had no problem in obtaining property insurance, due to
the fact that both properties have their windstorm coverage through
Citizens' Windstorm program.  However, we also manage a property that
sits directly  on Tampa Bay in Hillsborough County, which is of course
not eligible for windstorm coverage through Citizens.  Our total
insurance premium last year (4/05-5/06) totaled approximately $204,000.
This year's total premium is almost $900,000!  The replacement cost of
the condominium is approximately $19,000,000, and there was a two-week
period within which we only had windstorm coverage for the first
$2,500,000 and the last $9,000,000 of value - nothing in the middle
layer between  $2,500,000 and $10,000,000.  Coverage was finally
obtained through Lloyd's of London, but the cost was an astounding
$594,000!  Although our Board of Directors prudently budgeted for an
increase in insurance cost in the 2006 budget, no one could have
envisioned this size of an increase.  A large special assessment was
required, causing financial hardships for our condominium owners.  They
are also quite concerned about resales of units, since the regular
assessments will now rise considerably.  We were told by our insurance
agent that the insurance company that insured the first $2,500,000 of
wind coverage stated that if the policy excluded wind, the total
premium, covering all $19,000,000, would have been in the $80,000 range.

There are very few days that go by that an article is not in the St.
Pete Times regarding insurance, particularly stories of woe regarding
Citizens' property insurance problems.  Very rarely do I read a negative
article about Citizens' Windstorm policies; actually, there is very
little written about Citizens' windstorm policies at all.  The
commercial/residential windstorm policies are relatively affordable.
The 3% hurricane deductible is reasonable.  The $1,000 deductible for
non-hurricane wind is extremely reasonable.  Citizens could easily
increase that deductible to $5,000 or so, and "weed out" many of the
smaller claims.  With expanded participation in the wind pool, Citizens
could phase out its property coverage (or at least greatly reduce the
number of property policies), and concentrate on policies covering only
windstorm.  I don't know if this approach is financially viable, but
even if the cost to the state increased somewhat, I am sure that
individual homeowners, and owners of condominiums and commercial
property would save money in the long run.  Insurance companies would
gladly write policies in Florida if they were able to exclude wind
damage  from their policies.  

I suppose it is naïve of me to think that this suggestion has not been
proposed previously.  However, one never knows.  I saw you on the news
one day recently, and you looked so frustrated about the insurance
crisis and I believe you said something to the effect of you'd be glad
to call the legislature into special session to address this, but unless
any viable solutions were presented, it would be a waste of time.
Rather than just sit back and complain about it, I felt it was my duty
as a citizen of Florida to at least offer a suggestion.

On a personal note, I hope you and your family are doing well.  My heart
ached for you and your family in reading about problems encountered by
your daughter Noelle.  I am a single mother of two daughters (now grown
- one is a teacher of mentally handicapped students in Hillsborough
County, and one is an R.N. at Bay Pines VA Hospital).  I know how
difficult it can be to raise children, and at least most of us have the
luxury of dealing with our family issues in private.  I hope your
daughter is doing well now.

Good luck to you in your future endeavors as your tenure of governor
comes to an end.  If you return to developing property, perhaps our
companies can do some business together sometime in the future.  My
company has managed condo-hotel properties for 25 years.  I should note
that although our owners are technically "absentee owners", most
maintain their permanent residences within Florida.

Thank you for your time.

Sincerely,

Margaret Sue Dobson
