From:  "Jeb Bush" <jeb.bush@myflorida.com>
Reply-To:  jeb.bush@myflorida.com
To:  "Jeb Bush" <jeb.bush@myflorida.com>
Subject:  Governor Jeb Bush's IN THE NEWS... Friday, August 4, 2006
Date:  Fri, 4 Aug 2006 16:12:28 -0400
>For those E-Newsletter recipients who have Adobe Acrobat reader, Governor
>Bush's e-newsletter is available in .PDF format by clicking here:
>
>http://www.flgov.com/in_the_news
>
>The text version of the e-newsletter is below.
>
>
>STATE REINSURANCE POOL FOR FLORIDA BUSINESSES BEING ACTIVATED
>
>On Tuesday, the Florida Cabinet and I voted unanimously to activate a state
>reinsurance pool to support private property insurance for Florida
>businesses.   The move is a response to the growing commercial insurance
>challenge in the state.  We continue to aggressively seek measures to
>provide insurance relief for residents and businesses.  The availability and
>affordability of insurance is the biggest threat to our incredibly robust
>and growing economy.  Getting insurance, especially at a price they can
>afford, can make or break a small business today.  Small businesses need our
>help.  Many businesses across Florida have lost their commercial property
>insurance or can no longer afford the premiums to retain coverage.  The
>challenges are the result of global reinsurers dramatically raising rates
>and limiting the amount of coverage they are willing to write in Florida
>following two unprecedented hurricane seasons. Insurance companies purchase
>reinsurance to cover catastrophic losses in the wake of hurricanes.  For
>more information on the Property and Casualty Insurance Reform Committee,
>please visit www.myflorida.com.
>
>
>ALL ABOARD PLAN TO BRING COMMUTER RAIL TO CENTRAL FLORIDA
>
>On Wednesday, I announced a comprehensive plan to improve freight service
>and bring commuter rail to Central Florida.  Under the agreement in
>principle between the Florida Department of Transportation (FDOT) and CSX
>Transportation Inc. (CSXT), Florida will invest $491 million to improve
>infrastructure and expand capacity on two existing rail lines, one of which
>will be used to establish commuter rail service through a multi-county
>stretch in the region.  Establishing commuter rail will ease congestion,
>which will improve the quality of life of people both on and off the road.
>Improving the existing railways will enhance the safety and mobility of both
>goods and people, which will generate new economic opportunity for millions
>of Floridians.  In partnership with CSXT, Florida will invest $318 million
>to improve the infrastructure and expand capacity on existing train tracks.
>For more information on commuter rail, visit http://www.dot.state.fl.us.
>
>
>GROUND BROKEN ON MASSIVE RESERVOIR TO RESTORE AMERICA'S EVERGLADES
>
>On Wednesday, I also joined local, state and federal leaders to break ground
>on one of the most expansive reservoirs in the world as part of the massive
>effort to restore America's Everglades. When complete, the first component
>of the Everglades Agricultural Area Reservoir will cover 25 square miles and
>provide 190,000 acre-feet of water storage to better manage water released
>from Lake Okeechobee and to improve the timing and quality of water
>delivered to the famed River of Grass. The $400 million reservoir is the
>flagship project of the State's Acceler8 initiative to complete eight
>critical Everglades restoration projects ahead of schedule.  Florida is
>keeping its promise to restore the River of Grass and protect this national
>treasure.  By constructing this massive water storage system, we can better
>control water releases, restore wildlife habitat and protect the state's
>estuaries.  Engineers will move close to 18 million cubic yards of earth to
>construct the Everglades Agricultural Area Reservoir on 16,700 acres of
>former farmland. Along with capturing runoff from agricultural areas, the
>reservoir will store freshwater releases from Lake Okeechobee to reduce
>harmful discharges to the St. Lucie and Caloosahatchee estuaries. The
>reservoir will also provide additional water to hydrate the Everglades,
>increase flood protection and allow water managers to capture and direct
>phosphorus-laden water to constructed wetlands for treatment.  For more
>information on Acceler8, visit www.evergladesnow.org.
>
>
>POINTS OF LIGHT AWARD PRESENTED TO LAURA ADAMS
>
>Congratulations!
>
>To read more about this week's winner, please click here:
>http://www.flgov.com/release/8045
>
>
>GOVERNOR BUSH'S 2006 LEGISLATIVE INITIATIVES
>
>Please visit www.govfloridaforum.com.
>

Orlando Sentinel

WESH

I am a condominium owner in Lake Villas, Maitland Ave, Altamonte Springs, Florida since 1982 and I am shocked that as your constituents who own condominiums you are not doing something about the increasing insurance rates for condominium owners. How could you have allowed our Commercial Property insurances to be raised five times more than our previous premiums. Also, you have allowed Citizens to demand that we pay the entire premium immediately in order to get coverage, an unheard of request for all companies. Without regard for condominium owners you did not allow us time to obtain the massive necessary funding.

As owners in a 71 unit condominium, we are now in the position of having to pay over $181,000 or $2,500 each just for a Citizens policy that fails to cover much that our previous policy covered. Releasing legislation allowing Citizens, a State Agency, to do this is unconscionable. 

The Citizens policy 3% deductible for hurricane damage leaves us basically uncovered for most such damage. For example, if a $1,000,000 building suffers $30,000 of roof damage, we will receive no help from the insurance we purchased. 

In fact we had to pay over $7,400 more to another insurance underwriter just to get a bit more of the basic coverage that we had under our previous policy.

Our association has paid for uninterrupted insurance coverage for over 33 years with minimal claims. Now we condominium owners are being singled out to pay for such a large percentage of the State of Florida's losses. This is DISGRACEFUL AND OUT RIGHT DISCRIMINATION. As many people would say outright PRICE GOUGING

As you are probably aware most condominium owners are single people, retired people or single parents that you are allowing to be discriminated against. Condominium owners are just like private home owners. I have read articles on private home owners being upset regarding a 40-50% increase in their insurance premiums, imagine how they would feel if they were us.

Consequence to your lack of action is:

Some of our owners on fixed incomes may loose their homes when faced with this enormous increase.

A rash of foreclosures occurring in Florida will create an economic impact to our state. The condominium idea used to be a lucrative one where all owners shared and enjoyed the benefits of the property will no longer exist. 

Condominium property vales drop dramatically and condominiums will have little or no resale value.

At this point, we feel that our legislature has abandoned and blindsided us, leaving us in the position of being without reasonable insurance to protect us from the impact of natural disasters. We are asking that you, as a leader that we elected step up to the plate and take whatever action is required to immediately rectify this discrimination. We voted for you , we believed in you, now do your job.

Subject:	Insurance

Dear Governor Bush:
 
The following three numbers are a positive indicative of the fiasco that insurance has become in the state of Florida.
 
1) Last year the property insurance for my condominium association was $146,321.
 
2) The property insurance rate for the coming year is $726,728.
 
3) In the past five years our claims have totaled $12,759
 
I must admit that after over 50 years in the insurance business at all levels, I have never seen a situation that was obviously as fraught with incompetence and unfairness as the above three simple numbers clearly point out.  In addition, in 1998 the property insurance was $52,000 and the insurance industry was not "losing" money at that time. From:	academy <hacadem1@tampabay.rr.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, August 2, 2006 11:11 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] VPK Funding

Please read the following letter and respond as soon as you have the opportunity.  Florida Educational leaders should be aware of the situation that the VPK program has created for our private school and likely others.  Thank-you.  Wendy VIles
 
Dear Lt. Governor,
 
My name is Wendy Viles and I am the founder and director of Hand in Hand Academy, located in Lutz, Florida.  I had the pleasure of meeting with you last summer at the VPK contract signing in Hillsborough County.  I was excited about the program and fully believed it to be an incredible opportunity for Florida's children and their families.  
 
It is with mixed emotions that I write this email.  As I waited on hold to speak to a representative, I listened to a recording of you explaining how quickly the State's VPK program has grown and how positively we are impacting the children enrolled.  I certainly agree and truly believe that the opportunities that 'we' are creating for children within our program are dynamic.  
 
All of our teachers at Hand in Hand Academy are certified and 38% of our classroom teachers have advanced degrees in education.  We elected to participate in the summer VPK program, and as the VPK provider contract dictates we fully expected prepay for the months that we participated.  Unfortunately, the reality of the situation is that this program has been financially devastating.  We have not only yet to receive any timely "prepays", but we are also still owed $45,000 for the July prepay and the August prepay (for school year) was due to us last week.  
 
We are a small program and do not have a substantial savings to fall back on.  The majority of our tuition covers teacher salaries and operational expenses.  Any spare money in the budget goes directly to new curriculum, supplies and equipment.  We are proud that we have never had a teacher leave and only lose students when our families need to relocate.
 
I point out these things because we are incredibly pleased with our programs and student progress.  We have individualized goals for each student and we employ reading teachers who read with each child individually as well as in small groups.  Our students are reading at astounding levels at very early ages.  We also have teachers for Spanish, music, art and physical education.  
 
Because of the VPK shortfall, I have been forced to borrow money from my own personal savings.  I did so with the thought that we would receive the funding in a few short weeks.  When I depleted my savings, I turned to a lender for a loan to continue to pay the summer VPK teachers.  At one point this summer, Hillsborough County was in debt to Hand in Hand Academy approximately $75,000.  My loan, which is with a private lender, was at a 15% interest rate.  Not perfect terms, but I needed immediate funds and this was unfortunately the best option I could find for such short notice.
 
I was suppose to close on my newly awaited home on Friday, August 4th.  This has been delayed because I do no have the monies that I need available for closing.  I am devastated that I am in this situation and truly concerned that I am going to lose my new home along with a $10,000 deposit that I have in escrow.  
 
Many local providers did not participate in the VPK program because of various concerns that they had about being involved in a new and unproven program.  Our program has been operating at capacity for years with a substantial waitlist.  We chose to participate to help our families realize the most optimal educational opportunities for their child/children.  I want to continue to be involved and hope to continue to support the VPK program, but as you can imagine I am approaching levels of frustration which will ultimately force our withdrawal as a VPK provider.
 
I spoke with Maxine McConnell several times today.  She was quite responsive and assured me that Hillsborough County received the July "prepay" on July 31st.  I then spoke to Hillsborough County and was told that, yes, they did receive money which may have been intended for July- but, because the State still owed such significant amounts that they needed to apply that money to back debt.  I, in turn, left a message for Ms. McConnell with my new found frustration that it appeared that there may still not be any payments in the immediate future.  She responded later in the day that she had requested Hillsborough County to respond to me directly.  It turns out that Hillsborough County "thought" that the State owed them more money than they apparently did.
 
Sounds like a game of bad telephone, only on a much more complicated and damaging level. I am requesting payment that should have been made on June 29, 2006 in the amount of approximately $45,000.  I am hopeful that August prepayment will be just around the corner.  We are not contractually "allowed" to ask parents for tuition if their child is enrolled in a program that offers only 540 hours.  Facilities that are paying $7.00 to $10.00 an hour will most certainly still realize profit margins.  Our program employs teachers at an approximate salary breakdown of $25.00 to $30.00 an hour.  I ultimately lose money on children who are enrolled in a 540 hour program.  At the very least, I should be able to expect prepay.  Even worse, nobody bothered to contact us about possible delays.  The money just never came.  
 
I apologize for rambling on during this email.  I do not know where to turn and am not sure how to survive the situation I have been placed in.  If you find yourself in Hillsborough County, I would love the opportunity to share our programs with you.  We are incredibly proud of what we are offering our students and families. Please let me know if you can be of assistance with our payment situation.  I look forward to your response.
 
 
Wendy Viles
Hand in Hand Academy
19215 Livingston AVe.
Lutz, FL 33559
813-949-3367
813-949-3597 (fax)
hacadem1@tampabay.rr.com
www.handinhandacademy.com

But, I feel that our insurance commissioners, both past and present have allowed the ins. cos. to run rampant during the last decade with increasing premiums and cancelling policies at will with no one controlling it, they now feel that they can do anything they want. IT MUST STOP NOW!.

Whenever I hear a politician comment on putting controls on insurance companies they all say "well , if we try to control the premiums the ins. companies will leave the state". I say that is bunk. They are not about to leave possibly trillions of dollars in premiums just because some controls have been put on them. THERE ARE THINGS THAT CAN BE DONE WITHOUT LOSING THE INS. COS.

1. Mandate that ALL insurance companies offer ALL LINES of ins. If not, then they can not sell in Florida. This will spread out the risk and provide competition in the market--and, believe it or not, they all will still make money.

2. The Federal Govt. and the State Govt. need to assign funds to assist citizens when there is a disaster. For example, if a disaster strikes then the govts. step in after pre-determined loss limits have been met by the ins. cos.  Our federal govt. thinks nothing of going to Indonesia and giving them billions because they had a disaster.  And, they told us to leave, "just leave your money".  Our money should first be for our citizens and if there is any left over then maybe we can help someone else, but someone who appreciates it. This funding should be legislated as a "savings account" for any disasters within the 50 United States and not a spur of the moment decision as it is now.

I am sure that there are probably other things that can be done to halt this ins. problem. However, I leave you with my suggestions since you have the resources to come up with other ways of stemming the problem.

Incidentally, I have not heard from any politician (except Mike Fasano) come up with any thoughts as to how to solve this problem.  Mike, I went to one of your speeches and was glad to hear that you are trying to get this problem solved.

From:	kate madera <tikm4465@earthlink.net>
Sent:	Wednesday, August 2, 2006 2:27 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] spinal muscular atrophy

1 in 40 – SMA Could Affect You 

Dear Sir  

The statistic is: 1 in 40 people carry the gene that causes SMA – Spinal Muscular Atrophy. That means that more than 7 million Americans are carriers of disease that most people have never heard about. 

I learned about SMA last July when my eight-month-old daughter, Vivianna, was diagnosed.  I felt something was wrong; she lost a few abilities  most children that age have.  Her pediatrician agreed and an appointment was made with a neurologist.  He suspected SMA immediately and 9 days later called with the results of her DNA test.  I was told over the phone that my beautiful daughter would die before her second birthday and I should decide how I wanted to handle the end of her life.  Imagine a doctor telling you this over the phone while you are watching your child sitting on the floor eating a cracker.  My world came to an end that day.  I knew in my heart that he was wrong in stating which type of SMA she has.  His exam lasted ten minutes.  Thankfully, she was examined by other doctors who immediately stated that my daughter did not have the severest form of SMA and explained why.  At least now we have hope.

Parents of SMA children learn all too soon that doctors are quick to write off these children.  Egos come into play, many doctors I’ve encountered are unwilling to learn of the advancement other doctors who study and treat SMA children have made.  

Here are a few quick facts. SMA is the leading genetic killer of children under the age of two. SMA is a degenerative disease that affects the voluntary muscles. Those that survive face a life watching as their muscles slowly fail leaving them unable to walk, crawl, sit-up or even swallow. It is a recessive disease – two parents who are both carriers of the gene that causes SMA have a one in four chance of passing the disease on to a child. SMA crosses all racial, ethnic, religious and gender boundaries and while it is primarily diagnosed in children it can affect people of any age. August is SMA awareness month and there is hope. 

Families of SMA, a grassroots organization of which I am a member, is funding drug development programs and clinical trials which may mean a treatment is on the horizon. The federal government is considering the addition of SMA as one of the recommended diseases for newborn screening. You are reading this article so that one more person knows about SMA. Awareness is the beginning. 

Sometimes it takes celebrities to bring a disease from the shadows out into the light. Sometimes it just takes the dedication of individuals to make a difference. 

To learn more about how you can help contact Families of SMA at 800-886-1762 or on the web www.curesma.org. We are working to help raise awareness and funding for research, education, advocacy and patient services. By increasing funding, we can help to unravel the mysteries of this disease and continue working toward effective treatments. By participating and donating, you can make a difference in a life. Together we will find a cure! 

One in 40 may seem like a big number, but it became very small when it touched our family.  

Our children our suffering because of very little State and Federal Funding applied directly to a genetic disease that is the number one killer of children.  Our President has decided that Stem Cell research is immoral.  The eight cell blastocysts  in stem cells are not human beings.  Stem Cell research is not murder, stem cell research saves lives.

Our children also suffer every time an insurance company denies a claim for treatment or equipment.  I hope you never have to watch your child struggle to breath, and I hope you never have to insert a 16 inch catheter into your child’s lungs to suction out the teaspoon of water he or she is choking on.  SMA children cannot cough or sneeze due to weak muscles.  The next time you have a cold or have swallowed incorrectly, imagine not being able to cough.  

Many States, especially Florida offer such little help to parents.  Medicaid is non-existent for children with SMA 2.  

Our children need help; they need funding for research and coverage for health care needs.  Who will be the first Senator, Congressman to say the words Spinal Muscular Atrophy?

My last question is this:

Does my daughter have to be Iraqi to receive proper medical care in this Country?

 

 

 

 

Kate Madera

17 SE 61 CT 

Ocala FL 34472

 

 
 
kate madera
tikm4465@earthlink.net
EarthLink Revolves Around You.

From: Frank Hokenson [mailto:fhoke@comcast.net] 
Sent: Tuesday, July 25, 2006 5:50 PM
To: BCC
Cc: Administration, BCC
Subject: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY INSURANCE

 

A serious situation is taking place in Charlotte County, regarding property insurance for commercial buildings, and their contents.

 

The Punta Gorda Boat Club’s property insurance renewal, May 31, 200 6, was conditional, excluding wind coverage.  Following the notice of no wind coverage, a thorough search was conducted to obtain such coverage, through several insurance agencies, to no avail, and in fact were advised Charlotte County, other than the barrier islands, is not included in the Florida State Wind Pool.

 

We have also learned that we are not alone in not being able to purchase wind coverage, as the local insurance agencies contacted have stated generally commercial insurance policies in this area, particularly, within three miles of tidal water, are being renewed excluding wind.  A  recent newsletter from RE/ Max Harbor Realty, stated “ Commercial real estate insurance is not available at all”.  It is my understanding, Charlotte Harbor Yacht Club, St. Vincent de Paul, Punta Gorda Civic Association,  are experiencing the same problem.

 

Wind and Flood are our main hazard concerns.  We are able to purchase flood insurance through the Federal Flood Pool, leaving us without insurance for the very possible hurricane potential, as we have recently experienced in 2004.

 

 The seriousness of this situation, can be easily visualized, should a hurricane, such as Charley, again cross this area. The reality would be, very limited rebuilding of commercial buildings, debris clean up would be minimal, and many businesses would be permanently out of business, without necessary funds to continue.  

 

I have been in contact with Mr. Robert Hebert, County Administration, who advised, the State Legislature established the Wind Insurance Pool for specified Counties, several years ago, and it would take a Legislative act to include Charlotte County.  However, a temporary inclusion could be effected immediately by the Governor’s Cabinet, allowing Charlotte County commercial interests to purchase wind insurance coverage from the pool, as they can in many of the State’s Counties.

 

It is requested Charlotte County make application to the Governor’s Cabinet for immediate inclusion to the Florida Insurance Wind Pool.

 

Very truly yours, 

 

 

Frank Hokenson

Punta Gorda Boat Club

Vice Commodore

RE: Ludicrous Taxes For Americans, But Especially Floridians
Dear Governor Bush,
I know that you have been getting a lot of complaints about the increase
in taxes for the 2005 year.  However, our particular case really
illustrates the disregard for citizens of this state. Our tax increase
was $1,720.11 from $3619.95 for the year 2004 to $5340.06 for 2005. The
amazing thing is that there was no structure on this property for that
tax period. We didn't take occupancy of our new house until July 18,
2005. Another point is that this is a single story dwelling with a floor
plan of 673 square feet. Our neighbor to the East has a two story house
with 1,444 square feet, more than double that of ours. Their tax was
$3597.02 for 2005. I know that they have homestead exemption, plus other
exemptions totaling $40,000, but they had a two story livable house as
opposed to our vacant lot. The cost of a Cadillac Elderado is certainly
more than a Volkswagon Bug. Therefore, can you explain the high taxes on
our property to me? 
We were working in Miami when we bought this property in 1976. It was
like a get-a-way from the big city and something to work toward for
retirement. We moved to North Florida, but I became disabled and needed
to be in a warmer climate for the winter, for the same reason many other
Americans that come down from the North. Our children and grandchildren
still live in the area and we use this place to stay and see them.
Most of the folks here were average working people. We both had an income
and could afford the credit union payments to buy the land, a small
trailer and keep up with the condo fees. The taxes increased as expected,
but we had a chance to improve our skills and also received raises in our
wages enabling us to be able to afford to pay the increase in taxes. I'm
a retired Florida teacher, so you know I'm not some big entrepreneur. Our
tax bill for St. Lucie County had gone up almost 48% this past year. Our
cost of living (COLA) increase from our retirement sources has gone up
about 3%, not nearly enough to pay the tax with ease. This last tax
increase of 2005 has financially strapped many folks living in this
community. I have heard of several widows that can not afford to pay the
increase in taxes and are unable to sell because the tax is so high.
What is to happen to them?
Something should be done to help us. I hope this letter doesn't fall on
deaf ears and that I receive a reply from you. Thank you very much,
Best regards,

From:	Ed Johnes <ejohnes@ehsppo.com>
Sent:	Friday, July 28, 2006 11:47 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Healthcare in Florida

Dear Governor,

 

I’m amazed at the lack of government intervention into the healthcare issues in Florida.  Although these issues are not unique to Florida, I deal with them first hand as the chief executive of a PPO network based in New Port Richey.  You might say I have an insider’s perspective.

 

My most significant challenges in delivering a competitive health insurance network (offering savings to group health plans at contracted doctors and hospitals) are with the business practices used by large group health carriers and hospitals.

 

Despite my best efforts to provide a competitive PPO product in this state, a number of hospitals (mostly for-profits, but not all) refuse to contract with my company at a competitive reimbursement levels.  Or at least a level competitive with Blue Cross or United Healthcare.  Why would a for-profit or community based hospital not want to create more competition in the market?   Is competition in the group health market a bad thing?   Who loses… the buyer!

 

Additionally, I’ve seen numerous examples of hospitals charging at levels 3-5 time greater then that paid by Medicare, particularly for outpatient services.   By example, do you think it’s fair to get charged twice (at $4,500 ea) for an operating room because you had two procedures done at the same time?  Additionally, do you think it’s fair to go to a hospital without any obligation to disclose intended costs?  What else do we buy without knowing the cost?  Nothing!  These billing practices have to end, be more transparent, become much more consumer friendly, and allow for competitive alternatives.

 

On the part of the carriers…. Ask any agent, salesman, or consultant about the group health discounts associated with BCBS, United Health, Aetna, Cigna, or Humana health plans.  I unison they will throw out numbers ranging from 45-75% discounts.   These are the numbers that are given out by the carriers when asked.  The calculation of a network discount is complex but in short, they are all engaging in the process of providing false information in the process of a sale to their clients.   I’ve personally seen bids where a carrier will mark every claim at a 75% discount.  You can’t audit a carrier, and in many cases you can’t even get a report of your own company’s claims history with a carrier.  “Sorry that’s proprietary…. , but here’s your 15% premium increase. “ 

 

This is the same problem uncovered in the P&C consulting scandal which started in New York and is now in Florida.   It amounts to the commission of fraud, on a grand scale, against the people of Florida.  When you hire a group health consultant to assist in choosing a health insurance plan… shouldn’t you know how much the consultant and his company are being paid by each carrier that they represent?  Shouldn’t the carrier have to disclose their contract rates, their true discounts?  It’s the same P&C issue… lack of disclosure.   Carriers won’t disclose their claims information to a group because A) They don’t line up with the sales projected savings, and B) It makes it easier to shop carrier and reinsurance products.   Does this work… YES!  Just look at the profit and stock gains by the major carriers over the past three years.

 

If you ever get the chance to review a United Healthcare report for a large group, you will get an eyeful.  I have one on my desk… Group Savings over $2.4 million dollars…. When you look through the report… they also counted disallowed claims (duplicate claims, elective surgery, etc) as savings.  For this particular client they saved 69%!   That’s just outright mis-information.

 

Regulation is the key to good, faithful, and fruitful competition.  By example: utilities, the phone company, banking and brokerage, and soon the P&C industry will have all gone through greater regulation.    Healthcare needs the same treatment… sooner than later.

 

Sincerely,

 

 

 

Edward A. Johnes

CEO

Evolutions Healthcare Systems

ejohnes@ehsppo.com

800-881-4474 Ext. 2300

727-534-5434 Cell

727-938-2222 Fax

To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Gov. Bush, Please Sign SB 772

Dear Governor John Bush:

I am writing today to respectfully request your support for SB 772.
The portion of this large education bill that most concerns me relates to childhood obesity. I know that you care about this issue, too, as evidenced by the task force you created and the resulting Obesity Summits.
As your task force recommended, this bill will empower parents to help improve their children’s health.
In addition, SB 772 will help improve academic achievement in Florida. Healthy students are better students – with increased test scores, concentration and attendance, and reduced discipline problems.


SB 772 will encourage parents, communities, students and schools to work together in the fight against childhood obesity.  
In the U.S., the percentage of overweight children has more than doubled, and the percentage of overweight adolescents has tripled in the past 30 years. In Florida, the trend is similar.
Almost 60% of these overweight children have at least one heart or stroke risk factor, and 25% had two or more risk factors.
The implications of childhood obesity are far-reaching. If childhood obesity continues to increase, the current generation of children and the ones behind them will face devastating health and economic consequences.
Many studies and reports support the connection between academic achievement and student health. We cannot expect our children to excel if they are not physically fit.


Gov. Bush, I know you care about our children. Please demonstrate your support by signing SB 772 into law and helping us all work together on the solutions to childhood obesity.
Thank you in advance for your support.

Sincerely,

todd wassmer
PO Box 846
Melbourne, FL 32902-0846

From:	Shirley Nelson <jem@star2.abcm.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 26, 2006 10:34 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	A solution to the Insurance Crisis using Gap Insurance and Escrow accounts

Have the insured put the money that would have gone to insurance into an escrow account. Letting them drop their conventional insurance.

Give them Gap insurance that covers there house between the amount in their excrow which grows every year and the actual cost to rebuild their home from ground up.

 

Every year their Gap insurance would go down based on the amount they have accumulated in their escrow account. Eventually if the escrow account is equal or greater than the cost to rebuild their home they can drop the gap insurance and stop putting money into the account. Interest earned on the escrow account is deposited into their personal savings account or added back into the escrow account. If the account grows larger than the amount it takes to repair the house then the person gets to withdraw the extra money and put it into their savings account.

 

If the person sells their home they get to keep their escrow money transferring it to their personal account and may transfer the escrow account to apply to their next home. 

 

Why is this reasonable?

 

My parents have to pay the insurance company $6000 a year. Their deductable is also about $6000. When the hurricanes came through the insurance company said they didn’t meet their deductable even though their entire patio roof stripped off and a portion of the main house roof was destroyed. They aren’t able to repair their house. But they did give the insurance company their yearly $6000 which could have been used to repair the house which the insurance company elected to not repair. And yes, I do think the cost of repairing my parent’s home is greater than the $6000 deductable. I believe that the insurance companies are low balling people across the board paying only 60% of the actual cost of repairs and in my parents case just telling them they aren’t meeting their deductable.

 

Their house is completely paid off but they are retired and elderly. They can’t afford to pay for the repairs but that $6000 insurance premium could have been used to pay for the repairs. If the insurance company were to actually pay out my parents would have to pay $6000 for the premium and $6000 for the deductable. So $12,000 would come out of their pockets before seeing any money for repairs. This makes the insurance completely useless and even destructive as it prevents their home from being repaired.

 

Here is how this Gap insurance idea would work for my parents.

 

They put $6000 into the escrow account each year.  If they need to repair their home they can tap the escrow account to replace their roof and do maintenance like add hurricane shutters.  They get full use of the $6000 they would have sent to the insurance company. The gap insurance covers them for the amount of money between the cost of their home should it be destroyed or the difference between the total amount of repairs and the amount in the escrow account.

 

The $6000 earns interest which can be added back into the escrow or deposited into their personal savings account. 

 

If they die or sell their home the money goes into their savings account or to the heirs.

From:	CodyCat86@aol.com
Sent:	Tuesday, July 25, 2006 7:24 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	insurance

Dear Governor Bush. 
 
This is the second time I have written you in reference to the insurance issues in Florida. I wrote Chief Financial Officer (CFO) Tom Gallagher, as well, below is the response I received and my response.
 
----------------------------------------------
 
RE:   Homeowners Nonrenewal and Insurance Rates

Dear Ms. Bryant:

Chief Financial Officer (CFO) Tom Gallagher shared your e-mail with me and asked that I respond on his behalf. We certainly understand your concerns regarding the cancellation or non-renewal of your homeowner's insurance policy as well as the difficulty you are experiencing with the increase in your homeowners’ insurance premium.   

Florida law allows insurance companies to non-renew a customer’s homeowner policy, as long as they give the policyholder at least a 90-day notice, and provide a reason for the non-renewal.  Companies cannot non-renew a policy just for filing a hurricane claim.  However, they are permitted to non-renew the policy if the property no longer meets their underwriting guidelines, or if they choose to randomly select policyholders to reduce the amount of hurricane exposure the company currently possesses.  

In the aftermath of the 2004 and 2005 hurricane season, the homeowner insurance industry became one of the most challenging lines of business.  CFO Tom Gallagher is meeting these challenges by working to attract new companies to write this type of coverage.  You can view a list of all the new insurance companies that have been licensed by the Office of Insurance Regulation (OIR) via OIR's website at www.floir.com.  Once you are on the homepage, click on "New Companies" in the grey shaded area.

The devastation of the 2004 and 2005 hurricane seasons have caused a most profound affect on insurance costs and availability in our state.  The reality of the situation is the National Hurricane Center predicted we will continue to experience a large number of hurricanes over the next 10 to 20 years.  Although an insurance company cannot raise rates to recoup past losses, they can use the probability of future claims to prepare for future losses.   This must be done in order to assure the company can continue to pay benefits to its customers provided by the policy.    

Another reason for the record increases is the cost of reinsurance.  Reinsurance is insurance for insurance companies.  As a result of the past two unprecedented hurricane seasons, reinsurance has become very expensive and difficult to obtain.  For an example, in 2004 approximately .08 cent of each premium dollar was used to purchase re-insurance.  In 2006, the cost has risen to approximately .92 cent of each premium dollar for reinsurance.  

Also, part of the increase you received may have been a direct result of the assessment for Citizens Property Insurance Corporation (Citizens).  Citizens is a Risk Apportionment plan.  This means if there is a monetary deficit for any plan year, Florida law allows Citizens to assess other insurance companies doing business in the State of Florida.  The insurance companies in turn pass the assessment on to their policy holders.  Citizens experienced a deficit of $515 million as a result of claims from the 2004 Hurricane Season. 

Please check with your agent to make sure that you are being given credit for any possible discounts such as hurricane shutters, hurricane clips, and storm windows.  You may also consider increasing your deductible to help lower your premium.  We also encourage you to continue shopping by contacting other agents in your area.  The Florida Market Assistance Plan may also be able to help you locate an insurance agent who is writing property insurance in your area.  Their toll-free number is 1-800-524-9023, or you may access their website at www.fmap.org.

Use the Office’s website (https://apps.fldfs.com/WindMitigation/) to compare the wind mitigation discounts offered by companies writing homeowners insurance in Florida.  Some homeowners have been able to save on insurance premiums because their homes have hurricane shutters and other wind-resistant features.  Low-cost financing may be available to assist with mitigation improvements. 

The legislature also set aside $250 million to help Floridians strengthen their homes to withstand hurricane winds, bringing the total relief for insurance costs to nearly $1 billion.  The $250 million allocation would be used to do free home inspections for homeowners and provide matching grants up to $5,000 for home improvements. This portion of the bill will establish the Florida Comprehensive Hurricane Damage Mitigation Program within the Department of Financial Services.  You may obtain detail information regarding this program via website http://www.mysafefloridahome.com.

If you have additional questions or need assistance with a future insurance concern, please feel free to contact our toll-free Consumer HelpLine at 1-800-342-2762 in state, or 850-413-3132 out-of-state.  An Insurance Specialist will be happy to assist you.  Current information on insurance, banking, and financial issues is available through our free Consumer eViews Newsletter.  If you are interested, you may subscribe by visiting our website or calling our Consumer HelpLine.   

Sincerely, 

Mary Ann Nealy
Insurance Specialist III
(850) 413-5853

Dear Governor Bush,  

In August 2001, Trish Wimmer and I appeared before the Brevard County Board of County Commissioners to ask for a "crisis prevention program" for Brevard County after the death IN JAIL of her Son, Rob Ferris. Crisis Stabilization Units Update: As of 8 AM today, 12 June 2006, Circles of Care, Inc., had 32 people waiting for a Crisis Bed. Wuesthoff Behavioral Health had 1 waiting. http://www.floridatoday.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060710/OPINION/[REDACTED]/1004/opinion
 
July 10, 2006 
	


Your views: Today's letters to the editor

FLORIDA TODAY Readers 

More beds essential for mental-illness crises

The June newsletter of the National Alliance on Mental Illness-Space Coast reported that on June 14, 32 people were waiting for a crisis bed at either Circles of Care, Melbourne, or Wuesthoff Hospital, Rockledge.

They are the only two places in Brevard County with beds for those people with mental illnesses who need immediate care and have no place else to go.

Their average wait in a Brevard emergency room is 28 to 30 hours but can be much longer. Those waiting must have "sitters" with them, 24 hours a day, every day.

When those in need finally get a bed, they are discharged when they are "no longer a threat," instead of being kept there safe until stabilized.

Many in crisis are treated via hospital emergency rooms, or worse, held in jails. The dollar cost must be staggering.

The emotional toll is unimaginable.

Circles of Care has committed to build a 16-bed short-term residential treatment facility in Brevard County, at its own expense, when funds for staffing are received from the state.

To make it happen, Brevard County's legislative delegation, county commissioners and hospital administrators need to communicate Brevard's immediate and pressing need to the officials of District 7, which includes Brevard County.

Mary Previti

Viera

**************************************



http://www.floridatoday.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060719/OPINION/[REDACTED]/1004/opinion
 
July 19, 2006 
	


Your views: Letters to the editor

FLORIDA TODAY Readers 

Mentally ill need more long-term local care

Mary Previti's July 10 letter to the editor correctly portrayed the mushrooming problem of lack of available treatment for people in mental health crises in Brevard County.

For example, there were 25 people waiting in area hospitals for a crisis bed on July 10, and 30 on July 11.

Some crisis center clients do not recognize their illness and demand immediate discharge. Others realize how ill they are and want treatment but are discharged because they are compliant -- eating, taking the prescribed medications, going to therapy.

Because Brevard has no long-term care facility, they're released because people deemed dangerous to themselves or others need the beds.

The pain these clients experience is horrific: paranoia, auditory and/or visual hallucinations, delusions, fear and confusion.

Many are unable to care for themselves, stop taking their prescribed medications, suffer hopelessness, abuse substances, and end up homeless, in jail, or dead.

It is so wrong to allow people to suffer needlessly. As first vice president of the National Association for the Mentally Ill -- Space Coast, I ask, what is the price of a life?

Do we pay now or do we pay later?

Freda Schildroth
Merritt Island

BREVARD MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES & JAIL STATUS REPORTS - 12 June 2006 

By 1st VP Freda Schildroth 

Crisis Stabilization Units Update: As of 8 AM today, 12 June 2006, Circles of Care, Inc., had 32 people waiting for a Crisis Bed. Wuesthoff Behavioral Health had 1 waiting. Circles’ bed capacity is 52 and there were 56 people there at 8AM. Of the 56 people in Circles‘ Crisis Units today, 18 of them are awaiting transfer to long-term care. Wuesthoff has 0 people waiting for transfer to Northeast Florida State Hospital (NEFSH). The Past Month “Worst Case Scenario” (greatest number of people waiting to be admitted to a Crisis Bed) was 32 for Circles and 6 for Wuesthoff. The average wait in Brevard Emergency Rooms is 28-30 hours. Although I do not get formal reports of individual “wait times,” I was told by a hospital “sitter” that one man waited for 6 days for a Crisis bed and 2 women waited for 3 days! We need HELP in Brevard County. 

Brevard County Mental Health Court Update (The Honorable Judge Cathleen Clarke presiding): As of 31 May 2006, there are 10 people who were diverted from Jail and under the supervision of the Mental Health Court. There were 21 cases reviewed by staff for Mental Health Court referral. Thirteen (13) Clients did not fit the Administrative Order criteria due to charges. No Client refused the services offered by the Court. No Client was accepted into the Mental Health Court during the month of May. No Client was awaiting State Attorney approval for acceptance. No Client was discharged from the Court during the month of May. (Thanks to Lisa Krupa, Mental Health Court Coordinator, Circles of Care, Inc., for providing the Mental Health Court statistics.) 

Stats from Mental Health Services of Jail: During May 2006, there were a total of 1049 Mental Health Contacts by Mental Health Specialists. There were 394 Initial Assessments from Referrals at Booking. There were 334 Mental Health Follow-up Visits and 96 Consultations and Case Staffings. There were 120 Mental Health In-house Moves during May 2006. One hundred ninety-one (191) Contacts for People on Special Watch Status and 1 Case Management Contact were completed. There were a total of 129 Referrals to the Jail Psychiatrist including 116 Psychiatric Evaluation Referrals and 13 Emergency Medication Rechecks. Physician Contacts totaled 149. There were 37 Staffing Consults. There was 0 Court-ordered Mental Health Evaluations, 1 Baker Act Evaluation and Transfer from Brevard County Detention Center, 2 Case Management Placements , and no report for Inmates released with Aftercare Plans. During the month of August 2005, the Director of Mental Health Services began a Psycho-educational Group to help Inmates learn techniques for stress management and coping skills. During the month of September 2005, 66 Inmates participated in this program, 69 Inmates participated during the month of October, and 88 Inmates participated during the month of November. During the month of December 2005, 157 Inmates participated! There were no Psycho-educational Groups during the months of January, February, March, April, or May 2006. Plans are underway to begin a new group soon. Mental Health services were all completed by the Mental Health Services staff. The Circles of Care on-site staff member completed 94 Case Management Contacts and no report for Felony Diversion/Community Placements. There were 24 Inmate referrals to Mental Health Court. (Thanks to Tracy Higginbotham, Mental Health Secretary, Brevard County Detention Center (BCDC) for the Mental Health Services Stats.) 

Stats from Jail: The High Population for 31 May 2006 was 1645. The MONTH AVERAGE number of Inmates in the Jail for the month of May 2006 was 1617, the HIGH AVERAGE was 1632 and the LOW AVERAGE was 1601. These numbers compare to the May 2005 average high of 1440, average low of 1408; the December 2004 average high of 1262, average low of 1236; and the total Inmate population count on 29 February 2004 of 1459. (Thanks to Eryn Kelsey-Adkins, Administrative Assistant to the Commander of BCDC, for providing the BCDC Monthly Population Worksheet and End of Month Population Averages.) 

Other interesting Jail stats from the Jail Population Worksheet are: Of the 1641 total Inmates in the Jail on 31 May 2006, 1433 (87.3%) were male and 208 (12.7%) were female. There were a total of 1264 Inmates (77% of the Jail population) awaiting trial (1123 male, 141 female) of which 1001 were for felonies (897 male; 104 female) and 263 were for misdemeanors (226 male; 37 female). Only 19 Inmates (17 male; 2 female) were awaiting sentencing. Four percent (4%) of the Jail Population on 31 May 2006 - 73 Inmates (67 male; 6 female) - were awaiting transfer to Department of Corrections, five percent (5%) - 74 Inmates (65 male; 9 female) - were being held for other jurisdictions, and 0.7% - 11 Inmates (8 male; 3 female) - were awaiting transfer to a state hospital. A total of 200 Inmates (13% of the Jail population) are sentenced to BCDC (153 male; 47 female) on 31 May 2006. Note: 115 Inmates were sentenced to BCDC on 31 Jan 2006, 151 on 28 Feb 2006, 171 on 31 Mar 2006, and 202 Inmates were sentenced to BCDC on 30 Apr 2006. Of the 200 Inmates sentenced to BCDC on 31 May 2006, 141 were there for Felony convictions (105 male; 36 female) and 59 are there for Misdemeanor convictions (48 male; 11 female). Of the 1641 total Inmate population, 154 Inmates are in Jail for Violation of Probation Only and 359 Inmates are there for Violation of Probation w/Charges. From:	Allman, Bill (DSHS/ADSA) <AllmaWA@dshs.wa.gov>
Sent:	Tuesday, July 25, 2006 2:38 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Veteran Medicaid Program
Attachments:	2006AP story.doc; PARIS Thanks.doc; finalEXECUTIVE SUMMARY DRAFT.doc; Olympian 11-7-05.doc; NGA BestPrac.doc; Gov Advisoryltr[REDACTED].pdf; Vets briefingflyerFINALUpdate0413052.doc; Columbian.doc

Good afternoon Governor. My name is Bill Allman. I am the Program Manager of a
Veteran's Program in Washington State that is providing a valuable service
to Medicaid veterans and their families. In addition to saving State
Medicaid dollars, it places Medicaid veterans and their families with the
veteran related benefits for which they are entitled. Our program was
selected as a "Best Practice" by the NGA (National Governor's Association)
as well as earning the State of Washington's 2004 Governor's Award for
Customer Service.

I feel that by garnering visibility, through our continuous outreach efforts, perhaps many

more veterans and their family members will become familiarized with our efforts and

utilize us as a resource. I'm attaching some information to provide you with an overview of
our program. 

One important benefit our program provides is often overlooked by clients
and/or their representatives. As you may be aware, families/estates of
veterans, as well as all Medicaid recipients receiving long term care
services, are responsible to repay the state for all of the Medicaid
services associated with LTC. This is usually facilitated through the
state's Estate Recovery process. While our program saves Medicaid dollars
and places Medicaid veterans with the benefits they are eligible for, we are
also reducing the debt that families and estates of Medicaid veterans would
otherwise have to repay. In many cases, the veteran clients and their
families are not aware that they are eligible for VA related benefits.
Additionally, there are even more that overlook the requirement to repay the
state for LTC related Medicaid services. 


In addition to the veterans, our program targets the spouses and dependents
that are also eligible for benefits. In the past year (FY 2005), our program
saved $4.3 million dollars. With access to the VA and Department of Defense
data for all of our Medicaid clients through our membership with PARIS
(Public Assistance Reporting Information System), we have the ability to
continuously identify the veterans, spouses and dependents that are eligible
for VA related medical benefits. We recently found that many of the clients
we have targeted were not only eligible for medical benefits, they were also
eligible to receive increased monthly cash benefits. The VA authorizes
increased Aid and Attendance benefits as well as Improved Pensions for those
that require a third party to care for them (in many cases that would be the
nursing or assisted living facilities). 

By providing visibility to this program, you will assist our outreach
efforts that we're confident will save skyrocketing Medicaid dollars, as
well as the opportunity to facilitate access to VA related benefits for the
many veterans, spouses and dependents who are entitled to them.  

 

There are many states that are replicating our efforts and I'm sure that there would

be many more if there were more awareness and outreach. In the meantime, our

efforts are concentrated on our 600,000+ Washington State veterans and their dependents. 

 

Feel free to call or e-mail any questions or comments that you may have.

Here is our web page: http://www.aasa.dshs.wa.gov/topics/PARIS/

Thank you for your time.

Regards,

Bill Allman, Program Manager

Veteran's/PARIS Project

DSHS Aging and Disability Services Administration

Vancouver - 360-397-9508

Olympia    -  360-586-1075

FAX       -    360-992-7949

allmawa@dshs.wa.gov

>gravey (auto premiums) and said no thanks to helping solve the dwelling 
>insurance crisis. This way if you are going to do business in Florida you

>gets the state out of the insurance business which never was there primary 
>function. A second thought would be for the insurance pool to handle wind

>biggest fear is wind loss problems. You could have the insurance companies 
>run the wind pool under the same guidelines I previously outlined. Again 
>keeping the state out of having to run the day to day operations of a major

>coverage. This is a brief overview of what I feel could be some workable 
>solutions to our dwelling insurance delema. If you are interested I would

insurances, Life, Health etc....

Line of credit for $100k - yearly payment - $18,000

Homeowners Insurance - yearly payment - $6,000
Motor Insurance 1 average car - yearly payment - $750
Health Insurance - $7,000

The above totals - $40,250 per year.

Subject:	[*] Increase the quality of child care in our state



Governor Jeb Bush
Office of the Governor
PL 05 The Capitol, 400 South Monroe Stre
Tallahassee, FL 32399

Dear Governor Bush,

I am writing to you to urge you to support improvements to our
state licensing regulations for child care providers. I am
concerned that our state does not do enough to ensure that
children in child care are safe and learning.

Across the nation, nearly 12 million children under age 5 are
cared for each week in some type of child care setting. Many
parents don't have a choice; they must work to support their
family, so child care is a necessity. Research shows early
childhood experiences influence later school success, so it is
very important that care is of high quality.

As you may know, the National Association of Child Care Resource
and Referral Agencies recently undertook a national poll of
parents with young children specifically focused on child care.
The results of this poll found that the majority of parents want
their children to be safe and learning while in child care.
Parents logically assume that child care programs are regulated
to ensure child safety and educational value, but in reality
this is not always the case. Licensing regulations vary widely
by type of facility and by state. We need to strengthen our
licensing regulations to ensure that all children are receiving
adequate care. 

By requiring all caregivers to have training in child
development and conducting regular unannounced inspections, we
can ensure that children are having educational experiences in
safe environments. I urge you to support improvements to our
state licensing regulations for child care facilities to enhance
the quality of child care in our state. Please keep me informed
about your work on this issue.



Sincerely,

ashley cornier
7925 merrill rd apt 2503
jackosnville, Florida 32277

From: Markiewicz, Barbara 
Sent: Wednesday, June 14, 2006 1:13 PM
To: 'jeb.bush@myflorida.com'; 'Collins, Lucretia'
Cc: Helter, Julie
Subject: Governor's Office of Child Abuse Prevention

 

I am writing regarding the establishment of the Governor’s Office of Child Abuse Prevention.  The passage of HB 7173 elevates the significance of child abuse prevention to a new level.  Potentially, this new office can have a big effect on child well-being in our state.

 

Currently there is a great deal of momentum, both on a statewide and a local level, surrounding implementation of child abuse prevention efforts.  To maintain that momentum, it is important that individuals involved in these efforts perceive that their continued efforts are important.  For instance, the Florida Interprogram Task Force, the authors of Florida’s State Plan for the Prevention of Child Abuse, Abandonment, and Neglect: July 2005 through June 2010, has unanimously decided that they will continue their implementation efforts until they have the opportunity to turn maltreatment prevention coordination over to the new Office.  The groundswell behind plan implementation was very evident at the recent “Together We Have What It Takes” conference in Orlando.  A presentation about Florida’s planning and implementation efforts was attended by a standing-room-only crowd of enthusiastic supporters.  In addition, the Task Force was selected, through a competitive process, to participate in the PREVENT Institute at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (sponsored by the Centers for Disease Control).

 

Throughout the two years of the Task Force’s existence the Chiles Center of the University of South Florida has facilitated its planning and implementation efforts.  Facilitation includes planning, facilitating and documenting meetings; drafting reports; planning and delivering training; and providing technical assistance.  We recognize that, although the specific details of the prevention plan that emerges from the new Office may differ somewhat from the current prevention plan, the ultimate desired outcomes will remain the same: reducing initial incidences of child maltreatment through a variety of primary prevention efforts and reducing the likelihood of re-abuse.

 

I am writing to both of you to make a dual proposal.

*	First, to continue the current momentum and to ease the transition for the new Office, I am requesting that, until the Office of Child Abuse Prevention is established, some of the budget dollars allocated to the Office be used to support the continued activities of the Florida Interprogram Task Force.
*	Second, I am committed to promoting well-being for Florida’s children and have experience in they type of coordination that will be required to make the Governor’s Office of Child Abuse Prevention a success.  It would be an honor for you to consider me for the position of Director of this new office (see attached resume).  

 

In case you are not familiar with the prevention plan, I have attached a PDF version of the full plan and the Executive Summary.  The 2006 progress report will be available before the end of this month.

 

I would be happy to speak to either of you about this proposal at your earliest convenience.  I will be unavailable during the first half of July but, during the time I am away, you can contact Julie Helter at 850-488-4768 to set up an appointment.

 

Thank you for considering this proposal.

 

Bobbi Markiewicz, Ph. D.

RE: Ludicrous Taxes For Americans, But Especially Floridians
Dear Mr. Furst,
I know that you have been getting a lot of complaints about the increase
in taxes for the 2005 year.
However, our particular case really illustrates the disregard for
citizens of this state. Our tax increase was $1,720.11 from $3619.95 for
the year 2004 to $5340.06 for 2005. The amazing thing is that there was
no structrure on this property for that tax period. We didn't take
occupancy of our new house until July 18, 2005. Another point is that
this is a single story dwelling with a floor plan of 673 square feet. Our
neighbor to the East has a two story house with 1,444 square feet, more
than double that of ours. Their tax was $3597.02 for 2005. I know that
they have homestead exemption, plus other exemptions totaling $40,000,
but they had a two story liveable house as opposed to our vacant lot. The
cost of a Caddilac Elderado is certainly more than a Volkswagon Bug.
Therefore, can you explain the high taxes on our property to me? 
We were working in Miami when we bought this propery in 1976. It was like
a get-a-way from the big city and something to work toward for
retirement. We moved to North Florida, but I became disabled and needed
to be in a warmer climate for the winter, for the same reason many other
Americans that come down from the North. Our children and grandchildren
still live in the area and we use this place to stay and see them.
Most of the folks here were average working people. We both had an income
and could afford the credit union payments to buy the land, a small
trailer and keep up with the condo fees. The taxes increased as expected,
but we had a chance to improve our skills and also received raises in our
wages enabling us to be able to afford to pay the increase in taxes. I'm
a retired Florida teacher, so you know I'm not some big entrepreneur. Our
tax bill for St. Lucie County had gone up almost 48% this past year. Our
cost of living (COLA) increase from our retirement sources has gone up
about 3%, not nearly enough to pay the tax with ease. This last tax
increase of 2005 has financially strapped many folks living in this
community. I have heard of several widows that can not afford to pay the
increase in taxes and are unable to sell because the tax is so high.
What is to happen to them?
As the tax appraiser for St. Lucie County, you should be able to do
something to help people. I hope this letter doesn't fall on deaf ears
and that I receive a reply from you. Thank you very much,
Best regards,

From:	Pamela Johnson <streefkerk_p@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Friday, July 21, 2006 8:42 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush; cfo@dfs.state.fl.us; Mike@SenatorMike.com
Cc:	Gayla Schaefer
Subject:	Citizens Monopoly causes Homeowners to move out of state

July 21, 2006
 
Dear Mr. Jeb Bush;
 
I would like to inform you about a problem I’m faced with that probably many homeowners in Florida will be faced with in the very near future.
 
A couple of days ago I received notice from our Condo Association that our development’s insurance through Citizens was being increased from $84,000 per year (for the past 3 years) to $320,000 for 2006/2007.  According to our Board of Directors, they only gave them 3 days notice.  As the association doesn’t have that kind of money laying around, each of the 100 homeowners within our development has to pay an assessment.  We have to pay the first special assessment of $650 per unit (in addition to our regular $300 HOA) by August 10th, 2006 (total of $950 for August).  Then the second assessment of $1200 will be spread out as $300 per unit for each month the remainder of the year making our HOA $600 per month.  THEN our HOA will remain at $500 for all of 2007.   And just to remind you that these increases are with 14 days notice!
 
Please allow me to explain my situation further.  We have lived in our development since it was built 4 years ago.  I am a stay-at-home mom with 3 years old twins.  The reason I stay-at-home with them is because daycare for twins is $300 per week, which would be the same as my take home pay.  I do work in the evenings for $7 per hour to earn some extra income.  But it’s hard going to bed at 3 am and being up with the kids at 6:30 am and then being a perky mom.
 
We bought our home for $190,000 4 years ago.  It is now valued at around $350,000 BUT the likelihood of actually being able to sell it in a market where there are about 800+ condos for sale in a 5 mile stretch are very slim.  NOW with the assessments and $500 future HOA fees it will probably be impossible to sell my house – even if I sold it for $190K!  We have talked about moving somewhere else nearby.  However, we can’t afford to.  If we were to buy a house for about $250,000 here locally, we would be lucky if we could find something that’s not in a very dangerous neighborhood.  The house would be at least 50 years old if not older and be smaller than what we live in now (which is only 1600 sq ft).  On top of that, although hopefully the mortgage payment would be a lot smaller than what we have now, because of the equity that hopefully we would get out of our existing home (in an ideal world), we would end up with the same house payment because of the increases in Home Owners Insurance and the ridiculously high taxes when buying a new house.  Our millage rate here locally is 2 mil.  
 
As I see it, the already shaky housing market is going to get even worse when people start listing their houses to try and bail out of Florida due to increases in insurance, HOA dues and taxes.  When people can’t sell their houses, and can’t make their payments, they’re going to end up foreclosing on their homes.  Is that what we want to have happen?
 
My husband and I have worked all our lives, to get to the point where we could have a home and raise a family.  Now that we’re finally there, due to circumstances beyond our control, we don’t know what we can do to keep a roof above our children’s heads!
 
The condo association apparently can’t even shop around to try and get different insurance coverage because Citizens is the ONLY company in Florida will write policies for high rise on barrier islands.  We don’t live in a high-rise condo, ours is a townhouse, however we all belong to the same association.  What happened to fair choice and eliminating monopolies?  How can this be allowed to happen?  
 
In addition to all of the above, my husband has been working on a CO2 Global Change project for the Smithsonian Institute (out of Washington) here at the Space Center for the past 11 years!  Now apparently the project is coming to an end in March 2007 because of lack of funding by the government because of all the money being used for the War.  He has a Bachelors in Biomechanical Engineering and a Masters in Project Engineering Management and can’t find a job anywhere locally because the job market/economy is so bad and nobody is hiring.  There aren’t any jobs out there unless you want to work for $6 per hour because those jobs are plentiful.  The reason why those jobs can’t get filled is because the people, who work for $6 per hour can’t afford to live here, rent or own a house.  And as most of them rent at that pay rate, they can leave the area whenever they feel like it.  Us as homeowners are stuck here!  I also hold a Bachelors in Business Studies and can’t even get hired to work for $6 per hour because I’m overqualified!  Employers know that you’re only working the job because you’re desperate and that you’re out of there as soon as something better comes along so they won’t even hire you.
 
What are we supposed to do?  Is there anything you can do about this crazy situation?  Thanks for listening.
 
Sincerely,
Pamela Johnson
784 Bayside Drive
Cape Canaveral, FL 32920

   It has come to my attention Insurance companies who wish to conduct business in our great State of Florida - and by business I mean specifically "Collect Money from the residents (ie., constituents)", - with little to no risk on their part.  Viewing the situation from the consumer side of the issue:  I / We (hopefully) all citizens of Florida are obliged to and in some cases are bound by law, to purchase and maintain Insurance policies for a myriad of "What If's" that may and in 'most cases' never do happen.  Car; Life; Medical; Flood; Hurricane; Wind.... all "just in case something should happen".... Its nothing more than "Risk".  If I / We do not purchase Insurance Policies against to cover the "What If's", then we are choosing to take the risk of something happening which could potentially put us in the streets - homeless.  So, for the most part, we, as Floridians, like those who live all over this great Nation and in fact the World at large, make a decision on each of the potential "Risk" and choose to either role the dice and not "Insure" for our own peace of mind, or we pay a company, several actually, who for 99.9 % of the time, simply turn that money into their own capital gains in order to grow exponentially.  No one who has just half a brain is blind to the lavish extent with which Insurance companies treat themselves.  From huge beautiful office buildings that could easily outstate those found in any capital city in our land, over laden with management offices that rival the opulence and grandeur of Kings, spacious, comfortable, accommodations, Limousines, Mercedes Benz, Porches, Jaguars, Cadillac's and BMW's, all new and coming from some of the finest homes in America, covering the parking lots of these grand buildings, which are far beyond what the other 90% of Americans would call "Work" or our place of work and that house people who are so used to receiving tons of money for not actually doing "anything" to "earn" it, short of hiring heartless peons to pour over their policies looking for loopholes to get out of paying a teeny tiny bit of that un-earned money they are so used to sitting back and collecting "WITHOUT RISK", back to the people who actually do find themselves in a position where they need some of that money they have been pouring into these Insurance companies - THEIR ENTIRE LIVES!!!
   Mr. Bush, I implore you.  You seem, to me, to be a man who has a heart and a brain, despite coming from a wealthy background where neither are really necessary.  Clearly you decided, somewhere along your life's road, that there are people in this world that are not born with a silver spoon in their mouth and that it is those people who support the class structure but what sets you apart from those who would be in the same class as yourself, is your ability to "see" people who are clearly beneath your class, not just to recognize who is and who isn't but to see them and far more importantly, you can see through their eyes as they look up into the higher class structures, you have the ability to see through there eyes because you have chosen not to be hemmed in by those who are you equal in class.  Your not blind and you not ignorant and you choose not to be either.  Smug, patronizing, ignorant, self important people who have everything without having to do anything to get it, never earned it and will do 'anything' to keep anyone under them.... under them.  That's not who you.  I know it takes a vastly more elegant person to rise above those who are simply born above, those who take it and everyone for granted.  I understand the difference in class structure in our society and that money is not what determines which class a person is firmly a part of, the "pyramid principle" as sociologist call it and I can see you are one who has decided to be your own man.  Again I implore you... do not allow the Insurance companies, the people who run them, own them, get fat off of the insecurities of the general public, to come into Florida and squeeze us for more money. From:	Dan Wehking <danwehking@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Thursday, July 20, 2006 10:05 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Property Tax Committee

Dear Gov. Bush,

	I was pleased to learn that you are appointing a
committee to review our state’s property taxes.  It is
important that we repeal the “Save Our Homes”
amendment, and I hope that the review of the laws by
your office and the legislature will be an important
first step towards achieving that goal.

	I have just graduated law school and will begin my
service as an Assistant State Attorney next month.  In
the past three years, the median price for a single
family home in our state has gone up 70%.  It has gone
up 105% in the past five years.  A single family home
in my hometown of Miami has gone up 149% in the same
time.  The combination of my $127,000 of student
loans, the relatively low pay provided to ASAs, and
the increase in housing prices has driven me to work
in Polk County.  From what I can tell, it is a fine
place to live with a great deal to be proud of, but I
have a limited knowledge of the area because I have
never lived less than 2 hours away from it.  I am
working there because they have some of the lowest
housing costs in the state and working in one of the
counties with the least expensive housing is the only
way I might be able to afford a home.  Even using the
resources provided by the state to first time home
buyers, it is not certain I will be able to afford a
modest home.  It is bad enough that after seven years
in universities I may not be able to work for the
state and afford a home in one of our least expensive
communities.  It is even worse that I will be punished
by paying a disproportionate amount of taxes because I
chose to get an education rather than going straight
into the job force after high school.  That is what
the “Save Our Homes” amendment means to me.  It is a
punishment for going to school.  It is a punishment
for being young.  It is a punishment for not coming
from a family rich enough to buy me a house when I got
out of high school.  

	For my father, “Save Our Homes” is something
different.  For my father it is a trap.  My father is
living in the same four bedroom house that he bought
in 1986 when he had just had his fourth child.  At the
time, I was the oldest and would be over a decade
until I graduated high school.  Now he is a year and a
half away from his youngest graduating from college. 
He no longer needs the big house.  After being laid
off from FPL several years ago, he does need the
money.  In another state, he could sell his big house,
move to a smaller house and invest the proceeds so
that he could afford to live on half the money he used
to make for FPL that he now earns as a bailiff.  In
our state, it makes less sense for him to do this.  In
our state he will be punished for having finished
raising his family.  If he moves now he will have to
pay more taxes on a smaller house worth less money
than the one he currently lives in.  

	You were instrumental in repealing the bullet train
amendment several years ago.  That was a bad law that
came from good intentions.  “Save Our Homes” is
another bad law that comes from good intentions. 
Repealing the amendment would not lead to an increase
in taxes.  Repealing the amendment would lead to a
fair distribution of taxes.  I believe the citizens of
our state are smart enough to recognize that our
governments have certain budgets that needs to be met.
 They will recognize that if everyone pays their fair
share, then everyone’s millage rate will go down. 
They will recognize that some individuals will have to
pay more and some will pay less in the immediate
future, but this is the fair course of action that
will benefit almost everyone as years go by.

	Thank you for the attention you are giving this
matter.  Please inform me if there is anyway I can be
of service regarding this issue.


Sincerely,

Daniel Wehking

Governor Bush:
   I read where the Tampa Bay Regional Planning Council has said that you must call a special session of the Legislature to try and breathe life back into Florida's collapsed home resale market. Yes, the market has already collapsed. It collapsed because of your stubborn failure to call such a session right after the scheduled session failed to pass the only viable answer to the property insurance mess.
   The State of Florida needs a State Catastrophe Property Insurance Program with a state wide single per $1,000 of insured value premium rate that will cover all forms of natural or terrorist catastrophes. Yes, the same per $1,000 of insured value premium rate throughout Florida is necessary to solve the problem. Area, or regional rates are a part of the present problem, and they fail to recognize that Florida is a long narrow state that even "inland areas" are not safe from hurricanes, or tsunamis, earthquakes, or terrorist acts.
   Some facts: Over 25% of Floridian's have dropped their homeowner's insurance protection; Foreclosures have doubled, and the exhorbitant premium rates are the fault; Home for sale listings are up about 400% while home resales have slowed to a trickle as for sale signs litter our lawns.
   If you fail to call the special session, you will be labeled "The One Man Wrecking Team", the Governor who couldn't handle the single major crisis he faced during his period in office, as Florida's economy continues on it's way into the tank with the real estate market.
