Sent:	Wednesday, July 19, 2006 10:06 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Property Taxes

Importance:	High

Good evening, Governor.  I am concerned about the assessed values of property, as I own vacant land that I purchased in 1997/1998.  My plans are to build, but last year, my assessed value doubled, resulting in its taxes doubling.  This year, it is scheduled to go up another $50,000 – which will mean another $1000 (approx.) for me to pay.  I am single with only my income.  How can I budget from year to year?  My Aunt’s property that was valued at $15,000 five years ago will be valued at over $450,000 this year.  This year’s increase alone is approximately $120,000.  Her land has been in the family for generations – given to her by her mother as her father passed away before the transfer took place.

 

I hear about business property taxes, second homes, and “part-timers”, but what about those of us with dreams and goals?  What about those of us whose families settled here?  There is no consideration for family heritage.  For those of us who are real Florida Natives, land is not looked upon as an investment.  For us, it is a family treasure that has been handed down.  Something that is priceless.  Our descendants worked hard and toiled laboriously to obtain what we have been given.  It is a shame that we may have to consider “selling” because we can’t afford to pay the taxes – not because we’re trying to make it rich.  When you think about the fact that the property is paid for and that taxes are pushing us out, something is very wrong.  I guess that may explain why you very rarely run into a “true” native.....we are a dying breed.

 

Please express this concern for vacant residential parcels.  We should not be discriminated against.  In Charlotte County, I have found properties of similar qualities in which one parcel is experiencing constant increase in assessed value and the other a decrease – year after year.  The same parcel that decreases, the owner’s residential parcels also decrease.  All property should be assessed the same, and the market is going down.

 

Thank you for your time and consideration.

 

Sincerely,

Melissa C. Knight

Subject:	Gov. Bush, Please Sign SB 772

Dear Governor John Bush:

I am writing today to respectfully request your support for SB 772.
The portion of this large education bill that most concerns me relates to childhood obesity. I know that you care about this issue, too, as evidenced by the task force you created and the resulting Obesity Summits.
As your task force recommended, this bill will empower parents to help improve their children’s health.
In addition, SB 772 will help improve academic achievement in Florida. Healthy students are better students – with increased test scores, concentration and attendance, and reduced discipline problems.


SB 772 will encourage parents, communities, students and schools to work together in the fight against childhood obesity.  
In the U.S., the percentage of overweight children has more than doubled, and the percentage of overweight adolescents has tripled in the past 30 years. In Florida, the trend is similar.
Almost 60% of these overweight children have at least one heart or stroke risk factor, and 25% had two or more risk factors.
The implications of childhood obesity are far-reaching. If childhood obesity continues to increase, the current generation of children and the ones behind them will face devastating health and economic consequences.
Many studies and reports support the connection between academic achievement and student health. We cannot expect our children to excel if they are not physically fit.


Gov. Bush, I know you care about our children. Please demonstrate your support by signing SB 772 into law and helping us all work together on the solutions to childhood obesity.
Thank you in advance for your support.

Sincerely,

Recently, I received a letter from Nationwide Insurance Company outlining how the insurance industry is facing challenging times in the Florida marketplace, and as a company, Nationwide has had to make some tough choices.  I happen to be one of their "tough" business choices and had my homeowners policy canceled.  Please note, I have been a loyal customer for twelve years, have paid my premiums on time, never filed a claim and hold automobile coverage, an umbrella policy, boat insurance and a maritime policy with Nationwide.  
 
Nationwide further goes on to state in their letter that my agent may be able to assist me in finding insurance protection with another insurance company.  Guess what.  My current insurance agent can quote me a rate from Lexington Insurance Company.  I was paying $7,000 per year.  The quote from Lexington is for $17,293.16.  I looked at Citizen's Insurance and received a quote over $20,000.  Other insurance companies I contacted were not writing policies at this time.
 
Do you, as governor of Florida, see anything wrong with this?  I understand the principle that a company is in business to make money; however, when a company can arbitrarily drop a customer for no wrong doing and by that action places an undue hardship on that customer, where is the justice?
 
I am well aware insurance is a hot issue in Florida at this time.  I am well aware that insurance companies are worth big dollars.  I just think it is time to place sanctions on insurance companies that conduct business in our state, make a tidy profit and decide to drop customers because "the insurance industry is facing challenging times in the Florida marketplace."  GIVE ME A BREAK!  That is the cost of doing business.  What about the hardship Nationwide has thrust on the customers it has canceled.  Nationwide talks about its overall catastrophic loss.  Well, guess what, it is catastrophic for homeowners to be placed in a position where they must incur expenses they cannot afford or did not plan for.  For the homeowner who has been canceled, there is no choice but to pay.  So glad it's all right for insurance companies to control a homeowner's purse strings in the state of Florida.
 
Governor Bush, I understand you leave office in January of 2007.  I understand running a state is no easy task.  I just think our state government needs to put more thought and action in to protecting its citizens from the insurance companies who are currently in our state and deciding to take flight leaving citizens in a compromised position.

Dear Lt. Governor Toni Jennings:	
 	
I am writing to express my appreciation for your voting against reductions to the Medicaid program. As a member of the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI), I am grateful for your efforts to oppose cuts to this critical health care safety net for the most vulnerable. As you know, the budget reconciliation package contains provisions which would be disastrous for Medicaid beneficiaries living with severe mental illness. Of greatest concern are provisions in the legislation (S 1932) that will allow states to impose higher cost sharing for critical services such as prescription drugs, physician services and emergency room care. These higher cost sharing requirements are certain to result in large numbers of Medicaid recipients with mental illness not being able to access basic treatment and supportive services. The bill will also allow states to limit coverage on existing Medicaid services for many beneficiaries, placing at risk critical early intervention services for children. I urge you to continue to oppose these reductions to the Medicaid program. It is simply unfair to impose higher cost sharing and additional benefit cuts on the most vulnerable.	
 	
Sincerely,	
 	
Amberly Costello

From:	LINDA MAIELLO <badgbunny2003@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Sunday, July 16, 2006 2:25 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush

July 17, 2006
 
Dear Governor Bush,
 
I work as an emergency dispatcher for the Royal Palm Beach Police Department and am asking for your support on an issue that is of extreme importance.  
 
House Bill 9 (sponsored by Representative Robaina) and Senate Bill 936 (sponsored by Senator Bennett) will provide enhanced retirement benefits for 9-1-1 operators and emergency dispatchers. 
 
Each day, citizens throughout the State of Florida dial 9-1-1 to receive urgently needed assistance in times of crisis.  Specially trained public safety telecommunications personnel must answer each call quickly and make instant decisions on the deployment of law enforcement, fire rescue, and EMS resources.  Public Safety Telecommunicators are under constant stress as they make life and death decisions based on what limited information is available over the phone. They also work each day with the realization that an error could result in a serious injury or even death to law enforcement personnel, firefighters, paramedics, or a member of the community.
 
Senate Bill 936 and House Bill 9 will allow employees like me to receive benefits under the Special Risk category.  This change would enable a dispatcher to retire with twenty-five years of service in the Florida State Retirement System.  As I am sure you know, today in Florida an emergency dispatcher is forced to work thirty (30) years in order to retire with only 48% of their average salary.  


 
The skill level and mental acuity required to function in a busy 911 center makes it very difficult for dispatchers reach thirty years of service. Medical problems relating to constant shift work and other stressors frequently require our employees to retire early, and face significant penalties in their retirement benefits.
 
As a citizen of your district, I know that you care about public safety and the importance of the 9-1-1 system as the first line of defense in any emergency.  I hope I can count on your to lend your support to this most important bill.
 
I would be honored to answer any questions that you or your staff may have regarding the 9-1-1 system and our employees.
 
Sincerely,
 
Linda Maiello
1404 E. Lakeview Drive
Royal Palm Beach, FL 33411-8780
(561) 315-3788

From:	Ken Nichols <Ken@advantageinsgroup.com>
Sent:	Friday, July 14, 2006 4:31 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	ppatterson2@mindspring.com
Subject:	Citizens Windstorm-


Governor Bush- 

I saw the interview with you yesterday regarding the insurance situation in our state. Here's what I believe needs to happen as it relates to Citizens Property / Windstorm coverage and the entire insurance issue in an effort to stabilize the market:

In order to attract insurance companies back into the state, we need to have a tiered type coverage format: 

1. The insured needs to have higher deductibles (both residential and commercial). 

2. Companies (including Citizens) need to rate policies by different levels of exposure. South Florida policy holders need to pay more than Central and North Florida policy holders. Beachside policy holders need to pay more than inland policy holders. Types of construction as it relates to rates needs to be revised, etc. I know some of this is already being done, but these guidelines need to be revised and updated……….NOW. There needs to be substantial credits and surcharges for types of construction and location. If a person elects to build / live in a high exposure area, then they need to pay for the premium. Not everybody else!

3. Companies should take the second layer of coverage which will get them in a comfort zone by limiting their exposure. 

4. The state company, Citizens, needs to take the higher (catastrophic) layer. And, we as residents of the state need to contribute some reasonable amount of dollars each and every year to create a CAT fund that will have the ability to pay for this layer. We need to surcharge hotel nights, college and professional sporting events, and conventions, etc. to add to the CAT fund. If it's $ 100 per year per policy, and $ 2 per hotel night or sports ticket…that's the way it is.

5. Companies need to have rates approved that will give them the confidence to come back or stay in our market. 

6. Finally……..and this is IMPORTANT……..Citizens or any other company should NOT WRITE COVERAGE for any properties over a certain age unless that structure has documented updates. And, if it's over a certain age of let's say…………30 years, and it's not joisted masonry construction or better….it doesn't get written or it has another higher level of deductible.

I know this may sound simplistic, and I'm giving you the "quick input" here, but come on………………let's get this done! All the politicians say we don't need to be in the insurance business, but maybe what we need to do is change the way we are in it. Then, if we can get out down the road……great. But, for now we are in it, and changes must be made. Let's look at the alternatives instead of just keep on saying "we don't need to be in the business".

You said you wanted suggestions! 

Thank you for your time. 

Kenneth E. Nichols, AAI

From:	Frank Dame <fdame@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Friday, July 14, 2006 2:51 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	fdame@yahoo.com
Subject:	Insurance Crisis and Property Taxes

Dear Governor Bush:

 

The insurance crisis here in Florida has reached a crisis level which I’m sure you are already aware.  It is my intent in writing this email to you to express the sentiments of myself and many of the residents of our community.  I am the president of the Island Estates Civic Association, a waterfront community residing in Clearwater Beach.  In the past three years, our residents have experienced exponential increases of their insurance rates and escalating property taxes.  Obviously, most all are insured with Citizens Property Insurance Corporation as they have no alternative.  Many who live in our community are long time residents, retired and living on fixed incomes.  This situation, along with the rising property taxes, is forcing many homeowners with fixed incomes to contemplate selling their homes causing them to be confronted with other menacing challenges.

 

The insurance issue is not one easily solved because the large private insurance companies have segmented and declined high risk customers in efforts to optimize their profits.  The pure concept of insurance is sound, to spread the costs and risks of loss over many homeowners so that when catastrophes happen, there are adequate reserves, derived from those who did not experience losses, to take care of those unfortunate victims.  In the case of Florida, the losses in the past few years have been many more than anticipated by the actuarial analysts.  As a result, the insurance companies have been cancelling policies and withdrawing from high risk markets.  In keeping with the concept of insurance, the risk assessments cannot be micro-managed to squeeze every nickel of profit out of a particular market or withdraw from the market.

 

I believe the government must urgently focus on this crisis and force the insurance companies to write homeowner policies or ban them from writing other lines in Florida (those multiple line companies that offer homeowner policies in other states but not Florida).   However, it is acknowledged, there is a risk that these insurers will simply discontinue doing any business in Florida for all lines of insurance thus leaving Florida with additional challenges.  

 

If the State governing bodies are unwilling to confront and stand up to these insurance companies withdrawing their homeowners’ lines, another alternative is for the State to take over all homeowners’ policies thus spreading risks throughout all of Florida.  Currently, the way Citizens has been established, to underwrite only policies in high risk areas, is a recipe for certain failure.  It will require constant subsidies and increasing rates that ultimately will require such high premiums, eventually homeowners will be unable or unwilling to afford them and will be forced to self insure.  Self insuring is not the answer for when a catastrophe does occur, many of these people will have lost everything and turn to the government for assistance thus adding to the problem.  The Citizen program also defeats the concept of insurance to spread the risk over a wide range of risk factors so that no one element bankrupts the program.  

 

If commercial underwriters are able make decisions to abandon our markets, and the States Citizens Property Insurance program is not modified, then the insurance industry should be taken over by the Federal Government!  As an alternative of a national insurance program, I can hear the people in California, Kansas and New England objecting to pay for our hurricane damage in Florida.  But what about Floridians paying for losses caused in other areas?  Examples are the earthquakes in San Francisco and L.A., or the mudslides in Malibu, the wild fires destroying homes in the west, the tornadoes in Kansas and the Floods in New England?  Under a Federal program, we would all be in the same program, spreading risks to a wide variety of people and potential maladies to ensure the welfare of each other.  I liked your idea of a national disaster pool and believe it should be strongly promoted and supported.  Too bad you aren’t advocating it from Indiana instead of Florida, maybe then others would listen.

 

The other issue I wanted to bring to your attention was the escalating property taxes.  Of course the main driver to these increases, in most cases, is not millage but the increasing property values due to the influx of population migration to Florida.  Again, I would like to respectfully call your attention to this dilemma affecting our older population (if not our younger).  With the save our homes cap in Pinellas County, the property tax cannot increase more than 3.0% or the inflation rate, whichever is less.  However, in our community, as mentioned previously, many retirees are squeezed by the insurance rates and over time the property taxes.  Those who have lived in their home for many years and bought before the property boom have relatively low taxes but they are still increasing yearly.  If they are forced to sell and purchase another property even at perhaps half the price of what they sold their existing property, their new tax base will be at current escalated market value and they will pay even higher property taxes than they had before.

 

Two items to consider are the Homestead Exemption which was implemented many years ago at $25,000 and portability of taxable value.  The $25,000 exemption in real dollars today is worth far less than it was when it was implemented and is not relative (percentage wise) to today’s average home values.  Consideration should be given to adjusting and increasing the homestead exemption so that its “real” value today is what it was when it was implemented.  It is suggested on a going forward basis, this exemption should be adjusted each year (by the inflation or deflation rate) so that this original benefit inures to those for whom it was intended.  The other consideration should be to enable our senior citizens to carry the “taxable value” of their current property to another home (perhaps limiting this to a one time event) so they are not relegated to substandard living conditions because they cannot afford the property taxes.

 

Thank you in advance for your thoughtful attention and consideration to these matters.

 

Respectfully,

 

 Frank Dame

 

Frank L. Dame, President

Island Estates Civic Association

407 Leeward Island

Clearwater, FL 33767

B 727-692-2655

H 727-442-2237

F 727-239-7287

Email: fdame@yahoo.com

Dear Ms. Guy:

Chief Financial Officer (CFO) Tom Gallagher shared your e-mail with me and 
asked that I respond on his behalf.  We understand and appreciate the 
frustration you are experiencing.

As a Floridian and the stateâ€™s chief financial officer, he is concerned 
about the lack of affordability and availability of insurance coverage in 
Florida.  However, CFO Gallagher is not the stateâ€™s insurance commissioner 
and does not have a direct role in rate setting.

Florida law requires all admitted insurance companies to submit their rates 
to the Office of Insurance Regulation (OIR), under the direction of 
Insurance Commissioner Kevin McCarty, to justify the need for a rate change. 
  The OIR is obligated to review these rates and ensure that they are fair, 
not excessive, and non-discriminatory.  The law does not permit the Office 
of Insurance Regulation to deny a rate increase on the basis the rate 
increase will create a financial hardship for customers of the insurance 
company, even though we understand that higher rates create hardships in 
many cases.

Therefore, each rate filing receives the most careful attention the OIR can 
give to review every component of the filing and to make sure the rates 
being charged are not excessive.   Please be assured the OIRâ€™s actuaries 
closely scrutinize these filings, and if the rate is not justified, it is 
not approved.

Florida law outlines the basic considerations in premium rating for 
property/ casualty lines of insurance.  Some of the items the law requires 
OIR to consider in reviewing rate increases are a companyâ€™s anticipated 
losses, expenses, investment income, adequacy of loss reserves, and cost of 
reinsurance.  Rate increases are not permitted to be used to recoup from 
previous losses, only to prepare for current and future expenses.

We realize this does not resolve your concerns.  However, we hope this 
information helps you better understand how Florida law affects your 
insurance premiums.  Please keep in mind that this Department is 
administrative in nature.  Therefore, we are only capable of enforcing 
existing laws.  Establishing a new law or amending existing laws takes the 
action of our state legislative representatives.  CFO Gallagher and 
Commissioner McCarty can make recommendations to the House and Senate 
legislative bodies and the Governor, but it is the duty of those offices to 
create or amend Florida law.  As such, please contact your state legislators 
to express your specific concerns regarding the existing laws, and to 
propose possible new laws.  If you need assistance locating your 
legislators, please visit the Florida Legislatureâ€™s website at 
www.leg.state.fl.us.

If you have additional questions or need assistance with a future insurance 
concern, please feel free to contact our toll-free Consumer HelpLine at 
1-800-342-2762 in state, or 850-413-3132 out-of-state.  An Insurance 
Specialist will be happy to assist you.  Current information on insurance, 
banking, and financial issues is available through our free Consumer eViews 
Newsletter.  If you are interested, you may subscribe by visiting our 
website at www.fldfs.com or calling our Consumer HelpLine.

Sincerely,
Heather Davis
Insurance Specialist III

From:	Stephen Hertz <sghatty@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Thursday, July 13, 2006 5:52 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	FW: WINDSTORM INSURANCE STATE OF FLORIDA

 

 

-----Original Message-----
From: DR RONALD R LORING [mailto:drloring@the-beach.net] 
Sent: Tuesday, July 11, 2006 9:34 AM
 
Subject: WINDSTORM

 

                                                      Dr. Ronald R. Loring

                                        Board Certified Optometric Physician

                                                    542 Arthur Godfrey Rd.

                                                   Miami Beach, Fla. 33140

                                    Web Address: www.drloring.optometry.net

                                            E-Mail: drloring@the-beach.net

                                                       Tel. 305-534-3937

                                                       Fax 305-534-2020

 

   

 

                                                                                                                       7/10/06

 

Sun Sentinel

Miami Herald – Action Line

Channel 7

Miami Beach City Commission

 

It has recently come to my attention, that Citizen’s Ins., the State of Florida’s insurer of last resort, has transferred my windstorm insurance to HomeWise Ins. Co. based in Tampa, Fl. This has brought about some very unsatisfactory consequences for myself personally, but on reflection, more so for the majority of the property owners of the State of Fla. In particular, the ones most impacted will be those most vulnerable and least able to pay. My previous Citizen’s Windstorm Policy was costing me $7,200/yr with surcharges of $1,206 for a total of $8,406. I have received notice from HomeWise that 

my new premium for windstorm coverage will now be $21,747/yr. That is pushing a 300% increase in premium that they demand be PAID IN FULL UP FRONT before they will even send you a declarations page, or statement of the details of coverage much less acceptance!

 

When I contacted the Office of Ins. Regulation, CFO Tom Gallagher’s office, and the Office of the Consumer Advocate,  I was apprised of the following facts:

 

(1) The insurance industry lobby is extremely powerful in Tallahassee and has been able to push legislation that has removed much of the Ins. Commissioner’s power to regulate

them in the last couple of years.

 

(2) The insurance lobby has been able to keep and inspire a Use and File Law which allows an insurance company to elect whatever premium they wish to charge for a particular coverage such as windstorm.They can also bill their policy holders IMMEDIATELY without state approval of that increase demanding full payment up front. Should the State, at a later time, deny the increase previously charged the policy holders of the State of Fla., the only obligation of the insurer is to refund the difference in premium due the policy holder. The fly in the ointment, however, is that the insurers get to deposit millions and millions of dollars of the citizen’s money into their own accounts 

with the accrual of all interest thereof going into their coffers and not returned to the rightful owners.

 

(3) The insurer has the right to re-appraise the insured property each year and accordingly raise the policy coverage amount reflecting their unchallenged assessment. This also affects the determination of the amount of contents coverage which is automatically set at 50% of the property evaluation figure. For example, if your house is

appraised by them at $580,000 than your contents are valued at $290,000. How many of us have contents worth ½ of the value of your home?

 

(4) If you elect to increase your deductible from 2% to 5% or 10%, than your premium is NOT reduced by a comparable amount to justify the arbitrary premium reduction offered by the insurer. 

 

(5) By law, Citizen’s Ins., the State insurer of last resort must have the most expensive premium for the coverage offered in the State of Fla. Therefore, if these outrageous premiums are allowed, then Citizen’s must match or be slightly higher than any others allowed for admitted insurers within the State and must raise rates accordingly.

 

(6) If you have a mortgage on your property, you are legally and contractually bound to have all necessary insurance required by the mortgage entity. Failing to have that coverage, the mortgage entity has the right to call that mortgage in or to even foreclose 

on the property.  What is an elderly person living on social security of $15,000/$20,000

a year in the same home for 30 yrs, which has esculated in value and taxes, supposed to do? He’s already trying to decide how to spend his available moneys between his medicine or food. You may say,  he will have to downsize and sell. Of course, you are now confronted with the prospect of having to by something else with triple the real estate taxes because he lost the advantage of the 3% increase rule due on his old homestead residence. What does he do, lose his home to the mortgage company or in foreclosure? Can you imagine what this will do for for the real estate market coupled with the interest rate increases, condo glut, soaring insurance costs! Foreclosures should 

skyrocket.

 

(7) Insurers have been able to cry poverty and distress because they have been allowed to diversify their corporate structures from, for example, State Farm Ins. Co. to State Farm Ins. Co of Fla. so they can show legislators and regulators that they have sustained great losses rather than surpluses overall nationwide. They can then make their case for increases more reasonable.

 

(8) You have no right of choice or option but to accept the insurer’s inflated offer, other than to go bare if you don’t have mortgage obligations. Citizen’s Ins. will not take you back if another insurer is willing to assume the risk. There is no competitive market here to control premiums. Take it or leave it!

 

(9) Ninety percent of all hurricane losses last year were less than $25,000. When you factor in the cost of  windstorm coverage and the deductible, that’s like having no coverage at all.

 

 

What are the fixes:

 

(1) Make our legislators keenly aware of the fact that the Use and File law is grossly inequitable and unfair to the Citizens of the State of Fla. and do away with it. It would 

be fair to mandate billing only after an increase has been approved by the State. Failing that, at least all interest accrued thereof is the property of the policy holder and not the insurer and should be returned to him with his premium adjustment..

 

(2)  Create a Catastrophic State Reinsurance Fund to replace the ultra expensive offshore reinsurance funds currently causing the insurers to escalate their premiums so aggressively. This should be financed by a State surcharge spread over the entire State so that it helps lower everyone’s premiums and doesn’t fall so heavily on certain counties.

Not an easy task for less hurricane prone county legislators to swallow, yet fairer to the general population at large.  

 

(3) Make the insurers offer installment payment options for the asked premiums instead of asking the already stressed policy holders for full payment up front. The only other option for some of these people would be to take out additional loans, which they could ill afford, to satisfy their insurance and mortgage obligations.

 

(4) Tell the insurers that if they want to write any other types of coverage in the State of Fla., they must also write windstorm coverage and spread the cost of business to their other lines of insurance state wide or nationwide.

 

(5) Eliminate the Fla. corporate loophole allowing them to call themselves a separate Fla. ins. co. instead of a national ins. co. They could not then bypass certain financial proofs and justifications they would otherwise have to meet in order to attain increases.  

 

(6) Make the insurer’s premiums more accurately reflect the amount of deductible you choose when you increase it.

 

This is a problem that will affect all the citizens of the State of Fla. in one way or another now or in the immediate future. Maybe, you might want to do some further research into 

this as it is sure to be a hot button election issue with the Ins. Commissioner running for 

Governor.  

 

                                                              Respectfully,

 

 

 

                                                              Ronald R. Loring, O.D., P.A. 

RRL/eb

>RECORD NUMBER OF FLORIDIANS USING SAFETY BELTS
>
>On Thursday I announced that a record number of Floridians are using safety
>belts. The Preusser Research Group recently reported that 80.7 percent of
>drivers and their front seat passengers are using safety belts on Florida
>highways.  Overall, safety belt usage rates in Florida have climbed more
>than 20 percent since 2000. A vast majority of Floridians are using safety
>belts. Wearing a safety belt saves lives. It is the single most effective
>way to prevent injuries and reduce fatalities in motor vehicle crashes. For

From:	Gunther <gunther@ieee.org>
Sent:	Tuesday, July 11, 2006 3:19 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	 Housing and insurance crisis - it's time for action
Attachments:	elected officials contact information.xls

 
This is an issue so critical to South Florida residents that  your re-election depends on your position and the priority you give toward a reasonable and prompt resolution


July 11, 2006
From:             Gunther(Gus) Karger
To:                 Palmetto  Bay  area residents
Attachment:   elected officials contact information
email:  gunther@ieee.org
 
Subject:  Windstorm insurance and taxes
                We are in a housing crisis - what we can do about it
 
            While we rejoice in the  dramatic housing value  increase seen in the past couple of years,  we are  concerned about the  skyrocketing  insurance premiums. Some residents on fixed income  can’t afford the  windstorm premiums which can easily exceed $5,000/year  and it gets worse  when the basic fire insurance premiums have nearly  doubled over the past year with more increases coming.   
            Maybe it’s time to sell, take our huge profit and move somewhere else?  But this gives us another problem. Who will buy our house even at  $550,000, a drastic reduction from the $650,000 seen just a few months ago when the prospective buyer faces a $10,000 tax bill and a gigantic  $5,000 plus insurance cost?  This tax is a huge 300% increase over what many of us are paying,  thanks to  the 3% tax appraisal cap our wise legislature gave us some years ago.  The new buyer faces a tax appraisal based on what he pays  and that's the $500,000 plus.  There are people who can afford to pay these high expenses but they must be making salaries well exceeding $100,000/year  or have deep pockets.  But there are fewer and fewer of them. Employers have a problem attracting new employees because of these costs and especially the massive windstorm insurance.  This leads to further depressed housing values and worse still, a potential economic recession for the area as  employers,  unable to attract people to work for them pack up and move themselves thereby placing even more houses on the market.  
            This is a serious problem for all of us  and it’s time for all of us individually and collectively do take strong  and immediate action.  Palmetto Bay is a great community and fortunately, we have strong leaders in our mayor and others who already are working hard  to help  alleviate these problems.  
            What can be done?  The insurance companies help themselves by simply raising our premiums while silently praising the hurricanes all the way to their bank. We must  force our state insurance commissioner to switch allegiance from the insurance industry to us, the  citizens who  he is  supposed to serve.
             Our municipal  leaders, especially Miami –Dade Metro Commissioners  smile privately as they see tax revenues rise  while they take great credit for not raising our millage rates. It’s time for us to ask our leaders what they are doing with the extra money from the super high new taxes being collected. For example,  if we sold our house, the local governments would receive  about $10,000 more  tax revenue  from the new owner and that’s each year.  As more of us sell our houses for many reasons over time, the  tax revenues from this gradual process  can give significant new money to our local government.  Unless we reign them in,  they will just spend what they can collect while we see our property values stagnate or decline even further. 
 
What can we do about this?
            Plenty can be done and fast.  These are some of the options available  which could dramatically and quickly alleviate the housing cost crisis and secure our property values once again.
 
Insurance 
There are two options. One is for the federal government to  create  a national disaster insurance plan similar to its existing flood insurance or combine the two risks into one policy.  A second option is for the Florida insurance industry and  State of Florida work together to create a two tier system whereby  the insurance companies offer high deductibles (such as $75,000) disaster coverage while the State controlled Citizens Property Insurance Company   offers coverage  below that high deductible but also with its own deductible.  This would be statewide, not just for  storm prone areas  with premiums based on individual risk factors,  as is normal for insurance.  The state could provide  assistance  for low income families but make coverage mandatory.  Although there is a cost to this, there also is a saving because  resulting  from a drastic reduction in  tax  funded  public assistance now costing the governments billions.  
 
Taxes
The local municipal governments must realize  there are adverse consequences to simply collecting and spending the windfall tax revenues it is increasingly receiving as property owners sell their low tax appraised houses to new owners who must pay  tax based on what they pay for the houses. These consequences include depressed property values and at best a stagnant local economy and possibly an area recession.  The local leaders should recognize this problem by placing a cap on the amount taxes can be raised  to the new buyer.  
             What can we as individuals do?  It is urgent that we communicate our concerns and specific recommendations to the people who can do something about it.   To help you do this, I have attached a list of state and federal elected representatives including their names, addresses,  fax numbers and in some cases, email addresses.  You should get busy telling these people what you think and above all, tell them that they will no longer get your next vote unless  they declare this a top priority and get the job done. Specifically, I  would urge the Governor to call a special session of the state legislature to address these issues.
            What can our local Palmetto Bay government do?   Our officials are already communicating with state and federal officials. But I suggest  that Palmetto Bay declare  this a crisis by issuing a proclamation intended to bring added public local and national focus on this problem.
            Folks,  it’s time to act to preserve our great community for what it has become and make it an even better one. Shirley says it’s time to stop  complaining. Let’s start today to be heard.

Dear Governor Bush,

        Florida Trend - Florida's Source For Business News 

       
JULY 2006 ISSUE 
An Unwise Growth Subsidy?
Insurance
By Mike Vogel

Citizens insures $5 billion worth of construction projects in places many believe are unwise to build. Should Florida homeowners be on the hook for a $74-million condo project?

 

Most attention to Citizens Property Insurance focuses on the insurance coverage it provides to home and condo owners who can’t get insurance in the private market.
Citizens also provides other types of insurance, however — including a type of insurance to developers that critics say stimulates building in high-risk areas and will leave residential policyholders all over the state on the hook for the bill if a storm strikes the projects.

That “builders risk” insurance provides coverage to developers while their buildings are under construction. And the exposure Citizens has under those builders risk policies is growing rapidly — up by some $800 million this year alone. At the end of May, Citizens was covering 5,723 construction projects — condos, single-family homes, commercial buildings — with a total exposure of $5.1 billion.Without Citizens’ writing builders risk coverage, the state could see some of that $5.1 billion in development, and its jobs and economic opportunity, curtailed.

But critics say that by writing coverage in areas that private insurers find too risky, Citizens encourages development where it shouldn’t occur. And it all but guarantees that when the projects are done, the owners will wind up having to get their homeowners insurance from Citizens. That thwarts, rather than advances, the state’s goal of shrinking what has become Florida’s largest insurer.

In addition, because Citizens can assess non-Citizens policyholders everywhere in Florida to cover its losses, inland homeowners could pay more than what they already do to cover losses of coastal developers building projects the private market won’t cover.As with Citizens windstorm homeowners policies, the builders risk coverage involves properties in high-risk coastal areas. One builders risk policy covers a $74-million condo under construction on the beach. (Citizens is prohibited by law from identifying its customers.) Earlier this year, 1,000 of Citizens’ policies were for more than $1 million each, and the 10 biggest projects Citizens insures total $447 million in exposure.Geographically, Citizens’ heaviest risk is in southeast Florida, where it has $2.1 billion in vulnerabilities, and northwest Florida, where it has $1.3 billion in exposure. Typically required by lenders, builders risk has a sliding scale of vulnerability for an insurer — almost nothing when a project is just coming out of the ground but a large risk in the final days of construction.Like traditional homeowners insurance [“Breaking Point,” June, FloridaTrend.com], builders risk has gotten expensive and scarce after eight Florida hurricanes in two years. “It’s not so much that they won’t write, but the pricing is … there’s sticker shock,” says Matt Wester, agent relations administrator for the Florida Surplus Lines Service Office, a state-mandated non-profit association of agents who sell the specialty insurance products that fall under the surplus lines designation. High-priced projects, for which insurers turn to the reinsurance markets for support, are particularly tough to insure, he says.Pat Chouinard, a vice president and insurance broker with Amwins Brokerage of Florida in Tampa, says private carrrier coverage that cost 30 to 40 cents per $100 of value a year ago now costs as much as $1.50 per $100. A few carriers have stopped writing new builders risk coverage that includes windstorm insurance in Southeastern coastal states. Noting the condo buildings proposed for Tampa, Chouinard says, “You just wonder, who’s going to write the coverage on those?”

Builders risk coverage that used to cost 30 to 40 cents per $100 of value a year ago, now costs up to $1.50 per $100, says insurance broker Pat Chouinard.

Unlike Citizens, with its $74-million exposure on a single property, private sector insurers usually layer coverage on large projects, with different carriers taking different pieces of the risk — one taking, say, the first $5 million in losses, another the next $5 million.The Florida Insurance Council, an insurance industry group, has urged the state to get Citizens out of the builders risk business in high-hazard areas. “If Citizens is the only source for this coverage, it will be the only insurer available for the homes or businesses when they are completed,” according to a Florida Insurance Council report in February. “These are structures that are essentially uninsurable and should not be built.”The state’s insurance consumer advocate, Steve Burgess, says Citizens might want to consider the advisability of continuing builders risk insurance. “I would like to see the policymakers take a look at it and let every stakeholder bring forward their arguments. When you talk about $5 billion of exposure, I think it’s worth a look.”There is precedent for Citizens to leave a market in which the surplus lines industry offers coverage. The Legislature this year required Citizens, beginning in 2008, to stop insuring homes that are valued at more than $1 million. The state was trying to lower Citizens’ exposure to expensive properties [“Too Many Mansions?” February 2005, FloridaTrend.com].Citizens’ board supported eliminating coverage for the $1 million-and-up market and in a meeting in late June was scheduled to consider getting out of the builders risk business in high-risk areas. Citizens spokesman Justin Glover acknowledges that “eliminating coverage would be a way to reduce exposure.”

My insurance company, Nationwide, is asking for a rate hike. This will likely be granted. They are asking for at least a 70% increase. The problem I have is that this is an "Across the board" increase. This type of increase does not take into consideration the specific condition of an individuals' home. My home was built in 1963, before the current hurricane codes, and my insurance company says that is why my rate was already increased. But no one has surveyed my home to determine if this is a true statement.
   The house is all concrete block walls, even most of the interior walls. The roof is all hip design, with no eaves, and a low pitch, which offers little area for the winds to act on. In addition, I am at an elevation that virtually eliminates flooding concerns. I am on a hill, which is surrounded by higher hills, which serve to block the effects of high winds. I have 15 sheets of plywood stored for covering windows and doors, which are all numbered and fitted. I have two generators, one wired to the house with a transfer switch, and one as a spare. I keep over fifty gallons of bottled water on hand, as well as enough food to feed an army. This house has never suffered any damage due to any of the storms which have made direct hits on Hernando county. The power went out during several storms in the past, sometimes for a week. I had power the entire time. I work for the federal government, maintaining the emergency power system for a Veteran's Hospital, I know how to keep the lights on.
   Now, I am facing an another increase in my property insurance, which will break my budget. The first casualty will be my retirement plan, which is the first place I can cut expenses. Then the "For sale" signs will go up. Part of the expense I am experiencing is a bailout of the Citizens insurance plan. My health insurance has gone up. My auto insurance has gone up. And now my homeowner's is going up again. The same thing happened in New Jersey. Auto insurance rates were raised until most of the insured were on a state run auto insurance plan, all while the policies were being serviced by the agents of the same companies that caused the problem in the first place. The companies got paid to write and maintain the policies, and the state fund paid any claims. A clear win-win situation. Now we have Citizens, so companies can raise their rates without fear, because the state will take up the slack.
    Why did I bother to take all these Hurricane prevention measures, when I am being made to suffer for all those who don't do a thing to help themselves? I put a new roof on my house last year, because I wanted to make sure that I could withstand the storms. I put it on with my own two hands, and even Code enforcement was impressed by the measures I took to go the extra mile. I even stored bundles of shingles in case some should blow off, Not likely since they are all held down by twice the nails that code requires. Where is my reward for all this extra work and expense? It's sticking out of my back, right between the shoulder blades.

We are an independent agency owned by a community bank in Palm Beach County. 

I understand that Citizens Property Insurance Company was formed as an insurer of last resort. When all of the companies writing insurance in the state of Florida stopped writing hurricane coverage or they left the state all together to avoid writing wind coverage, Citizens would pick up the gap in coverage and write the wind coverage. In the case of homeowners, they wrote the entire policy & that is also true for condominium associations throughout Florida.

Since we are owned by a bank with 52 branches in mostly Palm Beach County, which write a lot of new residential and commercial loans for new construction and remodeling of homes and businesses we receive referrals for the builders risk coverage from a majority of these customers and have always been confident that we could help the customer.

When we received word that effective 7/15/06 Citizens would no longer be writing builders risk coverage for commercial or commercial residential, you can imagine our surprise and disappointment in the State of Florida!

After the last couple of years, we all thought that the government for the State of Florida would pull together and figure out a solution for the lack of companies and coverage's, before something drastic happened and we were left with HUGE gaps in coverage for our tax paying citizens! 

To our GREAT disappointment, the legislative session not only didn't address the problem, but it seems that the bureaucratic/bipartisan rhetoric in our state failed miserably to help the people who have been increasingly hit with high costs! 

People who are working are having a difficult time making ends meet and cannot pay the premiums that they are being hit with. The fact that the people on a fixed income are having to decide between taxes and insurance, as opposed to food and shelter, is something that your office and government body should be ashamed of! 

I use to be proud to help people with their insurance needs, but I am ashamed to be affiliated with it now as the industry is bleeding people dry and you are the only one that can fix the situation.

I STRONGLY recommend that you hold a special session and fix this situation before it goes into effect 7/15/06. 

The lack of urgency in amending the wind insurance problem in Florida is having a profound effect on our economy, with tens of thousands of home up for sale, forfeitures, businesses out of business and soon our entire economy will collapse! Anyone in the Florida government should be thrown out and left with no option to ever run for a governmental position again, if they cannot stand behind one of the proposals (like a federal program for wind coverage like the flood program) that the insurance companies have been discussing for several years!

Please set a special session to stop this atrocity from happening on 7/15/06 and put a good plan into effect before we all lose our homes, businesses and all leave the state of Florida!

Thank you in advance-A concerned citizen, tax payer and VOTER in Florida,

consider lowering their millage rates, it seems to fall on deaf ears, I even sent each taxing

authority a letter, asking them to consider lowering millage rates. The response was

mostly, it’s none of my business.

 

Bay County has finally become a Republican majority, all County Commissioners are Republican

and all School Board members are Republicans; I think we are sending the wrong type of message,

forgetting we are suppose to be the Conservative Party.

 

Taxing authorities increasing their budgets to the max will most likely set themselves up for having to

Increase their millage rates in the coming years, especially if the values continue to adjust downward.

The tax burden on many properties in Bay County will most likely place many more properties on the

market and drive values downward, resulting in fewer revenues in the future.

 

Another thought is when legislatures look at property tax legislation they should get input from 

Property Appraisers, via their associations, it would simplify laws and give them a better understanding

of the system.

Rick Barnett

Dear Governor John Ellis Bush:	
 	
On March 1, NAMI released "Grading the States: A Report on America's Health Care System for Serious Mental Illness." The report includes specific information on our state and I believe you will find the report helpful as you and your colleagues consider legislation and policy that impacts our state mental health system. A copy of the report is available online at: www.nami.org/grades. As you review this report, there are some key points that I hope you keep in mind. -- No state received an "A". We have significant room for improvement. We would not tolerate any grade but an "A" for cancer or cardiac care. Therefore, we cannot accept any other grade for our mental healthcare system either. -- A quality system must include a recovery focus and emphasis on consumer and family involvement. -- The grades represent a system-wide grade, not just a grade on our mental health agency. Treatment of mental illness requires a broad- based solution that reaches beyond agency boundaries. Our state recieved a low C B in some areas F in others. We are as astate making some progress but Our number of mentally ill are increasing faster. -- Please pay close attention to the urgent needs section of our state narrative. These are priority concerns and should be addressed quickly. Each state, including ours, is also credited for innovations. These are important and provide templates for improving our system of care. Medicaid now accounts for a majority of publicly- funded mental health services. Changes to our state Medicaid program can have negative consequences on people living with mental illness. As a constituent, I am counting on you to give serious attention to this report. The findings cannot be taken lightly. When quality treatment is available, people recover. When the system fails, lives are lost,And the state spends more on hospital stays and time spent in jails for those who fall through the cracks Our state must do better and I am asking you to take leadership in helping meet the challenges outlined in this report.Please have this report considered as one of your focuses	
 	
Sincerely,	
 	
Walter Griffith

Subject:	State Monopoly

Please be advised the insurance agents licensed in the State of Florida are NOT looking forward to working for a State Monopoly, namely Citizens Property Insurance Company. 
 
Florida's current policy of barring any new insurance companies from selling homeowners policies in Florida is a fraudulent scam and terrible injustice perpetrated on the property owners in Florida that is already causing a terrible and repulsive stench, the effects of which will be reflected in the next election, if not before. The news of these unfair business practices being implemented by our own government against our citizens is not being reported by the media, but I suspect that will have to change soon. 
 
The latest company to fall victim to Florida's Government scam is First Fidelity, a new and well-funded company who planned to sell auto and property insurance, with Homeowners rates far below those charged by Citizens Property Insurance Company. No reason was given for the State's denial to First Fidelity, but a company spokesperson writes, 
 
"After 10 months of exceedingly hard work accomplishing the nearly impossible tasks of obtaining significant capital commitments approaching $50 million dollars, obtaining reinsurance in a tough property market, designing competitive property and casualty products with a state of the art software backbone, contracting with the most qualified vendors to provide the best service possible to our customers  --  all in a market where a carrier offering to write new homeowner policies is desperately needed; we can no longer proceed as Office of Insurance Regulation would not approve First Fidelity's certificate of authority."
 
If the State wishes Citizens Property Insurance Company to become a regular insurance company, as was reported by the St Petersburg Times, the State can practice the same rules and guidelines it enforces on all regulated professional service companies and licensed professionals. We will not stand by while our elected officials use unfair business practices to create this monopoly on property insurance and scam the citizens of Florida.

Dear Governor Bush,

I have a home in north Walton County, more than 30 miles from the coast and 200 feet above sea level.   Hurricane insurance on my home has "gone thru the roof" this year.  

While I have no real beef with those willing to risk their own money in extravagant construction on the uncertain sands of south Walton, I do raise a hackle when I'm forced to help subsidize their folly.   

Citizens Property Insurance has become a scam on Florida's more prudent homeowners.    Please do something to rein it in.

--Bob Reid

        Florida Trend - Florida's Source For Business News 

       
JULY 2006 ISSUE 
An Unwise Growth Subsidy?
Insurance
By Mike Vogel

Citizens insures $5 billion worth of construction projects in places many believe are unwise to build. Should Florida homeowners be on the hook for a $74-million condo project?

 

Most attention to Citizens Property Insurance focuses on the insurance coverage it provides to home and condo owners who can’t get insurance in the private market.
Citizens also provides other types of insurance, however — including a type of insurance to developers that critics say stimulates building in high-risk areas and will leave residential policyholders all over the state on the hook for the bill if a storm strikes the projects.

That “builders risk” insurance provides coverage to developers while their buildings are under construction. And the exposure Citizens has under those builders risk policies is growing rapidly — up by some $800 million this year alone. At the end of May, Citizens was covering 5,723 construction projects — condos, single-family homes, commercial buildings — with a total exposure of $5.1 billion.Without Citizens’ writing builders risk coverage, the state could see some of that $5.1 billion in development, and its jobs and economic opportunity, curtailed.

But critics say that by writing coverage in areas that private insurers find too risky, Citizens encourages development where it shouldn’t occur. And it all but guarantees that when the projects are done, the owners will wind up having to get their homeowners insurance from Citizens. That thwarts, rather than advances, the state’s goal of shrinking what has become Florida’s largest insurer.

In addition, because Citizens can assess non-Citizens policyholders everywhere in Florida to cover its losses, inland homeowners could pay more than what they already do to cover losses of coastal developers building projects the private market won’t cover.As with Citizens windstorm homeowners policies, the builders risk coverage involves properties in high-risk coastal areas. One builders risk policy covers a $74-million condo under construction on the beach. (Citizens is prohibited by law from identifying its customers.) Earlier this year, 1,000 of Citizens’ policies were for more than $1 million each, and the 10 biggest projects Citizens insures total $447 million in exposure.Geographically, Citizens’ heaviest risk is in southeast Florida, where it has $2.1 billion in vulnerabilities, and northwest Florida, where it has $1.3 billion in exposure. Typically required by lenders, builders risk has a sliding scale of vulnerability for an insurer — almost nothing when a project is just coming out of the ground but a large risk in the final days of construction.Like traditional homeowners insurance [“Breaking Point,” June, FloridaTrend.com], builders risk has gotten expensive and scarce after eight Florida hurricanes in two years. “It’s not so much that they won’t write, but the pricing is … there’s sticker shock,” says Matt Wester, agent relations administrator for the Florida Surplus Lines Service Office, a state-mandated non-profit association of agents who sell the specialty insurance products that fall under the surplus lines designation. High-priced projects, for which insurers turn to the reinsurance markets for support, are particularly tough to insure, he says.Pat Chouinard, a vice president and insurance broker with Amwins Brokerage of Florida in Tampa, says private carrrier coverage that cost 30 to 40 cents per $100 of value a year ago now costs as much as $1.50 per $100. A few carriers have stopped writing new builders risk coverage that includes windstorm insurance in Southeastern coastal states. Noting the condo buildings proposed for Tampa, Chouinard says, “You just wonder, who’s going to write the coverage on those?”

Builders risk coverage that used to cost 30 to 40 cents per $100 of value a year ago, now costs up to $1.50 per $100, says insurance broker Pat Chouinard.

Unlike Citizens, with its $74-million exposure on a single property, private sector insurers usually layer coverage on large projects, with different carriers taking different pieces of the risk — one taking, say, the first $5 million in losses, another the next $5 million.The Florida Insurance Council, an insurance industry group, has urged the state to get Citizens out of the builders risk business in high-hazard areas. “If Citizens is the only source for this coverage, it will be the only insurer available for the homes or businesses when they are completed,” according to a Florida Insurance Council report in February. “These are structures that are essentially uninsurable and should not be built.”The state’s insurance consumer advocate, Steve Burgess, says Citizens might want to consider the advisability of continuing builders risk insurance. “I would like to see the policymakers take a look at it and let every stakeholder bring forward their arguments. When you talk about $5 billion of exposure, I think it’s worth a look.”There is precedent for Citizens to leave a market in which the surplus lines industry offers coverage. The Legislature this year required Citizens, beginning in 2008, to stop insuring homes that are valued at more than $1 million. The state was trying to lower Citizens’ exposure to expensive properties [“Too Many Mansions?” February 2005, FloridaTrend.com].Citizens’ board supported eliminating coverage for the $1 million-and-up market and in a meeting in late June was scheduled to consider getting out of the builders risk business in high-risk areas. Citizens spokesman Justin Glover acknowledges that “eliminating coverage would be a way to reduce exposure.”

Subject:	SB 1216

Dear Governor Bush;

 As the Director of a clinic for the primary care of persons with HIV/AIDS, I am very distressed by the signing of SB 1216 (HB 699) which no longer requires an HIV update for licensure renewal for physicians.

While we have made progress in the care and treatment of this illness, we have made none in the area of public education and removal of the stigma associated with HIV.  Medical personnel are not exempt form this prejudice and we often have great difficulty getting medical care for our patients because physicians will not treat them.

The reasons for physicians to be updated on HIV/AIDS go beyond a CME requirement.  The CDC has begun a campaign to make HIV testing a part of routine medical care.  If physicians are not aware of the newest information, they will pass on the outdated information they have.  The new medications available to treat HIV/AIDS can have serious drug interactions, potentially fatal, with medications routinely prescribed in other specialties.  HIV testing is done during prenatal care, physicians who are not updated on the latest treatment for HIV positive pregnant women will not refer and we will see a rise in positive babies born in Florida.

Florida is number one in the US for heterosexual transmission, number two in pediatric AIDS cases and number one, of the states who report, in HIV cases.  The counties represented by the sponsors of this bill are Title I Ryan White providers, the most heavily impacted by this epidemic, and yet, they have failed to recognize the need for HIV education, especially in the medical community.

Every physician in Florida has treated persons with HIV, whether they knew it at the time or not.  Physicians who are responsible enough to stay current on HIV trends will seek out the education they need.  Those who only attend “required” programs will not, and they are the ones who need it the most.

This bill has done a great disservice to the HIV/AIDS community.

Sincerely,

Sharon Murphy, RN, ACRN

Director, McGregor Clinic

2506 Second Street, Suite 105

Fort Myers, Florida 33901

Dear Governor Bush:
 
I recently reviewed a Call For Grant Proposal issued by your administration that prohibits grant recipients from lobbying the executive or legislative branches on any topic related to the granting authority, even if no grant funds are used for that purpose.  Here is the specific language used in the CGP:

"No grantee, including its employees, board members or volunteers may lobby any officials of the executive or legislative branch regarding the (Granting Authority) while also receiving funds under this CGP, even if no grant funds are utilized for that purpose."

I am familiar with the usual prohibition contained in the CGP against using grant funds for lobbying purposes.  This provision goes far beyond the standard prohibition.
 
My concern is that a not-for-profit entity, for which I do volunteer work, decided to not respond to this CGP because of the prohibition against lobbying regarding the Granting Authority, even if the lobbying was unrelated to the grant.  This not-for-profit entity is eminently qualified to produce superior results as called for by the CGP.  This not-for-profit entity, its Board members and volunteers do a great deal of advocacy work, both collectively and individually, with both the executive and legislative branches regarding a wide variety of needs in our community.  The above language in the CGP is so broadly written that we did not feel it prudent to take the chance that, had we been awarded a grant, a volunteer not familiar with the prohibition, might inadvertently violate the provision and put the grant and the not-for-profit entity at risk.
 
I would like to know if you concur in this use of this restriction.  Also, since I've not seen this kind of restriction elsewhere, I'm curious if it is in frequent use in Florida.
 
Based on your track record, I doubt that is the way you expect Florida's government to operate.  In this case, the prohibition had the effect of driving a well-qualified organization away from submitting a grant proposal.  That is a loss for the State and people of Florida.
 
Thank you.

With respect to the ADR portion of the bill, and particularly the Mediation section: please be advised that any modification or amendment to Mediation requirements should, in some way, require association boards and their attorneys to make a good faith effort to mediate disputes brought before an appointed mediator. Further, their attitude is akin to "what are you going to do about it (?)" when mediation reaches an impasse due to the association/board's attorney's refusal to mediate.  In addition to amending mediation requirements, it is clear that attorneys retained by the board of directors to represent the "association" believe that they represent the board of directors and not the "association".  The "association" is merely an entity (vehicle for operations) which if not financially supported by the membership will no longer exist.  Ergo, boards retain attorneys to represent the membership (which IS the "association") and NOT the members of the board of directors either individually or collectively.  We also understand that attorneys vehemently oppose defining their representation because the numbers of lawsuits may be reduced which, in turn, reduces the attorneys' income stream generated by lawsuits resulting from the basic misunderstanding of who is the "client".  When this basic foundational understanding is statutorially expressed in 718, 719, and 720 F.S. then we can begin to move forward with more meaningful resolutions of the monumental problems facing Florida common interest community homeowners.
Sally S. Rockrise

                                Furthermore enact legislation that requires payment of laboratory and procedures needed to adequately evaluate urgent care patients.                                 The proposal has the following added benefits:1)priced accordingly it will encourage PCPS to see their urgent care patients 2)place badly needed revenue into the primary care stream 3)reward PCPS for doing what they do best--treating their sick patients.
